that do strategy --

00:05:40.997 --> 00:05:43.760
the parts in other governments
that do this -- can't do it,

00:05:43.784 --> 00:05:45.942
because they're reacting
to the news cycle.

00:05:46.341 --> 00:05:48.245
And so we're not looking ahead.

00:05:48.269 --> 00:05:52.067
On 9/11, we had a crisis
because we were looking the wrong way.

00:05:52.485 --> 00:05:55.912
Today we have a crisis because,
because of 9/11,

00:05:55.936 --> 00:05:58.587
we are still looking
in the wrong direction,

00:05:58.611 --> 00:06:04.459
and we know because we see
transformational trends on the horizon

00:06:04.483 --> 00:06:09.335
that are far more important
than what we saw on 9/11;

00:06:09.359 --> 00:06:13.161
far more important than the threat
posed by these terrorists;

00:06:13.185 --> 00:06:16.435
far more important even
than the instability that we've got

00:06:16.459 --> 00:06:20.710
in some areas of the world
that are racked by instability today.

00:06:21.119 --> 00:06:25.779
In fact, the things that we are seeing
in those parts of the world

00:06:25.803 --> 00:06:28.417
may be symptoms.

00:06:28.841 --> 00:06:32.319
They may be a reaction to bigger trends.

00:06:32.343 --> 00:06:37.047
And if we are treating the symptom
and ignoring the bigger trend,

00:06:37.071 --> 00:06:40.135
then we've got far bigger
problems to deal with.

00:06:41.373 --> 00:06:42.870
And so what are those trends?

00:06:43.468 --> 00:06:45.245
Well, to a group like you,

00:06:45.269 --> 00:06:46.760
the trends are apparent.

00:06:48.402 --> 00:06:53.657
We are living at a moment
in which the very fabric of human society

00:06:53.681 --> 00:06:55.470
is being rewoven.

00:06:57.015 --> 00:07:00.235
If you saw the cover of The Economist
a couple of days ago --

00:07:00.259 --> 00:07:03.805
it said that 80 percent
of the people on the planet,

00:07:03.829 --> 00:07:06.762
by the year 2020, would have a smartphone.

00:07:07.522 --> 00:07:11.375
They would have a small computer
connected to the Internet in their pocket.

00:07:11.766 --> 00:07:16.291
In most of Africa, the cell phone
penetration rate is 80 percent.

00:07:17.707 --> 00:07:20.371
We passed the point last October

00:07:20.395 --> 00:07:24.366
when there were more
mobile cellular devices, SIM cards,

00:07:24.390 --> 00:07:26.506
out in the world than there were people.

00:07:27.124 --> 00:07:33.020
We are within years
of a profound moment in our history,

00:07:33.044 --> 00:07:38.401
when effectively every single
human being on the planet

00:07:38.425 --> 00:07:43.033
is going to be part of a man-made
system for the first time,

00:07:43.057 --> 00:07:45.098
able to touch anyone else --

00:07:45.122 --> 00:07:47.484
touch them for good, touch them for ill.

00:07:47.957 --> 00:07:53.783
And the changes associated with that
are changing the very nature

00:07:53.807 --> 00:07:57.408
of every aspect of governance
and life on the planet

00:07:57.432 --> 00:08:00.878
in ways that our leaders
ought to be thinking about,

00:08:00.902 --> 00:08:03.382
when they're thinking about
these immediate threats.

00:08:03.782 --> 00:08:05.548
On the security side,

00:08:05.572 --> 00:08:11.076
we've come out of a Cold War in which
it was too costly to fight a nuclear war,

00:08:11.100 --> 00:08:12.634
and so we didn't,

00:08:12.658 --> 00:08:16.475
to a period that I call
Cool War, cyber war,

00:08:16.499 --> 00:08:21.550
where the costs of conflict are actually
so low, that we may never stop.

00:08:22.095 --> 00:08:24.821
We may enter a period of constant warfare,

00:08:24.845 --> 00:08:29.256
and we know this because
we've been in it for several years.

00:08:29.280 --> 00:08:34.831
And yet, we don't have the basic doctrines
to guide us in this regard.

00:08:35.213 --> 00:08:37.304
We don't have the basic ideas formulated.

00:08:37.328 --> 00:08:39.868
If someone attacks us with a cyber attack,

00:08:39.892 --> 00:08:43.007
do have the ability to respond
with a kinetic attack?

00:08:43.745 --> 00:08:44.952
We don't know.

00:08:45.531 --> 00:08:49.616
If somebody launches a cyber attack,
how do we deter them?

00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.827
When China launched
a series of cyber attacks,

00:08:51.851 --> 00:08:53.378
what did the U.S. government do?

00:08:53.402 --> 00:08:57.387
It said, we're going to indict
a few of these Chinese guys,

00:08:57.411 --> 00:08:59.153
who are never coming to America.

00:08:59.855 --> 00:09:03.804
They're never going to be anywhere near
a law enforcement officer

00:09:03.828 --> 00:09:05.833
who's going to take them into custody.

00:09:06.210 --> 00:09:09.100
It's a gesture -- it's not a deterrent.

00:09:09.636 --> 00:09:13.434
Special forces operators
out there in the field today

00:09:13.458 --> 00:09:18.329
discover that small groups
of insurgents with cell phones

00:09:18.353 --> 00:09:23.624
have access to satellite imagery
that once only superpowers had.

00:09:23.648 --> 00:09:25.815
In fact, if you've got a cell phone,

00:09:25.839 --> 00:09:29.155
you've got access to power
that a superpower didn't have,

00:09:29.179 --> 00:09:31.334
and would have highly
classified 10 years ago.

00:09:31.358 --> 00:09:34.249
In my cell phone,
I have an app that tells me

00:09:34.273 --> 00:09:38.813
where every plane in the world is,
and its altitude, and its speed,

00:09:38.837 --> 00:09:40.659
and what kind of aircraft it is,

00:09:40.683 --> 00:09:43.599
and where it's going
and where it's landing.

00:09:44.387 --> 00:09:48.936
They have apps that allow them to know

00:09:48.960 --> 00:09:51.179
what their adversary is about to do.

00:09:51.203 --> 00:09:53.579
They're using these tools in new ways.

00:09:53.603 --> 00:09:57.717
When a cafe in Sydney
was taken over by a terrorist,

00:09:57.741 --> 00:10:00.034
he went in with a rifle...

00:10:00.058 --> 00:10:01.301
and an iPad.

00:10:01.894 --> 00:10:04.455
And the weapon was the iPad.

00:10:04.957 --> 00:10:08.256
Because he captured people,
he terrorized them,

00:10:08.280 --> 00:10:10.985
he pointed the iPad at them,

00:10:11.009 --> 00:10:13.681
and then he took the video
and he put it on the Internet,

00:10:13.705 --> 00:10:15.728
and he took over the world's media.

00:10:17.819 --> 00:10:21.287
But it doesn't just affect
the security side.

00:10:22.090 --> 00:10:23.919
The relations between great powers --

00:10:23.943 --> 00:10:26.308
we thought we were past the bipolar era.

00:10:27.217 --> 00:10:29.091
We thought we were in a unipolar world,

00:10:29.115 --> 00:10:31.009
where all the big issues were resolved.

00:10:31.033 --> 00:10:32.750
Remember? It was the end of history.

00:10:34.087 --> 00:10:35.383
But we're not.

00:10:35.407 --> 00:10:39.795
We're now seeing that our
basic assumptions about the Internet --

00:10:39.819 --> 00:10:43.880
that it was going to connect us,
weave society together --

00:10:43.904 --> 00:10:45.560
are not necessarily true.

00:10:46.041 --> 00:10:49.237
In countries like China,
you have the Great Firewall of China.

00:10:49.261 --> 00:10:52.781
You've got countries saying no,
if the Internet happens within our borders

00:10:52.805 --> 00:10:54.380
we control it within our borders.

00:10:54.404 --> 00:10:57.264
We control the content.
We are going to control our security.

00:10:57.288 --> 00:10:59.054
We are going to manage that Internet.

00:10:59.078 --> 00:11:00.891
We are going to say what can be on it.

00:11:00.915 --> 00:11:02.966
We're going to set
a different set of rules.

00:11:02.990 --> 00:11:05.087
Now you might think,
well, that's just China.

00:11:05.111 --> 00:11:06.825
But it's not just China.

00:11:07.609 --> 00:11:10.338
It's China, India, Russia.

00:11:10.666 --> 00:11:13.766
It's Saudi Arabia,
it's Singapore, it's Brazil.

00:11:13.790 --> 00:11:18.304
After the NSA scandal, the Russians,
the Chinese, the Indians, the Brazilians,

00:11:18.328 --> 00:11:21.383
they said, let's create
a new Internet backbone,

00:11:21.407 --> 00:11:23.889
because we can't be dependent
on this other one.

00:11:23.913 --> 00:11:25.882
And so all of a sudden, what do you have?

00:11:26.358 --> 00:11:28.857
You have a new bipolar world

00:11:28.881 --> 00:11:31.072
in which cyber-internationalism,

00:11:31.096 --> 00:11:32.247
our belief,

00:11:32.271 --> 00:11:35.108
is challenged by cyber-nationalism,

00:11:35.132 --> 00:11:36.397
another belief.

00:11:37.551 --> 00:11:40.722
We are seeing these changes
everywhere we look.

00:11:41.587 --> 00:11:43.565
We are seeing the advent of mobile money.

00:11:43.589 --> 00:11:45.886
It's happening in the places
you wouldn't expect.

00:11:45.910 --> 00:11:48.287
It's happening in Kenya and Tanzania,

00:11:48.311 --> 00:11:51.580
where millions of people who haven't
had access to financial services

00:11:51.604 --> 00:11:54.099
now conduct all those
services on their phones.

00:11:54.660 --> 00:11:59.160
There are 2.5 million people
who don't have financial service access

00:11:59.184 --> 00:12:01.200
that are going to get it soon.

00:12:01.698 --> 00:12:04.511
A billion of them are going
to have the ability to access it

00:12:04.535 --> 00:12:05.730
on their cell phone soon.

00:12:05.754 --> 00:12:08.607
It's not just going to give them
the ability to bank.

00:12:08.915 --> 00:12:11.792
It's going to change
what monetary policy is.

00:12:11.816 --> 00:12:14.452
It's going to change what money is.

00:12:15.220 --> 00:12:17.391
Education is changing in the same way.

00:12:18.388 --> 00:12:20.849
Healthcare is changing in the same way.

00:12:20.873 --> 00:12:24.367
How government services are delivered
is changing in the same way.

00:12:25.565 --> 00:12:29.827
And yet, in Washington, we are debating

00:12:29.851 --> 00:12:35.316
whether to call the terrorist group
that has taken over Syria and Iraq

00:12:35.340 --> 00:12:39.500
ISIS or ISIL or Islamic State.

00:12:40.498 --> 00:12:43.609
We are trying to determine

00:12:43.633 --> 00:12:48.922
how much we want to give
in a negotiation with the Iranians

00:12:48.946 --> 00:12:53.745
on a nuclear deal which deals
with the technologies of 50 years ago,

00:12:53.769 --> 00:12:59.127
when in fact, we know that the Iranians
right now are engaged in cyber war with us

00:12:59.151 --> 00:13:05.185
and we're ignoring it, partially
because businesses are not willing

00:13:05.209 --> 00:13:08.327
to talk about the attacks
that are being waged on them.

00:13:09.357 --> 00:13:12.166
And that gets us to another breakdown

00:13:12.190 --> 00:13:13.414
that's crucial,

00:13:13.438 --> 00:13:17.149
and another breakdown that couldn't be
more important to a group like this,

00:13:17.173 --> 00:13:20.825
because the growth of America
and real American national security

00:13:20.849 --> 00:13:25.290
and all of the things that drove progress
even during the Cold War,

00:13:25.314 --> 00:13:30.065
was a public-private partnership
between science, technology and government

00:13:30.089 --> 00:13:33.597
that began when Thomas Jefferson
sat alone in his laboratory

00:13:33.621 --> 00:13:35.464
inventing new things.

00:13:36.486 --> 00:13:40.296
But it was the canals
and railroads and telegraph;

00:13:40.320 --> 00:13:42.636
it was radar and the Internet.

00:13:43.087 --> 00:13:45.371
It was Tang, the breakfast drink --

00:13:45.395 --> 00:13:48.272
probably not the most important
of those developments.

00:13:48.753 --> 00:13:51.632
But what you had was
a partnership and a dialogue,

00:13:51.656 --> 00:13:53.921
and the dialogue has broken down.

00:13:53.945 --> 00:13:56.324
It's broken down because in Washington,

00:13:56.348 --> 00:13:58.114
less government is considered more.

00:13:58.138 --> 00:14:00.617
It's broken down because there is,
believe it or not,

00:14:00.641 --> 00:14:02.481
in Washington, a war on science --

00:14:02.505 --> 00:14:05.544
despite the fact that
in all of human history,

00:14:05.568 --> 00:14:08.528
every time anyone has waged
a war on science,

00:14:08.552 --> 00:14:10.153
science has won.

00:14:11.421 --> 00:14:16.348
(Applause)

00:14:16.670 --> 00:14:20.866
But we have a government
that doesn't want to listen,

00:14:20.890 --> 00:14:23.049
that doesn't have people
at the highest levels

00:14:23.073 --> 00:14:24.227
that understand this.

00:14:24.251 --> 00:14:25.402
In the nuclear age,

00:14:25.426 --> 00:14:28.593
when there were people
in senior national security jobs,

00:14:28.617 --> 00:14:31.645
they were expected to speak throw-weight.

00:14:31.963 --> 00:14:34.981
They were expected to know
the lingo, the vocabulary.

00:14:35.005 --> 00:14:37.804
If you went to the highest level
of the U.S. government now

00:14:37.828 --> 00:14:40.361
and said, "Talk to me about cyber,
about neuroscience,

00:14:40.385 --> 00:14:43.525
about the things that are going
to change the world of tomorrow,"

00:14:43.549 --> 00:14:44.700
you'd get a blank stare.

00:14:44.724 --> 00:14:46.645
I know, because when I wrote this book,

00:14:46.669 --> 00:14:49.709
I talked to 150 people,
many from the science and tech side,

00:14:49.733 --> 00:14:52.789
who felt like they were being
shunted off to the kids' table.

00:14:53.347 --> 00:14:55.429
Meanwhile, on the tech side,

00:14:55.453 --> 00:14:59.258
we have lots of wonderful people
creating wonderful things,

00:14:59.282 --> 00:15:02.239
but they started in garages
and they didn't need the government

00:15:02.263 --> 00:15:03.936
and they don't want the government.

00:15:03.960 --> 00:15:06.727
Many of them have a political view
that's somewhere between

00:15:06.751 --> 00:15:08.645
libertarian and anarchic:

00:15:08.669 --> 00:15:10.030
leave me alone.

00:15:11.263 --> 00:15:13.077
But the world's coming apart.

00:15:13.626 --> 00:15:17.015
All of a sudden, there are going to be
massive regulatory changes

00:15:17.039 --> 00:15:19.957
and massive issues
associated with conflict

00:15:19.981 --> 00:15:24.266
and massive issues associated
with security and privacy.

00:15:24.290 --> 00:15:26.785
And we haven't even gotten
to the next set of issues,

00:15:26.799 --> 00:15:28.773
which are philosophical issues.

00:15:29.559 --> 00:15:32.381
If you can't vote,
if you can't have a job,

00:15:32.405 --> 00:15:34.897
if you can't bank,
if you can't get health care,

00:15:34.921 --> 00:15:37.363
if you can't be educated
without Internet access,

00:15:37.387 --> 00:15:42.298
is Internet access a fundamental right
that should be written into constitutions?

00:15:42.322 --> 00:15:45.493
If Internet access is a fundamental right,

00:15:45.517 --> 00:15:49.675
is electricity access for the 1.2 billion
who don't have access to electricity

00:15:49.699 --> 00:15:51.116
a fundamental right?

00:15:51.458 --> 00:15:54.487
These are fundamental issues.
Where are the philosophers?

00:15:54.511 --> 00:15:56.171
Where's the dialogue?

00:15:57.548 --> 00:16:00.064
And that brings me
to the reason that I'm here.

00:16:00.517 --> 00:16:03.035
I live in Washington. Pity me.

00:16:03.059 --> 00:16:04.829
(Laughter)

00:16:04.853 --> 00:16:07.120
The dialogue isn't happening there.

00:16:07.890 --> 00:16:10.285
These big issues
that will change the world,

00:16:10.309 --> 00:16:12.957
change national security,
change economics,

00:16:12.981 --> 00:16:15.864
create hope, create threats,

00:16:15.888 --> 00:16:18.602
can only be resolved
when you bring together

00:16:18.626 --> 00:16:22.007
groups of people who understand
science and technology

00:16:22.031 --> 00:16:23.704
back together with government.

00:16:23.728 --> 00:16:25.908
Both sides need each other.

00:16:26.444 --> 00:16:31.196
And until we recreate that connection,

00:16:31.220 --> 00:16:36.651
until we do what helped America grow
and helped other countries grow,

00:16:36.675 --> 00:16:39.745
then we are going to grow
ever more vulnerable.

00:16:40.505 --> 00:16:44.316
The risks associated with 9/11
will not be measured

00:16:44.340 --> 00:16:47.346
in terms of lives lost by terror attacks

00:16:47.370 --> 00:16:51.455
or buildings destroyed
or trillions of dollars spent.

00:16:51.998 --> 00:16:56.901
They'll be measured in terms of the costs
of our distraction from critical issues

00:16:56.925 --> 00:17:00.658
and our inability to get together

00:17:00.682 --> 00:17:04.878
scientists, technologists,
government leaders,

00:17:04.902 --> 00:17:10.037
at a moment of transformation
akin to the beginning of the Renaissance,

00:17:10.061 --> 00:17:13.779
akin to the beginning
of the major transformational eras

00:17:13.803 --> 00:17:16.292
that have happened on Earth,

00:17:16.316 --> 00:17:20.762
and start coming up with,
if not the right answers,

00:17:20.786 --> 00:17:23.139
then at least the right questions.

00:17:23.163 --> 00:17:25.206
We are not there yet,

00:17:25.230 --> 00:17:28.294
but discussions like this
and groups like you

00:17:28.318 --> 00:17:32.104
are the places where those questions
can be formulated and posed.

00:17:32.511 --> 00:17:37.065
And that's why I believe
that groups like TED,

00:17:37.089 --> 00:17:39.682
discussions like this around the planet,

00:17:39.706 --> 00:17:44.416
are the place where the future
of foreign policy, of economic policy,

00:17:44.440 --> 00:17:49.927
of social policy, of philosophy,
will ultimately take place.

00:17:50.352 --> 00:17:52.782
And that's why it's been
a pleasure speaking to you.

00:17:52.806 --> 00:17:54.061
Thank you very, very much.

00:17:54.085 --> 00:17:58.951
(Applause)

title: The story we tell about poverty isn't true
transcript: For the last 50 years, a lot of smart, well-resourced people — some of you, no doubt — have been trying to figure out how to reduce poverty in the United States. People have created and invested millions of dollars into non-profit organizations with the mission of helping people who are poor.They've created think tanks that study issues like education, job creation and asset-building, and then advocated for policies to support our most marginalized communities. They've written books and columns and given passionate speeches, decrying the wealth gap that is leaving more and more people entrenched at the bottom end of the income scale. And that effort has helped. But it's not enough. Our poverty rates haven't changed that much in the last 50 years, since the War on Poverty was launched. I'm here to tell you that we have overlooked the most powerful and practical resource. Here it is: people who are poor.Up in the left-hand corner is Jobana, Sintia and Bertha. They met when they all had small children, through a parenting class at a family resource center in San Francisco. As they grew together as parents and friends, they talked a lot about how hard it was to make money when your kids are little. Child care is expensive, more than they'd earn in a job. Their husbands worked, but they wanted to contribute financially, too.So they hatched a plan. They started a cleaning business. They plastered neighborhoods with flyers and handed business cards out to their families and friends, and soon, they had clients calling. Two of them would clean the office or house and one of them would watch the kids. They'd rotate who'd cleaned and who'd watch the kids. (Laughs) It's awesome, right?(Laughter)And they split the money three ways. It was not a full-time gig, no one could watch the little ones all day. But it made a difference for their families. Extra money to pay for bills when a husband's work hours were cut. Money to buy the kids clothes as they were growing. A little extra money in their pockets to make them feel some independence.Up in the top-right corner is Theresa and her daughter, Brianna. Brianna is one of those kids with this sparkly, infectious, outgoing personality. For example, when Rosie, a little girl who spoke only Spanish, moved in next door, Brianna, who spoke only English, borrowed her mother's tablet and found a translation app so the two of them could communicate.(Laughter)I know, right? Rosie's family credits Brianna with helping Rosie to learn English.A few years ago, Brianna started to struggle academically. She was growing frustrated and kind of withdrawn and acting out in class. And her mother was heartbroken over what was happening. Then they found out that she was going to have to repeat second grade and Brianna was devastated. Her mother felt hopeless and overwhelmed and alone because she knew that her daughter was not getting the support she needed, and she did not know how to help her. One afternoon, Theresa was catching up with a group of friends, and one of them said, "Theresa, how are you?" And she burst into tears. After she shared her story, one of her friends said, "I went through the exact same thing with my son about a year ago." And in that moment, Theresa realized that so much of her struggle was not having anybody to talk with about it. So she created a support group for parents like her. The first meeting was her and two other people. But word spread, and soon 20 people, 30 people were showing up for these monthly meetings that she put together. She went from feeling helpless to realizing how capable she was of supporting her daughter, with the support of other people who were going through the same struggle. And Brianna is doing fantastic — she's doing great academically and socially.That in the middle is my man Baakir, standing in front of BlackStar Books and Caffe, which he runs out of part of his house. As you walk in the door, Baakir greets you with a "Welcome black home."(Laughter)Once inside, you can order some Algiers jerk chicken, perhaps a vegan walnut burger, or jive turkey sammich. And that's sammich — not sandwich. You must finish your meal with a buttermilk drop, which is several steps above a donut hole and made from a very secret family recipe. For real, it's very secret, he won't tell you about it.But BlackStar is much more than a café. For the kids in the neighborhood, it's a place to go after school to get help with homework. For the grown-ups, it's where they go to find out what's going on in the neighborhood and catch up with friends. It's a performance venue. It's a home for poets, musicians and artists. Baakir and his partner Nicole, with their baby girl strapped to her back, are there in the mix of it all, serving up a cup of coffee, teaching a child how to play Mancala, or painting a sign for an upcoming community event.I have worked with and learned from people just like them for more than 20 years. I have organized against the prison system, which impacts poor folks, especially black, indigenous and Latino folks, at an alarming rate. I have worked with young people who manifest hope and promise, despite being at the effect of racist discipline practices in their schools, and police violence in their communities. I have learned from families who are unleashing their ingenuity and tenacity to collectively create their own solutions. And they're not just focused on money. They're addressing education, housing, health, community — the things that we all care about. Everywhere I go, I see people who are broke but not broken. I see people who are struggling to realize their good ideas, so that they can create a better life for themselves, their families, their communities. Jobana, Sintia, Bertha, Theresa and Baakir are the rule, not the shiny exception. I am the exception.I was raised by a quietly fierce single mother in Rochester, New York. I was bussed to a school in the suburbs, from a neighborhood that many of my classmates and their parents considered dangerous. At eight, I was a latchkey kid. I'd get myself home after school every day and do homework and chores, and wait for my mother to come home. After school, I'd go to the corner store and buy a can of Chef Boyardee ravioli, which I'd heat up on the stove as my afternoon snack. If I had a little extra money, I'd buy a Hostess Fruit Pie.(Laughter)Cherry. Not as good as a buttermilk drop.(Laughter)We were poor when I was a kid. But now, I own a home in a quickly gentrifying neighborhood in Oakland, California. I've built a career. My husband is a business owner. I have a retirement account. My daughter is not even allowed to turn on the stove unless there's a grown-up at home and she doesn't have to, because she does not have to have the same kind of self-reliance that I had to at her age. My kids' raviolis are organic and full of things like spinach and ricotta, because I have the luxury of choice when it comes to what my children eat.I am the exception, not because I'm more talented than Baakir or my mother worked any harder than Jobana, Sintia or Bertha, or cared any more than Theresa. Marginalized communities are full of smart, talented people, hustling and working and innovating, just like our most revered and most rewarded CEOs. They are full of people tapping into their resilience to get up every day, get the kids off to school and go to jobs that don't pay enough, or get educations that are putting them in debt. They are full of people applying their savvy intelligence to stretch a minimum wage paycheck, or balance a job and a side hustle to make ends meet. They are full of people doing for themselves and for others, whether it's picking up medication for an elderly neighbor, or letting a sibling borrow some money to pay the phone bill, or just watching out for the neighborhood kids from the front stoop.I am the exception because of luck and privilege, not hard work. And I'm not being modest or self-deprecating — I am amazing.(Laughter)But most people work hard. Hard work is the common denominator in this equation, and I'm tired of the story we tell that hard work leads to success, because that allows —Thank you.(Applause)... because that story allows those of us who make it to believe we deserve it, and by implication, those who don't make it don't deserve it. We tell ourselves, in the back of our minds, and sometimes in the front of our mouths, "There must be something a little wrong with those poor people." We have a wide range of beliefs about what that something wrong is. Some people tell the story that poor folks are lazy freeloaders who would cheat and lie to get out of an honest day's work. Others prefer the story that poor people are helpless and probably had neglectful parents that didn't read to them enough, and if they were just told what to do and shown the right path, they could make it.For every story I hear demonizing low-income single mothers or absentee fathers, which is how people might think of my parents, I've got 50 that tell a different story about the same people, showing up every day and doing their best. I'm not saying that some of the negative stories aren't true, but those stories allow us to not really see who people really are, because they don't paint a full picture. The quarter-truths and limited plot lines have us convinced that poor people are a problem that needs fixing. What if we recognized that what's working is the people and what's broken is our approach? What if we realized that the experts we are looking for, the experts we need to follow, are poor people themselves? What if, instead of imposing solutions, we just added fire to the already-burning flame that they have? Not directing — not even empowering — but just fueling their initiative.Just north of here, we have an example of what this could look like: Silicon Valley. A whole venture capital industry has grown up around the belief that if people have good ideas and the desire to manifest them, we should give them lots and lots and lots of money.(Laughter)Right? But where is our strategy for Theresa and Baakir? There are no incubators for them, no accelerators, no fellowships. How are Jobana, Sintia and Bertha really all that different from the Mark Zuckerbergs of the world? Baakir has experience and a track record. I'd put my money on him.So, consider this an invitation to rethink a flawed strategy. Let's grasp this opportunity to let go of a tired, faulty narrative and listen and look for true stories, more beautifully complex stories, about who marginalized people and families and communities are.I'm going to take a minute to speak to my people. We cannot wait for somebody else to get it right. Let us remember what we are capable of; all that we have built with blood, sweat and dreams; all the cogs that keep turning; and the people kept afloat because of our backbreaking work. Let us remember that we are magic. If you need some inspiration to jog your memory, read Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." Listen to Reverend King's "Letter from Birmingham Jail." Listen to Suheir Hammad recite "First Writing Since," or Esperanza Spalding perform "Black Gold." Set your gaze upon the art of Kehinde Wiley or Favianna Rodriguez. Look at the hands of your grandmother or into the eyes of someone who loves you. We are magic. Individually, we don't have a lot of wealth and power, but collectively, we are unstoppable. And we spend a lot of our time and energy organizing our power to demand change from systems that were not made for us. Instead of trying to alter the fabric of existing ways, let's weave and cut some fierce new cloth. Let's use some of our substantial collective power toward inventing and bringing to life new ways of being that work for us.Desmond Tutu talks about the concept of ubuntu, in the context of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation process that they embarked on after apartheid. He says it means, "My humanity is caught up, is inextricably bound up, in yours; we belong to a bundle of life." A bundle of life. The Truth and Reconciliation process started by elevating the voices of the unheard. If this country is going to live up to its promise of liberty and justice for all, then we need to elevate the voices of our unheard, of people like Jobana, Sintia and Bertha, Theresa and Baakir. We must leverage their solutions and their ideas. We must listen to their true stories, their more beautifully complex stories.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.799 --> 00:00:14.981
For the last 50 years,

00:00:15.005 --> 00:00:20.596
a lot of smart, well-resourced people --
some of you, no doubt --

00:00:20.620 --> 00:00:23.922
have been trying to figure out
how to reduce poverty

00:00:23.946 --> 00:00:25.165
in the United States.

00:00:26.138 --> 00:00:30.102
People have created and invested
millions of dollars

00:00:30.126 --> 00:00:32.343
into non-profit organizations

00:00:32.367 --> 00:00:35.557
with the mission of helping
people who are poor.

00:00:36.207 --> 00:00:38.093
They've created think tanks

00:00:38.117 --> 00:00:43.371
that study issues like education,
job creation and asset-building,

00:00:43.395 --> 00:00:48.170
and then advocated for policies to support
our most marginalized communities.

00:00:48.694 --> 00:00:52.328
They've written books and columns
and given passionate speeches,

00:00:52.352 --> 00:00:56.123
decrying the wealth gap
that is leaving more and more people

00:00:56.147 --> 00:00:59.247
entrenched at the bottom end
of the income scale.

00:01:00.027 --> 00:01:01.603
And that effort has helped.

00:01:02.119 --> 00:01:03.531
But it's not enough.

00:01:04.059 --> 00:01:07.792
Our poverty rates haven't changed
that much in the last 50 years,

00:01:07.816 --> 00:01:09.919
since the War on Poverty was launched.

00:01:10.534 --> 00:01:12.685
I'm here to tell you

00:01:12.709 --> 00:01:18.136
that we have overlooked
the most powerful and practical resource.

00:01:18.733 --> 00:01:20.443
Here it is:

00:01:20.467 --> 00:01:22.160
people who are poor.

00:01:23.340 --> 00:01:27.352
Up in the left-hand corner
is Jobana, Sintia and Bertha.

00:01:27.883 --> 00:01:29.892
They met when they all had small children,

00:01:29.916 --> 00:01:32.753
through a parenting class
at a family resource center

00:01:32.777 --> 00:01:33.961
in San Francisco.

00:01:34.758 --> 00:01:38.377
As they grew together
as parents and friends,

00:01:38.401 --> 00:01:40.417
they talked a lot about how hard it was

00:01:40.441 --> 00:01:42.663
to make money when your kids are little.

00:01:42.687 --> 00:01:44.369
Child care is expensive,

00:01:44.393 --> 00:01:46.148
more than they'd earn in a job.

00:01:46.172 --> 00:01:47.332
Their husbands worked,

00:01:47.356 --> 00:01:49.832
but they wanted to contribute
financially, too.

00:01:49.856 --> 00:01:51.595
So they hatched a plan.

00:01:51.619 --> 00:01:53.504
They started a cleaning business.

00:01:54.049 --> 00:01:56.393
They plastered neighborhoods with flyers

00:01:56.417 --> 00:01:59.290
and handed business cards out
to their families and friends,

00:01:59.314 --> 00:02:01.198
and soon, they had clients calling.

00:02:01.555 --> 00:02:04.620
Two of them would clean
the office or house

00:02:04.644 --> 00:02:06.510
and one of them would watch the kids.

00:02:06.534 --> 00:02:09.449
They'd rotate who'd cleaned
and who'd watch the kids.

00:02:09.473 --> 00:02:11.686
(Laughs) It's awesome, right?

00:02:11.710 --> 00:02:12.924
(Laughter)

00:02:12.948 --> 00:02:14.800
And they split the money three ways.

00:02:14.824 --> 00:02:16.125
It was not a full-time gig,

00:02:16.149 --> 00:02:18.380
no one could watch
the little ones all day.

00:02:18.404 --> 00:02:20.918
But it made a difference
for their families.

00:02:22.007 --> 00:02:27.034
Extra money to pay for bills
when a husband's work hours were cut.

00:02:27.058 --> 00:02:30.336
Money to buy the kids clothes
as they were growing.

00:02:30.360 --> 00:02:32.279
A little extra money in their pockets

00:02:32.303 --> 00:02:34.797
to make them feel some independence.

00:02:34.821 --> 00:02:38.950
Up in the top-right corner
is Theresa and her daughter, Brianna.

00:02:38.974 --> 00:02:40.889
Brianna is one of those kids

00:02:40.913 --> 00:02:45.723
with this sparkly, infectious,
outgoing personality.

00:02:45.747 --> 00:02:47.459
For example, when Rosie,

00:02:47.483 --> 00:02:50.639
a little girl who spoke only Spanish,
moved in next door,

00:02:50.663 --> 00:02:52.811
Brianna, who spoke only English,

00:02:52.835 --> 00:02:56.420
borrowed her mother's tablet
and found a translation app

00:02:56.444 --> 00:02:58.224
so the two of them could communicate.

00:02:58.248 --> 00:02:59.350
(Laughter)

00:02:59.374 --> 00:03:00.556
I know, right?

00:03:00.580 --> 00:03:04.483
Rosie's family credits Brianna
with helping Rosie to learn English.

00:03:05.150 --> 00:03:07.035
A few years ago,

00:03:07.059 --> 00:03:09.846
Brianna started to struggle academically.

00:03:10.270 --> 00:03:14.685
She was growing frustrated
and kind of withdrawn

00:03:14.709 --> 00:03:16.957
and acting out in class.

00:03:16.981 --> 00:03:20.811
And her mother was heartbroken
over what was happening.

00:03:21.655 --> 00:03:24.917
Then they found out that she was going
to have to repeat second grade

00:03:24.941 --> 00:03:26.954
and Brianna was devastated.

00:03:26.978 --> 00:03:32.149
Her mother felt hopeless
and overwhelmed and alone

00:03:32.173 --> 00:03:35.677
because she knew that her daughter
was not getting the support she needed,

00:03:35.701 --> 00:03:37.639
and she did not know how to help her.

00:03:37.663 --> 00:03:41.227
One afternoon, Theresa was catching up
with a group of friends,

00:03:41.251 --> 00:03:42.810
and one of them said,

00:03:42.834 --> 00:03:44.770
"Theresa, how are you?"

00:03:45.302 --> 00:03:47.016
And she burst into tears.

00:03:47.762 --> 00:03:51.103
After she shared her story,
one of her friends said,

00:03:51.127 --> 00:03:54.404
"I went through the exact same thing
with my son about a year ago."

00:03:54.428 --> 00:03:55.579
And in that moment,

00:03:55.603 --> 00:03:57.860
Theresa realized
that so much of her struggle

00:03:57.884 --> 00:04:00.386
was not having anybody
to talk with about it.

00:04:00.942 --> 00:04:04.289
So she created a support group
for parents like her.

00:04:05.059 --> 00:04:08.393
The first meeting was her
and two other people.

00:04:08.417 --> 00:04:11.458
But word spread, and soon
20 people, 30 people

00:04:11.482 --> 00:04:14.857
were showing up for these
monthly meetings that she put together.

00:04:14.881 --> 00:04:17.098
She went from feeling helpless

00:04:17.122 --> 00:04:20.751
to realizing how capable she was
of supporting her daughter,

00:04:20.775 --> 00:04:24.456
with the support of other people
who were going through the same struggle.

00:04:24.480 --> 00:04:27.517
And Brianna is doing fantastic --
she's doing great academically

00:04:27.541 --> 00:04:28.718
and socially.

00:04:29.792 --> 00:04:33.178
That in the middle is my man Baakir,

00:04:33.202 --> 00:04:36.047
standing in front of
BlackStar Books and Caffe,

00:04:36.071 --> 00:04:38.656
which he runs out of part of his house.

00:04:38.680 --> 00:04:40.255
As you walk in the door,

00:04:40.279 --> 00:04:43.663
Baakir greets you
with a "Welcome black home."

00:04:43.687 --> 00:04:46.465
(Laughter)

00:04:46.489 --> 00:04:50.532
Once inside, you can order
some Algiers jerk chicken,

00:04:50.556 --> 00:04:53.079
perhaps a vegan walnut burger,

00:04:53.103 --> 00:04:55.453
or jive turkey sammich.

00:04:55.477 --> 00:04:58.370
And that's sammich -- not sandwich.

00:04:58.394 --> 00:05:02.625
You must finish your meal
with a buttermilk drop,

00:05:02.649 --> 00:05:05.007
which is several steps above a donut hole

00:05:05.031 --> 00:05:07.718
and made from a very secret family recipe.

00:05:08.155 --> 00:05:10.972
For real, it's very secret,
he won't tell you about it.

00:05:11.422 --> 00:05:14.655
But BlackStar is much more than a café.

00:05:15.004 --> 00:05:16.609
For the kids in the neighborhood,

00:05:16.633 --> 00:05:19.638
it's a place to go after school
to get help with homework.

00:05:19.662 --> 00:05:21.455
For the grown-ups, it's where they go

00:05:21.479 --> 00:05:23.682
to find out what's going on
in the neighborhood

00:05:23.706 --> 00:05:25.063
and catch up with friends.

00:05:25.087 --> 00:05:26.564
It's a performance venue.

00:05:26.588 --> 00:05:29.918
It's a home for poets,
musicians and artists.

00:05:30.382 --> 00:05:32.566
Baakir and his partner Nicole,

00:05:32.590 --> 00:05:34.730
with their baby girl strapped to her back,

00:05:34.754 --> 00:05:36.308
are there in the mix of it all,

00:05:36.332 --> 00:05:38.403
serving up a cup of coffee,

00:05:38.427 --> 00:05:40.567
teaching a child how to play Mancala,

00:05:40.591 --> 00:05:43.646
or painting a sign
for an upcoming community event.

00:05:44.140 --> 00:05:48.386
I have worked with and learned
from people just like them

00:05:48.410 --> 00:05:50.051
for more than 20 years.

00:05:50.075 --> 00:05:52.918
I have organized
against the prison system,

00:05:52.942 --> 00:05:55.275
which impacts poor folks,

00:05:55.299 --> 00:05:57.843
especially black, indigenous
and Latino folks,

00:05:57.867 --> 00:05:59.295
at an alarming rate.

00:05:59.716 --> 00:06:03.231
I have worked with young people
who manifest hope and promise,

00:06:03.255 --> 00:06:07.664
despite being at the effect of racist
discipline practices in their schools,

00:06:07.688 --> 00:06:10.124
and police violence in their communities.

00:06:10.563 --> 00:06:12.449
I have learned from families

00:06:12.473 --> 00:06:16.155
who are unleashing
their ingenuity and tenacity

00:06:16.179 --> 00:06:18.369
to collectively create
their own solutions.

00:06:18.393 --> 00:06:20.497
And they're not just focused on money.

00:06:20.869 --> 00:06:24.565
They're addressing education,
housing, health, community --

00:06:24.589 --> 00:06:26.787
the things that we all care about.

00:06:28.218 --> 00:06:29.601
Everywhere I go,

00:06:29.625 --> 00:06:32.759
I see people who are broke but not broken.

00:06:33.221 --> 00:06:37.040
I see people who are struggling
to realize their good ideas,

00:06:37.064 --> 00:06:39.632
so that they can create
a better life for themselves,

00:06:39.656 --> 00:06:42.194
their families, their communities.

00:06:43.274 --> 00:06:49.762
Jobana, Sintia, Bertha, Theresa
and Baakir are the rule,

00:06:49.786 --> 00:06:51.402
not the shiny exception.

00:06:51.881 --> 00:06:53.211
I am the exception.

00:06:54.498 --> 00:06:59.067
I was raised by a quietly fierce
single mother in Rochester, New York.

00:06:59.583 --> 00:07:02.525
I was bussed to a school
in the suburbs, from a neighborhood

00:07:02.549 --> 00:07:06.436
that many of my classmates
and their parents considered dangerous.

00:07:06.460 --> 00:07:08.455
At eight, I was a latchkey kid.

00:07:08.891 --> 00:07:13.299
I'd get myself home after school every day
and do homework and chores,

00:07:13.323 --> 00:07:15.309
and wait for my mother to come home.

00:07:15.333 --> 00:07:17.525
After school, I'd go to the corner store

00:07:17.549 --> 00:07:20.051
and buy a can of Chef Boyardee ravioli,

00:07:20.075 --> 00:07:22.698
which I'd heat up on the stove
as my afternoon snack.

00:07:23.103 --> 00:07:25.910
If I had a little extra money,
I'd buy a Hostess Fruit Pie.

00:07:25.934 --> 00:07:26.935
(Laughter)

00:07:26.959 --> 00:07:28.110
Cherry.

00:07:28.134 --> 00:07:29.788
Not as good as a buttermilk drop.

00:07:29.812 --> 00:07:30.813
(Laughter)

00:07:30.837 --> 00:07:32.531
We were poor when I was a kid.

00:07:32.555 --> 00:07:36.348
But now, I own a home
in a quickly gentrifying neighborhood

00:07:36.372 --> 00:07:37.901
in Oakland, California.

00:07:38.321 --> 00:07:39.968
I've built a career.

00:07:40.333 --> 00:07:42.778
My husband is a business owner.

00:07:43.563 --> 00:07:45.327
I have a retirement account.

00:07:46.263 --> 00:07:48.840
My daughter is not even allowed
to turn on the stove

00:07:48.864 --> 00:07:50.443
unless there's a grown-up at home

00:07:50.467 --> 00:07:51.625
and she doesn't have to,

00:07:51.649 --> 00:07:54.912
because she does not have to have
the same kind of self-reliance

00:07:54.936 --> 00:07:56.729
that I had to at her age.

00:07:56.753 --> 00:07:58.957
My kids' raviolis are organic

00:07:58.981 --> 00:08:01.888
and full of things
like spinach and ricotta,

00:08:01.912 --> 00:08:04.235
because I have the luxury of choice

00:08:04.259 --> 00:08:06.177
when it comes to what my children eat.

00:08:06.201 --> 00:08:08.301
I am the exception,

00:08:08.325 --> 00:08:10.657
not because I'm more talented than Baakir

00:08:10.681 --> 00:08:14.563
or my mother worked any harder
than Jobana, Sintia or Bertha,

00:08:14.587 --> 00:08:16.544
or cared any more than Theresa.

00:08:17.353 --> 00:08:22.459
Marginalized communities are full
of smart, talented people,

00:08:22.483 --> 00:08:24.797
hustling and working and innovating,

00:08:24.821 --> 00:08:28.762
just like our most revered
and most rewarded CEOs.

00:08:28.786 --> 00:08:31.419
They are full of people
tapping into their resilience

00:08:31.443 --> 00:08:33.945
to get up every day,
get the kids off to school

00:08:33.969 --> 00:08:35.955
and go to jobs that don't pay enough,

00:08:35.979 --> 00:08:38.447
or get educations
that are putting them in debt.

00:08:38.808 --> 00:08:43.612
They are full of people applying
their savvy intelligence

00:08:43.636 --> 00:08:46.023
to stretch a minimum wage paycheck,

00:08:46.047 --> 00:08:49.234
or balance a job and a side hustle
to make ends meet.

00:08:49.585 --> 00:08:53.360
They are full of people
doing for themselves and for others,

00:08:53.384 --> 00:08:56.888
whether it's picking up medication
for an elderly neighbor,

00:08:56.912 --> 00:09:00.646
or letting a sibling borrow some money
to pay the phone bill,

00:09:00.670 --> 00:09:02.913
or just watching out
for the neighborhood kids

00:09:02.937 --> 00:09:04.145
from the front stoop.

00:09:05.217 --> 00:09:08.604
I am the exception
because of luck and privilege,

00:09:08.628 --> 00:09:09.913
not hard work.

00:09:09.937 --> 00:09:12.275
And I'm not being modest
or self-deprecating --

00:09:12.299 --> 00:09:13.450
I am amazing.

00:09:13.474 --> 00:09:14.692
(Laughter)

00:09:14.716 --> 00:09:16.330
But most people work hard.

00:09:16.788 --> 00:09:20.957
Hard work is the common
denominator in this equation,

00:09:20.981 --> 00:09:23.350
and I'm tired of the story we tell

00:09:23.374 --> 00:09:25.982
that hard work leads to success,

00:09:26.006 --> 00:09:27.543
because that allows --

00:09:27.567 --> 00:09:28.757
Thank you.

00:09:28.781 --> 00:09:32.272
(Applause)

00:09:33.467 --> 00:09:38.080
... because that story allows those of us
who make it to believe we deserve it,

00:09:38.104 --> 00:09:39.337
and by implication,

00:09:39.361 --> 00:09:41.594
those who don't make it don't deserve it.

00:09:42.133 --> 00:09:44.336
We tell ourselves,
in the back of our minds,

00:09:44.360 --> 00:09:46.635
and sometimes in the front of our mouths,

00:09:46.659 --> 00:09:49.696
"There must be something a little wrong
with those poor people."

00:09:49.720 --> 00:09:51.212
We have a wide range of beliefs

00:09:51.236 --> 00:09:53.421
about what that something wrong is.

00:09:53.445 --> 00:09:56.729
Some people tell the story
that poor folks are lazy freeloaders

00:09:56.753 --> 00:09:59.935
who would cheat and lie
to get out of an honest day's work.

00:10:00.245 --> 00:10:03.158
Others prefer the story
that poor people are helpless

00:10:03.182 --> 00:10:06.463
and probably had neglectful parents
that didn't read to them enough,

00:10:06.487 --> 00:10:08.696
and if they were just told what to do

00:10:08.720 --> 00:10:09.977
and shown the right path,

00:10:10.001 --> 00:10:11.242
they could make it.

00:10:11.875 --> 00:10:18.014
For every story I hear demonizing
low-income single mothers

00:10:18.038 --> 00:10:19.387
or absentee fathers,

00:10:19.411 --> 00:10:22.153
which is how people
might think of my parents,

00:10:22.177 --> 00:10:27.039
I've got 50 that tell a different story
about the same people,

00:10:27.063 --> 00:10:29.973
showing up every day and doing their best.

00:10:30.449 --> 00:10:34.165
I'm not saying that some
of the negative stories aren't true,

00:10:34.189 --> 00:10:40.553
but those stories allow us
to not really see who people really are,

00:10:40.577 --> 00:10:42.764
because they don't paint a full picture.

00:10:43.207 --> 00:10:47.056
The quarter-truths and limited
plot lines have us convinced

00:10:47.080 --> 00:10:50.338
that poor people are a problem
that needs fixing.

00:10:51.528 --> 00:10:55.797
What if we recognized
that what's working is the people

00:10:55.821 --> 00:10:58.375
and what's broken is our approach?

00:10:58.399 --> 00:11:01.924
What if we realized that the experts
we are looking for,

00:11:01.948 --> 00:11:03.744
the experts we need to follow,

00:11:03.768 --> 00:11:05.689
are poor people themselves?

00:11:05.713 --> 00:11:08.716
What if, instead of imposing solutions,

00:11:08.740 --> 00:11:10.839
we just added fire

00:11:10.863 --> 00:11:13.807
to the already-burning flame
that they have?

00:11:13.831 --> 00:11:15.988
Not directing --

00:11:16.012 --> 00:11:18.602
not even empowering --

00:11:18.626 --> 00:11:20.855
but just fueling their initiative.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.315
Just north of here,

00:11:23.339 --> 00:11:26.506
we have an example
of what this could look like:

00:11:26.530 --> 00:11:27.780
Silicon Valley.

00:11:28.455 --> 00:11:32.629
A whole venture capital industry
has grown up around the belief

00:11:32.653 --> 00:11:36.941
that if people have good ideas
and the desire to manifest them,

00:11:36.965 --> 00:11:40.962
we should give them lots
and lots and lots of money.

00:11:40.986 --> 00:11:42.108
(Laughter)

00:11:42.132 --> 00:11:45.973
Right? But where is our strategy
for Theresa and Baakir?

00:11:47.085 --> 00:11:49.381
There are no incubators for them,

00:11:49.405 --> 00:11:52.114
no accelerators, no fellowships.

00:11:52.535 --> 00:11:56.210
How are Jobana, Sintia and Bertha
really all that different

00:11:56.234 --> 00:11:58.872
from the Mark Zuckerbergs of the world?

00:11:58.896 --> 00:12:01.880
Baakir has experience and a track record.

00:12:01.904 --> 00:12:03.613
I'd put my money on him.

00:12:04.607 --> 00:12:11.363
So, consider this an invitation
to rethink a flawed strategy.

00:12:12.148 --> 00:12:14.918
Let's grasp this opportunity

00:12:14.942 --> 00:12:18.759
to let go of a tired, faulty narrative

00:12:18.783 --> 00:12:21.820
and listen and look for true stories,

00:12:21.844 --> 00:12:23.857
more beautifully complex stories,

00:12:23.881 --> 00:12:28.726
about who marginalized people
and families and communities are.

00:12:31.107 --> 00:12:34.230
I'm going to take a minute
to speak to my people.

00:12:39.944 --> 00:12:41.404
We cannot wait

00:12:41.428 --> 00:12:43.808
for somebody else to get it right.

00:12:45.094 --> 00:12:48.250
Let us remember what we are capable of;

00:12:48.274 --> 00:12:52.143
all that we have built
with blood, sweat and dreams;

00:12:52.167 --> 00:12:53.946
all the cogs that keep turning;

00:12:53.970 --> 00:12:57.642
and the people kept afloat
because of our backbreaking work.

00:12:57.666 --> 00:13:00.024
Let us remember that we are magic.

00:13:00.635 --> 00:13:03.555
If you need some inspiration
to jog your memory,

00:13:03.579 --> 00:13:06.549
read Octavia Butler's
"Parable of the Sower."

00:13:06.573 --> 00:13:09.962
Listen to Reverend King's
"Letter from Birmingham Jail."

00:13:09.986 --> 00:13:14.606
Listen to Suheir Hammad recite
"First Writing Since,"

00:13:14.630 --> 00:13:17.679
or Esperanza Spalding
perform "Black Gold."

00:13:17.703 --> 00:13:20.351
Set your gaze upon the art
of Kehinde Wiley

00:13:20.375 --> 00:13:22.229
or Favianna Rodriguez.

00:13:22.872 --> 00:13:28.457
Look at the hands of your grandmother

00:13:28.481 --> 00:13:31.153
or into the eyes of someone who loves you.

00:13:32.344 --> 00:13:34.212
We are magic.

00:13:35.045 --> 00:13:37.915
Individually, we don't have
a lot of wealth and power,

00:13:37.939 --> 00:13:41.446
but collectively, we are unstoppable.

00:13:42.072 --> 00:13:44.343
And we spend a lot of our time and energy

00:13:44.367 --> 00:13:50.566
organizing our power to demand change
from systems that were not made for us.

00:13:51.447 --> 00:13:55.028
Instead of trying to alter
the fabric of existing ways,

00:13:55.052 --> 00:13:57.829
let's weave and cut some fierce new cloth.

00:13:58.313 --> 00:14:01.803
Let's use some of our
substantial collective power

00:14:01.827 --> 00:14:03.799
toward inventing and bringing to life

00:14:03.823 --> 00:14:06.770
new ways of being that work for us.

00:14:07.381 --> 00:14:12.316
Desmond Tutu talks
about the concept of ubuntu,

00:14:12.340 --> 00:14:15.995
in the context of South Africa's
Truth and Reconciliation process

00:14:16.019 --> 00:14:18.312
that they embarked on after apartheid.

00:14:18.336 --> 00:14:20.671
He says it means,

00:14:20.695 --> 00:14:26.221
"My humanity is caught up,
is inextricably bound up, in yours;

00:14:26.245 --> 00:14:30.791
we belong to a bundle of life."

00:14:32.339 --> 00:14:34.526
A bundle of life.

00:14:35.977 --> 00:14:37.765
The Truth and Reconciliation process

00:14:37.789 --> 00:14:41.439
started by elevating
the voices of the unheard.

00:14:42.026 --> 00:14:47.967
If this country is going to live up to its
promise of liberty and justice for all,

00:14:47.991 --> 00:14:51.080
then we need to elevate
the voices of our unheard,

00:14:51.104 --> 00:14:54.585
of people like Jobana,
Sintia and Bertha,

00:14:54.609 --> 00:14:57.076
Theresa and Baakir.

00:14:57.767 --> 00:15:00.752
We must leverage their solutions
and their ideas.

00:15:01.395 --> 00:15:04.525
We must listen to their true stories,

00:15:04.549 --> 00:15:07.199
their more beautifully complex stories.

00:15:07.914 --> 00:15:09.074
Thank you.

00:15:09.098 --> 00:15:14.942
(Applause)

title: Why gender equality is good for everyone — men included
transcript: I'm here to recruit men to support gender equality.(Cheers)Wait, wait. What? What do men have to do with gender equality? Gender equality is about women, right? I mean, the word gender is about women. Actually, I'm even here speaking as a middle class white man.Now, I wasn't always a middle class white man. It all happened for me about 30 years ago when I was in graduate school, and a bunch of us graduate students got together one day, and we said, you know, there's an explosion of writing and thinking in feminist theory, but there's no courses yet. So we did what graduate students typically do in a situation like that. We said, OK, let's have a study group. We'll read a text, we'll talk about it, we'll have a potluck dinner.(Laughter)So every week, 11 women and me got together.(Laughter)We would read some text in feminist theory and have a conversation about it. And during one of our conversations, I witnessed an interaction that changed my life forever. It was a conversation between two women. One of the women was white, and one was black. And the white woman said — this is going to sound very anachronistic now — the white woman said, "All women face the same oppression as women. All women are similarly situated in patriarchy, and therefore all women have a kind of intuitive solidarity or sisterhood." And the black woman said, "I'm not so sure. Let me ask you a question." So the black woman says to the white woman, "When you wake up in the morning and you look in the mirror, what do you see?" And the white woman said, "I see a woman." And the black woman said, "You see, that's the problem for me. Because when I wake up in the morning and I look in the mirror," she said, "I see a black woman. To me, race is visible. But to you, race is invisible. You don't see it." And then she said something really startling. She said, "That's how privilege works. Privilege is invisible to those who have it." It is a luxury, I will say to the white people sitting in this room, not to have to think about race every split second of our lives. Privilege is invisible to those who have it.Now remember, I was the only man in this group, so when I witnessed this, I went, "Oh no."(Laughter)And somebody said, "Well what was that reaction?" And I said, "Well, when I wake up in the morning and I look in the mirror, I see a human being. I'm kind of the generic person. You know, I'm a middle class white man. I have no race, no class, no gender. I'm universally generalizable."(Laughter)So I like to think that was the moment I became a middle class white man, that class and race and gender were not about other people, they were about me. I had to start thinking about them, and it had been privilege that had kept it invisible to me for so long.Now, I wish I could tell you this story ends 30 years ago in that little discussion group, but I was reminded of it quite recently at my university where I teach. I have a colleague, and she and I both teach the sociology of gender course on alternate semesters. So she gives a guest lecture for me when I teach. I give a guest lecture for her when she teaches. So I walk into her class to give a guest lecture, about 300 students in the room, and as I walk in, one of the students looks up and says, "Oh, finally, an objective opinion."All that semester, whenever my colleague opened her mouth, what my students saw was a woman. I mean, if you were to say to my students, "There is structural inequality based on gender in the United States," they'd say, "Well of course you'd say that. You're a woman. You're biased." When I say it, they go, "Wow, is that interesting. Is that going to be on the test? How do you spell 'structural'?"(Laughter)So I hope you all can see, this is what objectivity looks like.(Laughter) (Applause)Disembodied Western rationality.(Laughter)And that, by the way, is why I think men so often wear ties.(Laughter)Because if you are going to embody disembodied Western rationality, you need a signifier, and what could be a better signifier of disembodied Western rationality than a garment that at one end is a noose and the other end points to the genitals?(Laughter) (Applause)That is mind-body dualism right there.So making gender visible to men is the first step to engaging men to support gender equality.Now, when men first hear about gender equality, when they first start thinking about it, they often think, many men think, well, that's right, that's fair, that's just, that's the ethical imperative. But not all men. Some men think — the lightning bolt goes off, and they go, "Oh my God, yes, gender equality," and they will immediately begin to mansplain to you your oppression. They see supporting gender equality something akin to the cavalry, like, "Thanks very much for bringing this to our attention, ladies, we'll take it from here." This results in a syndrome that I like to call 'premature self-congratulation.'(Laughter) (Applause)There's another group, though, that actively resists gender equality, that sees gender equality as something that is detrimental to men. I was on a TV talk show opposite four white men. This is the beginning of the book I wrote, 'Angry White Men.' These were four angry white men who believed that they, white men in America, were the victims of reverse discrimination in the workplace. And they all told stories about how they were qualified for jobs, qualified for promotions, they didn't get them, they were really angry. And the reason I'm telling you this is I want you to hear the title of this particular show. It was a quote from one of the men, and the quote was, "A Black Woman Stole My Job." And they all told their stories, qualified for jobs, qualified for promotions, didn't get it, really angry. And then it was my turn to speak, and I said, "I have just one question for you guys, and it's about the title of the show, 'A Black Woman Stole My Job.' Actually, it's about one word in the title. I want to know about the word 'my.' Where did you get the idea it was your job? Why isn't the title of the show, 'A Black Woman Got the Job?' or 'A Black Woman Got A Job?'" Because without confronting men's sense of entitlement, I don't think we'll ever understand why so many men resist gender equality.(Applause)Look, we think this is a level playing field, so any policy that tilts it even a little bit, we think, "Oh my God, water's rushing uphill. It's reverse discrimination against us."(Laughter)So let me be very clear: white men in Europe and the United States are the beneficiaries of the single greatest affirmative action program in the history of the world. It is called "the history of the world."(Laughter) (Applause)So, now I've established some of the obstacles to engaging men, but why should we support gender equality? Of course, it's fair, it's right and it's just. But more than that, gender equality is also in our interest as men. If you listen to what men say about what they want in their lives, gender equality is actually a way for us to get the lives we want to live.Gender equality is good for countries. It turns out, according to most studies, that those countries that are the most gender equal are also the countries that score highest on the happiness scale. And that's not just because they're all in Europe.(Laughter)Even within Europe, those countries that are more gender equal also have the highest levels of happiness.It is also good for companies. Research by Catalyst and others has shown conclusively that the more gender-equal companies are, the better it is for workers, the happier their labor force is. They have lower job turnover. They have lower levels of attrition. They have an easier time recruiting. They have higher rates of retention, higher job satisfaction, higher rates of productivity. So the question I'm often asked in companies is, "Boy, this gender equality thing, that's really going to be expensive, huh?" And I say, "Oh no, in fact, what you have to start calculating is how much gender inequality is already costing you. It is extremely expensive." So it is good for business.And the other thing is, it's good for men. It is good for the kind of lives we want to live, because young men especially have changed enormously, and they want to have lives that are animated by terrific relationships with their children. They expect their partners, their spouses, their wives, to work outside the home and be just as committed to their careers as they are.I was talking, to give you an illustration of this change — Some of you may remember this. When I was a lot younger, there was a riddle that was posed to us. Some of you may wince to remember this riddle. This riddle went something like this.A man and his son are driving on the freeway, and they're in a terrible accident, and the father is killed, and the son is brought to the hospital emergency room, and as they're bringing the son into the hospital emergency room, the emergency room attending physician sees the boy and says, "Oh, I can't treat him, that's my son." How is this possible?We were flummoxed by this. We could not figure this out.(Laughter)Well, I decided to do a little experiment with my 16-year old son. He had a bunch of his friends hanging out at the house watching a game on TV recently. So I decided I would pose this riddle to them, just to see, to gauge the level of change. Well, 16-year-old boys, they immediately turned to me and said, "It's his mom." Right? No problem. Just like that. Except for my son, who said, "Well, he could have two dads."(Laughter) (Applause)That's an index, an indicator of how things have changed. Younger men today expect to be able to balance work and family. They want to be dual-career, dual-carer couples. They want to be able to balance work and family with their partners. They want to be involved fathers.Now, it turns out that the more egalitarian our relationships, the happier both partners are. Data from psychologists and sociologists are quite persuasive here. I think we have the persuasive numbers, the data, to prove to men that gender equality is not a zero-sum game, but a win-win. Here's what the data show. Now, when men begin the process of engaging with balancing work and family, we often have two phrases that we use to describe what we do. We pitch in and we help out.(Laughter)And I'm going to propose something a little bit more radical, one word: "share."(Laughter)Because here's what the data show: when men share housework and childcare, their children do better in school. Their children have lower rates of absenteeism, higher rates of achievement. They are less likely to be diagnosed with ADHD. They are less likely to see a child psychiatrist. They are less likely to be put on medication.So when men share housework and childcare, their children are happier and healthier, and men want this.When men share housework and childcare, their wives are happier. Duh. Not only that, their wives are healthier. Their wives are less likely to see a therapist, less likely to be diagnosed with depression, less likely to be put on medication, more likely to go to the gym, report higher levels of marital satisfaction. So when men share housework and childcare, their wives are happier and healthier, and men certainly want this as well. When men share housework and childcare, the men are healthier. They smoke less, drink less, take recreational drugs less often. They are less likely to go to the ER but more like to go to a doctor for routine screenings. They are less likely to see a therapist, less likely to be diagnosed with depression, less likely to be taking prescription medication. So when men share housework and childcare, the men are happier and healthier. And who wouldn't want that?And finally, when men share housework and childcare, they have more sex.(Laughter)Now, of these four fascinating findings, which one do you think Men's Health magazine put on its cover?(Laughter)"Housework Makes Her Horny. (Not When She Does It.)"(Laughter)Now, I will say, just to remind the men in the audience, these data were collected over a really long period of time, so I don't want listeners to say, "Hmm, OK, I think I'll do the dishes tonight." These data were collected over a really long period of time. But I think it shows something important, that when Men's Health magazine put it on their cover, they also called, you'll love this, "Choreplay."So, what we found is something really important, that gender equality is in the interest of countries, of companies, and of men, and their children and their partners, that gender equality is not a zero-sum game. It's not a win-lose. It is a win-win for everyone. And what we also know is we cannot fully empower women and girls unless we engage boys and men. We know this. And my position is that men need the very things that women have identified that they need to live the lives they say they want to live in order to live the lives that we say we want to live.In 1915, on the eve of one of the great suffrage demonstrations down Fifth Avenue in New York City, a writer in New York wrote an article in a magazine, and the title of the article was, "Feminism for Men." And this was the first line of that article: "Feminism will make it possible for the first time for men to be free."Thank you.(Applause)
