00:03:56.158 --> 00:03:59.374
and we need a framework,
we need a way to navigate through this.

00:03:59.398 --> 00:04:03.256
And so the first step of our compass is
finding out what our unique strengths are.

00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:06.294
What are the things that we wake up
loving to do no matter what,

00:04:06.318 --> 00:04:09.814
whether we're paid or we're not paid,
the things that people thank us for?

00:04:09.838 --> 00:04:12.814
And the Strengths Finder 2.0
is a book and also an online tool.

00:04:12.838 --> 00:04:16.574
I highly recommend it for sorting out
what it is that you're naturally good at.

00:04:16.598 --> 00:04:21.014
And next, what's our framework
or our hierarchy for making decisions?

00:04:21.038 --> 00:04:25.254
Do we care about the people,
our family, health,

00:04:25.278 --> 00:04:27.414
or is it achievement, success,
all this stuff?

00:04:27.438 --> 00:04:30.105
We have to figure out what it is
to make these decisions,

00:04:30.129 --> 00:04:31.854
so we know what our soul is made of,

00:04:31.878 --> 00:04:36.574
so that we don't go selling it
to some cause we don't give a shit about.

00:04:36.598 --> 00:04:40.294
And then the next step is our experiences.

00:04:40.318 --> 00:04:43.774
All of us have these experiences.
We learn things every day, every minute

00:04:43.798 --> 00:04:45.494
about what we love, what we hate,

00:04:45.518 --> 00:04:47.518
what we're good at,
what we're terrible at.

00:04:47.542 --> 00:04:49.934
And if we don't spend time
paying attention to that

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.494
and assimilating that learning

00:04:51.518 --> 00:04:54.494
and applying it to the rest of our lives,
it's all for nothing.

00:04:54.518 --> 00:04:57.174
Every day, every week,
every month of every year

00:04:57.198 --> 00:04:59.654
I spend some time
just reflecting on what went right,

00:04:59.678 --> 00:05:01.821
what went wrong,
and what do I want to repeat,

00:05:01.845 --> 00:05:03.421
what can I apply more to my life.

00:05:03.445 --> 00:05:06.534
And even more so than that,
as you see people, especially today,

00:05:06.558 --> 00:05:08.939
who inspire you, who are doing
things where you say

00:05:08.963 --> 00:05:11.894
"Oh God, what Jeff is doing,
I want to be like him."

00:05:11.918 --> 00:05:13.639
Why are you saying that?
Open up a journal.

00:05:13.664 --> 00:05:15.734
Write down what it is about them
that inspires you.

00:05:15.758 --> 00:05:17.814
It's not going to be
everything about their life,

00:05:17.838 --> 00:05:19.654
but whatever it is, take note on that,

00:05:19.678 --> 00:05:21.974
so over time we'll have
this repository of things

00:05:21.998 --> 00:05:26.214
that we can use to apply to our life
and have a more passionate existence

00:05:26.238 --> 00:05:27.734
and make a better impact.

00:05:27.758 --> 00:05:30.139
Because when we start
to put these things together,

00:05:30.163 --> 00:05:33.454
we can then define
what success actually means to us,

00:05:33.478 --> 00:05:36.614
and without these different parts
of the compass, it's impossible.

00:05:36.638 --> 00:05:39.258
We end up in the situation --
we have that scripted life

00:05:39.282 --> 00:05:42.414
that everybody seems to be living
going up this ladder to nowhere.

00:05:42.438 --> 00:05:45.094
It's kind of like in Wall Street 2,
if anybody saw that,

00:05:45.118 --> 00:05:48.934
the peon employee asks
the big Wall Street banker CEO,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.094
"What's your number?
Everyone's got a number,

00:05:51.118 --> 00:05:53.654
where if they make this money,
they'll leave it all."

00:05:53.678 --> 00:05:56.198
He says, "Oh, it's simple. More."

00:05:57.078 --> 00:05:58.374
And he just smiles.

00:05:58.398 --> 00:06:00.174
And it's the sad state
of most of the people

00:06:00.198 --> 00:06:02.734
that haven't spent time
understanding what matters for them,

00:06:02.758 --> 00:06:05.494
who keep reaching for something
that doesn't mean anything to us,

00:06:05.518 --> 00:06:08.014
but we're doing it because everyone
said we're supposed to.

00:06:08.038 --> 00:06:09.774
But once we have this framework together,

00:06:09.798 --> 00:06:12.414
we can start to identify
the things that make us come alive.

00:06:12.438 --> 00:06:15.654
You know, before this, a passion
could come and hit you in the face,

00:06:15.678 --> 00:06:18.374
or maybe in your possible line of work,
you might throw it away

00:06:18.398 --> 00:06:20.589
because you don't have
a way of identifying it.

00:06:20.613 --> 00:06:24.149
But once you do, you can see something
that's congruent with my strengths,

00:06:24.173 --> 00:06:25.974
my values, who I am as a person,

00:06:25.998 --> 00:06:29.284
so I'm going to grab ahold of this,
I'm going to do something with it,

00:06:29.308 --> 00:06:32.166
and I'm going to pursue it
and try to make an impact with it.

00:06:32.190 --> 00:06:34.734
And Live Your Legend
and the movement we've built

00:06:34.758 --> 00:06:37.425
wouldn't exist if I didn't have
this compass to identify,

00:06:37.449 --> 00:06:40.694
"Wow, this is something I want to pursue
and make a difference with."

00:06:40.718 --> 00:06:43.774
If we don't know what we're looking for,
we're never going to find it,

00:06:43.798 --> 00:06:46.334
but once we have
this framework, this compass,

00:06:46.358 --> 00:06:50.814
then we can move on to what's next --
and that's not me up there --

00:06:50.838 --> 00:06:53.054
doing the impossible
and pushing our limits.

00:06:53.078 --> 00:06:55.094
There's two reasons
why people don't do things.

00:06:55.118 --> 00:06:57.094
One is they tell themselves
they can't do them,

00:06:57.118 --> 00:06:59.254
or people around them
tell them they can't do them.

00:06:59.278 --> 00:07:00.814
Either way, we start to believe it.

00:07:00.838 --> 00:07:03.214
Either we give up,
or we never start in the first place.

00:07:03.238 --> 00:07:06.134
The things is, everyone was impossible
until somebody did it.

00:07:06.158 --> 00:07:08.694
Every invention,
every new thing in the world,

00:07:08.718 --> 00:07:10.385
people thought were crazy at first.

00:07:10.409 --> 00:07:13.838
Roger Bannister and the four-minute mile,
it was a physical impossibility

00:07:13.862 --> 00:07:16.254
to break the four-minute mile
in a foot race

00:07:16.278 --> 00:07:18.294
until Roger Bannister stood up and did it.

00:07:18.318 --> 00:07:19.534
And then what happened?

00:07:19.558 --> 00:07:22.174
Two months later,
16 people broke the four-minute mile.

00:07:22.198 --> 00:07:24.934
The things that we have in our head
that we think are impossible

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.094
are often just milestones
waiting to be accomplished

00:07:27.118 --> 00:07:28.738
if we can push those limits a bit.

00:07:28.762 --> 00:07:32.134
And I think this starts with probably
your physical body and fitness

00:07:32.158 --> 00:07:34.694
more than anything,
because we can control that.

00:07:34.718 --> 00:07:36.334
If you don't think you can run a mile,

00:07:36.358 --> 00:07:38.414
you show yourself
you can run a mile or two,

00:07:38.438 --> 00:07:40.974
or a marathon, or lose five pounds,
or whatever it is,

00:07:40.998 --> 00:07:43.494
you realize that confidence compounds

00:07:43.518 --> 00:07:46.014
and can be transferred
into the rest of your world.

00:07:46.038 --> 00:07:49.694
And I've actually gotten into the habit
of this a little bit with my friends.

00:07:49.718 --> 00:07:52.454
We have this little group.
We go on physical adventures,

00:07:52.478 --> 00:07:55.574
and recently, I found myself
in a kind of precarious spot.

00:07:55.598 --> 00:07:58.614
I'm terrified of deep, dark, blue water.

00:07:58.638 --> 00:08:00.654
I don't know if anyone's ever had
that same fear

00:08:00.678 --> 00:08:03.277
ever since they watched
Jaws 1, 2, 3 and 4 like six times

00:08:03.302 --> 00:08:04.454
when I was a kid.

00:08:04.478 --> 00:08:09.014
But anything above here, if it's murky,
I can already feel it right now.

00:08:09.038 --> 00:08:10.814
I swear there's something in there.

00:08:10.838 --> 00:08:13.974
Even if it's Lake Tahoe,
it's fresh water, totally unfounded fear,

00:08:13.998 --> 00:08:15.654
ridiculous, but it's there.

00:08:15.678 --> 00:08:18.174
Anyway, three years ago
I find myself on this tugboat

00:08:18.198 --> 00:08:20.174
right down here in the San Francisco Bay.

00:08:20.198 --> 00:08:23.654
It's a rainy, stormy, windy day,
and people are getting sick on the boat,

00:08:23.678 --> 00:08:27.012
and I'm sitting there wearing a wetsuit,
and I'm looking out the window

00:08:27.036 --> 00:08:30.014
in pure terror thinking
I'm about to swim to my death.

00:08:30.038 --> 00:08:32.294
I'm going to try to swim
across the Golden Gate.

00:08:32.318 --> 00:08:36.134
And my guess is some people in this room
might have done that before.

00:08:36.158 --> 00:08:39.374
I'm sitting there, and my buddy Jonathan,
who had talked me into it,

00:08:39.398 --> 00:08:41.654
he comes up to me
and he could see the state I was in.

00:08:41.678 --> 00:08:44.414
And he says, "Scott, hey man,
what's the worst that could happen?

00:08:44.438 --> 00:08:46.574
You're wearing a wetsuit.
You're not going to sink.

00:08:46.598 --> 00:08:49.414
And If you can't make it,
just hop on one of the 20 kayaks.

00:08:49.438 --> 00:08:52.254
Plus, if there's a shark attack,
why are they going to pick you

00:08:52.278 --> 00:08:54.898
over the 80 people in the water?"
So thanks, that helps.

00:08:54.922 --> 00:08:57.778
He's like, "But really,
just have fun with this. Good luck."

00:08:57.802 --> 00:09:00.294
And he dives in, swims off. OK.

00:09:00.318 --> 00:09:04.694
Turns out, the pep talk totally worked,
and I felt this total feeling of calm,

00:09:04.718 --> 00:09:07.654
and I think it was because
Jonathan was 13 years old.

00:09:07.678 --> 00:09:09.614
(Laughter)

00:09:09.638 --> 00:09:12.334
And of the 80 people swimming that day,

00:09:12.358 --> 00:09:15.174
65 of them were between
the ages of nine and 13.

00:09:15.198 --> 00:09:17.934
Think how you would have approached
your world differently

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:21.134
if at nine years old you found out
you could swim a mile and a half

00:09:21.158 --> 00:09:23.854
in 56-degree water
from Alcatraz to San Francisco.

00:09:23.878 --> 00:09:25.294
What would you have said yes to?

00:09:25.318 --> 00:09:28.174
What would you have not given up on?
What would you have tried?

00:09:28.198 --> 00:09:30.294
As I'm finishing this swim,
I get to Aquatic Park,

00:09:30.318 --> 00:09:31.694
and I'm getting out of the water

00:09:31.718 --> 00:09:33.814
and of course half the kids
are already finished,

00:09:33.838 --> 00:09:36.172
so they're cheering me on
and they're all excited.

00:09:36.196 --> 00:09:39.212
And I got total popsicle head,
if anyone's ever swam in the Bay,

00:09:39.236 --> 00:09:42.734
and I'm trying to just thaw my face out,
and I'm watching people finish.

00:09:42.768 --> 00:09:45.784
And I see this one kid,
something didn't look right.

00:09:45.798 --> 00:09:47.814
And he's just flailing like this.

00:09:47.838 --> 00:09:51.254
And he's barely able to sip some air
before he slams his head back down.

00:09:51.278 --> 00:09:53.494
And I notice other parents
were watching too,

00:09:53.518 --> 00:09:55.974
and I swear they were thinking
the same thing I was:

00:09:55.998 --> 00:09:59.934
this is why you don't let nine-year-olds
swim from Alcatraz.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.174
This was not fatigue.

00:10:01.198 --> 00:10:03.494
All of a sudden, two parents
run up and grab him,

00:10:03.518 --> 00:10:07.294
and they put him on their shoulders,
and they're dragging him like this,

00:10:07.318 --> 00:10:09.174
totally limp.

00:10:09.198 --> 00:10:11.534
And then all of a sudden
they walk a few more feet

00:10:11.558 --> 00:10:13.534
and they plop him down in his wheelchair.

00:10:13.558 --> 00:10:17.094
And he puts his fists up in the most
insane show of victory I've ever seen.

00:10:17.118 --> 00:10:19.774
I can still feel the warmth
and the energy on this guy

00:10:19.798 --> 00:10:21.374
when he made this accomplishment.

00:10:21.398 --> 00:10:24.374
I had seen him earlier that day
in his wheelchair.

00:10:24.398 --> 00:10:26.374
I just had no idea he was going to swim.

00:10:26.398 --> 00:10:29.494
I mean, where is he
going to be in 20 years?

00:10:29.518 --> 00:10:32.934
How many people told him he couldn't
do that, that he would die if tried that?

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.094
You prove people wrong,
you prove yourself wrong,

00:10:35.118 --> 00:10:36.934
that you can make
little incremental pushes

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.494
of what you believe is possible.

00:10:38.518 --> 00:10:40.934
You don't have to be
the fastest marathoner in the world,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.339
just your own impossibilities,
to accomplish those,

00:10:43.363 --> 00:10:45.339
and it starts with little bitty steps.

00:10:45.363 --> 00:10:47.694
And the best way to do this

00:10:47.718 --> 00:10:49.934
is to surround yourself
with passionate people.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.720
The fastest things to do things
you don't think can be done

00:10:52.744 --> 00:10:55.316
is to surround yourself
with people already doing them.

00:10:55.340 --> 00:10:57.774
There's this quote by Jim Rohn and it says.

00:10:57.798 --> 00:11:01.174
"You are the average of the five people
you spend the most time with."

00:11:01.198 --> 00:11:04.494
And there is no bigger lifehack
in the history of the world

00:11:04.518 --> 00:11:07.574
from getting where you are today
to where you want to be

00:11:07.598 --> 00:11:10.494
than the people you choose
to put in your corner.

00:11:10.518 --> 00:11:12.814
They change everything,
and it's a proven fact.

00:11:12.838 --> 00:11:17.134
In 1898, Norman Triplett did this study
with a bunch of cyclists,

00:11:17.158 --> 00:11:19.958
and he would measure their times
around the track in a group,

00:11:19.983 --> 00:11:21.134
and also individually.

00:11:21.158 --> 00:11:24.854
And he found that every time the cyclists
in the group would cycle faster.

00:11:24.878 --> 00:11:27.694
And it's been repeated
in all kinds of walks of life since then,

00:11:27.718 --> 00:11:29.614
and it proves the same thing over again,

00:11:29.638 --> 00:11:32.494
that the people around you matter,
and environment is everything.

00:11:32.518 --> 00:11:35.094
But it's on you to control it,
because it can go both ways.

00:11:35.118 --> 00:11:37.694
With 80 percent of people
who don't like the work they do,

00:11:37.718 --> 00:11:40.894
that means most people around us,
not in this room, but everywhere else,

00:11:40.918 --> 00:11:44.574
are encouraging complacency and keeping us
from pursuing the things that matter to us

00:11:44.598 --> 00:11:46.654
so we have to manage those surroundings.

00:11:46.678 --> 00:11:48.678
I found myself in this situation --

00:11:50.638 --> 00:11:53.534
personal example, a couple years ago.

00:11:53.558 --> 00:11:57.734
Has anyone ever had a hobby or a passion
they poured their heart and soul into,

00:11:57.758 --> 00:12:01.254
unbelievable amount of time, and they
so badly want to call it a business,

00:12:01.278 --> 00:12:05.414
but no one's paying attention
and it doesn't make a dime?

00:12:05.438 --> 00:12:09.534
OK, I was there for four years trying
to build this Live Your Legend movement

00:12:09.558 --> 00:12:12.894
to help people do work that they genuinely
cared about and that inspired them,

00:12:12.918 --> 00:12:14.254
and I was doing all I could,

00:12:14.278 --> 00:12:16.454
and there were only
three people paying attention,

00:12:16.478 --> 00:12:19.717
and they're all right there:
my mother, father and my wife, Chelsea.

00:12:19.741 --> 00:12:21.237
Thank you guys for the support.

00:12:21.261 --> 00:12:22.734
(Applause)

00:12:22.758 --> 00:12:27.454
And this is how badly I wanted it,
it grew at zero percent for four years,

00:12:27.478 --> 00:12:29.454
and I was about to shut it down,

00:12:29.478 --> 00:12:31.174
and right about then,

00:12:31.198 --> 00:12:34.734
I moved to San Francisco and started
to meet some pretty interesting people

00:12:34.758 --> 00:12:36.974
who had these crazy
lifestyles of adventure,

00:12:36.998 --> 00:12:39.014
of businesses and websites and blogs

00:12:39.038 --> 00:12:42.294
that surrounded their passions
and helped people in a meaningful way.

00:12:42.318 --> 00:12:44.974
And one of my friends,
now, he has a family of eight,

00:12:44.998 --> 00:12:47.334
and he supports his whole family

00:12:47.358 --> 00:12:50.214
with a blog that he
writes for twice a week.

00:12:50.238 --> 00:12:53.286
They just came back from a month
in Europe, all of them together.

00:12:53.310 --> 00:12:55.374
This blew my mind.
How does this even exist?

00:12:55.398 --> 00:12:58.894
And I got unbelievably inspired
by seeing this,

00:12:58.918 --> 00:13:01.894
and instead of shutting it down,
I decided, let's take it seriously.

00:13:01.918 --> 00:13:03.894
And I did everything I could
to spend my time,

00:13:03.918 --> 00:13:06.414
every waking hour possible
trying to hound these guys,

00:13:06.438 --> 00:13:09.214
hanging out and having beers
and workouts, whatever it was.

00:13:09.238 --> 00:13:10.974
And after four years of zero growth,

00:13:10.998 --> 00:13:13.334
within six months
of hanging around these people,

00:13:13.358 --> 00:13:16.054
the community at Live Your Legend
grew by 10 times.

00:13:16.078 --> 00:13:19.934
In another 12 months,
it grew by 160 times.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:23.014
And today over 30,000 people
from 158 countries

00:13:23.038 --> 00:13:26.134
use our career and connection tools
on a monthly basis.

00:13:26.158 --> 00:13:30.534
And those people have made up
that community of passionate folks

00:13:30.558 --> 00:13:32.774
who inspired that possibility
that I dreamed of

00:13:32.798 --> 00:13:35.974
for Live Your Legend so many years back.

00:13:35.998 --> 00:13:38.254
The people change everything,
and this is why --

00:13:38.278 --> 00:13:40.494
you know, you ask what was going on.

00:13:40.518 --> 00:13:42.974
Well, for four years,
I knew nobody in this space,

00:13:42.998 --> 00:13:46.494
and I didn't even know it existed,
that people could do this stuff,

00:13:46.518 --> 00:13:48.494
that you could have movements like this.

00:13:48.518 --> 00:13:52.174
And then I'm over here in San Francisco,
and everyone around me was doing it.

00:13:52.198 --> 00:13:56.294
It became normal, so my thinking went
from how could I possibly do this

00:13:56.318 --> 00:13:58.134
to how could I possibly not.

00:13:58.158 --> 00:14:01.374
And right then, when that happens,
that switch goes on in your head,

00:14:01.398 --> 00:14:03.065
it ripples across your whole world.

00:14:03.089 --> 00:14:06.014
And without even trying,
your standards go from here to here.

00:14:06.038 --> 00:14:09.753
You don't need to change your goals.
You just need to change your surroundings.

00:14:09.777 --> 00:14:14.134
That's it, and that's why I love
being around this whole group of people,

00:14:14.158 --> 00:14:15.778
why I go to every TED event I can,

00:14:15.802 --> 00:14:18.734
and watch them on my iPad
on the way to work, whatever it is.

00:14:18.758 --> 00:14:22.174
Because this is the group of people
that inspires possibility.

00:14:22.198 --> 00:14:25.214
We have a whole day
to spend together and plenty more.

00:14:25.238 --> 00:14:28.694
To sum things up,
in terms of these three pillars,

00:14:28.718 --> 00:14:32.654
they all have one thing in common
more than anything else.

00:14:32.678 --> 00:14:35.134
They are 100 percent in our control.

00:14:35.158 --> 00:14:38.214
No one can tell you
you can't learn about yourself.

00:14:38.238 --> 00:14:40.381
No one can tell you
you can't push your limits

00:14:40.405 --> 00:14:42.694
and learn your own impossible
and push that.

00:14:42.718 --> 00:14:45.654
No one can tell you you can't
surround yourself with inspiring people

00:14:45.678 --> 00:14:47.869
or get away from the people
who bring you down.

00:14:47.893 --> 00:14:49.322
You can't control a recession.

00:14:49.346 --> 00:14:52.534
You can't control getting fired
or getting in a car accident.

00:14:52.558 --> 00:14:54.654
Most things are totally out of our hands.

00:14:54.678 --> 00:14:57.038
These three things are totally on us,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:03.108
and they can change our whole world
if we decide to do something about it.

00:15:04.038 --> 00:15:07.038
And the thing is, it's starting to happen
on a widespread level.

00:15:07.062 --> 00:15:10.253
I just read in Forbes, the US Government
reported for the first time

00:15:10.277 --> 00:15:12.974
in a month where more people
had quit their jobs

00:15:12.998 --> 00:15:14.334
than had been laid off.

00:15:14.358 --> 00:15:17.574
They thought this was an anomaly,
but it's happened three months straight.

00:15:17.598 --> 00:15:20.294
In a time where people claim
it's kind of a tough environment,

00:15:20.318 --> 00:15:22.654
people are giving a middle finger
to this scripted life,

00:15:22.678 --> 00:15:24.734
the things that people
say you're supposed to do,

00:15:24.758 --> 00:15:28.494
in exchange for things that matter to them
and do the things that inspire them.

00:15:28.518 --> 00:15:31.294
And the thing is, people
are waking up to this possibility,

00:15:31.318 --> 00:15:37.294
that really the only thing that limits
possibility now is imagination.

00:15:37.318 --> 00:15:39.294
That's not a cliché anymore.

00:15:39.318 --> 00:15:42.494
I don't care what it is that you're into,
what passion, what hobby.

00:15:42.518 --> 00:15:45.974
If you're into knitting, you can find
someone who is killing it knitting,

00:15:45.998 --> 00:15:48.334
and you can learn from them. It's wild.

00:15:48.358 --> 00:15:51.854
And that's what this whole day is about,
to learn from the folks speaking,

00:15:51.878 --> 00:15:55.294
and we profile these people
on Live Your Legend every day,

00:15:55.318 --> 00:15:58.014
because when ordinary people
are doing the extraordinary,

00:15:58.038 --> 00:15:59.814
and we can be around that,

00:15:59.838 --> 00:16:01.574
it becomes normal.

00:16:01.598 --> 00:16:05.694
And this isn't about being Gandhi
or Steve Jobs, doing something crazy.

00:16:05.718 --> 00:16:08.147
It's just about doing something
that matters to you,

00:16:08.171 --> 00:16:10.211
and makes an impact
that only you can make.

00:16:11.558 --> 00:16:15.214
Speaking of Gandhi,
he was a recovering lawyer,

00:16:15.238 --> 00:16:16.574
as I've heard the term,

00:16:16.598 --> 00:16:19.854
and he was called to a greater cause,
something that mattered to him,

00:16:19.878 --> 00:16:21.094
he couldn't not do.

00:16:21.118 --> 00:16:23.357
And he has this quote
that I absolutely live by.

00:16:23.381 --> 00:16:25.694
"First they ignore you,
then they laugh at you,

00:16:25.718 --> 00:16:27.838
then they fight you, then you win."

00:16:29.918 --> 00:16:32.574
Everything was impossible
until somebody did it.

00:16:32.598 --> 00:16:35.774
You can either hang around the people
who tell you it can't be done

00:16:35.798 --> 00:16:37.614
and tell you you're stupid for trying,

00:16:37.638 --> 00:16:40.934
or surround yourself with the people
who inspire possibility,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.558
the people who are in this room.

00:16:43.558 --> 00:16:47.454
Because I see it as our responsibility
to show the world

00:16:47.478 --> 00:16:50.894
that what's seen as impossible
can become that new normal.

00:16:50.918 --> 00:16:53.094
And that's already starting to happen.

00:16:53.118 --> 00:16:55.814
First, do the things that inspire us,

00:16:55.838 --> 00:16:59.534
so we can inspire other people
to do the things that inspire them.

00:16:59.558 --> 00:17:01.198
But we can't find that

00:17:02.158 --> 00:17:04.214
unless we know what we're looking for.

00:17:04.238 --> 00:17:06.334
We have to do our work on ourself,

00:17:06.358 --> 00:17:08.934
be intentional about that,
and make those discoveries.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:12.482
Because I imagine a world where 80 percent
of people love the work they do.

00:17:12.506 --> 00:17:13.814
What would that look like?

00:17:13.838 --> 00:17:17.854
What would the innovation be like?
How would you treat the people around you?

00:17:17.878 --> 00:17:19.258
Things would start to change.

00:17:20.758 --> 00:17:23.974
And as we finish up,
I have just one question to ask you guys,

00:17:23.998 --> 00:17:26.734
and I think it's the only
question that matters.

00:17:26.758 --> 00:17:29.358
And it's what is the work
you can't not do?

00:17:30.438 --> 00:17:32.694
Discover that, live it,

00:17:32.718 --> 00:17:35.398
not just for you,
but for everybody around you,

00:17:36.358 --> 00:17:39.214
because that is what starts
to change the world.

00:17:39.238 --> 00:17:41.558
What is the work you can't not do?

00:17:42.358 --> 00:17:43.574
Thank you guys.

00:17:43.598 --> 00:17:46.118
(Applause)

title: How I stopped the Taliban from shutting down my school
transcript: (Arabic) I seek refuge in Allah from cursed Satan. In the Name of Allah, the most Gracious, the most Merciful.(English) I was born in a middle class family. My father was five years old when he lost his father, but by the time I was born, he was already a businessman. But it didn't make a difference to him if his children were going to be a boy or a girl: they were going to go to school. So I guess I was the lucky one.My mother had 16 pregnancies. From 16 pregnancies, five of us are alive. You can imagine as a child what I went through. Day to day, I watched women being carried to a graveyard, or watched children going to a graveyard. At that time, when I finished my high school, I really wanted to be a doctor. I wanted to be a doctor to help women and children. So I completed my education, but I wanted to go to university. Unfortunately, in my country, there wasn't a dormitory for girls, so I was accepted in medical school, but I could not go there. So as a result, my father sent me to America.I came to America. I completed my education. While I was completing my education, my country was invaded by Russia. And do you know that at the time I was completing my education, I didn't know what was going on with my family or with my country. There were months, years, I didn't know about it. My family was in a refugee camp. So as soon as I completed my education, I brought my family to America. I wanted them to be safe.But where was my heart? My heart was in Afghanistan. Day after day, when I listened to the news, when I followed what was going on with my country, my heart was breaking up. I really wanted to go back to my country, but at the same time I knew I could not go there, because there was no place for me. I had a good job. I was a professor at a university. I earned good money. I had a good life. My family was here. I could live with them. But I wasn't happy. I wanted to go back home. So I went to the refugee camp. And when I went to the refugee camp in Pakistan, there were 7.5 million refugees. 7.5 million refugees. About 90 percent of them were women and children. Most of the men have been killed or they were in war. And you know, in the refugee camp, when I went day-to-day to do a survey, I found things you never could imagine. I saw a widow with five to eight children sitting there and weeping and not knowing what to do. I saw a young woman have no way to go anywhere, no education, no entertainment, no place to even live. I saw young men that had lost their father and their home, and they are supporting the family as a 10-to-12-year old boy — being the head of the household, trying to protect their sister and their mother and their children.So it was a very devastating situation. My heart was beating for my people, and I didn't know what to do. At that moment, we talk about momentum. At that moment, I felt, what can I do for these people? How could I help these people? I am one individual. What can I do for them?But at that moment, I knew that education changed my life. It transformed me. It gave me status. It gave me confidence. It gave me a career. It helped me to support my family, to bring my family to another country, to be safe. And I knew that at that moment that what I should give to my people is education and health, and that's what I went after.But do you think it was easy? No, because at that time, education was banned for girls, completely. And also, by Russia invading Afghanistan, people were not trusting anyone. It was very hard to come and say, "I want to do this." Who am I? Somebody who comes from the United States. Somebody who got educated here. Did they trust me? Of course not.So I really needed to build the trust in this community. How am I going to do that? I went and surveyed and looked and looked. I asked. Finally, I found one man. He was 80 years old. He was a mullah. I went to his tent in the camp, and I asked him, "I want to make you a teacher." And he looked at me, and he said, "Crazy woman, crazy woman, how do you think I can be a teacher?" And I told him, "I will make you a teacher." Finally, he accepted my offer, and once I started a class in his compound, the word spread all over. In a matter of one year, we had 25 schools set up, 15,000 children going to school, and it was amazing.(Applause)Thank you. Thank you.But of course, we're doing all our work, we were giving teacher training. We were training women's rights, human rights, democracy, rule of law. We were giving all kinds of training. And one day, I tell you, one day I was in the office in Peshawar, Pakistan. All of a sudden, I saw my staff running to rooms and locking the doors and telling me, "Run away, hide!" And you know, as a leader, what do you do? You're scared. You know it's dangerous. You know your life is on the line. But as a leader, you have to hold it together. You have to hold it together and show strength. So I said, "What's going on?" And these people were pouring into my office. So I invited them to the office. They came, and there were nine of them — nine Taliban. They were the ugliest looking men you can ever see.(Laughter)Very mean-looking people, black clothes, black turban, and they pour into my office. And I invited them to have a seat and have tea. They said no. They are not going to drink tea. And of course, with the tone of voice they were using, it was very scary, but I was really shaking up. But also I was strong, holding myself up. And, of course, by that time, you know how I dress — I dress from head to toe in a black hijab. The only thing you could see, my eyes. They asked me, "What are you doing? Don't you know that school is banned for girls? What are you doing here?" And you know, I just looked at them, and I said, "What school? Where is the school?"(Laughter)(Applause)And they look at my face, and they said, "You are teaching girls here." I said, "This is a house of somebody. We have some students coming, and they are all learning Koran, Holy Book. And you know, Koran says that if you learn the Holy Book, the woman, they can be a good wife, and they can obey their husband."(Laughter)And I tell you one thing: that's the way you work with those people, and you know —(Laughter)So by that time, they started speaking Pashto. They talked to each other, and they said, "Let's go, leave her alone, she's OK." And you know, this time, I offered them tea again, and they took a sip and they left. By that time, my staff poured into my office. They were scared to death. They didn't know why they didn't kill me. They didn't know why they didn't take me away. But everybody was happy to see me. Very happy, and I was happy to be alive, of course.(Laughter)Of course, I was happy to be alive. But also, as we continuously gave training during the fall of the Taliban — of course during the Taliban there is another story. We went underground and we provided education for 80 schoolgirls, 3,000 students underground, and continuously we trained.With the fall of the Taliban, we went into the country, and we opened school after school. We opened women's learning center. We continuously opened clinics. We worked with mothers and children. We had reproductive health training. We had all kinds of training that you can imagine. I was very happy. I was delighted with the outcome of my work. And one day, with four trainers and one bodyguard, I was going up north of Kabul, and all of a sudden, again, I was stopped in the middle of the road by 19 young men. Rifles on their shoulders, they blocked the road. And I told my driver, "What's going on?" And the driver said, "I don't know." He asked them. They said, "We have nothing to do with you." They called my name. They said, "We want her." My bodyguard got out, said, "I can answer you. What do you want?" They said, "Nothing." They called my name. And by that time, the women are yelling and screaming inside the car. I am very shaken up, and I told myself, this is it. This time, we all are going to be killed. There is no doubt in my mind. But still, the moment comes, and you take strength from whatever you believe and whatever you do. It's in your heart. You believe in your worth, and you can walk on it.So I just hold myself on the side of the car. My leg was shaking, and I got outside. And I asked them, "What can I do for you?" You know what they said to me? They said, "We know who you are. We know where you are going. Every day you go up north here and there. You train women, you teach them and also you give them an opportunity to have a job. You build their skills. How about us?"(Laughter)(Applause)"And you know, how about us? What are we going to do?" I looked at them, and I said, "I don't know."(Laughter)They said, "It's OK. The only thing we can do, what we know, from the time we're born, we just hold the gun and kill. That's all we know." And you know what that means. It's a trap to me, of course. So I walk out of there. They said, "We'll let you go, go." And so I walked into the car, I sit in the car, and I told the driver, "Turn around and go back to the office." At that time, we only were supporting girls. We only had money for women to train them, to send them to school, and nothing else.By the time I came to the office, of course my trainers were gone. They ran away home. Nobody stayed there. My bodyguard was the only one there, and my voice was completely gone. I was shaken up, and I sat on my table, and I said, "What am I going to do?" How am I going to solve this problem? Because we had training going on up north already. Hundreds of women were there coming to get training.So I was sitting there, all of a sudden, at this moment, talking about momentum, we are, at that moment, one of my wonderful donors called me about a report. And she asked me, "Sakena?" And I answered her. She said, "It's not you. What's wrong with you?" I said, "Nothing." I tried to cover. No matter what I tried to do, she didn't believe me, and she asked me again. "OK, tell me what's going on?" I told her the whole story. At that time, she said, "OK, you go next time, and you will help them. You will help them." And when, two days later, I went the same route, and do you know, they were not in here, they were a little back further, the same young men, standing up there and holding the rifle and pointing to us to stop the car. So we stopped the car. I got out. I said, "OK, let's go with me." And they said, "Yes." I said, "On one condition, that whatever I say, you accept it." And they said, yes, they do. So I took them to the mosque, and to make a long story short, I told them I'd give them teachers. Today, they are the best trainers. They learn English, they learn how to be teachers, they learn computers, and they are my guides. Every area that is unknown to us in the mountain areas, they go with me. They are ahead, and we go. And they protect us. And —(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)That tells you that education transforms people. When you educate people, they are going to be different, and today all over, we need to work for gender equality. We cannot only train women but forget about the men, because the men are the real people who are giving women the hardest time.(Laughter)So we started training men because the men should know the potential of women, know how much these potential men has, and how much these women can do the same job they are doing. So we are continuously giving training to men, and I really believe strongly. I live in a country that was a beautiful country. I just want to share this with you. It was a beautiful country, beautiful, peaceful country. We were going everywhere. Women were getting education: lawyer, engineer, teacher, and we were going from house to house. We never locked our doors. But you know what happened to my country. Today, people cannot walk out of their door without security issues. But we want the same Afghanistan we had before. And I want to tell you the other side. Today, the women of Afghanistan are working very, very hard. They are earning degrees. They are training to be lawyers. They are training to be doctors, back again. They are training to be teachers, and they are running businesses. So it is so wonderful to see people like that reach their complete potential, and all of this is going to happen.I want to share this with you, because of love, because of compassion, and because of trust and honesty. If you have these few things with you, you will accomplish. We have one poet, Mawlānā Rūmī. He said that by having compassion and having love, you can conquer the world. And I tell you, we could. And if we could do it in Afghanistan, I am sure 100 percent that everyone can do it in any part of the world.Thank you very, very much.(Applause)Thank you. Thank you.(Applause)

"I will make you a teacher."

00:05:52.663 --> 00:05:54.806
Finally, he accepted my offer,

00:05:55.512 --> 00:05:58.314
and once I started a class
in his compound,

00:05:58.893 --> 00:06:00.806
the word spread all over.

00:06:01.615 --> 00:06:03.757
In a matter of one year,

00:06:03.781 --> 00:06:06.702
we had 25 schools set up,

00:06:06.726 --> 00:06:09.670
15,000 children going to school,

00:06:09.694 --> 00:06:11.790
and it was amazing.

00:06:11.814 --> 00:06:14.051
(Applause)

00:06:14.075 --> 00:06:15.226
Thank you.

00:06:16.194 --> 00:06:17.345
Thank you.

00:06:18.210 --> 00:06:23.752
But of course, we're doing all our work,
we were giving teacher training.

00:06:23.776 --> 00:06:28.545
We were training women's rights,
human rights, democracy, rule of law.

00:06:28.569 --> 00:06:30.998
We were giving all kinds of training.

00:06:31.022 --> 00:06:33.498
And one day, I tell you,

00:06:34.045 --> 00:06:37.704
one day I was in the office
in Peshawar, Pakistan.

00:06:38.514 --> 00:06:43.424
All of a sudden, I saw my staff
running to rooms and locking the doors

00:06:43.448 --> 00:06:46.401
and telling me, "Run away, hide!"

00:06:47.226 --> 00:06:49.734
And you know, as a leader, what do you do?

00:06:50.377 --> 00:06:54.251
You're scared. You know it's dangerous.

00:06:54.275 --> 00:06:56.045
You know your life is on the line.

00:06:56.069 --> 00:06:58.854
But as a leader,
you have to hold it together.

00:06:59.267 --> 00:07:01.965
You have to hold it together
and show strength.

00:07:02.370 --> 00:07:04.576
So I said, "What's going on?"

00:07:04.600 --> 00:07:07.465
And these people were pouring
into my office.

00:07:07.838 --> 00:07:09.497
So I invited them to the office.

00:07:09.521 --> 00:07:14.132
They came, and there were
nine of them -- nine Taliban.

00:07:14.711 --> 00:07:17.433
They were the ugliest looking men
you can ever see.

00:07:17.457 --> 00:07:19.498
(Laughter)

00:07:19.522 --> 00:07:21.520
Very mean-looking people,

00:07:21.544 --> 00:07:23.791
black clothes, black turban,

00:07:23.815 --> 00:07:25.551
and they pour into my office.

00:07:26.004 --> 00:07:29.297
And I invited them
to have a seat and have tea.

00:07:29.599 --> 00:07:32.091
They said no. They are not
going to drink tea.

00:07:32.892 --> 00:07:36.344
And of course, with the tone
of voice they were using,

00:07:36.368 --> 00:07:37.764
it was very scary,

00:07:37.788 --> 00:07:40.375
but I was really shaking up.

00:07:40.399 --> 00:07:43.978
But also I was strong, holding myself up.

00:07:44.382 --> 00:07:47.312
And, of course, by that time,
you know how I dress --

00:07:47.336 --> 00:07:49.907
I dress from head to toe in a black hijab.

00:07:49.931 --> 00:07:52.414
The only thing you could see, my eyes.

00:07:53.422 --> 00:07:55.876
They asked me, "What are you doing?

00:07:55.900 --> 00:07:59.305
Don't you know that school
is banned for girls?

00:07:59.734 --> 00:08:01.472
What are you doing here?"

00:08:01.884 --> 00:08:04.481
And you know, I just looked at them,

00:08:04.505 --> 00:08:07.100
and I said, "What school?
Where is the school?"

00:08:07.465 --> 00:08:10.266
(Laughter)

00:08:10.290 --> 00:08:13.386
(Applause)

00:08:13.410 --> 00:08:17.171
And they look at my face, and they said,
"You are teaching girls here."

00:08:17.195 --> 00:08:20.029
I said, "This is a house of somebody.

00:08:20.386 --> 00:08:22.290
We have some students coming,

00:08:22.314 --> 00:08:25.266
and they are all learning
Koran, Holy Book.

00:08:25.750 --> 00:08:30.020
And you know, Koran says that
if you learn the Holy Book, the woman,

00:08:30.044 --> 00:08:32.297
they can be a good wife,

00:08:32.321 --> 00:08:34.361
and they can obey their husband."

00:08:34.726 --> 00:08:38.870
(Laughter)

00:08:38.894 --> 00:08:40.711
And I tell you one thing:

00:08:40.735 --> 00:08:43.458
that's the way you work with those people,
and you know --

00:08:43.482 --> 00:08:44.933
(Laughter)

00:08:44.957 --> 00:08:48.980
So by that time,
they started speaking Pashto.

00:08:49.004 --> 00:08:50.933
They talked to each other,

00:08:50.957 --> 00:08:53.647
and they said, "Let's go,
leave her alone, she's OK."

00:08:54.862 --> 00:08:58.766
And you know, this time,
I offered them tea again,

00:08:58.790 --> 00:09:01.448
and they took a sip and they left.

00:09:02.099 --> 00:09:06.226
By that time, my staff
poured into my office.

00:09:06.250 --> 00:09:08.265
They were scared to death.

00:09:08.289 --> 00:09:10.360
They didn't know why they didn't kill me.

00:09:10.384 --> 00:09:12.821
They didn't know why
they didn't take me away.

00:09:12.845 --> 00:09:15.583
But everybody was happy to see me.

00:09:16.122 --> 00:09:19.115
Very happy, and I was happy
to be alive, of course.

00:09:19.139 --> 00:09:20.290
(Laughter)

00:09:20.314 --> 00:09:22.328
Of course, I was happy to be alive.

00:09:22.352 --> 00:09:28.228
But also, as we continuously gave
training during the fall of the Taliban --

00:09:28.252 --> 00:09:30.689
of course during the Taliban
there is another story.

00:09:30.713 --> 00:09:34.872
We went underground and we provided
education for 80 schoolgirls,

00:09:34.896 --> 00:09:38.419
3,000 students underground,
and continuously we trained.

00:09:38.760 --> 00:09:41.677
With the fall of the Taliban,
we went into the country,

00:09:41.701 --> 00:09:44.161
and we opened school after school.

00:09:44.185 --> 00:09:46.590
We opened women's learning center.

00:09:46.614 --> 00:09:48.550
We continuously opened clinics.

00:09:48.574 --> 00:09:50.558
We worked with mothers and children.

00:09:50.582 --> 00:09:52.305
We had reproductive health training.

00:09:52.329 --> 00:09:55.145
We had all kinds of training
that you can imagine.

00:09:55.447 --> 00:09:59.716
I was very happy. I was delighted
with the outcome of my work.

00:10:00.113 --> 00:10:03.372
And one day, with four trainers
and one bodyguard,

00:10:03.729 --> 00:10:06.165
I was going up north of Kabul,

00:10:06.650 --> 00:10:08.570
and all of a sudden, again,

00:10:09.197 --> 00:10:11.475
I was stopped in the middle of the road

00:10:11.499 --> 00:10:13.390
by 19 young men.

00:10:13.794 --> 00:10:16.437
Rifles on their shoulders,
they blocked the road.

00:10:17.604 --> 00:10:20.509
And I told my driver, "What's going on?"

00:10:20.533 --> 00:10:22.256
And the driver said, "I don't know."

00:10:22.280 --> 00:10:25.049
He asked them. They said,
"We have nothing to do with you."

00:10:25.073 --> 00:10:28.080
They called my name.
They said, "We want her."

00:10:28.786 --> 00:10:31.689
My bodyguard got out, said,
"I can answer you.

00:10:31.713 --> 00:10:33.007
What do you want?"

00:10:33.031 --> 00:10:35.038
They said, "Nothing." They called my name.

00:10:35.062 --> 00:10:39.933
And by that time, the women
are yelling and screaming inside the car.

00:10:39.957 --> 00:10:42.512
I am very shaken up,
and I told myself, this is it.

00:10:42.536 --> 00:10:45.053
This time, we all are going to be killed.

00:10:45.077 --> 00:10:47.377
There is no doubt in my mind.

00:10:47.679 --> 00:10:52.591
But still, the moment comes,
and you take strength

00:10:52.615 --> 00:10:55.489
from whatever you believe
and whatever you do.

00:10:55.513 --> 00:10:56.878
It's in your heart.

00:10:56.902 --> 00:10:59.777
You believe in your worth,
and you can walk on it.

00:10:59.801 --> 00:11:03.340
So I just hold myself
on the side of the car.

00:11:03.364 --> 00:11:06.919
My leg was shaking, and I got outside.

00:11:06.943 --> 00:11:09.443
And I asked them, "What can I do for you?"

00:11:09.467 --> 00:11:11.054
You know what they said to me?

00:11:11.078 --> 00:11:14.220
They said, "We know who you are.

00:11:14.244 --> 00:11:16.166
We know where you are going.

00:11:16.190 --> 00:11:18.871
Every day you go up north here and there.

00:11:18.895 --> 00:11:21.943
You train women, you teach them

00:11:21.967 --> 00:11:25.014
and also you give them an
opportunity to have a job.

00:11:25.038 --> 00:11:27.838
You build their skills. How about us?"

00:11:27.862 --> 00:11:30.713
(Laughter)

00:11:30.737 --> 00:11:33.705
(Applause)

00:11:33.729 --> 00:11:38.093
"And you know, how about us?

00:11:38.117 --> 00:11:39.703
What are we going to do?"

00:11:39.727 --> 00:11:42.099
I looked at them, and I said,
"I don't know."

00:11:42.123 --> 00:11:44.941
(Laughter)

00:11:44.965 --> 00:11:46.536
They said, "It's OK.

00:11:46.560 --> 00:11:48.720
The only thing we can do, what we know,

00:11:48.744 --> 00:11:51.823
from the time we're born,
we just hold the gun and kill.

00:11:51.847 --> 00:11:53.123
That's all we know."

00:11:53.671 --> 00:11:55.140
And you know what that means.

00:11:55.164 --> 00:11:57.051
It's a trap to me, of course.

00:11:57.480 --> 00:12:00.933
So I walk out of there.
They said, "We'll let you go, go."

00:12:01.393 --> 00:12:04.297
And so I walked into the car,
I sit in the car,

00:12:04.321 --> 00:12:07.591
and I told the driver,
"Turn around and go back to the office."

00:12:07.957 --> 00:12:11.370
At that time, we only
were supporting girls.

00:12:11.394 --> 00:12:14.855
We only had money for women to train them,

00:12:14.879 --> 00:12:17.497
to send them to school, and nothing else.

00:12:17.839 --> 00:12:20.370
By the time I came to the office,

00:12:20.680 --> 00:12:22.933
of course my trainers were gone.

00:12:22.957 --> 00:12:25.927
They ran away home. Nobody stayed there.

00:12:26.372 --> 00:12:28.872
My bodyguard was the only one there,

00:12:29.348 --> 00:12:32.054
and my voice was completely gone.

00:12:32.078 --> 00:12:35.213
I was shaken up, and I sat on my table,

00:12:35.237 --> 00:12:37.245
and I said, "What am I going to do?"

00:12:37.785 --> 00:12:40.261
How am I going to solve this problem?

00:12:40.285 --> 00:12:43.689
Because we had training
going on up north already.

00:12:44.038 --> 00:12:47.665
Hundreds of women were there
coming to get training.

00:12:48.253 --> 00:12:52.006
So I was sitting there,
all of a sudden, at this moment,

00:12:52.030 --> 00:12:53.983
talking about momentum, we are,

00:12:54.459 --> 00:12:56.340
at that moment,

00:12:56.364 --> 00:13:00.332
one of my wonderful donors
called me about a report.

00:13:01.165 --> 00:13:04.698
And she asked me, "Sakena?"
And I answered her.

00:13:04.722 --> 00:13:07.070
She said, "It's not you.
What's wrong with you?"

00:13:07.094 --> 00:13:09.713
I said, "Nothing." I tried to cover.

00:13:10.419 --> 00:13:13.275
No matter what I tried to do,
she didn't believe me,

00:13:13.299 --> 00:13:14.950
and she asked me again.

00:13:14.974 --> 00:13:16.816
"OK, tell me what's going on?"

00:13:16.840 --> 00:13:18.878
I told her the whole story.

00:13:18.902 --> 00:13:23.553
At that time, she said, "OK,
you go next time, and you will help them.

00:13:24.180 --> 00:13:25.791
You will help them."

00:13:26.100 --> 00:13:29.775
And when, two days later,
I went the same route,

00:13:30.322 --> 00:13:32.815
and do you know, they were not in here,

00:13:32.839 --> 00:13:35.012
they were a little back further,

00:13:35.036 --> 00:13:39.585
the same young men, standing up there
and holding the rifle

00:13:39.609 --> 00:13:41.915
and pointing to us to stop the car.

00:13:41.939 --> 00:13:43.663
So we stopped the car.

00:13:43.687 --> 00:13:46.567
I got out. I said, "OK, let's go with me."

00:13:46.957 --> 00:13:48.235
And they said, "Yes."

00:13:48.259 --> 00:13:52.687
I said, "On one condition,
that whatever I say, you accept it."

00:13:53.004 --> 00:13:54.583
And they said, yes, they do.

00:13:54.607 --> 00:13:56.480
So I took them to the mosque,

00:13:56.821 --> 00:13:59.610
and to make a long story short,

00:13:59.957 --> 00:14:02.380
I told them I'd give them teachers.

00:14:02.721 --> 00:14:06.673
Today, they are the best trainers.

00:14:06.697 --> 00:14:08.356
They learn English,

00:14:08.380 --> 00:14:10.816
they learn how to be teachers,

00:14:10.840 --> 00:14:12.578
they learn computers,

00:14:12.602 --> 00:14:14.452
and they are my guides.

00:14:14.476 --> 00:14:18.313
Every area that is unknown to us
in the mountain areas,

00:14:18.337 --> 00:14:20.584
they go with me.
They are ahead, and we go.

00:14:20.608 --> 00:14:22.265
And they protect us.

00:14:23.233 --> 00:14:24.384
And --

00:14:24.408 --> 00:14:25.559
(Applause)

00:14:25.583 --> 00:14:26.734
Thank you.

00:14:26.758 --> 00:14:30.264
(Applause)

00:14:30.288 --> 00:14:34.447
That tells you that education
transforms people.

00:14:35.471 --> 00:14:37.605
When you educate people,

00:14:37.629 --> 00:14:39.597
they are going to be different,

00:14:39.621 --> 00:14:41.304
and today all over,

00:14:41.328 --> 00:14:43.700
we need to work for gender equality.

00:14:43.724 --> 00:14:47.430
We cannot only train women
but forget about the men,

00:14:47.454 --> 00:14:52.908
because the men are the real people
who are giving women the hardest time.

00:14:52.932 --> 00:14:54.511
(Laughter)

00:14:54.535 --> 00:14:58.296
So we started training men
because the men should know

00:14:58.320 --> 00:14:59.787
the potential of women,

00:14:59.811 --> 00:15:02.312
know how much these potential men has,

00:15:02.336 --> 00:15:06.931
and how much these women
can do the same job they are doing.

00:15:06.955 --> 00:15:10.335
So we are continuously giving
training to men,

00:15:10.359 --> 00:15:13.645
and I really believe strongly.

00:15:13.669 --> 00:15:16.789
I live in a country
that was a beautiful country.

00:15:16.813 --> 00:15:18.631
I just want to share this with you.

00:15:18.964 --> 00:15:20.782
It was a beautiful country,

00:15:20.806 --> 00:15:22.837
beautiful, peaceful country.

00:15:23.234 --> 00:15:25.186
We were going everywhere.

00:15:25.210 --> 00:15:27.283
Women were getting education:

00:15:27.307 --> 00:15:29.694
lawyer, engineer, teacher,

00:15:30.163 --> 00:15:32.330
and we were going from house to house.

00:15:32.354 --> 00:15:34.228
We never locked our doors.

00:15:34.870 --> 00:15:36.832
But you know what happened to my country.

00:15:36.856 --> 00:15:42.672
Today, people cannot walk
out of their door without security issues.

00:15:43.255 --> 00:15:48.188
But we want the same
Afghanistan we had before.

00:15:48.212 --> 00:15:50.156
And I want to tell you the other side.

00:15:50.180 --> 00:15:53.735
Today, the women of Afghanistan
are working very, very hard.

00:15:54.124 --> 00:15:58.584
They are earning degrees.
They are training to be lawyers.

00:15:58.608 --> 00:16:00.838
They are training to be
doctors, back again.

00:16:00.862 --> 00:16:02.512
They are training to be teachers,

00:16:02.536 --> 00:16:04.520
and they are running businesses.

00:16:04.885 --> 00:16:07.323
So it is so wonderful

00:16:07.347 --> 00:16:11.750
to see people like that
reach their complete potential,

00:16:12.067 --> 00:16:14.345
and all of this is going to happen.

00:16:14.670 --> 00:16:16.512
I want to share this with you,

00:16:16.536 --> 00:16:17.940
because of love,

00:16:18.250 --> 00:16:20.043
because of compassion,

00:16:20.067 --> 00:16:23.154
and because of trust and honesty.

00:16:23.178 --> 00:16:26.596
If you have these few things with you,

00:16:26.897 --> 00:16:28.636
you will accomplish.

00:16:28.977 --> 00:16:32.524
We have one poet, Mawlānā Rūmī.

00:16:32.548 --> 00:16:37.358
He said that by having compassion

00:16:37.382 --> 00:16:40.605
and having love,
you can conquer the world.

00:16:40.629 --> 00:16:42.199
And I tell you, we could.

00:16:42.223 --> 00:16:44.484
And if we could do it in Afghanistan,

00:16:44.508 --> 00:16:48.850
I am sure 100 percent that everyone
can do it in any part of the world.

00:16:48.874 --> 00:16:50.613
Thank you very, very much.

00:16:50.637 --> 00:16:53.482
(Applause)

00:16:53.506 --> 00:16:58.933
Thank you. Thank you.

00:16:58.957 --> 00:17:02.196
(Applause)

title: Why public beheadings get millions of views
transcript: For the last year, everyone's been watching the same show, and I'm not talking about "Game of Thrones," but a horrifying, real-life drama that's proved too fascinating to turn off. It's a show produced by murderers and shared around the world via the Internet. Their names have become familiar: James Foley, Steven Sotloff, David Haines, Alan Henning, Peter Kassig, Haruna Yukawa, Kenji Goto Jogo.Their beheadings by the Islamic State were barbaric, but if we think they were archaic, from a remote, obscure age, then we're wrong. They were uniquely modern, because the murderers acted knowing well that millions of people would tune in to watch.The headlines called them savages and barbarians, because the image of one man overpowering another, killing him with a knife to the throat, conforms to our idea of ancient, primitive practices, the polar opposite of our urban, civilized ways. We don't do things like that. But that's the irony. We think a beheading has nothing to do with us, even as we click on the screen to watch. But it is to do with us. The Islamic State beheadings are not ancient or remote. They're a global, 21st century event, a 21st century event that takes place in our living rooms, at our desks, on our computer screens. They're entirely dependent on the power of technology to connect us. And whether we like it or not, everyone who watches is a part of the show.And lots of people watch. We don't know exactly how many. Obviously, it's difficult to calculate. But a poll taken in the UK, for example, in August 2014, estimated that 1.2 million people had watched the beheading of James Foley in the few days after it was released. And that's just the first few days, and just Britain. A similar poll taken in the United States in November 2014 found that nine percent of those surveyed had watched beheading videos, and a further 23 percent had watched the videos but had stopped just before the death was shown. Nine percent may be a small minority of all the people who could watch, but it's still a very large crowd. And of course that crowd is growing all the time, because every week, every month, more people will keep downloading and keep watching.If we go back 11 years, before sites like YouTube and Facebook were born, it was a similar story. When innocent civilians like Daniel Pearl, Nick Berg, Paul Johnson, were beheaded, those videos were shown during the Iraq War.Nick Berg's beheading quickly became one of the most searched for items on the Internet. Within a day, it was the top search term across search engines like Google, Lycos, Yahoo. In the week after Nick Berg's beheading, these were the top 10 search terms in the United States. The Berg beheading video remained the most popular search term for a week, and it was the second most popular search term for the whole month of May, runner-up only to "American Idol." The al-Qaeda-linked website that first showed Nick Berg's beheading had to close down within a couple of days due to overwhelming traffic to the site. One Dutch website owner said that his daily viewing figures rose from 300,000 to 750,000 every time a beheading in Iraq was shown. He told reporters 18 months later that it had been downloaded many millions of times, and that's just one website. A similar pattern was seen again and again when videos of beheadings were released during the Iraq War.Social media sites have made these images more accessible than ever before, but if we take another step back in history, we'll see that it was the camera that first created a new kind of crowd in our history of beheadings as public spectacle. As soon as the camera appeared on the scene, a full lifetime ago on June 17, 1939, it had an immediate and unequivocal effect.That day, the first film of a public beheading was created in France. It was the execution, the guillotining, of a German serial killer, Eugen Weidmann, outside the prison Saint-Pierre in Versailles. Weidmann was due to be executed at the crack of dawn, as was customary at the time, but his executioner was new to the job, and he'd underestimated how long it would take him to prepare. So Weidmann was executed at 4:30 in the morning, by which time on a June morning, there was enough light to take photographs, and a spectator in the crowd filmed the event, unbeknownst to the authorities. Several still photographs were taken as well, and you can still watch the film online today and look at the photographs. The crowd on the day of Weidmann's execution was called "unruly" and "disgusting" by the press, but that was nothing compared to the untold thousands of people who could now study the action over and over again, freeze-framed in every detail.The camera may have made these scenes more accessible than ever before, but it's not just about the camera. If we take a bigger leap back in history, we'll see that for as long as there have been public judicial executions and beheadings, there have been the crowds to see them. In London, as late as the early 19th century, there might be four or five thousand people to see a standard hanging. There could be 40,000 or 50,000 to see a famous criminal killed. And a beheading, which was a rare event in England at the time, attracted even more.In May 1820, five men known as the Cato Street Conspirators were executed in London for plotting to assassinate members of the British government. They were hung and then decapitated. It was a gruesome scene. Each man's head was hacked off in turn and held up to the crowd. And 100,000 people, that's 10,000 more than can fit into Wembley Stadium, had turned out to watch. The streets were packed. People had rented out windows and rooftops. People had climbed onto carts and wagons in the street. People climbed lamp posts. People had been known to have died in the crush on popular execution days.Evidence suggests that throughout our history of public beheadings and public executions, the vast majority of the people who come to see are either enthusiastic or, at best, unmoved. Disgust has been comparatively rare, and even when people are disgusted and are horrified, it doesn't always stop them from coming out all the same to watch.Perhaps the most striking example of the human ability to watch a beheading and remain unmoved and even be disappointed was the introduction in France in 1792 of the guillotine, that famous decapitation machine. To us in the 21st century, the guillotine may seem like a monstrous contraption, but to the first crowds who saw it, it was actually a disappointment. They were used to seeing long, drawn-out, torturous executions on the scaffold, where people were mutilated and burned and pulled apart slowly. To them, watching the guillotine in action, it was so quick, there was nothing to see. The blade fell, the head fell into a basket, out of sight immediately, and they called out, "Give me back my gallows, give me back my wooden gallows."The end of torturous public judicial executions in Europe and America was partly to do with being more humane towards the criminal, but it was also partly because the crowd obstinately refused to behave in the way that they should. All too often, execution day was more like a carnival than a solemn ceremony.Today, a public judicial execution in Europe or America is unthinkable, but there are other scenarios that should make us cautious about thinking that things are different now and we don't behave like that anymore.Take, for example, the incidents of suicide baiting. This is when a crowd gathers to watch a person who has climbed to the top of a public building in order to kill themselves, and people in the crowd shout and jeer, "Get on with it! Go on and jump!" This is a well-recognized phenomenon. One paper in 1981 found that in 10 out of 21 threatened suicide attempts, there was incidents of suicide baiting and jeering from a crowd. And there have been incidents reported in the press this year. This was a very widely reported incident in Telford and Shropshire in March this year.And when it happens today, people take photographs and they take videos on their phones and they post those videos online. When it comes to brutal murderers who post their beheading videos, the Internet has created a new kind of crowd. Today, the action takes place in a distant time and place, which gives the viewer a sense of detachment from what's happening, a sense of separation. It's nothing to do with me. It's already happened. We are also offered an unprecedented sense of intimacy. Today, we are all offered front row seats. We can all watch in private, in our own time and space, and no one need ever know that we've clicked on the screen to watch.This sense of separation — from other people, from the event itself — seems to be key to understanding our ability to watch, and there are several ways in which the Internet creates a sense of detachment that seems to erode individual moral responsibility. Our activities online are often contrasted with real life, as though the things we do online are somehow less real. We feel less accountable for our actions when we interact online. There's a sense of anonymity, a sense of invisibility, so we feel less accountable for our behavior. The Internet also makes it far easier to stumble upon things inadvertently, things that we would usually avoid in everyday life. Today, a video can start playing before you even know what you're watching. Or you may be tempted to look at material that you wouldn't look at in everyday life or you wouldn't look at if you were with other people at the time. And when the action is pre-recorded and takes place in a distant time and space, watching seems like a passive activity. There's nothing I can do about it now. It's already happened.All these things make it easier as an Internet user for us to give in to our sense of curiosity about death, to push our personal boundaries, to test our sense of shock, to explore our sense of shock.But we're not passive when we watch. On the contrary, we're fulfilling the murderer's desire to be seen. When the victim of a decapitation is bound and defenseless, he or she essentially becomes a pawn in their killer's show. Unlike a trophy head that's taken in battle, that represents the luck and skill it takes to win a fight, when a beheading is staged, when it's essentially a piece of theater, the power comes from the reception the killer receives as he performs. In other words, watching is very much part of the event. The event no longer takes place in a single location at a certain point in time as it used to and as it may still appear to. Now the event is stretched out in time and place, and everyone who watches plays their part.We should stop watching, but we know we won't. History tells us we won't, and the killers know it too.Thank you.(Applause)Bruno Giussani: Thank you. Let me get this back. Thank you. Let's move here. While they install for the next performance, I want to ask you the question that probably many here have, which is how did you get interested in this topic?Frances Larson: I used to work at a museum called the Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford, which was famous for its display of shrunken heads from South America. People used to say, "Oh, the shrunken head museum, the shrunken head museum!" And at the time, I was working on the history of scientific collections of skulls. I was working on the cranial collections, and it just struck me as ironic that here were people coming to see this gory, primitive, savage culture that they were almost fantasizing about and creating without really understanding what they were seeing, and all the while these vast — I mean hundreds of thousands of skulls in our museums, all across Europe and the States — were kind of upholding this Enlightenment pursuit of scientific rationality. So I wanted to kind of twist it round and say, "Let's look at us." We're looking through the glass case at these shrunken heads. Let's look at our own history and our own cultural fascination with these things. BG: Thank you for sharing that.FL: Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:12.918 --> 00:00:14.174
For the last year,

00:00:14.198 --> 00:00:16.854
everyone's been watching the same show,

00:00:16.878 --> 00:00:19.094
and I'm not talking
about "Game of Thrones,"

00:00:19.118 --> 00:00:22.054
but a horrifying, real-life drama

00:00:22.078 --> 00:00:25.334
that's proved too fascinating to turn off.

00:00:25.358 --> 00:00:28.054
It's a show produced by murderers

00:00:28.078 --> 00:00:30.838
and shared around the world
via the Internet.

00:00:32.038 --> 00:00:34.494
Their names have become familiar:

00:00:34.518 --> 00:00:41.414
James Foley, Steven Sotloff,
David Haines, Alan Henning, Peter Kassig,

00:00:41.438 --> 00:00:45.054
Haruna Yukawa, Kenji Goto Jogo.

00:00:45.078 --> 00:00:47.774
Their beheadings by the Islamic State

00:00:47.798 --> 00:00:49.414
were barbaric,

00:00:49.438 --> 00:00:52.358
but if we think they were archaic,

00:00:53.238 --> 00:00:56.094
from a remote, obscure age,

00:00:56.118 --> 00:00:57.774
then we're wrong.

00:00:57.798 --> 00:01:00.534
They were uniquely modern,

00:01:00.558 --> 00:01:03.414
because the murderers acted knowing well

00:01:03.438 --> 00:01:06.118
that millions of people
would tune in to watch.

00:01:07.638 --> 00:01:10.974
The headlines called them
savages and barbarians,

00:01:10.998 --> 00:01:14.454
because the image of one man
overpowering another,

00:01:14.478 --> 00:01:16.733
killing him with a knife to the throat,

00:01:16.758 --> 00:01:21.054
conforms to our idea
of ancient, primitive practices,

00:01:21.078 --> 00:01:24.758
the polar opposite
of our urban, civilized ways.

00:01:26.198 --> 00:01:28.878
We don't do things like that.

00:01:29.918 --> 00:01:31.734
But that's the irony.

00:01:31.758 --> 00:01:34.414
We think a beheading
has nothing to do with us,

00:01:34.438 --> 00:01:37.278
even as we click on the screen to watch.

00:01:38.238 --> 00:01:40.118
But it is to do with us.

00:01:41.798 --> 00:01:44.254
The Islamic State beheadings

00:01:44.278 --> 00:01:46.974
are not ancient or remote.

00:01:46.998 --> 00:01:50.014
They're a global, 21st century event,

00:01:50.038 --> 00:01:54.974
a 21st century event that takes place
in our living rooms, at our desks,

00:01:54.998 --> 00:01:57.334
on our computer screens.

00:01:57.358 --> 00:02:01.678
They're entirely dependent
on the power of technology to connect us.

00:02:02.838 --> 00:02:04.414
And whether we like it or not,

00:02:04.438 --> 00:02:07.518
everyone who watches
is a part of the show.

00:02:09.238 --> 00:02:11.478
And lots of people watch.

00:02:13.518 --> 00:02:15.054
We don't know exactly how many.

00:02:15.078 --> 00:02:17.734
Obviously, it's difficult to calculate.

00:02:17.758 --> 00:02:23.414
But a poll taken in the UK,
for example, in August 2014,

00:02:23.438 --> 00:02:28.278
estimated that 1.2 million people

00:02:29.278 --> 00:02:32.734
had watched the beheading of James Foley

00:02:32.758 --> 00:02:35.398
in the few days after it was released.

00:02:36.558 --> 00:02:39.014
And that's just the first few days,

00:02:39.038 --> 00:02:40.238
and just Britain.

00:02:41.638 --> 00:02:44.054
A similar poll taken in the United States

00:02:44.078 --> 00:02:45.798
in November 2014

00:02:46.918 --> 00:02:49.654
found that nine percent of those surveyed

00:02:49.678 --> 00:02:51.758
had watched beheading videos,

00:02:52.478 --> 00:02:54.734
and a further 23 percent

00:02:54.758 --> 00:02:58.758
had watched the videos but had stopped
just before the death was shown.

00:03:00.678 --> 00:03:05.654
Nine percent may be a small minority
of all the people who could watch,

00:03:05.678 --> 00:03:08.734
but it's still a very large crowd.

00:03:08.758 --> 00:03:11.494
And of course that crowd
is growing all the time,

00:03:11.518 --> 00:03:13.654
because every week, every month,

00:03:13.678 --> 00:03:16.838
more people will keep downloading
and keep watching.

00:03:18.558 --> 00:03:20.494
If we go back 11 years,

00:03:20.518 --> 00:03:23.974
before sites like YouTube
and Facebook were born,

00:03:23.998 --> 00:03:25.734
it was a similar story.

00:03:25.758 --> 00:03:29.134
When innocent civilians like Daniel Pearl,

00:03:29.158 --> 00:03:33.094
Nick Berg, Paul Johnson, were beheaded,

00:03:33.118 --> 00:03:36.734
those videos were shown
during the Iraq War.

00:03:36.758 --> 00:03:38.414
Nick Berg's beheading

00:03:38.438 --> 00:03:43.238
quickly became one of the most
searched for items on the Internet.

00:03:44.158 --> 00:03:47.174
Within a day, it was the top search term

00:03:47.198 --> 00:03:52.294
across search engines
like Google, Lycos, Yahoo.

00:03:52.318 --> 00:03:55.494
In the week after Nick Berg's beheading,

00:03:55.518 --> 00:03:59.758
these were the top 10 search terms
in the United States.

00:04:00.838 --> 00:04:05.734
The Berg beheading video remained
the most popular search term for a week,

00:04:05.758 --> 00:04:10.374
and it was the second most popular
search term for the whole month of May,

00:04:10.398 --> 00:04:13.118
runner-up only to "American Idol."

00:04:14.598 --> 00:04:19.294
The al-Qaeda-linked website
that first showed Nick Berg's beheading

00:04:19.318 --> 00:04:24.638
had to close down within a couple of days
due to overwhelming traffic to the site.

00:04:25.558 --> 00:04:29.694
One Dutch website owner said
that his daily viewing figures

00:04:29.718 --> 00:04:34.534
rose from 300,000 to 750,000

00:04:34.558 --> 00:04:37.518
every time a beheading in Iraq was shown.

00:04:38.398 --> 00:04:41.534
He told reporters 18 months later

00:04:41.558 --> 00:04:44.934
that it had been downloaded
many millions of times,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.878
and that's just one website.

00:04:47.718 --> 00:04:50.214
A similar pattern was seen again and again

00:04:50.238 --> 00:04:54.878
when videos of beheadings
were released during the Iraq War.

00:04:56.838 --> 00:05:01.854
Social media sites have made these images
more accessible than ever before,

00:05:01.878 --> 00:05:05.414
but if we take
another step back in history,

00:05:05.438 --> 00:05:10.574
we'll see that it was the camera
that first created a new kind of crowd

00:05:10.598 --> 00:05:14.774
in our history of beheadings
as public spectacle.

00:05:14.798 --> 00:05:17.854
As soon as the camera
appeared on the scene,

00:05:17.878 --> 00:05:21.614
a full lifetime ago on June 17, 1939,

00:05:21.638 --> 00:05:25.334
it had an immediate
and unequivocal effect.

00:05:25.358 --> 00:05:30.478
That day, the first film of a public
beheading was created in France.

00:05:31.638 --> 00:05:37.374
It was the execution, the guillotining,
of a German serial killer, Eugen Weidmann,

00:05:37.398 --> 00:05:40.118
outside the prison
Saint-Pierre in Versailles.

00:05:42.198 --> 00:05:45.174
Weidmann was due to be executed
at the crack of dawn,

00:05:45.198 --> 00:05:47.374
as was customary at the time,

00:05:47.398 --> 00:05:49.974
but his executioner was new to the job,

00:05:49.998 --> 00:05:53.854
and he'd underestimated
how long it would take him to prepare.

00:05:53.878 --> 00:05:58.014
So Weidmann was executed
at 4:30 in the morning,

00:05:58.038 --> 00:06:00.414
by which time on a June morning,

00:06:00.438 --> 00:06:02.998
there was enough light
to take photographs,

00:06:03.838 --> 00:06:07.974
and a spectator in the crowd
filmed the event,

00:06:07.998 --> 00:06:10.974
unbeknownst to the authorities.

00:06:10.998 --> 00:06:15.294
Several still photographs
were taken as well,

00:06:15.318 --> 00:06:19.454
and you can still watch
the film online today

00:06:19.478 --> 00:06:21.598
and look at the photographs.

00:06:22.918 --> 00:06:26.334
The crowd on the day
of Weidmann's execution

00:06:26.358 --> 00:06:30.334
was called "unruly"
and "disgusting" by the press,

00:06:30.358 --> 00:06:34.534
but that was nothing compared
to the untold thousands of people

00:06:34.558 --> 00:06:37.174
who could now study the action

00:06:37.198 --> 00:06:38.414
over and over again,

00:06:38.438 --> 00:06:40.718
freeze-framed in every detail.

00:06:43.078 --> 00:06:47.934
The camera may have made these scenes
more accessible than ever before,

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.614
but it's not just about the camera.

00:06:50.638 --> 00:06:53.054

00:06:53.078 --> 00:06:55.254

as there have been

00:06:55.278 --> 00:06:58.374

00:06:58.398 --> 00:07:00.478

00:07:01.878 --> 00:07:05.014
In London, as late as
the early 19th century,

00:07:05.038 --> 00:07:09.694

people to see a standard hanging.

00:07:09.718 --> 00:07:14.038

to see a famous criminal killed.

00:07:15.038 --> 00:07:19.454
And a beheading, which was
a rare event in England at the time,

00:07:19.478 --> 00:07:20.798
attracted even more.

00:07:21.798 --> 00:07:24.158
In May 1820,

00:07:24.878 --> 00:07:28.894
five men known as
the Cato Street Conspirators

00:07:28.918 --> 00:07:31.054
were executed in London for plotting

00:07:31.078 --> 00:07:33.678
to assassinate members
of the British government.

00:07:34.398 --> 00:07:38.054
They were hung and then decapitated.

00:07:38.078 --> 00:07:40.054
It was a gruesome scene.

00:07:40.078 --> 00:07:44.454
Each man's head was hacked off in turn
and held up to the crowd.

00:07:44.478 --> 00:07:46.654
And 100,000 people,

00:07:46.678 --> 00:07:50.294

00:07:50.318 --> 00:07:52.254

00:08:16.878 --> 00:08:20.214

00:08:20.238 --> 00:08:24.438

00:08:29.118 --> 00:08:33.334

are disgusted and are horrified,

00:08:33.358 --> 00:08:37.398
it doesn't always stop them
from coming out all the same to watch.

00:08:38.558 --> 00:08:41.774
Perhaps the most striking example

00:08:41.798 --> 00:08:47.093

a beheading and remain unmoved

00:08:47.117 --> 00:08:49.454
and even be disappointed

00:08:49.478 --> 00:08:54.934

in 1792 of the guillotine,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:58.174

00:08:58.198 --> 00:09:00.814
To us in the 21st century,

00:09:00.838 --> 00:09:04.334
the guillotine may seem
like a monstrous contraption,

00:09:04.358 --> 00:09:09.518
but to the first crowds who saw it,
it was actually a disappointment.

00:09:10.838 --> 00:09:17.374

torturous executions on the scaffold,

00:09:17.398 --> 00:09:22.854
where people were mutilated
and burned and pulled apart slowly.

00:09:22.878 --> 00:09:25.854
To them, watching
the guillotine in action,

00:09:25.878 --> 00:09:29.054
it was so quick, there was nothing to see.

00:09:29.078 --> 00:09:34.294
The blade fell, the head fell
into a basket, out of sight immediately,

00:09:34.318 --> 00:09:36.014
and they called out,

00:09:36.038 --> 00:09:39.878

give me back my wooden gallows."

00:09:41.318 --> 00:09:46.494
The end of torturous public
judicial executions in Europe and America

00:09:46.518 --> 00:09:50.454

more humane towards the criminal,

00:09:50.478 --> 00:09:55.214

obstinately refused to behave

00:09:55.238 --> 00:09:57.494

00:09:57.518 --> 00:09:59.854

00:09:59.878 --> 00:10:03.038

00:10:12.078 --> 00:10:14.134

00:10:14.158 --> 00:10:16.478

00:10:24.358 --> 00:10:27.974

00:10:27.998 --> 00:10:30.414

00:10:30.438 --> 00:10:33.414

00:11:02.638 --> 00:11:04.254

00:12:17.238 --> 00:12:20.574

00:12:24.718 --> 00:12:27.358
