title: Don't ask where I'm from, ask where I'm a local
transcript: Last year, I went on my first book tour. In 13 months, I flew to 14 countries and gave some hundred talks. Every talk in every country began with an introduction, and every introduction began, alas, with a lie: "Taiye Selasi comes from Ghana and Nigeria," or "Taiye Selasi comes from England and the States." Whenever I heard this opening sentence, no matter the country that concluded it — England, America, Ghana, Nigeria — I thought, "But that's not true." Yes, I was born in England and grew up in the United States. My mum, born in England, and raised in Nigeria, currently lives in Ghana. My father was born in Gold Coast, a British colony, raised in Ghana, and has lived for over 30 years in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. For this reason, my introducers also called me "multinational." "But Nike is multinational," I thought, "I'm a human being."Then, one fine day, mid-tour, I went to Louisiana, a museum in Denmark where I shared the stage with the writer Colum McCann. We were discussing the role of locality in writing, when suddenly it hit me. I'm not multinational. I'm not a national at all. How could I come from a nation? How can a human being come from a concept? It's a question that had been bothering me for going on two decades. From newspapers, textbooks, conversations, I had learned to speak of countries as if they were eternal, singular, naturally occurring things, but I wondered: to say that I came from a country suggested that the country was an absolute, some fixed point in place in time, a constant thing, but was it? In my lifetime, countries had disappeared — Czechoslovakia; appeared — Timor-Leste; failed — Somalia. My parents came from countries that didn't exist when they were born. To me, a country — this thing that could be born, die, expand, contract — hardly seemed the basis for understanding a human being.And so it came as a huge relief to discover the sovereign state. What we call countries are actually various expressions of sovereign statehood, an idea that came into fashion only 400 years ago. When I learned this, beginning my masters degree in international relations, I felt a sort of surge of relief. It was as I had suspected. History was real, cultures were real, but countries were invented. For the next 10 years, I sought to re- or un-define myself, my world, my work, my experience, beyond the logic of the state.In 2005, I wrote an essay, "What is an Afropolitan," sketching out an identity that privileged culture over country. It was thrilling how many people could relate to my experience, and instructional how many others didn't buy my sense of self. "How can Selasi claim to come from Ghana," one such critic asked, "when she's never known the indignities of traveling abroad on a Ghanian passport?"Now, if I'm honest, I knew just what she meant. I've got a friend named Layla who was born and raised in Ghana. Her parents are third-generation Ghanians of Lebanese descent. Layla, who speaks fluent Twi, knows Accra like the back of her hand, but when we first met years ago, I thought, "She's not from Ghana." In my mind, she came from Lebanon, despite the patent fact that all her formative experience took place in suburban Accra. I, like my critics, was imagining some Ghana where all Ghanaians had brown skin or none held U.K. passports. I'd fallen into the limiting trap that the language of coming from countries sets — the privileging of a fiction, the singular country, over reality: human experience. Speaking with Colum McCann that day, the penny finally dropped. "All experience is local," he said. "All identity is experience," I thought. "I'm not a national," I proclaimed onstage. "I'm a local. I'm multi-local."See, "Taiye Selasi comes from the United States," isn't the truth. I have no relationship with the United States, all 50 of them, not really. My relationship is with Brookline, the town where I grew up; with New York City, where I started work; with Lawrenceville, where I spend Thanksgiving. What makes America home for me is not my passport or accent, but these very particular experiences and the places they occur. Despite my pride in Ewe culture, the Black Stars, and my love of Ghanaian food, I've never had a relationship with the Republic of Ghana, writ large. My relationship is with Accra, where my mother lives, where I go each year, with the little garden in Dzorwulu where my father and I talk for hours. These are the places that shape my experience. My experience is where I'm from.What if we asked, instead of "Where are you from?" — "Where are you a local?" This would tell us so much more about who and how similar we are. Tell me you're from France, and I see what, a set of clichés? Adichie's dangerous single story, the myth of the nation of France? Tell me you're a local of Fez and Paris, better yet, Goutte d'Or, and I see a set of experiences. Our experience is where we're from.So, where are you a local? I propose a three-step test. I call these the three "R’s": rituals, relationships, restrictions.First, think of your daily rituals, whatever they may be: making your coffee, driving to work, harvesting your crops, saying your prayers. What kind of rituals are these? Where do they occur? In what city or cities in the world do shopkeepers know your face? As a child, I carried out fairly standard suburban rituals in Boston, with adjustments made for the rituals my mother brought from London and Lagos. We took off our shoes in the house, we were unfailingly polite with our elders, we ate slow-cooked, spicy food. In snowy North America, ours were rituals of the global South. The first time I went to Delhi or to southern parts of Italy, I was shocked by how at home I felt. The rituals were familiar. "R" number one, rituals.Now, think of your relationships, of the people who shape your days. To whom do you speak at least once a week, be it face to face or on FaceTime? Be reasonable in your assessment; I'm not talking about your Facebook friends. I'm speaking of the people who shape your weekly emotional experience. My mother in Accra, my twin sister in Boston, my best friends in New York: these relationships are home for me. "R" number two, relationships.We're local where we carry out our rituals and relationships, but how we experience our locality depends in part on our restrictions. By restrictions, I mean, where are you able to live? What passport do you hold? Are you restricted by, say, racism, from feeling fully at home where you live? By civil war, dysfunctional governance, economic inflation, from living in the locality where you had your rituals as a child? This is the least sexy of the R’s, less lyric than rituals and relationships, but the question takes us past "Where are you now?" to "Why aren't you there, and why?" Rituals, relationships, restrictions.Take a piece of paper and put those three words on top of three columns, then try to fill those columns as honestly as you can. A very different picture of your life in local context, of your identity as a set of experiences, may emerge.So let's try it. I have a friend named Olu. He's 35 years old. His parents, born in Nigeria, came to Germany on scholarships. Olu was born in Nuremberg and lived there until age 10. When his family moved to Lagos, he studied in London, then came to Berlin. He loves going to Nigeria — the weather, the food, the friends — but hates the political corruption there. Where is Olu from?I have another friend named Udo. He's also 35 years old. Udo was born in Córdoba, in northwest Argentina, where his grandparents migrated from Germany, what is now Poland, after the war. Udo studied in Buenos Aires, and nine years ago came to Berlin. He loves going to Argentina —  the weather, the food, the friends — but hates the economic corruption there. Where is Udo from? With his blonde hair and blue eyes, Udo could pass for German, but holds an Argentinian passport, so needs a visa to live in Berlin. That Udo is from Argentina has largely to do with history. That he's a local of Buenos Aires and Berlin, that has to do with life.Olu, who looks Nigerian, needs a visa to visit Nigeria. He speaks Yoruba with an English accent, and English with a German one. To claim that he's "not really Nigerian," though, denies his experience in Lagos, the rituals he practiced growing up, his relationship with family and friends.Meanwhile, though Lagos is undoubtedly one of his homes, Olu always feels restricted there, not least by the fact that he's gay.Both he and Udo are restricted by the political conditions of their parents' countries, from living where some of their most meaningful rituals and relationships occur. To say Olu is from Nigeria and Udo is from Argentina distracts from their common experience. Their rituals, their relationships, and their restrictions are the same.Of course, when we ask, "Where are you from?" we're using a kind of shorthand. It's quicker to say "Nigeria" than "Lagos and Berlin," and as with Google Maps, we can always zoom in closer, from country to city to neighborhood. But that's not quite the point. The difference between "Where are you from?" and "Where are you a local?" isn't the specificity of the answer; it's the intention of the question. Replacing the language of nationality with the language of locality asks us to shift our focus to where real life occurs. Even that most glorious expression of countryhood, the World Cup, gives us national teams comprised mostly of multilocal players. As a unit of measurement for human experience, the country doesn't quite work. That's why Olu says, "I'm German, but my parents come from Nigeria." The "but" in that sentence belies the inflexibility of the units, one fixed and fictional entity bumping up against another. "I'm a local of Lagos and Berlin," suggests overlapping experiences, layers that merge together, that can't be denied or removed. You can take away my passport, but you can't take away my experience. That I carry within me. Where I'm from comes wherever I go.To be clear, I'm not suggesting that we do away with countries. There's much to be said for national history, more for the sovereign state. Culture exists in community, and community exists in context. Geography, tradition, collective memory: these things are important. What I'm questioning is primacy. All of those introductions on tour began with reference to nation, as if knowing what country I came from would tell my audience who I was. What are we really seeking, though, when we ask where someone comes from? And what are we really seeing when we hear an answer?Here's one possibility: basically, countries represent power. "Where are you from?" Mexico. Poland. Bangladesh. Less power. America. Germany. Japan. More power. China. Russia. Ambiguous.(Laughter)It's possible that without realizing it, we're playing a power game, especially in the context of multi-ethnic countries. As any recent immigrant knows, the question "Where are you from?" or "Where are you really from?" is often code for "Why are you here?"Then we have the scholar William Deresiewicz's writing of elite American colleges. "Students think that their environment is diverse if one comes from Missouri and another from Pakistan — never mind that all of their parents are doctors or bankers."I'm with him. To call one student American, another Pakistani, then triumphantly claim student body diversity ignores the fact that these students are locals of the same milieu. The same holds true on the other end of the economic spectrum. A Mexican gardener in Los Angeles and a Nepali housekeeper in Delhi have more in common in terms of rituals and restrictions than nationality implies.Perhaps my biggest problem with coming from countries is the myth of going back to them. I'm often asked if I plan to "go back" to Ghana. I go to Accra every year, but I can't "go back" to Ghana. It's not because I wasn't born there. My father can't go back, either. The country in which he was born, that country no longer exists. We can never go back to a place and find it exactly where we left it. Something, somewhere will always have changed, most of all, ourselves. People.Finally, what we're talking about is human experience, this notoriously and gloriously disorderly affair. In creative writing, locality bespeaks humanity. The more we know about where a story is set, the more local color and texture, the more human the characters start to feel, the more relatable, not less. The myth of national identity and the vocabulary of coming from confuses us into placing ourselves into mutually exclusive categories. In fact, all of us are multi — multi-local, multi-layered. To begin our conversations with an acknowledgement of this complexity brings us closer together, I think, not further apart. So the next time that I'm introduced, I'd love to hear the truth: "Taiye Selasi is a human being, like everybody here. She isn't a citizen of the world, but a citizen of worlds. She is a local of New York, Rome and Accra."Thank you.(Applause)

or "Taiye Selasi comes
from England and the States."

00:00:40.386 --> 00:00:42.933
Whenever I heard this opening sentence,

00:00:42.957 --> 00:00:45.522
no matter the country that concluded it --

00:00:45.546 --> 00:00:47.933
England, America, Ghana, Nigeria --

00:00:47.957 --> 00:00:50.529
I thought, "But that's not true."

00:00:51.085 --> 00:00:55.084
Yes, I was born in England
and grew up in the United States.

00:00:55.394 --> 00:00:58.741
My mum, born in England,
and raised in Nigeria,

00:00:58.765 --> 00:01:00.749
currently lives in Ghana.

00:01:00.773 --> 00:01:04.998
My father was born in Gold Coast,
a British colony,

00:01:05.022 --> 00:01:06.607
raised in Ghana,

00:01:06.631 --> 00:01:10.738
and has lived for over 30 years
in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

00:01:10.762 --> 00:01:15.925
For this reason, my introducers
also called me "multinational."

00:01:16.456 --> 00:01:20.424
"But Nike is multinational," I thought,

00:01:20.448 --> 00:01:22.439
"I'm a human being."

00:01:23.082 --> 00:01:26.242
Then, one fine day, mid-tour,

00:01:26.266 --> 00:01:29.742
I went to Louisiana, a museum in Denmark

00:01:29.766 --> 00:01:33.094
where I shared the stage
with the writer Colum McCann.

00:01:33.538 --> 00:01:36.428
We were discussing the role
of locality in writing,

00:01:36.452 --> 00:01:38.631
when suddenly it hit me.

00:01:39.115 --> 00:01:41.100
I'm not multinational.

00:01:41.124 --> 00:01:44.120
I'm not a national at all.

00:01:44.144 --> 00:01:46.516
How could I come from a nation?

00:01:46.957 --> 00:01:50.298
How can a human being come from a concept?

00:01:50.703 --> 00:01:54.996
It's a question that had been bothering me
for going on two decades.

00:01:55.361 --> 00:01:58.534
From newspapers, textbooks, conversations,

00:01:58.558 --> 00:02:00.820
I had learned to speak of countries

00:02:00.844 --> 00:02:05.607
as if they were eternal, singular,
naturally occurring things,

00:02:05.631 --> 00:02:07.488
but I wondered:

00:02:07.512 --> 00:02:09.284
to say that I came from a country

00:02:09.308 --> 00:02:12.323
suggested that the country
was an absolute,

00:02:12.347 --> 00:02:15.029
some fixed point in place in time,

00:02:15.053 --> 00:02:17.401
a constant thing, but was it?

00:02:18.149 --> 00:02:22.775
In my lifetime, countries
had disappeared -- Czechoslovakia;

00:02:22.799 --> 00:02:27.158
appeared -- Timor-Leste;
failed -- Somalia.

00:02:27.182 --> 00:02:31.456
My parents came from countries
that didn't exist when they were born.

00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:37.790
To me, a country -- this thing that could
be born, die, expand, contract --

00:02:37.814 --> 00:02:41.235
hardly seemed the basis
for understanding a human being.

00:02:41.560 --> 00:02:46.714
And so it came as a huge relief
to discover the sovereign state.

00:02:47.190 --> 00:02:49.128
What we call countries are actually

00:02:49.152 --> 00:02:51.801
various expressions
of sovereign statehood,

00:02:51.825 --> 00:02:55.689
an idea that came into fashion
only 400 years ago.

00:02:56.253 --> 00:03:01.139
When I learned this, beginning my
masters degree in international relations,

00:03:01.163 --> 00:03:03.532
I felt a sort of surge of relief.

00:03:03.556 --> 00:03:05.802
It was as I had suspected.

00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:09.981
History was real, cultures were real,

00:03:10.005 --> 00:03:12.519
but countries were invented.

00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:17.441
For the next 10 years, I sought
to re- or un-define myself,

00:03:17.465 --> 00:03:19.933
my world, my work, my experience,

00:03:19.957 --> 00:03:22.132
beyond the logic of the state.

00:03:22.156 --> 00:03:26.695
In 2005, I wrote an essay,
"What is an Afropolitan,"

00:03:26.719 --> 00:03:31.987
sketching out an identity
that privileged culture over country.

00:03:32.011 --> 00:03:36.530
It was thrilling how many people
could relate to my experience,

00:03:36.554 --> 00:03:41.531
and instructional how many others
didn't buy my sense of self.

00:03:42.182 --> 00:03:47.182
"How can Selasi claim to come from Ghana,"
one such critic asked,

00:03:47.206 --> 00:03:49.474
"when she's never known the indignities

00:03:49.498 --> 00:03:52.211
of traveling abroad
on a Ghanian passport?"

00:03:52.735 --> 00:03:54.933
Now, if I'm honest,

00:03:54.957 --> 00:03:56.389
I knew just what she meant.

00:03:56.957 --> 00:04:00.406
I've got a friend named Layla
who was born and raised in Ghana.

00:04:00.430 --> 00:04:04.972
Her parents are third-generation
Ghanians of Lebanese descent.

00:04:05.464 --> 00:04:10.464
Layla, who speaks fluent Twi,
knows Accra like the back of her hand,

00:04:10.488 --> 00:04:15.223
but when we first met years ago,
I thought, "She's not from Ghana."

00:04:15.606 --> 00:04:18.193
In my mind, she came from Lebanon,

00:04:18.217 --> 00:04:21.933
despite the patent fact
that all her formative experience

00:04:21.957 --> 00:04:23.802
took place in suburban Accra.

00:04:24.334 --> 00:04:26.676
I, like my critics,

00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:32.230
was imagining some Ghana
where all Ghanaians had brown skin

00:04:32.254 --> 00:04:34.765
or none held U.K. passports.

00:04:35.177 --> 00:04:37.384
I'd fallen into the limiting trap

00:04:37.408 --> 00:04:40.579
that the language of coming
from countries sets --

00:04:40.603 --> 00:04:44.334
the privileging of a fiction,
the singular country,

00:04:44.358 --> 00:04:47.567
over reality: human experience.

00:04:48.321 --> 00:04:52.987
Speaking with Colum McCann that day,
the penny finally dropped.

00:04:53.391 --> 00:04:56.135
"All experience is local," he said.

00:04:56.746 --> 00:05:00.349
"All identity is experience," I thought.

00:05:00.794 --> 00:05:04.255
"I'm not a national,"
I proclaimed onstage.

00:05:04.668 --> 00:05:07.468
"I'm a local. I'm multi-local."

00:05:07.834 --> 00:05:11.981
See, "Taiye Selasi comes
from the United States," isn't the truth.

00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:15.187
I have no relationship
with the United States,

00:05:15.211 --> 00:05:17.376
all 50 of them, not really.

00:05:17.789 --> 00:05:21.572
My relationship is with Brookline,
the town where I grew up;

00:05:21.596 --> 00:05:24.137
with New York City, where I started work;

00:05:24.161 --> 00:05:26.945
with Lawrenceville,
where I spend Thanksgiving.

00:05:27.755 --> 00:05:32.995
What makes America home for me
is not my passport or accent,

00:05:33.019 --> 00:05:35.655
but these very particular experiences

00:05:35.679 --> 00:05:37.637
and the places they occur.

00:05:38.034 --> 00:05:40.765
Despite my pride in Ewe culture,

00:05:40.789 --> 00:05:43.933
the Black Stars,
and my love of Ghanaian food,

00:05:43.957 --> 00:05:48.315
I've never had a relationship
with the Republic of Ghana, writ large.

00:05:48.696 --> 00:05:52.351
My relationship is with Accra,
where my mother lives,

00:05:52.375 --> 00:05:53.986
where I go each year,

00:05:54.010 --> 00:05:58.406
with the little garden in Dzorwulu
where my father and I talk for hours.

00:05:59.167 --> 00:06:02.129
These are the places
that shape my experience.

00:06:02.565 --> 00:06:04.914
My experience is where I'm from.

00:06:05.957 --> 00:06:09.336
What if we asked, instead
of "Where are you from?" --

00:06:09.740 --> 00:06:11.544
"Where are you a local?"

00:06:11.568 --> 00:06:15.981
This would tell us so much more
about who and how similar we are.

00:06:16.005 --> 00:06:20.589
Tell me you're from France,
and I see what, a set of clichés?

00:06:20.613 --> 00:06:24.853
Adichie's dangerous single story,
the myth of the nation of France?

00:06:25.313 --> 00:06:28.547
Tell me you're a local of Fez and Paris,

00:06:28.571 --> 00:06:32.936
better yet, Goutte d'Or, and I see
a set of experiences.

00:06:32.960 --> 00:06:35.933
Our experience is where we're from.

00:06:35.957 --> 00:06:38.004
So, where are you a local?

00:06:38.028 --> 00:06:40.099
I propose a three-step test.

00:06:40.559 --> 00:06:46.220
I call these the three "R’s":
rituals, relationships, restrictions.

00:06:46.577 --> 00:06:50.491
First, think of your daily rituals,
whatever they may be:

00:06:50.515 --> 00:06:52.548
making your coffee, driving to work,

00:06:52.572 --> 00:06:55.448
harvesting your crops,
saying your prayers.

00:06:55.472 --> 00:06:57.694
What kind of rituals are these?

00:06:57.718 --> 00:06:59.171
Where do they occur?

00:06:59.195 --> 00:07:03.834
In what city or cities in the world
do shopkeepers know your face?

00:07:04.540 --> 00:07:08.933
As a child, I carried out fairly standard
suburban rituals in Boston,

00:07:08.957 --> 00:07:13.588
with adjustments made for the rituals
my mother brought from London and Lagos.

00:07:13.612 --> 00:07:15.459
We took off our shoes in the house,

00:07:15.483 --> 00:07:18.173
we were unfailingly
polite with our elders,

00:07:18.197 --> 00:07:20.434
we ate slow-cooked, spicy food.

00:07:20.823 --> 00:07:25.519
In snowy North America,
ours were rituals of the global South.

00:07:26.090 --> 00:07:29.933
The first time I went to Delhi
or to southern parts of Italy,

00:07:29.957 --> 00:07:32.293
I was shocked by how at home I felt.

00:07:32.317 --> 00:07:34.448
The rituals were familiar.

00:07:34.933 --> 00:07:37.036
"R" number one, rituals.

00:07:37.536 --> 00:07:41.650
Now, think of your relationships,
of the people who shape your days.

00:07:42.023 --> 00:07:44.563
To whom do you speak at least once a week,

00:07:44.587 --> 00:07:47.387
be it face to face or on FaceTime?

00:07:47.411 --> 00:07:49.117
Be reasonable in your assessment;

00:07:49.141 --> 00:07:51.998
I'm not talking about
your Facebook friends.

00:07:52.022 --> 00:07:56.305
I'm speaking of the people who shape
your weekly emotional experience.

00:07:56.329 --> 00:07:58.933
My mother in Accra,
my twin sister in Boston,

00:07:58.957 --> 00:08:00.999
my best friends in New York:

00:08:01.023 --> 00:08:03.368
these relationships are home for me.

00:08:03.780 --> 00:08:06.067
"R" number two, relationships.

00:08:06.623 --> 00:08:10.933
We're local where we carry out
our rituals and relationships,

00:08:10.957 --> 00:08:13.699
but how we experience our locality

00:08:13.723 --> 00:08:17.009
depends in part on our restrictions.

00:08:17.033 --> 00:08:19.876
By restrictions, I mean,
where are you able to live?

00:08:19.900 --> 00:08:21.933
What passport do you hold?

00:08:21.957 --> 00:08:27.224
Are you restricted by, say, racism,
from feeling fully at home where you live?

00:08:27.248 --> 00:08:31.511
By civil war, dysfunctional governance,
economic inflation,

00:08:31.535 --> 00:08:35.933
from living in the locality
where you had your rituals as a child?

00:08:36.354 --> 00:08:38.951
This is the least sexy of the R’s,

00:08:38.975 --> 00:08:41.933
less lyric than rituals and relationships,

00:08:41.957 --> 00:08:45.267
but the question takes us past
"Where are you now?"

00:08:45.291 --> 00:08:48.315
to "Why aren't you there, and why?"

00:08:49.132 --> 00:08:51.969
Rituals, relationships, restrictions.

00:08:52.461 --> 00:08:53.986
Take a piece of paper

00:08:54.010 --> 00:08:57.302
and put those three words
on top of three columns,

00:08:57.326 --> 00:09:00.642
then try to fill those columns
as honestly as you can.

00:09:00.999 --> 00:09:05.160
A very different picture
of your life in local context,

00:09:05.184 --> 00:09:08.598
of your identity as a set of experiences,

00:09:08.622 --> 00:09:09.782
may emerge.

00:09:09.806 --> 00:09:11.022
So let's try it.

00:09:11.046 --> 00:09:12.811
I have a friend named Olu.

00:09:12.835 --> 00:09:14.430
He's 35 years old.

00:09:14.454 --> 00:09:18.399
His parents, born in Nigeria,
came to Germany on scholarships.

00:09:18.423 --> 00:09:21.984
Olu was born in Nuremberg
and lived there until age 10.

00:09:22.008 --> 00:09:24.801
When his family moved to Lagos,
he studied in London,

00:09:24.825 --> 00:09:26.250
then came to Berlin.

00:09:26.274 --> 00:09:28.933
He loves going to Nigeria --

00:09:28.957 --> 00:09:31.591
the weather, the food, the friends --

00:09:31.615 --> 00:09:34.129
but hates the political corruption there.

00:09:34.613 --> 00:09:35.813
Where is Olu from?

00:09:36.384 --> 00:09:38.575
I have another friend named Udo.

00:09:38.599 --> 00:09:40.106
He's also 35 years old.

00:09:40.582 --> 00:09:43.781
Udo was born in Córdoba,
in northwest Argentina,

00:09:43.805 --> 00:09:46.993
where his grandparents migrated
from Germany, what is now Poland,

00:09:47.017 --> 00:09:48.445
after the war.

00:09:48.469 --> 00:09:52.351
Udo studied in Buenos Aires,
and nine years ago came to Berlin.

00:09:52.375 --> 00:09:56.576
He loves going to Argentina -- 
the weather, the food, the friends --

00:09:56.600 --> 00:09:59.060
but hates the economic corruption there.

00:09:59.425 --> 00:10:01.363
Where is Udo from?

00:10:01.387 --> 00:10:05.020
With his blonde hair and blue eyes,
Udo could pass for German,

00:10:05.044 --> 00:10:09.100
but holds an Argentinian passport,
so needs a visa to live in Berlin.

00:10:09.124 --> 00:10:13.433
That Udo is from Argentina
has largely to do with history.

00:10:13.457 --> 00:10:16.614
That he's a local
of Buenos Aires and Berlin,

00:10:16.638 --> 00:10:18.423
that has to do with life.

00:10:18.732 --> 00:10:22.933
Olu, who looks Nigerian,
needs a visa to visit Nigeria.

00:10:22.957 --> 00:10:25.348
He speaks Yoruba with an English accent,

00:10:25.372 --> 00:10:27.451
and English with a German one.

00:10:27.475 --> 00:10:30.016
To claim that he's
"not really Nigerian," though,

00:10:30.040 --> 00:10:32.368
denies his experience in Lagos,

00:10:32.392 --> 00:10:34.575
the rituals he practiced growing up,

00:10:34.599 --> 00:10:37.028
his relationship with family and friends.

00:10:37.489 --> 00:10:41.410
Meanwhile, though Lagos
is undoubtedly one of his homes,

00:10:41.434 --> 00:10:43.933
Olu always feels restricted there,

00:10:43.957 --> 00:10:46.226
not least by the fact that he's gay.

00:10:47.186 --> 00:10:50.908
Both he and Udo are restricted
by the political conditions

00:10:50.933 --> 00:10:52.586
of their parents' countries,

00:10:52.610 --> 00:10:55.594
from living where some of their
most meaningful rituals

00:10:55.618 --> 00:10:57.568
and relationships occur.

00:10:57.592 --> 00:11:01.693
To say Olu is from Nigeria
and Udo is from Argentina

00:11:01.717 --> 00:11:03.830
distracts from their common experience.

00:11:03.854 --> 00:11:07.469
Their rituals, their relationships,
and their restrictions are the same.

00:11:08.104 --> 00:11:10.518
Of course, when we ask,
"Where are you from?"

00:11:10.542 --> 00:11:12.463
we're using a kind of shorthand.

00:11:12.487 --> 00:11:16.414
It's quicker to say "Nigeria"
than "Lagos and Berlin,"

00:11:16.874 --> 00:11:20.705
and as with Google Maps,
we can always zoom in closer,

00:11:20.729 --> 00:11:23.189
from country to city to neighborhood.

00:11:23.213 --> 00:11:25.506
But that's not quite the point.

00:11:26.268 --> 00:11:28.857
The difference between
"Where are you from?"

00:11:28.881 --> 00:11:30.397
and "Where are you a local?"

00:11:30.421 --> 00:11:33.383
isn't the specificity of the answer;

00:11:33.407 --> 00:11:35.522
it's the intention of the question.

00:11:35.998 --> 00:11:41.139
Replacing the language of nationality
with the language of locality asks us

00:11:41.164 --> 00:11:44.855
to shift our focus
to where real life occurs.

00:11:45.307 --> 00:11:49.524
Even that most glorious expression
of countryhood, the World Cup,

00:11:49.548 --> 00:11:55.244
gives us national teams comprised
mostly of multilocal players.

00:11:55.617 --> 00:11:58.134
As a unit of measurement
for human experience,

00:11:58.158 --> 00:12:00.933
the country doesn't quite work.

00:12:00.957 --> 00:12:04.810
That's why Olu says, "I'm German,
but my parents come from Nigeria."

00:12:05.207 --> 00:12:10.563
The "but" in that sentence
belies the inflexibility of the units,

00:12:10.587 --> 00:12:14.725
one fixed and fictional entity
bumping up against another.

00:12:15.122 --> 00:12:19.544
"I'm a local of Lagos and Berlin,"
suggests overlapping experiences,

00:12:19.568 --> 00:12:23.793
layers that merge together,
that can't be denied or removed.

00:12:24.134 --> 00:12:26.366
You can take away my passport,

00:12:26.390 --> 00:12:28.497
but you can't take away my experience.

00:12:28.521 --> 00:12:30.632
That I carry within me.

00:12:30.656 --> 00:12:33.298
Where I'm from comes wherever I go.

00:12:34.211 --> 00:12:37.578
To be clear, I'm not suggesting
that we do away with countries.

00:12:37.603 --> 00:12:39.736
There's much to be said
for national history,

00:12:39.761 --> 00:12:41.722
more for the sovereign state.

00:12:41.746 --> 00:12:46.443
Culture exists in community,
and community exists in context.

00:12:46.467 --> 00:12:50.433
Geography, tradition, collective memory:
these things are important.

00:12:50.964 --> 00:12:53.472
What I'm questioning is primacy.

00:12:53.957 --> 00:12:58.621
All of those introductions on tour
began with reference to nation,

00:12:58.645 --> 00:13:02.968
as if knowing what country I came
from would tell my audience who I was.

00:13:03.468 --> 00:13:07.373
What are we really seeking, though,
when we ask where someone comes from?

00:13:07.397 --> 00:13:10.338
And what are we really seeing
when we hear an answer?

00:13:10.957 --> 00:13:12.228
Here's one possibility:

00:13:12.252 --> 00:13:15.022
basically, countries represent power.

00:13:15.546 --> 00:13:20.121
"Where are you from?"
Mexico. Poland. Bangladesh. Less power.

00:13:20.629 --> 00:13:24.123
America. Germany. Japan. More power.

00:13:24.147 --> 00:13:27.034
China. Russia. Ambiguous.

00:13:27.661 --> 00:13:29.321
(Laughter)

00:13:29.345 --> 00:13:33.006
It's possible that without realizing it,
we're playing a power game,

00:13:33.030 --> 00:13:36.371
especially in the context
of multi-ethnic countries.

00:13:36.395 --> 00:13:38.664
As any recent immigrant knows,

00:13:38.689 --> 00:13:42.933
the question "Where are you from?"
or "Where are you really from?"

00:13:42.957 --> 00:13:45.426
is often code for "Why are you here?"

00:13:46.282 --> 00:13:49.394
Then we have the scholar
William Deresiewicz's writing

00:13:49.418 --> 00:13:51.191
of elite American colleges.

00:13:51.215 --> 00:13:54.366
"Students think that
their environment is diverse

00:13:54.390 --> 00:13:57.645
if one comes from Missouri
and another from Pakistan --

00:13:57.669 --> 00:14:01.707
never mind that all of their parents
are doctors or bankers."

00:14:02.072 --> 00:14:03.231
I'm with him.

00:14:03.255 --> 00:14:06.726
To call one student American,
another Pakistani,

00:14:06.750 --> 00:14:10.011
then triumphantly claim
student body diversity

00:14:10.035 --> 00:14:13.678
ignores the fact that these students
are locals of the same milieu.

00:14:13.702 --> 00:14:17.051
The same holds true on the other end
of the economic spectrum.

00:14:17.551 --> 00:14:22.223
A Mexican gardener in Los Angeles
and a Nepali housekeeper in Delhi

00:14:22.247 --> 00:14:26.070
have more in common
in terms of rituals and restrictions

00:14:26.094 --> 00:14:27.880
than nationality implies.

00:14:27.904 --> 00:14:31.499
Perhaps my biggest problem
with coming from countries

00:14:31.523 --> 00:14:33.237
is the myth of going back to them.

00:14:33.261 --> 00:14:36.356
I'm often asked if I plan
to "go back" to Ghana.

00:14:36.380 --> 00:14:40.700
I go to Accra every year,
but I can't "go back" to Ghana.

00:14:40.724 --> 00:14:42.525
It's not because I wasn't born there.

00:14:42.549 --> 00:14:44.882
My father can't go back, either.

00:14:44.906 --> 00:14:46.933
The country in which he was born,

00:14:46.957 --> 00:14:49.291
that country no longer exists.

00:14:49.315 --> 00:14:53.150
We can never go back to a place
and find it exactly where we left it.

00:14:53.174 --> 00:14:56.022
Something, somewhere
will always have changed,

00:14:56.046 --> 00:14:57.942
most of all, ourselves.

00:14:58.696 --> 00:14:59.918
People.

00:14:59.943 --> 00:15:02.490
Finally, what we're talking
about is human experience,

00:15:02.514 --> 00:15:06.377
this notoriously and gloriously
disorderly affair.

00:15:06.846 --> 00:15:10.244
In creative writing,
locality bespeaks humanity.

00:15:10.268 --> 00:15:12.545
The more we know
about where a story is set,

00:15:12.569 --> 00:15:14.933
the more local color and texture,

00:15:14.957 --> 00:15:17.434
the more human
the characters start to feel,

00:15:17.458 --> 00:15:19.734
the more relatable, not less.

00:15:19.758 --> 00:15:24.202
The myth of national identity
and the vocabulary of coming from

00:15:24.226 --> 00:15:29.188
confuses us into placing ourselves
into mutually exclusive categories.

00:15:29.212 --> 00:15:33.517
In fact, all of us are multi --
multi-local, multi-layered.

00:15:33.541 --> 00:15:37.325
To begin our conversations
with an acknowledgement of this complexity

00:15:37.349 --> 00:15:40.930
brings us closer together, I think,
not further apart.

00:15:40.954 --> 00:15:44.256
So the next time that I'm introduced,

00:15:44.280 --> 00:15:46.129
I'd love to hear the truth:

00:15:46.153 --> 00:15:50.160
"Taiye Selasi is a human being,
like everybody here.

00:15:50.184 --> 00:15:54.242
She isn't a citizen of the world,
but a citizen of worlds.

00:15:54.266 --> 00:15:57.027
She is a local of New York,
Rome and Accra."

00:15:57.369 --> 00:15:58.530
Thank you.

00:15:58.554 --> 00:16:02.957
(Applause)

transcript: So I've had the great privilege of traveling to some incredible places, photographing these distant landscapes and remote cultures all over the world. I love my job.But people think it's this string of epiphanies and sunrises and rainbows, when in reality, it looks more something like this.(Laughter)This is my office.We can't afford the fanciest places to stay at night, so we tend to sleep a lot outdoors. As long as we can stay dry, that's a bonus. We also can't afford the fanciest restaurants. So we tend to eat whatever's on the local menu. And if you're in the Ecuadorian Páramo, you're going to eat a large rodent called a cuy.(Laughter)But what makes our experiences perhaps a little bit different and a little more unique than that of the average person is that we have this gnawing thing in the back of our mind that even in our darkest moments, and those times of despair, we think, "Hey, there might be an image to be made here, there might be a story to be told."And why is storytelling important? Well, it helps us to connect with our cultural and our natural heritage. And in the Southeast, there's an alarming disconnect between the public and the natural areas that allow us to be here in the first place. We're visual creatures, so we use what we see to teach us what we know.Now the majority of us aren't going to willingly go way down to a swamp. So how can we still expect those same people to then advocate on behalf of their protection? We can't.So my job, then, is to use photography as a communication tool, to help bridge the gap between the science and the aesthetics, to get people talking, to get them thinking, and to hopefully, ultimately, get them caring.I started doing this 15 years ago right here in Gainesville, right here in my backyard. And I fell in love with adventure and discovery, going to explore all these different places that were just minutes from my front doorstep. There are a lot of beautiful places to find. Despite all these years that have passed, I still see the world through the eyes of a child and I try to incorporate that sense of wonderment and that sense of curiosity into my photography as often as I can.And we're pretty lucky because here in the South, we're still blessed with a relatively blank canvas that we can fill with the most fanciful adventures and incredible experiences. It's just a matter of how far our imagination will take us. See, a lot of people look at this and they say, "Oh yeah, wow, that's a pretty tree." But I don't just see a tree — I look at this and I see opportunity. I see an entire weekend. Because when I was a kid, these were the types of images that got me off the sofa and dared me to explore, dared me to go find the woods and put my head underwater and see what we have.And folks, I've been photographing all over the world and I promise you, what we have here in the South, what we have in the Sunshine State, rivals anything else that I've seen. But yet our tourism industry is busy promoting all the wrong things. Before most kids are 12, they'll have been to Disney World more times than they've been in a canoe or camping under a starry sky. And I have nothing against Disney or Mickey; I used to go there, too. But they're missing out on those fundamental connections that create a real sense of pride and ownership for the place that they call home.And this is compounded by the issue that the landscapes that define our natural heritage and fuel our aquifer for our drinking water have been deemed as scary and dangerous and spooky. When our ancestors first came here, they warned, "Stay out of these areas, they're haunted. They're full of evil spirits and ghosts." I don't know where they came up with that idea. But it's actually led to a very real disconnect, a very real negative mentality that has kept the public disinterested, silent, and ultimately, our environment at risk. We're a state that's surrounded and defined by water, and yet for centuries, swamps and wetlands have been regarded as these obstacles to overcome. And so we've treated them as these second-class ecosystems, because they have very little monetary value and of course, they're known to harbor alligators and snakes — which, I'll admit, these aren't the most cuddly of ambassadors.(Laughter)So it became assumed, then, that the only good swamp was a drained swamp. And in fact, draining a swamp to make way for agriculture and development was considered the very essence of conservation not too long ago.But now we're backpedaling, because the more we come to learn about these sodden landscapes, the more secrets we're starting to unlock about interspecies relationships and the connectivity of habitats, watersheds and flyways. Take this bird, for example: this is the prothonotary warbler. I love this bird because it's a swamp bird, through and through, a swamp bird. They nest and they mate and they breed in these old-growth swamps in these flooded forests. And so after the spring, after they raise their young, they then fly thousand of miles over the Gulf of Mexico into Central and South America. And then after the winter, the spring rolls around and they come back. They fly thousands of miles over the Gulf of Mexico. And where do they go? Where do they land? Right back in the same tree. That's nuts. This is a bird the size of a tennis ball — I mean, that's crazy! I used a GPS to get here today, and this is my hometown.(Laughter)It's crazy. So what happens, then, when this bird flies over the Gulf of Mexico into Central America for the winter and then the spring rolls around and it flies back, and it comes back to this: a freshly sodded golf course?This is a narrative that's all too commonly unraveling here in this state. And this is a natural process that's occurred for thousands of years and we're just now learning about it. So you can imagine all else we have to learn about these landscapes if we just preserve them first. Now despite all this rich life that abounds in these swamps, they still have a bad name.Many people feel uncomfortable with the idea of wading into Florida's blackwater. I can understand that. But what I loved about growing up in the Sunshine State is that for so many of us, we live with this latent but very palpable fear that when we put our toes into the water, there might be something much more ancient and much more adapted than we are. Knowing that you're not top dog is a welcomed discomfort, I think. How often in this modern and urban and digital age do you actually get the chance to feel vulnerable, or consider that the world may not have been made for just us?So for the last decade, I began seeking out these areas where the concrete yields to forest and the pines turn to cypress, and I viewed all these mosquitoes and reptiles, all these discomforts, as affirmations that I'd found true wilderness, and I embrace them wholly. Now as a conservation photographer obsessed with blackwater, it's only fitting that I'd eventually end up in the most famous swamp of all: the Everglades.Growing up here in North Central Florida, it always had these enchanted names, places like Loxahatchee and Fakahatchee, Corkscrew, Big Cypress. I started what turned into a five-year project to hopefully reintroduce the Everglades in a new light, in a more inspired light. But I knew this would be a tall order, because here you have an area that's roughly a third the size the state of Florida, it's huge. And when I say Everglades, most people are like, "Oh, yeah, the national park." But the Everglades is not just a park; it's an entire watershed, starting with the Kissimmee chain of lakes in the north, and then as the rains would fall in the summer, these downpours would flow into Lake Okeechobee, and Lake Okeechobee would fill up and it would overflow its banks and spill southward, ever slowly, with the topography, and get into the river of grass, the Sawgrass Prairies, before meting into the cypress slews, until going further south into the mangrove swamps, and then finally — finally — reaching Florida Bay, the emerald gem of the Everglades, the great estuary, the 850 square-mile estuary.So sure, the national park is the southern end of this system, but all the things that make it unique are these inputs that come in, the fresh water that starts 100 miles north. So no manner of these political or invisible boundaries protect the park from polluted water or insufficient water. And unfortunately, that's precisely what we've done. Over the last 60 years, we have drained, we have dammed, we have dredged the Everglades to where now only one third of the water that used to reach the bay now reaches the bay today. So this story is not all sunshine and rainbows, unfortunately. For better or for worse, the story of the Everglades is intrinsically tied to the peaks and the valleys of mankind's relationship with the natural world.But I'll show you these beautiful pictures, because it gets you on board. And while I have your attention, I can tell you the real story. It's that we're taking this, and we're trading it for this, at an alarming rate. And what's lost on so many people is the sheer scale of which we're discussing. Because the Everglades is not just responsible for the drinking water for 7 million Floridians; today it also provides the agricultural fields for the year-round tomatoes and oranges for over 300 million Americans. And it's that same seasonal pulse of water in the summer that built the river of grass 6,000 years ago. Ironically, today, it's also responsible for the over half a million acres of the endless river of sugarcane. These are the same fields that are responsible for dumping exceedingly high levels of fertilizers into the watershed, forever changing the system.But in order for you to not just understand how this system works, but to also get personally connected to it, I decided to break the story down into several different narratives. And I wanted that story to start in Lake Okeechobee, the beating heart of the Everglade system. And to do that, I picked an ambassador, an iconic species. This is the Everglade snail kite. It's a great bird, and they used to nest in the thousands, thousands in the northern Everglades. And then they've gone down to about 400 nesting pairs today. And why is that? Well, it's because they eat one source of food, an apple snail, about the size of a ping-pong ball, an aquatic gastropod.So as we started damming up the Everglades, as we started diking Lake Okeechobee and draining the wetlands, we lost the habitat for the snail. And thus, the population of the kites declined. And so, I wanted a photo that would not only communicate this relationship between wetland, snail and bird, but I also wanted a photo that would communicate how incredible this relationship was, and how very important it is that they've come to depend on each other, this healthy wetland and this bird. And to do that, I brainstormed this idea. I started sketching out these plans to make a photo, and I sent it to the wildlife biologist down in Okeechobee — this is an endangered bird, so it takes special permission to do. So I built this submerged platform that would hold snails just right under the water. And I spent months planning this crazy idea. And I took this platform down to Lake Okeechobee and I spent over a week in the water, wading waist-deep, 9-hour shifts from dawn until dusk, to get one image that I thought might communicate this. And here's the day that it finally worked:[Video: (Mac Stone narrating) After setting up the platform, I look off and I see a kite coming over the cattails. And I see him scanning and searching. And he gets right over the trap, and I see that he's seen it. And he beelines, he goes straight for the trap. And in that moment, all those months of planning, waiting, all the sunburn, mosquito bites — suddenly, they're all worth it. (Mac Stone in film) Oh my gosh, I can't believe it!]You can believe how excited I was when that happened. But what the idea was, is that for someone who's never seen this bird and has no reason to care about it, these photos, these new perspectives, will help shed a little new light on just one species that makes this watershed so incredible, so valuable, so important. Now, I know I can't come here to Gainesville and talk to you about animals in the Everglades without talking about gators. I love gators, I grew up loving gators. My parents always said I had an unhealthy relationship with gators. But what I like about them is, they're like the freshwater equivalent of sharks. They're feared, they're hated, and they are tragically misunderstood. Because these are a unique species, they're not just apex predators. In the Everglades, they are the very architects of the Everglades, because as the water drops down in the winter during the dry season, they start excavating these holes called gator holes. And they do this because as the water drops down, they'll be able to stay wet and they'll be able to forage. And now this isn't just affecting them, other animals also depend on this relationship, so they become a keystone species as well. So how do you make an apex predator, an ancient reptile, at once look like it dominates the system, but at the same time, look vulnerable? Well, you wade into a pit of about 120 of them, then you hope that you've made the right decision.(Laughter)I still have all my fingers, it's cool.But I understand, I know I'm not going to rally you guys, I'm not going to rally the troops to "Save the Everglades for the gators!" It won't happen because they're so ubiquitous, we see them now, they're one of the great conservation success stories of the US. But there is one species in the Everglades that no matter who you are, you can't help but love, too, and that's the roseate spoonbill. These birds are great, but they've had a really tough time in the Everglades, because they started out with thousands of nesting pairs in Florida Bay, and at the turn of the 20th century, they got down to two — two nesting pairs. And why? That's because women thought they looked better on their hats then they did flying in the sky. Then we banned the plume trade, and their numbers started rebounding. And as their numbers started rebounding, scientists began to pay attention, they started studying these birds.And what they found out is that these birds' behavior is intrinsically tied to the annual draw-down cycle of water in the Everglades, the thing that defines the Everglades watershed. What they found out is that these birds started nesting in the winter as the water drew down, because they're tactile feeders, so they have to touch whatever they eat. And so they wait for these concentrated pools of fish to be able to feed enough to feed their young. So these birds became the very icon of the Everglades — an indicator species of the overall health of the system. And just as their numbers were rebounding in the mid-20th century — shooting up to 900, 1,000, 1,100, 1,200 — just as that started happening, we started draining the southern Everglades. And we stopped two-thirds of that water from moving south. And it had drastic consequences. And just as those numbers started reaching their peak, unfortunately, today, the real spoonbill story, the real photo of what it looks like is more something like this. And we're down to less than 70 nesting pairs in Florida Bay today, because we've disrupted the system so much. So all these different organizations are shouting, they're screaming, "The Everglades is fragile! It's fragile!" It is not. It is resilient. Because despite all we've taken, despite all we've done and we've drained and we've dammed and we've dredged it, pieces of it are still here, waiting to be put back together.And this is what I've loved about South Florida, that in one place, you have this unstoppable force of mankind meeting the immovable object of tropical nature. And it's at this new frontier that we are forced with a new appraisal. What is wilderness worth? What is the value of biodiversity, or our drinking water? And fortunately, after decades of debate, we're finally starting to act on those questions. We're slowly undertaking these projects to bring more freshwater back to the bay. But it's up to us as citizens, as residents, as stewards to hold our elected officials to their promises.What can you do to help? It's so easy. Just get outside, get out there. Take your friends out, take your kids out, take your family out. Hire a fishing guide. Show the state that protecting wilderness not only makes ecological sense, but economic sense as well. It's a lot of fun, just do it — put your feet in the water. The swamp will change you, I promise.Over the years, we've been so generous with these other landscapes around the country, cloaking them with this American pride, places that we now consider to define us: Grand Canyon, Yosemite, Yellowstone. And we use these parks and these natural areas as beacons and as cultural compasses. And sadly, the Everglades is very commonly left out of that conversation. But I believe it's every bit as iconic and emblematic of who we are as a country as any of these other wildernesses. It's just a different kind of wild.But I'm encouraged, because maybe we're finally starting to come around, because what was once deemed this swampy wasteland, today is a World Heritage site. It's a wetland of international importance. And we've come a long way in the last 60 years. And as the world's largest and most ambitious wetland restoration project, the international spotlight is on us in the Sunshine State. Because if we can heal this system, it's going to become an icon for wetland restoration all over the world. But it's up to us to decide which legacy we want to attach our flag to.They say that the Everglades is our greatest test. If we pass it, we get to keep the planet. I love that quote, because it's a challenge, it's a prod. Can we do it? Will we do it? We have to, we must. But the Everglades is not just a test. It's also a gift, and ultimately, our responsibility.Thank you.(Applause)

00:05:16.998 --> 00:05:18.983
Take this bird, for example:

00:05:19.007 --> 00:05:20.895
this is the prothonotary warbler.

00:05:20.919 --> 00:05:23.105
I love this bird because
it's a swamp bird,

00:05:23.129 --> 00:05:24.833
through and through, a swamp bird.

00:05:24.857 --> 00:05:28.505
They nest and they mate and they breed
in these old-growth swamps

00:05:28.529 --> 00:05:29.993
in these flooded forests.

00:05:30.017 --> 00:05:32.565
And so after the spring,
after they raise their young,

00:05:32.589 --> 00:05:35.394
they then fly thousand of miles
over the Gulf of Mexico

00:05:35.418 --> 00:05:37.367
into Central and South America.

00:05:37.764 --> 00:05:39.016
And then after the winter,

00:05:39.040 --> 00:05:41.055
the spring rolls around
and they come back.

00:05:41.079 --> 00:05:43.978
They fly thousands of miles
over the Gulf of Mexico.

00:05:44.002 --> 00:05:46.908
And where do they go? Where do they land?

00:05:47.432 --> 00:05:49.948
Right back in the same tree.

00:05:50.644 --> 00:05:51.794
That's nuts.

00:05:52.109 --> 00:05:55.456
This is a bird the size
of a tennis ball --

00:05:55.480 --> 00:05:57.157
I mean, that's crazy!

00:05:57.181 --> 00:05:59.731
I used a GPS to get here today,

00:05:59.755 --> 00:06:01.422
and this is my hometown.

00:06:01.446 --> 00:06:02.717
(Laughter)

00:06:02.741 --> 00:06:03.898
It's crazy.

00:06:04.332 --> 00:06:08.022
So what happens, then, when this bird
flies over the Gulf of Mexico

00:06:08.046 --> 00:06:09.914
into Central America for the winter

00:06:09.938 --> 00:06:12.379
and then the spring rolls around
and it flies back,

00:06:12.403 --> 00:06:15.170
and it comes back to this:

00:06:15.194 --> 00:06:17.088
a freshly sodded golf course?

00:06:17.900 --> 00:06:20.489
This is a narrative that's
all too commonly unraveling

00:06:20.513 --> 00:06:21.700
here in this state.

00:06:21.724 --> 00:06:24.963
And this is a natural process
that's occurred for thousands of years

00:06:24.987 --> 00:06:26.765
and we're just now learning about it.

00:06:26.789 --> 00:06:29.952
So you can imagine all else we have
to learn about these landscapes

00:06:29.976 --> 00:06:31.834
if we just preserve them first.

00:06:31.858 --> 00:06:36.389
Now despite all this rich life
that abounds in these swamps,

00:06:36.413 --> 00:06:38.237
they still have a bad name.

00:06:38.786 --> 00:06:42.452
Many people feel uncomfortable
with the idea of wading

00:06:42.476 --> 00:06:44.140
into Florida's blackwater.

00:06:44.164 --> 00:06:45.953
I can understand that.

00:06:45.977 --> 00:06:49.118
But what I loved about growing up
in the Sunshine State

00:06:49.142 --> 00:06:50.424
is that for so many of us,

00:06:50.448 --> 00:06:54.237
we live with this latent
but very palpable fear

00:06:54.261 --> 00:06:56.602
that when we put our toes into the water,

00:06:56.626 --> 00:06:59.608
there might be something much more ancient

00:06:59.632 --> 00:07:01.769
and much more adapted than we are.

00:07:02.622 --> 00:07:07.421
Knowing that you're not top dog
is a welcomed discomfort, I think.

00:07:08.040 --> 00:07:11.926
How often in this modern
and urban and digital age

00:07:11.950 --> 00:07:15.594
do you actually get the chance
to feel vulnerable,

00:07:15.618 --> 00:07:19.784
or consider that the world may not
have been made for just us?

00:07:19.808 --> 00:07:21.090
So for the last decade,

00:07:21.114 --> 00:07:24.509
I began seeking out these areas
where the concrete yields to forest

00:07:24.533 --> 00:07:26.711
and the pines turn to cypress,

00:07:26.735 --> 00:07:30.380
and I viewed all these
mosquitoes and reptiles,

00:07:30.404 --> 00:07:31.903
all these discomforts,

00:07:31.927 --> 00:07:35.459
as affirmations that I'd found
true wilderness,

00:07:35.483 --> 00:07:37.643
and I embrace them wholly.

00:07:37.667 --> 00:07:41.070
Now as a conservation photographer
obsessed with blackwater,

00:07:41.094 --> 00:07:43.214
it's only fitting that I'd
eventually end up

00:07:43.238 --> 00:07:45.415
in the most famous swamp of all:

00:07:45.439 --> 00:07:46.689
the Everglades.

00:07:47.102 --> 00:07:49.071
Growing up here in North Central Florida,

00:07:49.095 --> 00:07:50.825
it always had these enchanted names,

00:07:50.849 --> 00:07:54.191
places like Loxahatchee and Fakahatchee,

00:07:54.215 --> 00:07:56.337
Corkscrew, Big Cypress.

00:07:56.361 --> 00:07:59.901
I started what turned
into a five-year project

00:07:59.925 --> 00:08:03.675
to hopefully reintroduce
the Everglades in a new light,

00:08:03.699 --> 00:08:05.380
in a more inspired light.

00:08:05.880 --> 00:08:09.105
But I knew this would be a tall order,
because here you have an area

00:08:09.129 --> 00:08:12.158
that's roughly a third the size
the state of Florida, it's huge.

00:08:12.182 --> 00:08:13.459
And when I say Everglades,

00:08:13.483 --> 00:08:15.951
most people are like,
"Oh, yeah, the national park."

00:08:15.975 --> 00:08:20.988
But the Everglades is not just a park;
it's an entire watershed,

00:08:21.012 --> 00:08:24.017
starting with the Kissimmee
chain of lakes in the north,

00:08:24.041 --> 00:08:26.266
and then as the rains
would fall in the summer,

00:08:26.290 --> 00:08:28.922
these downpours would flow
into Lake Okeechobee,

00:08:28.946 --> 00:08:32.193
and Lake Okeechobee would fill up
and it would overflow its banks

00:08:32.217 --> 00:08:35.491
and spill southward, ever slowly,
with the topography,

00:08:35.515 --> 00:08:38.111
and get into the river of grass,
the Sawgrass Prairies,

00:08:38.135 --> 00:08:40.180
before meting into the cypress slews,

00:08:40.204 --> 00:08:42.891
until going further south
into the mangrove swamps,

00:08:42.915 --> 00:08:46.665
and then finally -- finally --
reaching Florida Bay,

00:08:46.689 --> 00:08:48.462
the emerald gem of the Everglades,

00:08:48.486 --> 00:08:49.669
the great estuary,

00:08:49.693 --> 00:08:51.946
the 850 square-mile estuary.

00:08:52.422 --> 00:08:56.755
So sure, the national park
is the southern end of this system,

00:08:56.779 --> 00:09:00.082
but all the things that make it unique
are these inputs that come in,

00:09:00.106 --> 00:09:02.913
the fresh water that starts
100 miles north.

00:09:02.937 --> 00:09:06.202
So no manner of these political
or invisible boundaries

00:09:06.226 --> 00:09:10.613
protect the park from polluted water
or insufficient water.

00:09:11.200 --> 00:09:14.026
And unfortunately, that's precisely
what we've done.

00:09:14.588 --> 00:09:16.121
Over the last 60 years,

00:09:16.145 --> 00:09:19.502
we have drained, we have dammed,
we have dredged the Everglades

00:09:19.526 --> 00:09:23.507
to where now only one third of the water
that used to reach the bay

00:09:23.531 --> 00:09:25.538
now reaches the bay today.

00:09:26.544 --> 00:09:30.212
So this story is not all sunshine
and rainbows, unfortunately.

00:09:30.911 --> 00:09:32.797
For better or for worse,

00:09:32.821 --> 00:09:36.238
the story of the Everglades
is intrinsically tied

00:09:36.262 --> 00:09:39.458
to the peaks and the valleys
of mankind's relationship

00:09:39.482 --> 00:09:40.822
with the natural world.

00:09:41.213 --> 00:09:43.238
But I'll show you
these beautiful pictures,

00:09:43.262 --> 00:09:44.723
because it gets you on board.

00:09:44.747 --> 00:09:47.875
And while I have your attention,
I can tell you the real story.

00:09:47.899 --> 00:09:49.850
It's that we're taking this,

00:09:49.874 --> 00:09:52.837
and we're trading it for this,

00:09:52.861 --> 00:09:54.356
at an alarming rate.

00:09:55.316 --> 00:09:57.026
And what's lost on so many people

00:09:57.050 --> 00:09:59.561
is the sheer scale
of which we're discussing.

00:09:59.585 --> 00:10:03.013
Because the Everglades is not just
responsible for the drinking water

00:10:03.037 --> 00:10:05.241
for 7 million Floridians;

00:10:05.265 --> 00:10:07.803
today it also provides
the agricultural fields

00:10:07.827 --> 00:10:10.386
for the year-round tomatoes and oranges

00:10:10.410 --> 00:10:13.241
for over 300 million Americans.

00:10:14.349 --> 00:10:17.663
And it's that same seasonal pulse
of water in the summer

00:10:17.687 --> 00:10:21.580
that built the river of grass
6,000 years ago.

00:10:22.242 --> 00:10:26.620
Ironically, today, it's also responsible
for the over half a million acres

00:10:26.644 --> 00:10:29.099
of the endless river of sugarcane.

00:10:29.857 --> 00:10:32.026
These are the same fields
that are responsible

00:10:32.050 --> 00:10:36.074
for dumping exceedingly high levels
of fertilizers into the watershed,

00:10:36.098 --> 00:10:38.261
forever changing the system.

00:10:38.707 --> 00:10:41.919
But in order for you to not just
understand how this system works,

00:10:41.943 --> 00:10:44.006
but to also get personally
connected to it,

00:10:44.030 --> 00:10:47.305
I decided to break the story down
into several different narratives.

00:10:47.329 --> 00:10:50.117
And I wanted that story to start
in Lake Okeechobee,

00:10:50.141 --> 00:10:52.888
the beating heart of the Everglade system.

00:10:52.912 --> 00:10:55.375
And to do that, I picked an ambassador,

00:10:55.399 --> 00:10:56.648
an iconic species.

00:10:57.162 --> 00:10:59.154
This is the Everglade snail kite.

00:10:59.678 --> 00:11:00.924
It's a great bird,

00:11:00.948 --> 00:11:02.822
and they used to nest in the thousands,

00:11:02.846 --> 00:11:04.649
thousands in the northern Everglades.

00:11:04.673 --> 00:11:08.177
And then they've gone down
to about 400 nesting pairs today.

00:11:08.201 --> 00:11:09.546
And why is that?

00:11:09.570 --> 00:11:12.694
Well, it's because they eat
one source of food, an apple snail,

00:11:12.718 --> 00:11:16.119
about the size of a ping-pong ball,
an aquatic gastropod.

00:11:16.143 --> 00:11:19.368
So as we started damming up
the Everglades,

00:11:19.392 --> 00:11:22.869
as we started diking Lake Okeechobee
and draining the wetlands,

00:11:22.893 --> 00:11:25.005
we lost the habitat for the snail.

00:11:25.029 --> 00:11:27.821
And thus, the population
of the kites declined.

00:11:28.412 --> 00:11:31.908
And so, I wanted a photo that would
not only communicate this relationship

00:11:31.932 --> 00:11:35.021
between wetland, snail and bird,

00:11:35.045 --> 00:11:37.294
but I also wanted a photo
that would communicate

00:11:37.318 --> 00:11:40.112
how incredible this relationship was,

00:11:40.136 --> 00:11:44.292
and how very important it is
that they've come to depend on each other,

00:11:44.316 --> 00:11:45.983
this healthy wetland and this bird.

00:11:46.007 --> 00:11:47.979
And to do that, I brainstormed this idea.

00:11:48.003 --> 00:11:51.241
I started sketching
out these plans to make a photo,

00:11:51.265 --> 00:11:54.152
and I sent it to the wildlife biologist
down in Okeechobee --

00:11:54.176 --> 00:11:57.263
this is an endangered bird,
so it takes special permission to do.

00:11:57.287 --> 00:11:58.981
So I built this submerged platform

00:11:59.005 --> 00:12:01.487
that would hold snails
just right under the water.

00:12:01.511 --> 00:12:05.969
And I spent months planning
this crazy idea.

00:12:05.993 --> 00:12:08.969
And I took this platform
down to Lake Okeechobee

00:12:08.993 --> 00:12:11.065
and I spent over a week in the water,

00:12:11.089 --> 00:12:14.805
wading waist-deep,
9-hour shifts from dawn until dusk,

00:12:14.829 --> 00:12:17.989
to get one image that I thought
might communicate this.

00:12:18.013 --> 00:12:20.228
And here's the day that it finally worked:

00:12:20.252 --> 00:12:23.109
[Video: (Mac Stone narrating)
After setting up the platform,

00:12:23.133 --> 00:12:25.670
I look off and I see a kite
coming over the cattails.

00:12:25.694 --> 00:12:27.616
And I see him scanning and searching.

00:12:27.640 --> 00:12:29.245
And he gets right over the trap,

00:12:29.269 --> 00:12:30.790
and I see that he's seen it.

00:12:30.814 --> 00:12:33.537
And he beelines,
he goes straight for the trap.

00:12:33.561 --> 00:12:36.717
And in that moment,
all those months of planning, waiting,

00:12:36.741 --> 00:12:38.851
all the sunburn, mosquito bites --

00:12:38.875 --> 00:12:41.413
suddenly, they're all worth it.

00:12:41.437 --> 00:12:45.352
(Mac Stone in film) Oh my gosh,
I can't believe it!]

00:12:45.653 --> 00:12:48.250
You can believe how excited I was
when that happened.

00:12:48.274 --> 00:12:49.614
But what the idea was,

00:12:49.638 --> 00:12:51.837
is that for someone
who's never seen this bird

00:12:51.861 --> 00:12:53.931
and has no reason to care about it,

00:12:53.955 --> 00:12:56.580
these photos, these new perspectives,

00:12:56.604 --> 00:12:59.726
will help shed a little new light
on just one species

00:12:59.750 --> 00:13:04.032
that makes this watershed
so incredible, so valuable, so important.

00:13:04.573 --> 00:13:07.496
Now, I know I can't come
here to Gainesville

00:13:07.520 --> 00:13:09.766
and talk to you about animals
in the Everglades

00:13:09.790 --> 00:13:11.578
without talking about gators.

00:13:11.602 --> 00:13:13.892
I love gators, I grew up loving gators.

00:13:14.319 --> 00:13:17.735
My parents always said I had
an unhealthy relationship with gators.

00:13:17.759 --> 00:13:19.227
But what I like about them is,

00:13:19.251 --> 00:13:21.855
they're like the freshwater
equivalent of sharks.

00:13:21.879 --> 00:13:23.527
They're feared, they're hated,

00:13:23.551 --> 00:13:25.915
and they are tragically misunderstood.

00:13:26.344 --> 00:13:30.108
Because these are a unique species,
they're not just apex predators.

00:13:30.132 --> 00:13:31.422
In the Everglades,

00:13:31.446 --> 00:13:33.940
they are the very architects
of the Everglades,

00:13:33.964 --> 00:13:36.107
because as the water drops
down in the winter

00:13:36.131 --> 00:13:37.289
during the dry season,

00:13:37.313 --> 00:13:40.335
they start excavating these holes
called gator holes.

00:13:40.359 --> 00:13:42.669
And they do this because
as the water drops down,

00:13:42.693 --> 00:13:46.080
they'll be able to stay wet
and they'll be able to forage.

00:13:46.603 --> 00:13:48.922
And now this isn't just affecting them,

00:13:48.946 --> 00:13:51.179
other animals also depend
on this relationship,

00:13:51.203 --> 00:13:53.881
so they become a keystone species as well.

00:13:54.635 --> 00:13:58.870
So how do you make an apex predator,
an ancient reptile,

00:13:58.894 --> 00:14:01.372
at once look like it dominates the system,

00:14:01.396 --> 00:14:03.839
but at the same time, look vulnerable?

00:14:04.664 --> 00:14:08.707
Well, you wade into a pit
of about 120 of them,

00:14:08.731 --> 00:14:11.137
then you hope that you've made
the right decision.

00:14:11.161 --> 00:14:12.925
(Laughter)

00:14:13.913 --> 00:14:15.873
I still have all my fingers, it's cool.

00:14:16.635 --> 00:14:19.337
But I understand, I know
I'm not going to rally you guys,

00:14:19.361 --> 00:14:22.971
I'm not going to rally the troops to
"Save the Everglades for the gators!"

00:14:22.995 --> 00:14:25.193
It won't happen because
they're so ubiquitous,

00:14:25.217 --> 00:14:26.368
we see them now,

00:14:26.392 --> 00:14:29.734
they're one of the great conservation
success stories of the US.

00:14:29.758 --> 00:14:33.084
But there is one species in the Everglades
that no matter who you are,

00:14:33.108 --> 00:14:36.187
you can't help but love, too,
and that's the roseate spoonbill.

00:14:36.211 --> 00:14:39.842
These birds are great, but they've had
a really tough time in the Everglades,

00:14:39.866 --> 00:14:43.332
because they started out with thousands
of nesting pairs in Florida Bay,

00:14:43.356 --> 00:14:45.419
and at the turn of the 20th century,

00:14:45.443 --> 00:14:49.035
they got down to two -- two nesting pairs.

00:14:49.059 --> 00:14:50.223
And why?

00:14:50.639 --> 00:14:53.535
That's because women thought
they looked better on their hats

00:14:53.559 --> 00:14:55.572
then they did flying in the sky.

00:14:56.282 --> 00:14:58.691
Then we banned the plume trade,

00:14:58.715 --> 00:15:00.833
and their numbers started rebounding.

00:15:00.857 --> 00:15:02.882
And as their numbers started rebounding,

00:15:02.906 --> 00:15:04.645
scientists began to pay attention,

00:15:04.669 --> 00:15:06.382
they started studying these birds.

00:15:06.406 --> 00:15:07.891
And what they found out is that

00:15:07.915 --> 00:15:10.073
these birds' behavior
is intrinsically tied

00:15:10.097 --> 00:15:13.015
to the annual draw-down
cycle of water in the Everglades,

00:15:13.039 --> 00:15:15.718
the thing that defines
the Everglades watershed.

00:15:16.249 --> 00:15:17.786
What they found out is that

00:15:17.810 --> 00:15:20.878
these birds started nesting in the winter
as the water drew down,

00:15:20.902 --> 00:15:24.482
because they're tactile feeders,
so they have to touch whatever they eat.

00:15:24.506 --> 00:15:27.604
And so they wait for these
concentrated pools of fish

00:15:27.628 --> 00:15:30.025
to be able to feed enough
to feed their young.

00:15:30.835 --> 00:15:33.824
So these birds became the very icon
of the Everglades --

00:15:33.848 --> 00:15:37.340
an indicator species
of the overall health of the system.

00:15:37.364 --> 00:15:40.571
And just as their numbers were rebounding
in the mid-20th century --

00:15:40.595 --> 00:15:45.244
shooting up to 900, 1,000, 1,100, 1,200 --

00:15:45.268 --> 00:15:49.024
just as that started happening, we started
draining the southern Everglades.

00:15:49.048 --> 00:15:52.552
And we stopped two-thirds
of that water from moving south.

00:15:52.576 --> 00:15:55.075
And it had drastic consequences.

00:15:55.542 --> 00:15:58.156
And just as those numbers
started reaching their peak,

00:15:58.180 --> 00:16:01.253
unfortunately, today,
the real spoonbill story,

00:16:01.277 --> 00:16:05.894
the real photo of what it looks like
is more something like this.

00:16:06.965 --> 00:16:11.581
And we're down to less than 70
nesting pairs in Florida Bay today,

00:16:11.605 --> 00:16:14.149
because we've disrupted
the system so much.

00:16:14.173 --> 00:16:17.424
So all these different organizations
are shouting, they're screaming,

00:16:17.448 --> 00:16:19.463
"The Everglades is fragile! It's fragile!"

00:16:19.487 --> 00:16:20.638
It is not.

00:16:20.662 --> 00:16:22.212
It is resilient.

00:16:22.236 --> 00:16:25.728
Because despite all we've taken,
despite all we've done and we've drained

00:16:25.752 --> 00:16:27.591
and we've dammed and we've dredged it,

00:16:27.615 --> 00:16:30.511
pieces of it are still here,
waiting to be put back together.

00:16:30.535 --> 00:16:32.789
And this is what I've loved
about South Florida,

00:16:32.813 --> 00:16:36.587
that in one place, you have
this unstoppable force of mankind

00:16:36.611 --> 00:16:40.046
meeting the immovable object
of tropical nature.

00:16:40.931 --> 00:16:44.771
And it's at this new frontier
that we are forced with a new appraisal.

00:16:44.795 --> 00:16:46.478
What is wilderness worth?

00:16:47.077 --> 00:16:50.171
What is the value of biodiversity,
or our drinking water?

00:16:51.153 --> 00:16:53.586
And fortunately, after decades of debate,

00:16:53.610 --> 00:16:56.577
we're finally starting to act
on those questions.

00:16:56.601 --> 00:16:58.958
We're slowly undertaking these projects

00:16:58.982 --> 00:17:01.478
to bring more freshwater back to the bay.

00:17:01.502 --> 00:17:05.157
But it's up to us as citizens,
as residents, as stewards

00:17:05.181 --> 00:17:08.136
to hold our elected officials
to their promises.

00:17:09.112 --> 00:17:10.945
What can you do to help?

00:17:10.969 --> 00:17:12.224
It's so easy.

00:17:12.248 --> 00:17:14.216
Just get outside, get out there.

00:17:14.240 --> 00:17:16.271
Take your friends out, take your kids out,

00:17:16.295 --> 00:17:17.870
take your family out.

00:17:17.894 --> 00:17:19.556
Hire a fishing guide.

00:17:19.580 --> 00:17:21.563
Show the state that protecting wilderness

00:17:21.587 --> 00:17:25.674
not only makes ecological sense,
but economic sense as well.

00:17:26.246 --> 00:17:29.573
It's a lot of fun, just do it --
put your feet in the water.

00:17:29.597 --> 00:17:32.111
The swamp will change you, I promise.

00:17:33.309 --> 00:17:35.181
Over the years, we've been so generous

00:17:35.205 --> 00:17:38.275
with these other landscapes
around the country,

00:17:38.299 --> 00:17:41.120
cloaking them with this American pride,

00:17:41.144 --> 00:17:43.515
places that we now consider to define us:

00:17:43.539 --> 00:17:46.664
Grand Canyon, Yosemite, Yellowstone.

00:17:46.688 --> 00:17:49.097
And we use these parks
and these natural areas

00:17:49.121 --> 00:17:52.364
as beacons and as cultural compasses.

00:17:53.142 --> 00:17:55.187
And sadly, the Everglades is very commonly

00:17:55.211 --> 00:17:57.127
left out of that conversation.

00:17:57.558 --> 00:18:00.066
But I believe it's every bit
as iconic and emblematic

00:18:00.090 --> 00:18:01.963
of who we are as a country

00:18:01.987 --> 00:18:04.488
as any of these other wildernesses.

00:18:04.512 --> 00:18:06.999
It's just a different kind of wild.

00:18:08.015 --> 00:18:09.342
But I'm encouraged,

00:18:09.366 --> 00:18:12.060
because maybe we're finally
starting to come around,

00:18:12.084 --> 00:18:14.671
because what was once deemed
this swampy wasteland,

00:18:14.695 --> 00:18:16.758
today is a World Heritage site.

00:18:17.362 --> 00:18:20.116
It's a wetland
of international importance.

00:18:20.657 --> 00:18:23.460
And we've come a long way
in the last 60 years.

00:18:23.484 --> 00:18:27.878
And as the world's largest and most
ambitious wetland restoration project,

00:18:27.902 --> 00:18:32.243
the international spotlight
is on us in the Sunshine State.

00:18:32.267 --> 00:18:34.000
Because if we can heal this system,

00:18:34.024 --> 00:18:37.473
it's going to become an icon
for wetland restoration

00:18:37.497 --> 00:18:38.862
all over the world.

00:18:40.194 --> 00:18:44.740
But it's up to us to decide which legacy
we want to attach our flag to.

00:18:45.466 --> 00:18:48.850
They say that the Everglades
is our greatest test.

00:18:49.942 --> 00:18:52.612
If we pass it, we get to keep the planet.

00:18:53.523 --> 00:18:54.926
I love that quote,

00:18:54.950 --> 00:18:56.983
because it's a challenge, it's a prod.

00:18:57.007 --> 00:18:58.886
Can we do it? Will we do it?

00:18:58.910 --> 00:19:00.649
We have to, we must.

00:19:01.465 --> 00:19:03.430
But the Everglades is not just a test.

00:19:03.874 --> 00:19:05.493
It's also a gift,

00:19:05.517 --> 00:19:08.384
and ultimately, our responsibility.

00:19:08.917 --> 00:19:10.068
Thank you.
