So to help us with this benchmarking,

00:03:37.831 --> 00:03:41.577
I'm going to use a tool
called the Social Progress Index.

00:03:42.124 --> 00:03:46.078
What this does is measures all the stuff
the Global Goals are trying to achieve,

00:03:46.102 --> 00:03:50.264
but sums it up into a single number
that we can use as our benchmark

00:03:50.288 --> 00:03:52.437
and track progress over time.

00:03:52.858 --> 00:03:56.411
The Social Progress Index basically asks
three fundamental questions

00:03:56.435 --> 00:03:57.696
about a society.

00:03:58.172 --> 00:04:01.637
First of all, does everyone have
the basic needs of survival:

00:04:01.661 --> 00:04:04.469
food, water, shelter, safety?

00:04:04.493 --> 00:04:08.247
Secondly, does everyone have
the building blocks of a better life:

00:04:08.271 --> 00:04:12.532
education, information, health
and a sustainable environment?

00:04:13.111 --> 00:04:16.797
And does everyone have
the opportunity to improve their lives,

00:04:16.821 --> 00:04:20.821
through rights, freedom of choice,
freedom from discrimination,

00:04:20.845 --> 00:04:23.548
and access to the world's
most advanced knowledge?

00:04:24.421 --> 00:04:28.533
The Social Progress Index sums all this
together using 52 indicators

00:04:28.557 --> 00:04:32.489
to create an aggregate score
on a scale of 0 to 100.

00:04:33.394 --> 00:04:36.557
And what we find is that there's
a wide diversity of performance

00:04:36.581 --> 00:04:37.742
in the world today.

00:04:38.147 --> 00:04:41.676
The highest performing country,
Norway, scores 88.

00:04:42.239 --> 00:04:46.626
The lowest performing country,
Central African Republic, scores 31.

00:04:47.557 --> 00:04:49.653
And we can add up
all the countries together,

00:04:49.677 --> 00:04:52.111
weighting for the different
population sizes,

00:04:52.135 --> 00:04:55.533
and that global score is 61.

00:04:56.118 --> 00:04:57.269
In concrete terms,

00:04:57.293 --> 00:05:01.051
that means that the average human being
is living on a level of social progress

00:05:01.075 --> 00:05:04.497
about the same of Cuba
or Kazakhstan today.

00:05:05.187 --> 00:05:07.743
That's where we are today: 61 out of 100.

00:05:08.378 --> 00:05:11.386
What do we have to get to
to achieve the Global Goals?

00:05:12.212 --> 00:05:14.700
Now, the Global Goals
are certainly ambitious,

00:05:14.724 --> 00:05:18.758
but they're not about turning the world
into Norway in just 15 years.

00:05:19.353 --> 00:05:23.452
So having looked at the numbers,
my estimate is that a score of 75

00:05:23.476 --> 00:05:27.533
would not only be a giant leap forward
in human well-being,

00:05:27.557 --> 00:05:30.679
it would also count as hitting
the Global Goals target.

00:05:31.370 --> 00:05:34.156
So there's our target, 75 out of 100.

00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:36.209
Can we get there?

00:05:36.233 --> 00:05:39.217
Well, the Social Progress Index
can help us calculate this,

00:05:39.241 --> 00:05:40.907
because as you might have noticed,

00:05:40.931 --> 00:05:43.156
there are no economic indicators in there;

00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:47.657
there's no GDP or economic growth
in the Social Progress Index model.

00:05:47.990 --> 00:05:51.533
And what that lets us do
is understand the relationship

00:05:51.557 --> 00:05:54.841
between economic growth
and social progress.

00:05:55.707 --> 00:05:57.327
Let me show you on this chart.

00:05:57.351 --> 00:06:00.533
So here on the vertical axis,
I've put social progress,

00:06:00.557 --> 00:06:03.125
the stuff the Global Goals
are trying to achieve.

00:06:03.149 --> 00:06:04.695
Higher is better.

00:06:04.719 --> 00:06:08.103
And then on the horizontal axis,
is GDP per capita.

00:06:08.127 --> 00:06:10.666
Further to the right means richer.

00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:13.990
And in there, I'm now going to put
all the countries of the world,

00:06:14.014 --> 00:06:16.122
each one represented by a dot,

00:06:16.146 --> 00:06:18.741
and on top of that I'm going to put
the regression line

00:06:18.765 --> 00:06:20.764
that shows the average relationship.

00:06:21.119 --> 00:06:24.649
And what this tells us
is that as we get richer,

00:06:24.673 --> 00:06:27.181
social progress does tend to improve.

00:06:28.030 --> 00:06:32.621
However, as we get richer,
each extra dollar of GDP

00:06:32.645 --> 00:06:36.242
is buying us less and less
social progress.

00:06:37.067 --> 00:06:40.806
And now we can use this information
to start building our forecast.

00:06:41.361 --> 00:06:44.167
So here is the world in 2015.

00:06:44.676 --> 00:06:48.074
We have a social progress score of 61

00:06:48.098 --> 00:06:51.282
and a GDP per capita of $14,000.

00:06:51.853 --> 00:06:56.081
And the place we're trying to get to,
remember, is 75, that Global Goals target.

00:06:56.105 --> 00:06:59.763
So here we are today,
$14,000 per capita GDP.

00:07:00.248 --> 00:07:02.613
How rich are we going to be in 2030?

00:07:02.637 --> 00:07:04.475
That's what we need to know next.

00:07:04.499 --> 00:07:08.750
Well, the best forecast we can find comes
from the US Department of Agriculture,

00:07:08.774 --> 00:07:13.425
which forecasts 3.1 percent
average global economic growth

00:07:13.449 --> 00:07:15.193
over the next 15 years,

00:07:15.217 --> 00:07:18.336
which means that in 2030,
if they're right,

00:07:18.360 --> 00:07:22.386
per capita GDP will be about $23,000.

00:07:23.251 --> 00:07:25.792
So now the question is:
if we get that much richer,

00:07:25.816 --> 00:07:28.117
how much social progress
are we going to get?

00:07:28.705 --> 00:07:31.315
Well, we asked a team
of economists at Deloitte

00:07:31.339 --> 00:07:33.108
who checked and crunched the numbers,

00:07:33.132 --> 00:07:38.084
and they came back and said, well, look:
if the world's average wealth goes

00:07:38.108 --> 00:07:41.884
from $14,000 a year to $23,000 a year,

00:07:41.908 --> 00:07:44.196
social progress is going to increase

00:07:44.220 --> 00:07:48.583
from 61 to 62.4.

00:07:48.884 --> 00:07:50.797
(Laughter)

00:07:50.821 --> 00:07:55.320
Just 62.4. Just a tiny increase.

00:07:56.273 --> 00:07:57.820
Now this seems a bit strange.

00:07:57.844 --> 00:08:00.056
Economic growth seems
to have really helped

00:08:00.080 --> 00:08:01.769
in the fight against poverty,

00:08:01.793 --> 00:08:03.993
but it doesn't seem
to be having much impact

00:08:04.017 --> 00:08:06.100
on trying to get to the Global Goals.

00:08:06.425 --> 00:08:07.719
So what's going on?

00:08:08.140 --> 00:08:09.831
Well, I think there are two things.

00:08:09.855 --> 00:08:13.722
The first is that in a way,
we're the victims of our own success.

00:08:13.746 --> 00:08:16.738
We've used up the easy wins
from economic growth,

00:08:16.762 --> 00:08:19.110
and now we're moving on
to harder problems.

00:08:19.608 --> 00:08:23.996
And also, we know that economic growth
comes with costs as well as benefits.

00:08:24.020 --> 00:08:28.544
There are costs to the environment, costs
from new health problems like obesity.

00:08:29.783 --> 00:08:31.068
So that's the bad news.

00:08:31.489 --> 00:08:35.399
We're not going to get to the Global Goals
just by getting richer.

00:08:36.169 --> 00:08:37.991
So are the pessimists right?

00:08:38.557 --> 00:08:39.899
Well, maybe not.

00:08:39.923 --> 00:08:43.826
Because the Social Progress Index
also has some very good news.

00:08:44.641 --> 00:08:47.000
Let me take you back
to that regression line.

00:08:47.024 --> 00:08:50.404
So this is the average relationship
between GDP and social progress,

00:08:50.428 --> 00:08:53.314
and this is what our
last forecast was based on.

00:08:53.998 --> 00:08:55.671
But as you saw already,

00:08:55.695 --> 00:08:59.620
there is actually lots of noise
around this trend line.

00:09:00.429 --> 00:09:02.866
What that tells us, quite simply,

00:09:02.890 --> 00:09:05.993
is that GDP is not destiny.

00:09:06.547 --> 00:09:09.025
We have countries that are underperforming

00:09:09.049 --> 00:09:11.698
on social progress,
relative to their wealth.

00:09:12.279 --> 00:09:14.629
Russia has lots
of natural resource wealth,

00:09:14.653 --> 00:09:16.805
but lots of social problems.

00:09:16.829 --> 00:09:19.060
China has boomed economically,

00:09:19.084 --> 00:09:23.287
but hasn't made much headway
on human rights or environmental issues.

00:09:23.888 --> 00:09:28.532
India has a space program
and millions of people without toilets.

00:09:29.222 --> 00:09:32.519
Now, on the other hand, we have countries
that are overperforming

00:09:32.543 --> 00:09:35.533
on social progress relative to their GDP.

00:09:35.880 --> 00:09:41.591
Costa Rica has prioritized education,
health and environmental sustainability,

00:09:41.615 --> 00:09:45.536
and as a result, it's achieving
a very high level of social progress,

00:09:45.560 --> 00:09:48.810
despite only having a rather modest GDP.

00:09:49.429 --> 00:09:51.533
And Costa Rica's not alone.

00:09:51.557 --> 00:09:55.533
From poor countries like Rwanda
to richer countries like New Zealand,

00:09:55.557 --> 00:09:59.155
we see that it's possible to get
lots of social progress,

00:09:59.179 --> 00:10:01.782
even if your GDP is not so great.

00:10:02.607 --> 00:10:05.861
And that's really important,
because it tells us two things.

00:10:06.242 --> 00:10:11.450
First of all, it tells us that we already
in the world have the solutions

00:10:11.474 --> 00:10:15.302
to many of the problems
that the Global Goals are trying to solve.

00:10:15.837 --> 00:10:19.559
It also tells us
that we're not slaves to GDP.

00:10:19.987 --> 00:10:24.262
Our choices matter: if we prioritize
the well-being of people,

00:10:24.286 --> 00:10:28.162
then we can make a lot more progress
than our GDP might expect.

00:10:28.966 --> 00:10:32.118
How much? Enough to get us
to the Global Goals?

00:10:32.142 --> 00:10:33.753
Well, let's look at some numbers.

00:10:33.777 --> 00:10:37.638
What we know already: the world today
is scoring 61 on social progress,

00:10:37.662 --> 00:10:40.460
and the place we want to get to is 75.

00:10:40.484 --> 00:10:42.704
If we rely on economic growth alone,

00:10:42.728 --> 00:10:45.309
we're going to get to 62.4.

00:10:45.333 --> 00:10:49.435
So let's assume now that we can get
the countries that are currently

00:10:49.459 --> 00:10:52.653
underperforming on social progress --
the Russia, China, Indias --

00:10:52.677 --> 00:10:53.977
just up to the average.

00:10:54.366 --> 00:10:56.557
How much social progress does that get us?

00:10:56.581 --> 00:10:58.692
Well, that takes us to 65.

00:10:59.255 --> 00:11:02.161
It's a bit better, but still
quite a long way to go.

00:11:02.185 --> 00:11:04.546
So let's get a little bit more
optimistic and say,

00:11:04.570 --> 00:11:07.360
what if every country
gets a little bit better

00:11:07.384 --> 00:11:09.771
at turning its wealth into well-being?

00:11:10.152 --> 00:11:12.549
Well then, we get to 67.

00:11:13.398 --> 00:11:16.053
And now let's be even bolder still.

00:11:16.077 --> 00:11:20.533
What if every country in the world
chose to be like Costa Rica

00:11:20.557 --> 00:11:22.927
in prioritizing human well-being,

00:11:22.951 --> 00:11:25.533
using its wealth for the well-being
of its citizens?

00:11:25.557 --> 00:11:29.776
Well then, we get to nearly 73,
very close to the Global Goals.

00:11:30.557 --> 00:11:32.533
Can we achieve the Global Goals?

00:11:32.557 --> 00:11:34.759
Certainly not with business as usual.

00:11:35.236 --> 00:11:39.587
Even a flood tide of economic growth
is not going to get us there,

00:11:39.611 --> 00:11:42.674
if it just raises the mega-yachts
and the super-wealthy

00:11:42.698 --> 00:11:44.492
and leaves the rest behind.

00:11:45.135 --> 00:11:49.129
If we're going to achieve the Global Goals
we have to do things differently.

00:11:49.153 --> 00:11:53.362
We have to prioritize social progress,
and really scale solutions

00:11:53.386 --> 00:11:54.876
around the world.

00:11:54.900 --> 00:11:58.615
I believe the Global Goals
are a historic opportunity,

00:11:58.639 --> 00:12:02.234
because the world's leaders
have promised to deliver them.

00:12:03.059 --> 00:12:07.032
Let's not dismiss the goals
or slide into pessimism;

00:12:07.056 --> 00:12:09.048
let's hold them to that promise.

00:12:09.787 --> 00:12:13.117
And we need to hold them to that promise
by holding them accountable,

00:12:13.141 --> 00:12:16.432
tracking their progress all the way
through the next 15 years.

00:12:16.886 --> 00:12:18.568
And I want to finish by showing you

00:12:18.592 --> 00:12:21.357
a way to do that, called
the People's Report Card.

00:12:21.381 --> 00:12:26.288
The People's Report Card brings together
all this data into a simple framework

00:12:26.312 --> 00:12:28.852
that we'll all be familiar
with from our school days,

00:12:28.876 --> 00:12:30.304
to hold them to account.

00:12:30.328 --> 00:12:32.583
It grades our performance
on the Global Goals

00:12:32.607 --> 00:12:36.078
on a scale from F to A,

00:12:36.102 --> 00:12:41.195
where F is humanity at its worst,
and A is humanity at its best.

00:12:41.648 --> 00:12:46.419
Our world today is scoring a C-.

00:12:47.363 --> 00:12:50.792
The Global Goals are all about
getting to an A,

00:12:50.816 --> 00:12:54.533
and that's why we're going to be updating
the People's Report Card annually,

00:12:54.557 --> 00:12:57.770
for the world and for all
the countries of the world,

00:12:57.794 --> 00:13:00.385
so we can hold our leaders to account

00:13:00.409 --> 00:13:04.551
to achieve this target
and fulfill this promise.

00:13:05.138 --> 00:13:09.785
Because getting to the Global Goals will
only happen if we do things differently,

00:13:09.809 --> 00:13:11.976
if our leaders do things differently,

00:13:12.000 --> 00:13:15.897
and for that to happen,
that needs us to demand it.

00:13:16.452 --> 00:13:19.929
So let's reject business as usual.

00:13:20.413 --> 00:13:22.871
Let's demand a different path.

00:13:23.323 --> 00:13:27.141
Let's choose the world that we want.

00:13:28.115 --> 00:13:29.267
Thank you.

00:13:29.291 --> 00:13:34.533
(Applause)

00:13:34.557 --> 00:13:36.434
Bruno Giussani: Thank you, Michael.

00:13:38.633 --> 00:13:41.456
Michael, just one question:
the Millennium Development Goals

00:13:41.480 --> 00:13:42.961
established 15 years ago,

00:13:42.985 --> 00:13:46.062
they were kind of applying
to every country

00:13:46.086 --> 00:13:49.653
but it turned out to be really
a scorecard for emerging countries.

00:13:49.677 --> 00:13:52.129
Now the new Global Goals
are explicitly universal.

00:13:52.153 --> 00:13:56.305
They ask for every country to show action
and to show progress.

00:13:56.329 --> 00:13:59.317
How can I, as a private citizen,
use the report card

00:13:59.341 --> 00:14:02.175
to create pressure for action?

00:14:02.199 --> 00:14:06.074
Michael Green: This is a really important
point; it's a big shift in priorities --

00:14:06.098 --> 00:14:08.577
it's no longer about poor
countries and just poverty.

00:14:08.601 --> 00:14:09.816
It's about every country.

00:14:09.840 --> 00:14:13.470
And every country is going to have
challenges in getting to the Global Goals.

00:14:13.494 --> 00:14:16.804
Even, I'm sorry to say, Bruno,
Switzerland has got to work to do.

00:14:16.828 --> 00:14:20.198
And so that's why we're going to produce
these report cards in 2016

00:14:20.222 --> 00:14:21.708
for every country in the world.

00:14:21.732 --> 00:14:23.811
Then we can really see, how are we doing?

00:14:23.835 --> 00:14:26.716
And it's not going to be rich countries
scoring straight A's.

00:14:26.740 --> 00:14:29.348
And that, then, I think,
is to provide a point of focus

00:14:29.372 --> 00:14:32.828
for people to start demanding action
and start demanding progress.

00:14:32.852 --> 00:14:34.300
BG: Thank you very much.

00:14:34.324 --> 00:14:37.557
(Applause)

title: The future of flying robots
transcript: In my lab, we build autonomous aerial robots like the one you see flying here. Unlike the commercially available drones that you can buy today, this robot doesn't have any GPS on board. So without GPS, it's hard for robots like this to determine their position. This robot uses onboard sensors, cameras and laser scanners, to scan the environment. It detects features from the environment, and it determines where it is relative to those features, using a method of triangulation. And then it can assemble all these features into a map, like you see behind me. And this map then allows the robot to understand where the obstacles are and navigate in a collision-free manner.What I want to show you next is a set of experiments we did inside our laboratory, where this robot was able to go for longer distances. So here you'll see, on the top right, what the robot sees with the camera. And on the main screen — and of course this is sped up by a factor of four — on the main screen you'll see the map that it's building. So this is a high-resolution map of the corridor around our laboratory. And in a minute you'll see it enter our lab, which is recognizable by the clutter that you see.(Laughter)But the main point I want to convey to you is that these robots are capable of building high-resolution maps at five centimeters resolution, allowing somebody who is outside the lab, or outside the building to deploy these without actually going inside, and trying to infer what happens inside the building.Now there's one problem with robots like this. The first problem is it's pretty big. Because it's big, it's heavy. And these robots consume about 100 watts per pound. And this makes for a very short mission life. The second problem is that these robots have onboard sensors that end up being very expensive — a laser scanner, a camera and the processors. That drives up the cost of this robot.So we asked ourselves a question: what consumer product can you buy in an electronics store that is inexpensive, that's lightweight, that has sensing onboard and computation? And we invented the flying phone.(Laughter)So this robot uses a Samsung Galaxy smartphone that you can buy off the shelf, and all you need is an app that you can download from our app store. And you can see this robot reading the letters, "TED" in this case, looking at the corners of the "T" and the "E" and then triangulating off of that, flying autonomously. That joystick is just there to make sure if the robot goes crazy, Giuseppe can kill it.(Laughter)In addition to building these small robots, we also experiment with aggressive behaviors, like you see here. So this robot is now traveling at two to three meters per second, pitching and rolling aggressively as it changes direction. The main point is we can have smaller robots that can go faster and then travel in these very unstructured environments.And in this next video, just like you see this bird, an eagle, gracefully coordinating its wings, its eyes and feet to grab prey out of the water, our robot can go fishing, too.(Laughter)In this case, this is a Philly cheesesteak hoagie that it's grabbing out of thin air.(Laughter)So you can see this robot going at about three meters per second, which is faster than walking speed, coordinating its arms, its claws and its flight with split-second timing to achieve this maneuver. In another experiment, I want to show you how the robot adapts its flight to control its suspended payload, whose length is actually larger than the width of the window. So in order to accomplish this, it actually has to pitch and adjust the altitude and swing the payload through. But of course we want to make these even smaller, and we're inspired in particular by honeybees. So if you look at honeybees, and this is a slowed down video, they're so small, the inertia is so lightweight —(Laughter)that they don't care — they bounce off my hand, for example. This is a little robot that mimics the honeybee behavior. And smaller is better, because along with the small size you get lower inertia. Along with lower inertia —(Robot buzzing, laughter)along with lower inertia, you're resistant to collisions. And that makes you more robust. So just like these honeybees, we build small robots. And this particular one is only 25 grams in weight. It consumes only six watts of power. And it can travel up to six meters per second. So if I normalize that to its size, it's like a Boeing 787 traveling ten times the speed of sound.(Laughter)And I want to show you an example. This is probably the first planned mid-air collision, at one-twentieth normal speed. These are going at a relative speed of two meters per second, and this illustrates the basic principle. The two-gram carbon fiber cage around it prevents the propellers from entangling, but essentially the collision is absorbed and the robot responds to the collisions. And so small also means safe. In my lab, as we developed these robots, we start off with these big robots and then now we're down to these small robots. And if you plot a histogram of the number of Band-Aids we've ordered in the past, that sort of tailed off now. Because these robots are really safe.The small size has some disadvantages, and nature has found a number of ways to compensate for these disadvantages. The basic idea is they aggregate to form large groups, or swarms. So, similarly, in our lab, we try to create artificial robot swarms. And this is quite challenging because now you have to think about networks of robots. And within each robot, you have to think about the interplay of sensing, communication, computation — and this network then becomes quite difficult to control and manage. So from nature we take away three organizing principles that essentially allow us to develop our algorithms. The first idea is that robots need to be aware of their neighbors. They need to be able to sense and communicate with their neighbors.So this video illustrates the basic idea. You have four robots — one of the robots has actually been hijacked by a human operator, literally. But because the robots interact with each other, they sense their neighbors, they essentially follow. And here there's a single person able to lead this network of followers. So again, it's not because all the robots know where they're supposed to go. It's because they're just reacting to the positions of their neighbors.(Laughter)So the next experiment illustrates the second organizing principle. And this principle has to do with the principle of anonymity. Here the key idea is that the robots are agnostic to the identities of their neighbors. They're asked to form a circular shape, and no matter how many robots you introduce into the formation, or how many robots you pull out, each robot is simply reacting to its neighbor. It's aware of the fact that it needs to form the circular shape, but collaborating with its neighbors it forms the shape without central coordination. Now if you put these ideas together, the third idea is that we essentially give these robots mathematical descriptions of the shape they need to execute. And these shapes can be varying as a function of time, and you'll see these robots start from a circular formation, change into a rectangular formation, stretch into a straight line, back into an ellipse. And they do this with the same kind of split-second coordination that you see in natural swarms, in nature.So why work with swarms? Let me tell you about two applications that we are very interested in. The first one has to do with agriculture, which is probably the biggest problem that we're facing worldwide. As you well know, one in every seven persons in this earth is malnourished. Most of the land that we can cultivate has already been cultivated. And the efficiency of most systems in the world is improving, but our production system efficiency is actually declining. And that's mostly because of water shortage, crop diseases, climate change and a couple of other things.So what can robots do? Well, we adopt an approach that's called Precision Farming in the community. And the basic idea is that we fly aerial robots through orchards, and then we build precision models of individual plants. So just like personalized medicine, while you might imagine wanting to treat every patient individually, what we'd like to do is build models of individual plants and then tell the farmer what kind of inputs every plant needs — the inputs in this case being water, fertilizer and pesticide. Here you'll see robots traveling through an apple orchard, and in a minute you'll see two of its companions doing the same thing on the left side. And what they're doing is essentially building a map of the orchard. Within the map is a map of every plant in this orchard.(Robot buzzing)Let's see what those maps look like. In the next video, you'll see the cameras that are being used on this robot. On the top-left is essentially a standard color camera. On the left-center is an infrared camera. And on the bottom-left is a thermal camera. And on the main panel, you're seeing a three-dimensional reconstruction of every tree in the orchard as the sensors fly right past the trees. Armed with information like this, we can do several things. The first and possibly the most important thing we can do is very simple: count the number of fruits on every tree. By doing this, you tell the farmer how many fruits she has in every tree and allow her to estimate the yield in the orchard, optimizing the production chain downstream.The second thing we can do is take models of plants, construct three-dimensional reconstructions, and from that estimate the canopy size, and then correlate the canopy size to the amount of leaf area on every plant. And this is called the leaf area index. So if you know this leaf area index, you essentially have a measure of how much photosynthesis is possible in every plant, which again tells you how healthy each plant is. By combining visual and infrared information, we can also compute indices such as NDVI. And in this particular case, you can essentially see there are some crops that are not doing as well as other crops. This is easily discernible from imagery, not just visual imagery but combining both visual imagery and infrared imagery.And then lastly, one thing we're interested in doing is detecting the early onset of chlorosis — and this is an orange tree — which is essentially seen by yellowing of leaves. But robots flying overhead can easily spot this autonomously and then report to the farmer that he or she has a problem in this section of the orchard.Systems like this can really help, and we're projecting yields that can improve by about ten percent and, more importantly, decrease the amount of inputs such as water by 25 percent by using aerial robot swarms.Lastly, I want you to applaud the people who actually create the future, Yash Mulgaonkar, Sikang Liu and Giuseppe Loianno, who are responsible for the three demonstrations that you saw.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.238 --> 00:00:16.894
In my lab, we build
autonomous aerial robots

00:00:16.918 --> 00:00:18.798
like the one you see flying here.

00:00:20.678 --> 00:00:24.374
Unlike the commercially available drones
that you can buy today,

00:00:24.398 --> 00:00:27.038
this robot doesn't have any GPS on board.

00:00:28.118 --> 00:00:29.334
So without GPS,

00:00:29.358 --> 00:00:32.638
it's hard for robots like this
to determine their position.

00:00:34.198 --> 00:00:38.934
This robot uses onboard sensors,
cameras and laser scanners,

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.654
to scan the environment.

00:00:40.678 --> 00:00:43.734
It detects features from the environment,

00:00:43.758 --> 00:00:46.494
and it determines where it is
relative to those features,

00:00:46.518 --> 00:00:48.654
using a method of triangulation.

00:00:48.678 --> 00:00:52.134
And then it can assemble
all these features into a map,

00:00:52.158 --> 00:00:53.894
like you see behind me.

00:00:53.918 --> 00:00:57.854
And this map then allows the robot
to understand where the obstacles are

00:00:57.878 --> 00:01:00.598
and navigate in a collision-free manner.

00:01:01.118 --> 00:01:03.214
What I want to show you next

00:01:03.238 --> 00:01:06.454
is a set of experiments
we did inside our laboratory,

00:01:06.478 --> 00:01:09.958
where this robot was able
to go for longer distances.

00:01:10.358 --> 00:01:15.374
So here you'll see, on the top right,
what the robot sees with the camera.

00:01:15.398 --> 00:01:16.614
And on the main screen --

00:01:16.638 --> 00:01:19.094
and of course this is sped up
by a factor of four --

00:01:19.118 --> 00:01:21.785
on the main screen you'll see
the map that it's building.

00:01:21.809 --> 00:01:26.094
So this is a high-resolution map
of the corridor around our laboratory.

00:01:26.118 --> 00:01:28.454
And in a minute
you'll see it enter our lab,

00:01:28.478 --> 00:01:31.334
which is recognizable
by the clutter that you see.

00:01:31.358 --> 00:01:32.374
(Laughter)

00:01:32.398 --> 00:01:34.405
But the main point I want to convey to you

00:01:34.430 --> 00:01:38.014
is that these robots are capable
of building high-resolution maps

00:01:38.038 --> 00:01:40.534
at five centimeters resolution,

00:01:40.558 --> 00:01:44.734
allowing somebody who is outside the lab,
or outside the building

00:01:44.758 --> 00:01:47.974
to deploy these
without actually going inside,

00:01:47.998 --> 00:01:51.758
and trying to infer
what happens inside the building.

00:01:52.358 --> 00:01:54.598
Now there's one problem
with robots like this.

00:01:55.558 --> 00:01:57.758
The first problem is it's pretty big.

00:01:58.078 --> 00:01:59.758
Because it's big, it's heavy.

00:02:00.598 --> 00:02:03.638
And these robots consume
about 100 watts per pound.

00:02:04.318 --> 00:02:06.598
And this makes for
a very short mission life.

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.414
The second problem

00:02:09.438 --> 00:02:13.334
is that these robots have onboard sensors
that end up being very expensive --

00:02:13.358 --> 00:02:16.798
a laser scanner, a camera
and the processors.

00:02:17.238 --> 00:02:20.278
That drives up the cost of this robot.

00:02:21.398 --> 00:02:24.054
So we asked ourselves a question:

00:02:24.078 --> 00:02:27.854
what consumer product
can you buy in an electronics store

00:02:27.878 --> 00:02:34.158
that is inexpensive, that's lightweight,
that has sensing onboard and computation?

00:02:36.038 --> 00:02:38.694
And we invented the flying phone.

00:02:38.718 --> 00:02:40.654
(Laughter)

00:02:40.678 --> 00:02:46.854
So this robot uses a Samsung Galaxy
smartphone that you can buy off the shelf,

00:02:46.878 --> 00:02:50.894
and all you need is an app that you
can download from our app store.

00:02:50.918 --> 00:02:55.134
And you can see this robot
reading the letters, "TED" in this case,

00:02:55.158 --> 00:02:58.094
looking at the corners
of the "T" and the "E"

00:02:58.118 --> 00:03:01.598
and then triangulating off of that,
flying autonomously.

00:03:02.678 --> 00:03:05.934
That joystick is just there
to make sure if the robot goes crazy,

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.374
Giuseppe can kill it.

00:03:07.398 --> 00:03:09.038
(Laughter)

00:03:10.878 --> 00:03:14.694
In addition to building
these small robots,

00:03:14.718 --> 00:03:19.518
we also experiment with aggressive
behaviors, like you see here.

00:03:19.878 --> 00:03:25.174
So this robot is now traveling
at two to three meters per second,

00:03:25.198 --> 00:03:28.694
pitching and rolling aggressively
as it changes direction.

00:03:28.718 --> 00:03:32.974
The main point is we can have
smaller robots that can go faster

00:03:32.998 --> 00:03:35.958
and then travel in these
very unstructured environments.

00:03:37.078 --> 00:03:39.134
And in this next video,

00:03:39.158 --> 00:03:45.054
just like you see this bird, an eagle,
gracefully coordinating its wings,

00:03:45.078 --> 00:03:49.374
its eyes and feet
to grab prey out of the water,

00:03:49.398 --> 00:03:51.294
our robot can go fishing, too.

00:03:51.318 --> 00:03:52.814
(Laughter)

00:03:52.838 --> 00:03:56.894
In this case, this is a Philly cheesesteak
hoagie that it's grabbing out of thin air.

00:03:56.918 --> 00:03:59.318
(Laughter)

00:03:59.638 --> 00:04:02.934
So you can see this robot
going at about three meters per second,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:08.094
which is faster than walking speed,
coordinating its arms, its claws

00:04:08.118 --> 00:04:12.238
and its flight with split-second timing
to achieve this maneuver.

00:04:14.078 --> 00:04:15.294
In another experiment,

00:04:15.318 --> 00:04:18.974
I want to show you
how the robot adapts its flight

00:04:18.998 --> 00:04:21.374
to control its suspended payload,

00:04:21.398 --> 00:04:25.198
whose length is actually larger
than the width of the window.

00:04:25.638 --> 00:04:27.334
So in order to accomplish this,

00:04:27.358 --> 00:04:31.054
it actually has to pitch
and adjust the altitude

00:04:31.078 --> 00:04:33.398
and swing the payload through.

00:04:38.878 --> 00:04:41.174
But of course we want
to make these even smaller,

00:04:41.198 --> 00:04:44.214
and we're inspired
in particular by honeybees.

00:04:44.238 --> 00:04:47.494
So if you look at honeybees,
and this is a slowed down video,

00:04:47.518 --> 00:04:51.238
they're so small,
the inertia is so lightweight --

00:04:51.918 --> 00:04:53.094
(Laughter)

00:04:53.118 --> 00:04:56.654
that they don't care --
they bounce off my hand, for example.

00:04:56.678 --> 00:04:59.838
This is a little robot
that mimics the honeybee behavior.

00:05:00.558 --> 00:05:01.774
And smaller is better,

00:05:01.798 --> 00:05:05.334
because along with the small size
you get lower inertia.

00:05:05.358 --> 00:05:06.894
Along with lower inertia --

00:05:06.918 --> 00:05:09.774
(Robot buzzing, laughter)

00:05:09.798 --> 00:05:12.614
along with lower inertia,
you're resistant to collisions.

00:05:12.638 --> 00:05:14.358
And that makes you more robust.

00:05:15.758 --> 00:05:18.414
So just like these honeybees,
we build small robots.

00:05:18.438 --> 00:05:21.814
And this particular one
is only 25 grams in weight.

00:05:21.838 --> 00:05:23.998
It consumes only six watts of power.

00:05:24.398 --> 00:05:26.934
And it can travel
up to six meters per second.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.294
So if I normalize that to its size,

00:05:29.318 --> 00:05:32.958
it's like a Boeing 787 traveling
ten times the speed of sound.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.054
(Laughter)

00:05:38.078 --> 00:05:39.998
And I want to show you an example.

00:05:40.798 --> 00:05:46.054
This is probably the first planned mid-air
collision, at one-twentieth normal speed.

00:05:46.078 --> 00:05:48.936
These are going at a relative speed
of two meters per second,

00:05:48.960 --> 00:05:51.440
and this illustrates the basic principle.

00:05:52.158 --> 00:05:57.134
The two-gram carbon fiber cage around it
prevents the propellers from entangling,

00:05:57.158 --> 00:06:02.454
but essentially the collision is absorbed
and the robot responds to the collisions.

00:06:02.478 --> 00:06:05.038
And so small also means safe.

00:06:05.358 --> 00:06:07.374
In my lab, as we developed these robots,

00:06:07.398 --> 00:06:09.018
we start off with these big robots

00:06:09.042 --> 00:06:11.854
and then now we're down
to these small robots.

00:06:11.878 --> 00:06:15.334
And if you plot a histogram
of the number of Band-Aids we've ordered

00:06:15.358 --> 00:06:17.934
in the past, that sort of tailed off now.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.918
Because these robots are really safe.

00:06:20.718 --> 00:06:23.174
The small size has some disadvantages,

00:06:23.198 --> 00:06:27.278
and nature has found a number of ways
to compensate for these disadvantages.

00:06:27.918 --> 00:06:31.918
The basic idea is they aggregate
to form large groups, or swarms.

00:06:32.278 --> 00:06:36.254
So, similarly, in our lab,
we try to create artificial robot swarms.

00:06:36.278 --> 00:06:37.659
And this is quite challenging

00:06:37.683 --> 00:06:41.003
because now you have to think
about networks of robots.

00:06:41.318 --> 00:06:42.614
And within each robot,

00:06:42.638 --> 00:06:48.254
you have to think about the interplay
of sensing, communication, computation --

00:06:48.278 --> 00:06:53.238
and this network then becomes
quite difficult to control and manage.

00:06:54.118 --> 00:06:57.414
So from nature we take away
three organizing principles

00:06:57.438 --> 00:07:00.598
that essentially allow us
to develop our algorithms.

00:07:01.598 --> 00:07:06.134
The first idea is that robots
need to be aware of their neighbors.

00:07:06.158 --> 00:07:09.598
They need to be able to sense
and communicate with their neighbors.

00:07:09.998 --> 00:07:12.654
So this video illustrates the basic idea.

00:07:12.678 --> 00:07:13.974
You have four robots --

00:07:13.998 --> 00:07:18.238
one of the robots has actually been
hijacked by a human operator, literally.

00:07:19.175 --> 00:07:21.414
But because the robots
interact with each other,

00:07:21.438 --> 00:07:23.094
they sense their neighbors,

00:07:23.118 --> 00:07:24.414
they essentially follow.

00:07:24.438 --> 00:07:29.798
And here there's a single person
able to lead this network of followers.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:37.014
So again, it's not because all the robots
know where they're supposed to go.

00:07:37.038 --> 00:07:41.358
It's because they're just reacting
to the positions of their neighbors.

00:07:43.678 --> 00:07:47.798
(Laughter)

00:07:48.238 --> 00:07:53.478
So the next experiment illustrates
the second organizing principle.

00:07:54.878 --> 00:07:58.678
And this principle has to do
with the principle of anonymity.

00:07:59.358 --> 00:08:03.654
Here the key idea is that

00:08:03.678 --> 00:08:07.918
the robots are agnostic
to the identities of their neighbors.

00:08:08.398 --> 00:08:11.014
They're asked to form a circular shape,

00:08:11.038 --> 00:08:14.334
and no matter how many robots
you introduce into the formation,

00:08:14.358 --> 00:08:16.934
or how many robots you pull out,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.094
each robot is simply
reacting to its neighbor.

00:08:20.118 --> 00:08:25.094
It's aware of the fact that it needs
to form the circular shape,

00:08:25.118 --> 00:08:26.894
but collaborating with its neighbors

00:08:26.918 --> 00:08:30.638
it forms the shape
without central coordination.

00:08:31.478 --> 00:08:33.894
Now if you put these ideas together,

00:08:33.918 --> 00:08:37.814
the third idea is that we
essentially give these robots

00:08:37.838 --> 00:08:42.134
mathematical descriptions
of the shape they need to execute.

00:08:42.158 --> 00:08:45.654
And these shapes can be varying
as a function of time,

00:08:45.678 --> 00:08:50.174
and you'll see these robots
start from a circular formation,

00:08:50.198 --> 00:08:53.454
change into a rectangular formation,
stretch into a straight line,

00:08:53.478 --> 00:08:54.853
back into an ellipse.

00:08:54.877 --> 00:08:58.494
And they do this with the same
kind of split-second coordination

00:08:58.518 --> 00:09:01.798
that you see in natural swarms, in nature.

00:09:03.038 --> 00:09:05.174
So why work with swarms?

00:09:05.198 --> 00:09:09.318
Let me tell you about two applications
that we are very interested in.

00:09:10.118 --> 00:09:12.494
The first one has to do with agriculture,

00:09:12.518 --> 00:09:15.878
which is probably the biggest problem
that we're facing worldwide.

00:09:16.718 --> 00:09:17.974
As you well know,

00:09:17.998 --> 00:09:21.518
one in every seven persons
in this earth is malnourished.

00:09:21.878 --> 00:09:25.358
Most of the land that we can cultivate
has already been cultivated.

00:09:25.918 --> 00:09:29.134
And the efficiency of most systems
in the world is improving,

00:09:29.158 --> 00:09:32.678
but our production system
efficiency is actually declining.

00:09:33.038 --> 00:09:37.254
And that's mostly because of water
shortage, crop diseases, climate change

00:09:37.278 --> 00:09:38.798
and a couple of other things.

00:09:39.318 --> 00:09:40.798
So what can robots do?

00:09:41.158 --> 00:09:45.774
Well, we adopt an approach that's
called Precision Farming in the community.

00:09:45.798 --> 00:09:51.174
And the basic idea is that we fly
aerial robots through orchards,

00:09:51.198 --> 00:09:54.318
and then we build
precision models of individual plants.

00:09:54.787 --> 00:09:56.454
So just like personalized medicine,

00:09:56.478 --> 00:10:01.294
while you might imagine wanting
to treat every patient individually,

00:10:01.318 --> 00:10:05.014
what we'd like to do is build
models of individual plants

00:10:05.038 --> 00:10:09.174
and then tell the farmer
what kind of inputs every plant needs --

00:10:09.198 --> 00:10:13.638
the inputs in this case being water,
fertilizer and pesticide.

00:10:14.598 --> 00:10:18.214
Here you'll see robots
traveling through an apple orchard,

00:10:18.238 --> 00:10:20.494
and in a minute you'll see
two of its companions

00:10:20.518 --> 00:10:22.328
doing the same thing on the left side.

00:10:22.758 --> 00:10:26.414
And what they're doing is essentially
building a map of the orchard.

00:10:26.438 --> 00:10:29.254
Within the map is a map
of every plant in this orchard.

00:10:29.278 --> 00:10:30.934
(Robot buzzing)

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.854
Let's see what those maps look like.

00:10:32.878 --> 00:10:37.174
In the next video, you'll see the cameras
that are being used on this robot.

00:10:37.198 --> 00:10:40.438
On the top-left is essentially
a standard color camera.

00:10:41.598 --> 00:10:44.894
On the left-center is an infrared camera.

00:10:44.918 --> 00:10:48.694
And on the bottom-left
is a thermal camera.

00:10:48.718 --> 00:10:52.054
And on the main panel, you're seeing
a three-dimensional reconstruction

00:10:52.078 --> 00:10:58.198
of every tree in the orchard
as the sensors fly right past the trees.

00:10:59.598 --> 00:11:03.638
Armed with information like this,
we can do several things.

00:11:04.158 --> 00:11:08.414
The first and possibly the most important
thing we can do is very simple:

00:11:08.438 --> 00:11:10.878
count the number of fruits on every tree.

00:11:11.478 --> 00:11:16.014
By doing this, you tell the farmer
how many fruits she has in every tree

00:11:16.038 --> 00:11:20.294
and allow her to estimate
the yield in the orchard,

00:11:20.318 --> 00:11:23.158
optimizing the production
chain downstream.

00:11:23.598 --> 00:11:25.214
The second thing we can do

00:11:25.238 --> 00:11:29.734
is take models of plants, construct
three-dimensional reconstructions,

00:11:29.758 --> 00:11:32.294
and from that estimate the canopy size,

00:11:32.318 --> 00:11:36.094
and then correlate the canopy size
to the amount of leaf area on every plant.

00:11:36.118 --> 00:11:38.294
And this is called the leaf area index.

00:11:38.318 --> 00:11:40.254
So if you know this leaf area index,

00:11:40.278 --> 00:11:45.734
you essentially have a measure of how much
photosynthesis is possible in every plant,

00:11:45.758 --> 00:11:48.638
which again tells you
how healthy each plant is.

00:11:49.478 --> 00:11:53.694
By combining visual
and infrared information,

00:11:53.718 --> 00:11:57.014
we can also compute indices such as NDVI.

00:11:57.038 --> 00:11:59.854
And in this particular case,
you can essentially see

00:11:59.878 --> 00:12:02.894
there are some crops that are
not doing as well as other crops.

00:12:02.918 --> 00:12:06.974
This is easily discernible from imagery,

00:12:06.998 --> 00:12:09.214
not just visual imagery but combining

00:12:09.238 --> 00:12:12.014
both visual imagery and infrared imagery.

00:12:12.038 --> 00:12:13.374
And then lastly,

00:12:13.398 --> 00:12:17.414
one thing we're interested in doing is
detecting the early onset of chlorosis --

00:12:17.438 --> 00:12:18.934
and this is an orange tree --

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.518
which is essentially seen
by yellowing of leaves.

00:12:21.838 --> 00:12:25.734
But robots flying overhead
can easily spot this autonomously

00:12:25.758 --> 00:12:28.694
and then report to the farmer
that he or she has a problem

00:12:28.718 --> 00:12:30.238

00:12:30.758 --> 00:12:33.454
Systems like this can really help,

00:12:33.478 --> 00:12:39.294
and we're projecting yields
that can improve by about ten percent

00:12:39.318 --> 00:12:42.534
and, more importantly, decrease
the amount of inputs such as water

00:12:42.558 --> 00:12:45.838
by 25 percent by using
aerial robot swarms.

00:12:47.158 --> 00:12:52.894
Lastly, I want you to applaud
the people who actually create the future,

00:12:52.918 --> 00:12:57.838
Yash Mulgaonkar, Sikang Liu
and Giuseppe Loianno,

00:12:57.878 --> 00:13:01.374
who are responsible for the three
demonstrations that you saw.

00:13:01.398 --> 00:13:02.574
Thank you.

00:13:02.598 --> 00:13:08.518

title: Why medicine often has dangerous side effects for women
transcript: We all go to doctors. And we do so with trust and blind faith that the test they are ordering and the medications they're prescribing are based upon evidence — evidence that's designed to help us. However, the reality is that that hasn't always been the case for everyone. What if I told you that the medical science discovered over the past century has been based on only half the population?I'm an emergency medicine doctor. I was trained to be prepared in a medical emergency. It's about saving lives. How cool is that? OK, there's a lot of runny noses and stubbed toes, but no matter who walks through the door to the ER, we order the same tests, we prescribe the same medication, without ever thinking about the sex or gender of our patients. Why would we? We were never taught that there were any differences between men and women.A recent Government Accountability study revealed that 80 percent of the drugs withdrawn from the market are due to side effects on women. So let's think about that for a minute. Why are we discovering side effects on women only after a drug has been released to the market? Do you know that it takes years for a drug to go from an idea to being tested on cells in a laboratory, to animal studies, to then clinical trials on humans, finally to go through a regulatory approval process, to be available for your doctor to prescribe to you? Not to mention the millions and billions of dollars of funding it takes to go through that process. So why are we discovering unacceptable side effects on half the population after that has gone through? What's happening?Well, it turns out that those cells used in that laboratory, they're male cells, and the animals used in the animal studies were male animals, and the clinical trials have been performed almost exclusively on men.How is it that the male model became our framework for medical research? Let's look at an example that has been popularized in the media, and it has to do with the sleep aid Ambien. Ambien was released on the market over 20 years ago, and since then, hundreds of millions of prescriptions have been written, primarily to women, because women suffer more sleep disorders than men. They don't have the constantly fluctuating levels of hormones that could disrupt clean data they could get if they had only men. It was easier. It was cheaper. 00:13:57.104 --> 00:14:01.496
It's essentially changing the way
we think about medicine

00:14:01.520 --> 00:14:04.517
and health and research.

00:14:05.669 --> 00:14:08.805
It's changing our relationship
to the health care system.

00:14:09.718 --> 00:14:12.606
But there's no going back.

00:14:13.297 --> 00:14:16.996
We now know just enough

00:14:17.020 --> 00:14:19.376
to know that we weren't doing it right.

00:14:21.630 --> 00:14:23.948
Martin Luther King, Jr. has said,

00:14:23.972 --> 00:14:28.621
"Change does not roll in
on the wheels of inevitability,

00:14:28.645 --> 00:14:30.819
but comes through continuous struggle."

00:14:32.272 --> 00:14:35.002
And the first step
towards change is awareness.

00:14:36.074 --> 00:14:40.152
This is not just about improving
medical care for women.

00:14:40.660 --> 00:14:45.619
This is about personalized,
individualized health care for everyone.

00:14:47.048 --> 00:14:53.150
This awareness has the power to transform
medical care for men and women.

00:14:54.785 --> 00:15:00.473
And from now on, I want you
to ask your doctors

00:15:00.497 --> 00:15:04.774
whether the treatments you are receiving
are specific to your sex and gender.

00:15:06.204 --> 00:15:08.893
They may not know the answer --

00:15:08.917 --> 00:15:10.083
yet.

00:15:11.059 --> 00:15:14.921
But the conversation has begun,
and together we can all learn.

00:15:15.755 --> 00:15:20.132
Remember, for me
and my colleagues in this field,

00:15:20.156 --> 00:15:22.433
your sex and gender matter.

00:15:23.337 --> 00:15:24.489
Thank you.

title: Two nameless bodies washed up on the beach. Here are their stories
transcript: So this right here is the tiny village of Elle, close to Lista. It's right at the southernmost tip of Norway. And on January 2 this year, an elderly guy who lives in the village, he went out to see what was cast ashore during a recent storm. And on a patch of grass right next to the water's edge, he found a wetsuit. It was grey and black, and he thought it looked cheap. Out of each leg of the wetsuit there were sticking two white bones. It was clearly the remains of a human being.And usually, in Norway, dead people are identified quickly. So the police started searching through missing reports from the local area, national missing reports, and looked for accidents with a possible connection. They found nothing. So they ran a DNA profile, and they started searching internationally through Interpol. Nothing. This was a person that nobody seemed to be missing. It was an invisible life heading for a nameless grave. But then, after a month, the police in Norway got a message from the police in the Netherlands. A couple of months earlier, they had found a body, in an identical wetsuit, and they had no idea who this person was. But the police in the Netherlands managed to trace the wetsuit by an RFID chip that was sewn in the suit. So they were then able to tell that both wetsuits were bought by the same customer at the same time, October 7, 2014, in the French city of Calais by the English Channel. But this was all they were able to figure out. The customer paid cash. There was no surveillance footage from the shop. So it became a cold case.We heard this story, and it triggered me and my colleague, photographer Tomm Christiansen, and we of course had the obvious question: who were these people? At the time, I'd barely heard about Calais, but it took about two or three seconds to figure out Calais is basically known for two things. It's the spot in continental Europe closest to Britain, and a lot of migrants and refugees are staying in this camp and are trying desperately to cross over to Britain. And right there was a plausible theory about the identity of the two people, and the police made this theory as well. Because if you or I or anybody else with a firm connection to Europe goes missing off the coast of France, people would just know. Your friends or family would report you missing, the police would come search for you, the media would know, and there would be pictures of you on lampposts. It's difficult to disappear without a trace. But if you just fled the war in Syria, and your family, if you have any family left, don't necessarily know where you are, and you're staying here illegally amongst thousands of others who come and go every day. Well, if you disappear one day, nobody will notice. The police won't come search for you because nobody knows you're gone.And this is what happened to Shadi Omar Kataf and Mouaz Al Balkhi from Syria.Me and Tomm went to Calais for the first time in April this year, and after three months of investigation, we were able to tell the story about how these two young men fled the war in Syria, ended up stuck in Calais, bought wetsuits and drowned in what seems to have been an attempt to swim across the English Channel in order to reach England. It is a story about the fact that everybody has a name, everybody has a story, everybody is someone. But it is also a story about what it's like to be a refugee in Europe today.So this is where we started our search. This is in Calais. Right now, between 3,500 and 5,000 people are living here under horrible conditions. It has been dubbed the worst refugee camp in Europe. Limited access to food, limited access to water, limited access to health care. Disease and infections are widespread. And they're all stuck here because they're trying to get to England in order to claim asylum. And they do that by hiding in the back of trucks headed for the ferry, or the Eurotunnel, or they sneak inside the tunnel terminal at night to try to hide on the trains.Most want to go to Britain because they know the language, and so they figure it would be easier to restart their lives from there. They want to work, they want to study, they want to be able to continue their lives. A lot of these people are highly educated and skilled workers. If you go to Calais and talk to refugees, you'll meet lawyers, politicians, engineers, graphic designers, farmers, soldiers. You've got the whole spectrum. But who all of these people are usually gets lost in the way we talk about refugees and migrants, because we usually do that in statistics.So you have 60 million refugees globally. About half a million have made the crossing over the Mediterranean into Europe so far this year, and roughly 4,000 are staying in Calais. But these are numbers, and the numbers don't say anything about who these people are, where they came from, or why they're here.And first, I want to tell you about one of them. This is 22-year-old Mouaz Al Balkhi from Syria. We first heard about him after being in Calais the first time looking for answers to the theory of the two dead bodies. And after a while, we heard this story about a Syrian man who was living in Bradford in England, and had been desperately searching for his nephew Mouaz for months. And it turned out the last time anybody had heard anything from Mouaz was October 7, 2014. That was the same date the wetsuits were bought. So we flew over there and we met the uncle and we did DNA samples of him, and later on got additional DNA samples from Mouaz's closest relative who now lives in Jordan. The analysis concluded the body who was found in a wetsuit on a beach in the Netherlands was actually Mouaz Al Balkhi. And while we were doing all this investigation, we got to know Mouaz's story. He was born in the Syrian capital of Damascus in 1991. He was raised in a middle class family, and his father in the middle there is a chemical engineer who spent 11 years in prison for belonging to the political opposition in Syria. While his father was in prison, Mouaz took responsibility and he cared for his three sisters. They said he was that kind of guy. Mouaz studied to become an electrical engineer at the University of Damascus.So a couple of years into the Syrian war, the family fled Damascus and went to the neighboring country, Jordan. Their father had problems finding work in Jordan, and Mouaz could not continue his studies, so he figured, "OK, the best thing I can do to help my family would be to go somewhere where I can finish my studies and find work." So he goes to Turkey.In Turkey, he's not accepted at a university, and once he had left Jordan as a refugee, he was not allowed to reenter. So then he decides to head for the UK, where his uncle lives. He makes it into Algeria, walks into Libya, pays a people smuggler to help him with the crossing into Italy by boat, and from there on he heads to Dunkirk, the city right next to Calais by the English Channel. We know he made at least 12 failed attempts to cross the English Channel by hiding in a truck. But at some point, he must have given up all hope. The last night we know he was alive, he spent at a cheap hotel close to the train station in Dunkirk. We found his name in the records, and he seems to have stayed there alone. The day after, he went into Calais, entered a sports shop a couple of minutes before 8 o'clock in the evening, along with Shadi Kataf. They both bought wetsuits, and the woman in the shop was the last person we know of to have seen them alive. We have tried to figure out where Shadi met Mouaz, but we weren't able to do that. But they do have a similar story. We first heard about Shadi after a cousin of his, living in Germany, had read an Arabic translation of the story made of Mouaz on Facebook. So we got in touch with him. Shadi, a couple of years older than Mouaz, was also raised in Damascus. He was a working kind of guy. He ran a tire repair shop and later worked in a printing company. He lived with his extended family, but their house got bombed early in the war. So the family fled to an area of Damascus known as Camp Yarmouk.Yarmouk is being described as the worst place to live on planet Earth. They've been bombed by the military, they've been besieged, they've been stormed by ISIS and they've been cut off from supplies for years. There was a UN official who visited last year, and he said, "They ate all the grass so there was no grass left." Out of a population of 150,000, only 18,000 are believed to still be left in Yarmouk. Shadi and his sisters got out. The parents are still stuck inside.So Shadi and one of his sisters, they fled to Libya. This was after the fall of Gaddafi, but before Libya turned into full-blown civil war. And in this last remaining sort of stability in Libya, Shadi took up scuba diving, and he seemed to spend most of his time underwater. He fell completely in love with the ocean, so when he finally decided that he could no longer be in Libya, late August 2014, he hoped to find work as a diver when he reached Italy. Reality was not that easy. We don't know much about his travels because he had a hard time communicating with his family, but we do know that he struggled. And by the end of September, he was living on the streets somewhere in France. On October 7, he calls his cousin in Belgium, and explains his situation. He said, "I'm in Calais. I need you to come get my backpack and my laptop. I can't afford to pay the people smugglers to help me with the crossing to Britain, but I will go buy a wetsuit and I will swim." His cousin, of course, tried to warn him not to, but Shadi's battery on the phone went flat, and his phone was never switched on again. What was left of Shadi was found nearly three months later, 800 kilometers away in a wetsuit on a beach in Norway. He's still waiting for his funeral in Norway, and none of his family will be able to attend.Many may think that the story about Shadi and Mouaz is a story about death, but I don't agree. To me, this is a story about two questions that I think we all share: what is a better life, and what am I willing to do to achieve it? And to me, and probably a lot of you, a better life would mean being able to do more of what we think of as meaningful, whether that be spending more time with your family and friends, travel to an exotic place, or just getting money to buy that cool new device or a pair of new sneakers. And this is all within our reach pretty easily.But if you are fleeing a war zone, the answers to those two questions are dramatically different. A better life is a life in safety. It's a life in dignity. A better life means not having your house bombed, not fearing being kidnapped. It means being able to send your children to school, go to university, or just find work to be able to provide for yourself and the ones you love. A better life would be a future of some possibilities compared to nearly none, and that's a strong motivation. And I have no trouble imagining that after spending weeks or even months as a second-grade citizen, living on the streets or in a horrible makeshift camp with a stupid, racist name like "The Jungle," most of us would be willing to do just about anything. If I could ask Shadi and Mouaz the second they stepped into the freezing waters of the English Channel, they would probably say, "This is worth the risk," because they could no longer see any other option. And that's desperation, but that's the reality of living as a refugee in Western Europe in 2015.Thank you.(Applause)Bruno Giussani: Thank you, Anders. This is Tomm Christiansen, who took most of the pictures you have seen and they've done reporting together. Tomm, you two have been back to Calais recently. This was the third trip. It was after the publication of the article. What has changed? What have you seen there?Tomm Christiansen: The first time we were in Calais, it was about 1,500 refugees there. They had a difficult time, but they were positive, they had hope. The last time, the camp has grown, maybe four or five thousand people. It seemed more permanent, NGOs have arrived, a small school has opened. But the thing is that the refugees have stayed for a longer time, and the French government has managed to seal off the borders better, so now The Jungle is growing, along with the despair and hopelessness among the refugees.BG: Are you planning to go back? And continue the reporting?TC: Yes.BG: Anders, I'm a former journalist, and to me, it's amazing that in the current climate of slashing budgets and publishers in crisis, Dagbladet has consented so many resources for this story, which tells a lot about newspapers taking the responsibility, but how did you sell it to your editors?Anders Fjellberg: It wasn't easy at first, because we weren't able to know what we actually could figure out. As soon as it became clear that we actually could be able to identify who the first one was, we basically got the message that we could do whatever we wanted, just travel wherever you need to go, do whatever you need to do, just get this done.BG: That's an editor taking responsibility. The story, by the way, has been translated and published across several European countries, and certainly will continue to do. And we want to read the updates from you. Thank you Anders. Thank you Tomm.(Applause)
