would be to go somewhere
where I can finish my studies

00:06:57.198 --> 00:06:58.734
and find work."

00:06:58.758 --> 00:07:00.174
So he goes to Turkey.

00:07:00.198 --> 00:07:02.838
In Turkey, he's not accepted
at a university,

00:07:03.398 --> 00:07:08.174
and once he had left Jordan as a refugee,
he was not allowed to reenter.

00:07:08.198 --> 00:07:10.814
So then he decides to head for the UK,

00:07:10.838 --> 00:07:12.374
where his uncle lives.

00:07:12.398 --> 00:07:15.534
He makes it into Algeria,
walks into Libya,

00:07:15.558 --> 00:07:19.374
pays a people smuggler to help him
with the crossing into Italy by boat,

00:07:19.398 --> 00:07:21.294
and from there on he heads to Dunkirk,

00:07:21.318 --> 00:07:23.998
the city right next to Calais
by the English Channel.

00:07:25.913 --> 00:07:29.294
We know he made at least 12 failed
attempts to cross the English Channel

00:07:29.318 --> 00:07:30.918
by hiding in a truck.

00:07:31.478 --> 00:07:34.158
But at some point,
he must have given up all hope.

00:07:35.318 --> 00:07:37.374
The last night we know he was alive,

00:07:37.398 --> 00:07:40.918
he spent at a cheap hotel
close to the train station in Dunkirk.

00:07:41.478 --> 00:07:44.955
We found his name in the records,
and he seems to have stayed there alone.

00:07:45.638 --> 00:07:49.574
The day after, he went into Calais,
entered a sports shop

00:07:49.598 --> 00:07:52.054
a couple of minutes
before 8 o'clock in the evening,

00:07:52.078 --> 00:07:53.614
along with Shadi Kataf.

00:07:53.638 --> 00:07:55.654
They both bought wetsuits,

00:07:55.678 --> 00:07:57.094
and the woman in the shop

00:07:57.118 --> 00:07:59.690
was the last person we know of
to have seen them alive.

00:08:01.718 --> 00:08:05.014
We have tried to figure out
where Shadi met Mouaz,

00:08:05.038 --> 00:08:07.454
but we weren't able to do that.

00:08:07.478 --> 00:08:09.574
But they do have a similar story.

00:08:09.598 --> 00:08:13.494
We first heard about Shadi
after a cousin of his, living in Germany,

00:08:13.518 --> 00:08:17.974
had read an Arabic translation
of the story made of Mouaz on Facebook.

00:08:17.998 --> 00:08:19.332
So we got in touch with him.

00:08:20.878 --> 00:08:23.414
Shadi, a couple of years older than Mouaz,

00:08:23.438 --> 00:08:25.814
was also raised in Damascus.

00:08:25.838 --> 00:08:27.374
He was a working kind of guy.

00:08:27.398 --> 00:08:30.814
He ran a tire repair shop
and later worked in a printing company.

00:08:30.838 --> 00:08:32.734
He lived with his extended family,

00:08:32.758 --> 00:08:35.694
but their house got bombed
early in the war.

00:08:35.718 --> 00:08:40.638
So the family fled to an area
of Damascus known as Camp Yarmouk.

00:08:42.998 --> 00:08:46.894
Yarmouk is being described
as the worst place to live

00:08:46.918 --> 00:08:48.117
on planet Earth.

00:08:49.198 --> 00:08:51.973
They've been bombed by the military,
they've been besieged,

00:08:51.997 --> 00:08:53.379
they've been stormed by ISIS

00:08:53.403 --> 00:08:56.254
and they've been cut off
from supplies for years.

00:08:56.278 --> 00:08:58.421
There was a UN official
who visited last year,

00:08:58.445 --> 00:09:03.565
and he said, "They ate all the grass
so there was no grass left."

00:09:05.398 --> 00:09:07.774
Out of a population of 150,000,

00:09:07.798 --> 00:09:11.894
only 18,000 are believed
to still be left in Yarmouk.

00:09:11.918 --> 00:09:13.974
Shadi and his sisters got out.

00:09:13.998 --> 00:09:15.998
The parents are still stuck inside.

00:09:18.358 --> 00:09:21.894
So Shadi and one of his sisters,
they fled to Libya.

00:09:21.918 --> 00:09:23.585
This was after the fall of Gaddafi,

00:09:23.609 --> 00:09:26.849
but before Libya turned
into full-blown civil war.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:31.414
And in this last remaining
sort of stability in Libya,

00:09:31.438 --> 00:09:36.558
Shadi took up scuba diving, and he seemed
to spend most of his time underwater.

00:09:37.758 --> 00:09:39.758
He fell completely in love with the ocean,

00:09:40.638 --> 00:09:43.854
so when he finally decided
that he could no longer be in Libya,

00:09:43.878 --> 00:09:46.134
late August 2014,

00:09:46.158 --> 00:09:49.038
he hoped to find work
as a diver when he reached Italy.

00:09:50.558 --> 00:09:52.398
Reality was not that easy.

00:09:53.478 --> 00:09:55.294
We don't know much about his travels

00:09:55.318 --> 00:09:58.014
because he had a hard time
communicating with his family,

00:09:58.038 --> 00:10:00.054
but we do know that he struggled.

00:10:00.078 --> 00:10:01.454
And by the end of September,

00:10:01.478 --> 00:10:03.764
he was living on the streets
somewhere in France.

00:10:04.798 --> 00:10:07.814
On October 7, he calls
his cousin in Belgium,

00:10:07.838 --> 00:10:09.814
and explains his situation.

00:10:09.838 --> 00:10:15.014
He said, "I'm in Calais. I need you
to come get my backpack and my laptop.

00:10:15.038 --> 00:10:18.974
I can't afford to pay the people smugglers
to help me with the crossing to Britain,

00:10:18.998 --> 00:10:21.238
but I will go buy a wetsuit
and I will swim."

00:10:22.518 --> 00:10:24.974
His cousin, of course,
tried to warn him not to,

00:10:24.998 --> 00:10:27.134
but Shadi's battery
on the phone went flat,

00:10:27.158 --> 00:10:29.958
and his phone was never switched on again.

00:10:31.478 --> 00:10:35.534
What was left of Shadi
was found nearly three months later,

00:10:35.558 --> 00:10:37.494
800 kilometers away

00:10:37.518 --> 00:10:39.558
in a wetsuit on a beach in Norway.

00:10:40.518 --> 00:10:42.654
He's still waiting
for his funeral in Norway,

00:10:42.678 --> 00:10:45.238
and none of his family
will be able to attend.

00:10:47.038 --> 00:10:49.574
Many may think that the story
about Shadi and Mouaz

00:10:49.598 --> 00:10:51.398
is a story about death,

00:10:52.758 --> 00:10:53.974
but I don't agree.

00:10:53.998 --> 00:10:59.454
To me, this is a story about two questions
that I think we all share:

00:10:59.478 --> 00:11:01.254
what is a better life,

00:11:01.278 --> 00:11:03.598
and what am I willing to do to achieve it?

00:11:04.718 --> 00:11:06.494
And to me, and probably a lot of you,

00:11:06.518 --> 00:11:08.094
a better life would mean

00:11:08.118 --> 00:11:11.014
being able to do more
of what we think of as meaningful,

00:11:11.038 --> 00:11:14.038
whether that be spending more time
with your family and friends,

00:11:14.062 --> 00:11:15.574
travel to an exotic place,

00:11:15.598 --> 00:11:17.934
or just getting money
to buy that cool new device

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.654
or a pair of new sneakers.

00:11:19.678 --> 00:11:22.398
And this is all
within our reach pretty easily.

00:11:23.798 --> 00:11:25.734
But if you are fleeing a war zone,

00:11:25.758 --> 00:11:29.734
the answers to those two questions
are dramatically different.

00:11:29.758 --> 00:11:32.014
A better life is a life in safety.

00:11:32.038 --> 00:11:34.374
It's a life in dignity.

00:11:34.398 --> 00:11:37.054
A better life means
not having your house bombed,

00:11:37.078 --> 00:11:38.614
not fearing being kidnapped.

00:11:38.638 --> 00:11:41.067
It means being able
to send your children to school,

00:11:41.091 --> 00:11:42.254
go to university,

00:11:42.278 --> 00:11:46.694
or just find work to be able to provide
for yourself and the ones you love.

00:11:46.718 --> 00:11:50.334
A better life would be
a future of some possibilities

00:11:50.358 --> 00:11:52.654
compared to nearly none,

00:11:52.678 --> 00:11:54.438
and that's a strong motivation.

00:11:55.438 --> 00:11:57.534
And I have no trouble imagining

00:11:57.558 --> 00:12:01.054
that after spending weeks or even months

00:12:01.078 --> 00:12:02.974
as a second-grade citizen,

00:12:02.998 --> 00:12:07.134
living on the streets
or in a horrible makeshift camp

00:12:07.158 --> 00:12:10.614
with a stupid, racist name
like "The Jungle,"

00:12:10.638 --> 00:12:14.158
most of us would be willing
to do just about anything.

00:12:15.158 --> 00:12:17.414
If I could ask Shadi and Mouaz

00:12:17.438 --> 00:12:21.494
the second they stepped into the freezing
waters of the English Channel,

00:12:21.518 --> 00:12:24.278
they would probably say,
"This is worth the risk,"

00:12:25.118 --> 00:12:28.078
because they could
no longer see any other option.

00:12:29.358 --> 00:12:30.558
And that's desperation,

00:12:31.638 --> 00:12:36.758
but that's the reality of living
as a refugee in Western Europe in 2015.

00:12:37.718 --> 00:12:38.934
Thank you.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:44.174
(Applause)

00:12:49.868 --> 00:12:51.508
Bruno Giussani: Thank you, Anders.

00:12:51.538 --> 00:12:52.774
This is Tomm Christiansen,

00:12:52.798 --> 00:12:56.560
who took most of the pictures you have
seen and they've done reporting together.

00:12:57.638 --> 00:13:00.014
Tomm, you two have been
back to Calais recently.

00:13:00.038 --> 00:13:01.654
This was the third trip.

00:13:01.678 --> 00:13:03.734
It was after the publication
of the article.

00:13:03.758 --> 00:13:05.894
What has changed?
What have you seen there?

00:13:05.918 --> 00:13:08.347
Tomm Christiansen:
The first time we were in Calais,

00:13:08.371 --> 00:13:10.014
it was about 1,500 refugees there.

00:13:10.038 --> 00:13:13.694
They had a difficult time,
but they were positive, they had hope.

00:13:13.718 --> 00:13:18.734
The last time, the camp has grown,
maybe four or five thousand people.

00:13:18.758 --> 00:13:21.334
It seemed more permanent,
NGOs have arrived,

00:13:21.358 --> 00:13:23.174
a small school has opened.

00:13:23.198 --> 00:13:26.574
But the thing is that the refugees
have stayed for a longer time,

00:13:26.598 --> 00:13:31.494
and the French government has managed
to seal off the borders better,

00:13:31.518 --> 00:13:34.574
so now The Jungle is growing,

00:13:34.598 --> 00:13:38.814
along with the despair
and hopelessness among the refugees.

00:13:38.838 --> 00:13:43.534
BG: Are you planning to go back?
And continue the reporting?

00:13:43.558 --> 00:13:44.774
TC: Yes.

00:13:44.798 --> 00:13:46.814
BG: Anders, I'm a former journalist,

00:13:46.838 --> 00:13:49.254
and to me, it's amazing
that in the current climate

00:13:49.278 --> 00:13:51.814
of slashing budgets
and publishers in crisis,

00:13:51.838 --> 00:13:55.734
Dagbladet has consented
so many resources for this story,

00:13:55.758 --> 00:13:58.616
which tells a lot about newspapers
taking the responsibility,

00:13:58.640 --> 00:14:00.560
but how did you sell it to your editors?

00:14:02.318 --> 00:14:04.334
Anders Fjellberg: It wasn't easy at first,

00:14:04.358 --> 00:14:08.334
because we weren't able to know
what we actually could figure out.

00:14:08.358 --> 00:14:09.614
As soon as it became clear

00:14:09.638 --> 00:14:14.094
that we actually could be able
to identify who the first one was,

00:14:14.118 --> 00:14:17.174
we basically got the message
that we could do whatever we wanted,

00:14:17.198 --> 00:14:20.214
just travel wherever you need to go,
do whatever you need to do,

00:14:20.238 --> 00:14:23.358
just get this done.

00:14:23.678 --> 00:14:26.014
BG: That's an editor
taking responsibility.

00:14:26.038 --> 00:14:28.658
The story, by the way,
has been translated and published

00:14:28.682 --> 00:14:31.934
across several European countries,
and certainly will continue to do.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.494
And we want to read the updates from you.
Thank you Anders. Thank you Tomm.

00:14:35.518 --> 00:14:39.918
(Applause)

title: The unexpected beauty of everyday sounds
transcript: As a singer-songwriter, people often ask me about my influences or, as I like to call them, my sonic lineages. And I could easily tell you that I was shaped by the jazz and hip hop that I grew up with, by the Ethiopian heritage of my ancestors, or by the 1980s pop on my childhood radio stations. But beyond genre, there is another question: how do the sounds we hear every day influence the music that we make? I believe that everyday soundscape can be the most unexpected inspiration for songwriting, and to look at this idea a little bit more closely, I'm going to talk today about three things: nature, language and silence — or rather, the impossibility of true silence. And through this I hope to give you a sense of a world already alive with musical expression, with each of us serving as active participants, whether we know it or not.I'm going to start today with nature, but before we do that, let's quickly listen to this snippet of an opera singer warming up. Here it is.(Singing)(Singing ends)It's beautiful, isn't it? Gotcha! That is actually not the sound of an opera singer warming up. That is the sound of a bird slowed down to a pace that the human ear mistakenly recognizes as its own. It was released as part of Peter Szöke's 1987 Hungarian recording "The Unknown Music of Birds," where he records many birds and slows down their pitches to reveal what's underneath. Let's listen to the full-speed recording.(Bird singing)Now, let's hear the two of them together so your brain can juxtapose them.(Bird singing at slow then full speed)(Singing ends)It's incredible. Perhaps the techniques of opera singing were inspired by birdsong. As humans, we intuitively understand birds to be our musical teachers.In Ethiopia, birds are considered an integral part of the origin of music itself. The story goes like this: 1,500 years ago, a young man was born in the Empire of Aksum, a major trading center of the ancient world. His name was Yared. When Yared was seven years old his father died, and his mother sent him to go live with an uncle, who was a priest of the Ethiopian Orthodox tradition, one of the oldest churches in the world. Now, this tradition has an enormous amount of scholarship and learning, and Yared had to study and study and study and study, and one day he was studying under a tree, when three birds came to him. One by one, these birds became his teachers. They taught him music — scales, in fact. And Yared, eventually recognized as Saint Yared, used these scales to compose five volumes of chants and hymns for worship and celebration. And he used these scales to compose and to create an indigenous musical notation system. And these scales evolved into what is known as kiñit, the unique, pentatonic, five-note, modal system that is very much alive and thriving and still evolving in Ethiopia today.Now, I love this story because it's true at multiple levels. Saint Yared was a real, historical figure, and the natural world can be our musical teacher. And we have so many examples of this: the Pygmies of the Congo tune their instruments to the pitches of the birds in the forest around them. Musician and natural soundscape expert Bernie Krause describes how a healthy environment has animals and insects taking up low, medium and high-frequency bands, in exactly the same way as a symphony does. And countless works of music were inspired by bird and forest song. Yes, the natural world can be our cultural teacher.So let's go now to the uniquely human world of language. Every language communicates with pitch to varying degrees, whether it's Mandarin Chinese, where a shift in melodic inflection gives the same phonetic syllable an entirely different meaning, to a language like English, where a raised pitch at the end of a sentence ... (Going up in pitch) implies a question?(Laughter)As an Ethiopian-American woman, I grew up around the language of Amharic, Amhariña. It was my first language, the language of my parents, one of the main languages of Ethiopia. And there are a million reasons to fall in love with this language: its depth of poetics, its double entendres, its wax and gold, its humor, its proverbs that illuminate the wisdom and follies of life. But there's also this melodicism, a musicality built right in. And I find this distilled most clearly in what I like to call emphatic language — language that's meant to highlight or underline or that springs from surprise. Take, for example, the word: "indey." Now, if there are Ethiopians in the audience, they're probably chuckling to themselves, because the word means something like "No!" or "How could he?" or "No, he didn't." It kind of depends on the situation. But when I was a kid, this was my very favorite word, and I think it's because it has a pitch. It has a melody. You can almost see the shape as it springs from someone's mouth. "Indey" — it dips, and then raises again. And as a musician and composer, when I hear that word, something like this is floating through my mind.(Music and singing "Indey")(Music ends)Or take, for example, the phrase for "It is right" or "It is correct" — "Lickih nehu ... Lickih nehu." It's an affirmation, an agreement. "Lickih nehu." When I hear that phrase, something like this starts rolling through my mind.(Music and singing "Lickih nehu")(Music ends)And in both of those cases, what I did was I took the melody and the phrasing of those words and phrases and I turned them into musical parts to use in these short compositions. And I like to write bass lines, so they both ended up kind of as bass lines.Now, this is based on the work of Jason Moran and others who work intimately with music and language, but it's also something I've had in my head since I was a kid, how musical my parents sounded when they were speaking to each other and to us. It was from them and from Amhariña that I learned that we are awash in musical expression with every word, every sentence that we speak, every word, every sentence that we receive. Perhaps you can hear it in the words I'm speaking even now.Finally, we go to the 1950s United States and the most seminal work of 20th century avant-garde composition: John Cage's "4:33," written for any instrument or combination of instruments. The musician or musicians are invited to walk onto the stage with a stopwatch and open the score, which was actually purchased by the Museum of Modern Art — the score, that is. And this score has not a single note written and there is not a single note played for four minutes and 33 seconds. And, at once enraging and enrapturing, Cage shows us that even when there are no strings being plucked by fingers or hands hammering piano keys, still there is music, still there is music, still there is music. And what is this music? It was that sneeze in the back.(Laughter)It is the everyday soundscape that arises from the audience themselves: their coughs, their sighs, their rustles, their whispers, their sneezes, the room, the wood of the floors and the walls expanding and contracting, creaking and groaning with the heat and the cold, the pipes clanking and contributing. And controversial though it was, and even controversial though it remains, Cage's point is that there is no such thing as true silence. Even in the most silent environments, we still hear and feel the sound of our own heartbeats. The world is alive with musical expression. We are already immersed.Now, I had my own moment of, let's say, remixing John Cage a couple of months ago when I was standing in front of the stove cooking lentils. And it was late one night and it was time to stir, so I lifted the lid off the cooking pot, and I placed it onto the kitchen counter next to me, and it started to roll back and forth making this sound.(Sound of metal lid clanking against a counter)(Clanking ends)And it stopped me cold. I thought, "What a weird, cool swing that cooking pan lid has." So when the lentils were ready and eaten, I hightailed it to my backyard studio, and I made this.(Music, including the sound of the lid, and singing)(Music ends)Now, John Cage wasn't instructing musicians to mine the soundscape for sonic textures to turn into music. He was saying that on its own, the environment is musically generative, that it is generous, that it is fertile, that we are already immersed.Musician, music researcher, surgeon and human hearing expert Charles Limb is a professor at Johns Hopkins University and he studies music and the brain. And he has a theory that it is possible — it is possible — that the human auditory system actually evolved to hear music, because it is so much more complex than it needs to be for language alone. And if that's true, it means that we're hard-wired for music, that we can find it anywhere, that there is no such thing as a musical desert, that we are permanently hanging out at the oasis, and that is marvelous. We can add to the soundtrack, but it's already playing.And it doesn't mean don't study music. Study music, trace your sonic lineages and enjoy that exploration. But there is a kind of sonic lineage to which we all belong. So the next time you are seeking percussion inspiration, look no further than your tires, as they roll over the unusual grooves of the freeway, or the top-right burner of your stove and that strange way that it clicks as it is preparing to light. When seeking melodic inspiration, look no further than dawn and dusk avian orchestras or to the natural lilt of emphatic language. We are the audience and we are the composers and we take from these pieces we are given. We make, we make, we make, we make, knowing that when it comes to nature or language or soundscape, there is no end to the inspiration — if we are listening.Thank you.(Applause)

Now, let's hear the two of them together

00:02:17.532 --> 00:02:19.104
so your brain can juxtapose them.

00:02:20.125 --> 00:02:25.125
(Bird singing at slow then full speed)

00:02:38.296 --> 00:02:40.296
(Singing ends)

00:02:42.021 --> 00:02:43.212
It's incredible.

00:02:43.822 --> 00:02:48.084
Perhaps the techniques of opera singing
were inspired by birdsong.

00:02:48.838 --> 00:02:53.726
As humans, we intuitively understand birds
to be our musical teachers.

00:02:54.397 --> 00:02:57.301
In Ethiopia, birds
are considered an integral part

00:02:57.325 --> 00:02:59.931
of the origin of music itself.

00:03:00.500 --> 00:03:01.975
The story goes like this:

00:03:03.496 --> 00:03:08.529
1,500 years ago, a young man
was born in the Empire of Aksum,

00:03:08.553 --> 00:03:11.100
a major trading center
of the ancient world.

00:03:11.483 --> 00:03:13.024
His name was Yared.

00:03:14.360 --> 00:03:17.568
When Yared was seven years old
his father died,

00:03:17.592 --> 00:03:21.215
and his mother sent him to go live
with an uncle, who was a priest

00:03:21.239 --> 00:03:23.534
of the Ethiopian Orthodox tradition,

00:03:23.558 --> 00:03:25.692
one of the oldest churches in the world.

00:03:26.850 --> 00:03:30.311
Now, this tradition has an enormous amount
of scholarship and learning,

00:03:30.335 --> 00:03:33.347
and Yared had to study and study
and study and study,

00:03:33.371 --> 00:03:35.987
and one day he was studying under a tree,

00:03:36.011 --> 00:03:38.538
when three birds came to him.

00:03:39.279 --> 00:03:42.347
One by one, these birds
became his teachers.

00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:46.162
They taught him music -- scales, in fact.

00:03:47.537 --> 00:03:50.040
And Yared, eventually
recognized as Saint Yared,

00:03:50.064 --> 00:03:54.502
used these scales to compose
five volumes of chants and hymns

00:03:54.526 --> 00:03:56.698
for worship and celebration.

00:03:56.722 --> 00:04:00.111
And he used these scales
to compose and to create

00:04:00.135 --> 00:04:02.885
an indigenous musical notation system.

00:04:03.603 --> 00:04:07.226
And these scales evolved
into what is known as kiñit,

00:04:07.250 --> 00:04:13.143
the unique, pentatonic, five-note,
modal system that is very much alive

00:04:13.167 --> 00:04:17.391
and thriving and still evolving
in Ethiopia today.

00:04:18.489 --> 00:04:21.652
Now, I love this story because
it's true at multiple levels.

00:04:21.676 --> 00:04:24.699
Saint Yared was a real, historical figure,

00:04:24.723 --> 00:04:28.672
and the natural world
can be our musical teacher.

00:04:29.015 --> 00:04:31.169
And we have so many examples of this:

00:04:31.193 --> 00:04:33.416
the Pygmies of the Congo
tune their instruments

00:04:33.440 --> 00:04:36.040
to the pitches of the birds
in the forest around them.

00:04:36.354 --> 00:04:39.532
Musician and natural soundscape
expert Bernie Krause describes

00:04:39.556 --> 00:04:42.930
how a healthy environment
has animals and insects

00:04:42.954 --> 00:04:46.382
taking up low, medium
and high-frequency bands,

00:04:46.406 --> 00:04:49.600
in exactly the same way
as a symphony does.

00:04:50.024 --> 00:04:54.387
And countless works of music
were inspired by bird and forest song.

00:04:54.930 --> 00:04:59.803
Yes, the natural world
can be our cultural teacher.

00:05:00.709 --> 00:05:04.082
So let's go now to the uniquely
human world of language.

00:05:05.041 --> 00:05:08.285
Every language communicates
with pitch to varying degrees,

00:05:08.309 --> 00:05:09.747
whether it's Mandarin Chinese,

00:05:09.771 --> 00:05:13.763
where a shift in melodic inflection
gives the same phonetic syllable

00:05:13.787 --> 00:05:15.544
an entirely different meaning,

00:05:15.568 --> 00:05:16.910
to a language like English,

00:05:16.934 --> 00:05:19.304
where a raised pitch
at the end of a sentence ...

00:05:19.328 --> 00:05:21.346
(Going up in pitch) implies a question?

00:05:21.370 --> 00:05:22.979
(Laughter)

00:05:23.003 --> 00:05:24.662
As an Ethiopian-American woman,

00:05:24.686 --> 00:05:27.094
I grew up around the language
of Amharic, Amhariña.

00:05:27.118 --> 00:05:29.597
It was my first language,
the language of my parents,

00:05:29.621 --> 00:05:32.178
one of the main languages of Ethiopia.

00:05:32.674 --> 00:05:35.868
And there are a million reasons
to fall in love with this language:

00:05:35.892 --> 00:05:38.733
its depth of poetics,
its double entendres,

00:05:38.757 --> 00:05:41.374
its wax and gold, its humor,

00:05:41.398 --> 00:05:45.288
its proverbs that illuminate
the wisdom and follies of life.

00:05:45.996 --> 00:05:50.075
But there's also this melodicism,
a musicality built right in.

00:05:50.692 --> 00:05:52.567
And I find this distilled most clearly

00:05:52.591 --> 00:05:55.064
in what I like to call
emphatic language --

00:05:55.088 --> 00:05:57.324
language that's meant
to highlight or underline

00:05:57.348 --> 00:05:59.403
or that springs from surprise.

00:05:59.994 --> 00:06:02.401
Take, for example, the word: "indey."

00:06:03.162 --> 00:06:05.264
Now, if there are Ethiopians
in the audience,

00:06:05.288 --> 00:06:07.295
they're probably chuckling to themselves,

00:06:07.319 --> 00:06:09.403
because the word means
something like "No!"

00:06:09.427 --> 00:06:11.238
or "How could he?" or "No, he didn't."

00:06:11.262 --> 00:06:13.363
It kind of depends on the situation.

00:06:13.387 --> 00:06:17.238
But when I was a kid,
this was my very favorite word,

00:06:17.262 --> 00:06:20.362
and I think it's because it has a pitch.

00:06:20.679 --> 00:06:21.890
It has a melody.

00:06:21.914 --> 00:06:24.915
You can almost see the shape
as it springs from someone's mouth.

00:06:24.939 --> 00:06:27.668
"Indey" -- it dips, and then raises again.

00:06:28.349 --> 00:06:31.438
And as a musician and composer,
when I hear that word,

00:06:31.462 --> 00:06:34.531
something like this
is floating through my mind.

00:06:35.940 --> 00:06:40.940
(Music and singing "Indey")

00:06:45.790 --> 00:06:47.790
(Music ends)

00:06:48.669 --> 00:06:52.660
Or take, for example, the phrase
for "It is right" or "It is correct" --

00:06:52.684 --> 00:06:54.256
"Lickih nehu ... Lickih nehu."

00:06:54.280 --> 00:06:56.913
It's an affirmation, an agreement.

00:06:56.937 --> 00:06:58.095
"Lickih nehu."

00:06:58.119 --> 00:06:59.271
When I hear that phrase,

00:06:59.295 --> 00:07:02.792
something like this starts rolling
through my mind.

00:07:03.989 --> 00:07:08.989
(Music and singing "Lickih nehu")

00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:13.530
(Music ends)

00:07:14.157 --> 00:07:16.974
And in both of those cases,
what I did was I took the melody

00:07:16.998 --> 00:07:19.457
and the phrasing
of those words and phrases

00:07:19.481 --> 00:07:24.047
and I turned them into musical parts
to use in these short compositions.

00:07:24.497 --> 00:07:25.978
And I like to write bass lines,

00:07:26.002 --> 00:07:28.053
so they both ended up
kind of as bass lines.

00:07:29.345 --> 00:07:31.971
Now, this is based on the work
of Jason Moran and others

00:07:31.995 --> 00:07:35.033
who work intimately
with music and language,

00:07:35.057 --> 00:07:38.001
but it's also something I've had
in my head since I was a kid,

00:07:38.025 --> 00:07:40.056
how musical my parents sounded

00:07:40.080 --> 00:07:43.232
when they were speaking
to each other and to us.

00:07:44.028 --> 00:07:46.402
It was from them
and from Amhariña that I learned

00:07:46.426 --> 00:07:49.306
that we are awash in musical expression

00:07:49.330 --> 00:07:51.945
with every word,
every sentence that we speak,

00:07:51.969 --> 00:07:54.721
every word, every sentence
that we receive.

00:07:54.745 --> 00:07:59.004
Perhaps you can hear it
in the words I'm speaking even now.

00:08:00.195 --> 00:08:02.610
Finally, we go to the 1950s United States

00:08:02.634 --> 00:08:06.545
and the most seminal work
of 20th century avant-garde composition:

00:08:06.569 --> 00:08:08.693
John Cage's "4:33,"

00:08:08.717 --> 00:08:11.951
written for any instrument
or combination of instruments.

00:08:12.870 --> 00:08:16.429
The musician or musicians are invited
to walk onto the stage

00:08:16.453 --> 00:08:19.643
with a stopwatch and open the score,

00:08:19.667 --> 00:08:22.598
which was actually purchased
by the Museum of Modern Art --

00:08:22.622 --> 00:08:24.004
the score, that is.

00:08:24.599 --> 00:08:28.107
And this score has not
a single note written

00:08:28.131 --> 00:08:30.605
and there is not a single note played

00:08:30.629 --> 00:08:33.361
for four minutes and 33 seconds.

00:08:34.498 --> 00:08:39.188
And, at once enraging and enrapturing,

00:08:39.212 --> 00:08:42.100
Cage shows us that even
when there are no strings

00:08:42.124 --> 00:08:47.172
being plucked by fingers
or hands hammering piano keys,

00:08:47.196 --> 00:08:49.673
still there is music,
still there is music,

00:08:49.697 --> 00:08:51.759
still there is music.

00:08:51.783 --> 00:08:53.911
And what is this music?

00:08:54.861 --> 00:08:57.066
It was that sneeze in the back.

00:08:57.090 --> 00:08:58.636
(Laughter)

00:08:58.660 --> 00:09:03.720
It is the everyday soundscape
that arises from the audience themselves:

00:09:03.745 --> 00:09:08.014
their coughs, their sighs, their rustles,
their whispers, their sneezes,

00:09:08.038 --> 00:09:10.579
the room, the wood
of the floors and the walls

00:09:10.603 --> 00:09:13.061
expanding and contracting,
creaking and groaning

00:09:13.085 --> 00:09:14.489
with the heat and the cold,

00:09:14.513 --> 00:09:17.604
the pipes clanking and contributing.

00:09:19.264 --> 00:09:22.904
And controversial though it was,
and even controversial though it remains,

00:09:22.928 --> 00:09:27.172
Cage's point is that there is no
such thing as true silence.

00:09:28.065 --> 00:09:32.570
Even in the most silent environments,
we still hear and feel the sound

00:09:32.594 --> 00:09:34.121
of our own heartbeats.

00:09:34.604 --> 00:09:37.772
The world is alive
with musical expression.

00:09:38.341 --> 00:09:40.548
We are already immersed.

00:09:42.288 --> 00:09:45.981
Now, I had my own moment of,
let's say, remixing John Cage

00:09:46.005 --> 00:09:47.672
a couple of months ago

00:09:47.696 --> 00:09:50.699
when I was standing
in front of the stove cooking lentils.

00:09:50.723 --> 00:09:53.865
And it was late one night
and it was time to stir,

00:09:53.889 --> 00:09:55.861
so I lifted the lid off the cooking pot,

00:09:55.885 --> 00:09:58.318
and I placed it onto
the kitchen counter next to me,

00:09:58.342 --> 00:10:00.605
and it started to roll back and forth

00:10:00.629 --> 00:10:03.390
making this sound.

00:10:04.723 --> 00:10:09.723
(Sound of metal lid
clanking against a counter)

00:10:10.887 --> 00:10:12.037
(Clanking ends)

00:10:13.483 --> 00:10:15.017
And it stopped me cold.

00:10:15.685 --> 00:10:20.908
I thought, "What a weird, cool swing
that cooking pan lid has."

00:10:22.158 --> 00:10:26.742
So when the lentils were ready and eaten,

00:10:26.766 --> 00:10:30.260
I hightailed it to my backyard studio,

00:10:30.284 --> 00:10:32.127
and I made this.

00:10:33.145 --> 00:10:38.145
(Music, including the sound
of the lid, and singing)

00:10:50.229 --> 00:10:51.379
(Music ends)

00:10:52.437 --> 00:10:54.849
Now, John Cage
wasn't instructing musicians

00:10:54.873 --> 00:10:58.568
to mine the soundscape
for sonic textures to turn into music.

00:10:59.018 --> 00:11:01.871
He was saying that on its own,

00:11:01.895 --> 00:11:05.356
the environment is musically generative,

00:11:05.380 --> 00:11:09.621
that it is generous, that it is fertile,

00:11:09.645 --> 00:11:11.808
that we are already immersed.

00:11:12.723 --> 00:11:18.736
Musician, music researcher, surgeon
and human hearing expert Charles Limb

00:11:18.760 --> 00:11:20.815
is a professor at Johns Hopkins University

00:11:20.839 --> 00:11:23.108
and he studies music and the brain.

00:11:24.697 --> 00:11:26.463
And he has a theory

00:11:27.693 --> 00:11:30.789
that it is possible -- it is possible --

00:11:30.813 --> 00:11:35.961
that the human auditory system
actually evolved to hear music,

00:11:35.985 --> 00:11:41.056
because it is so much more complex
than it needs to be for language alone.

00:11:41.691 --> 00:11:43.466
And if that's true,

00:11:43.490 --> 00:11:46.435
it means that we're hard-wired for music,

00:11:46.459 --> 00:11:48.572
that we can find it anywhere,

00:11:48.596 --> 00:11:51.674
that there is no such thing
as a musical desert,

00:11:51.698 --> 00:11:55.397
that we are permanently
hanging out at the oasis,

00:11:55.421 --> 00:11:57.478
and that is marvelous.

00:11:58.093 --> 00:12:01.286
We can add to the soundtrack,
but it's already playing.

00:12:02.218 --> 00:12:04.072
And it doesn't mean don't study music.

00:12:04.096 --> 00:12:08.592
Study music, trace your sonic lineages
and enjoy that exploration.

00:12:09.313 --> 00:12:13.048
But there is a kind of sonic lineage
to which we all belong.

00:12:14.225 --> 00:12:16.848
So the next time you are seeking
percussion inspiration,

00:12:16.872 --> 00:12:20.221
look no further than your tires,
as they roll over the unusual grooves

00:12:20.245 --> 00:12:21.969
of the freeway,

00:12:21.993 --> 00:12:24.171
or the top-right burner of your stove

00:12:24.195 --> 00:12:25.904
and that strange way that it clicks

00:12:25.928 --> 00:12:27.990
as it is preparing to light.

00:12:28.691 --> 00:12:30.303
When seeking melodic inspiration,

00:12:30.327 --> 00:12:33.819
look no further than dawn
and dusk avian orchestras

00:12:33.843 --> 00:12:37.071
or to the natural lilt
of emphatic language.

00:12:37.095 --> 00:12:40.094
We are the audience
and we are the composers

00:12:40.118 --> 00:12:41.913
and we take from these pieces

00:12:41.937 --> 00:12:43.088
we are given.

00:12:43.112 --> 00:12:44.980
We make, we make, we make, we make,

00:12:45.004 --> 00:12:49.424
knowing that when it comes to nature
or language or soundscape,

00:12:49.448 --> 00:12:52.445
there is no end to the inspiration --

00:12:52.469 --> 00:12:54.903
if we are listening.

00:12:55.379 --> 00:12:56.531
Thank you.

00:12:56.555 --> 00:13:02.329
(Applause)

title: The secret US prisons you've never heard of before
transcript: Father Daniel Berrigan once said that "writing about prisoners is a little like writing about the dead." I think what he meant is that we treat prisoners as ghosts. They're unseen and unheard. It's easy to simply ignore them and it's even easier when the government goes to great lengths to keep them hidden.As a journalist, I think these stories of what people in power do when no one is watching, are precisely the stories that we need to tell. That's why I began investigating the most secretive and experimental prison units in the United States, for so-called "second-tier" terrorists. The government calls these units Communications Management Units or CMUs. Prisoners and guards call them "Little Guantanamo." They are islands unto themselves. But unlike Gitmo they exist right here, at home, floating within larger federal prisons.There are 2 CMUs. One was opened inside the prison in Terre Haute, Indiana, and the other is inside this prison, in Marion, Illinois. Neither of them underwent the formal review process that is required by law when they were opened. CMU prisoners have all been convicted of crimes. Some of their cases are questionable and some involve threats and violence. I'm not here to argue the guilt or innocence of any prisoner. I'm here because as Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall said, "When the prisons and gates slam shut, prisoners do not lose their human quality."Every prisoner I've interviewed has said there are three flecks of light in the darkness of prison: phone calls, letters and visits from family. CMUs aren't solitary confinement, but they radically restrict all of these to levels that meet or exceed the most extreme prisons in the United States. Their phone calls can be limited to 45 minutes a month, compared to the 300 minutes other prisoners receive. Their letters can be limited to six pieces of paper. Their visits can be limited to four hours per month, compared to the 35 hours that people like Olympic Park bomber Eric Rudolph receive in the supermax. On top of that, CMU visits are non-contact which means prisoners are not allowed to even hug their family. As one CMU prisoner said, "We're not being tortured here, except psychologically."The government won't say who is imprisoned here. But through court documents, open records requests and interviews with current and former prisoners, some small windows into the CMUs have opened.There's an estimated 60 to 70 prisoners here, and they're overwhelmingly Muslim. They include people like Dr. Rafil Dhafir, who violated the economic sanctions on Iraq by sending medical supplies for the children there. They've included people like Yassin Aref. Aref and his family fled to New York from Saddam Hussein's Iraq as refugees. He was arrested in 2004 as part of an FBI sting. Aref is an imam and he was asked to bear witness to a loan, which is a tradition in Islamic culture. It turned out that one of the people involved in the loan was trying to enlist someone else in a fake attack. Aref didn't know. For that, he was convicted of conspiracy to provide material support to a terrorist group.The CMUs also include some non-Muslim prisoners. The guards call them "balancers," meaning they help balance out the racial numbers, in hopes of deflecting law suits. These balancers include animal rights and environmental activists like Daniel McGowan.McGowan was convicted of participating in two arsons in the name of defending the environment as part of the Earth Liberation Front. During his sentencing, he was afraid that he would be sent to a rumored secret prison for terrorists. The judge dismissed all those fears, saying that they weren't supported by any facts. But that might be because the government hasn't fully explained why some prisoners end up in a CMU, and who is responsible for these decisions. When McGowan was transferred, he was told it's because he is a "domestic terrorist," a term the FBI uses repeatedly when talking about environmental activists. Now, keep in mind there are about 400 prisoners in US prisons who are classified as terrorists, and only a handful of them are in the CMUs. In McGowan's case, he was previously at a low-security prison and he had no communications violations.So, why was he moved? Like other CMU prisoners, McGowan repeatedly asked for an answer, a hearing, or some opportunity for an appeal. This example from another prisoner shows how those requests are viewed. "Wants a transfer." "Told him no." At one point, the prison warden himself recommended McGowan's transfer out of the CMU citing his good behavior, but the warden was overruled by the Bureau of Prison's Counterterrorism Unit, working with the Joint Terrorism Task Force of the FBI.Later I found out that McGowan was really sent to a CMU not because of what he did, but what he has said. A memo from the Counterterrorism Unit cited McGowan's "anti-government beliefs." While imprisoned, he continued writing about environmental issues, saying that activists must reflect on their mistakes and listen to each other. Now, in fairness, if you've spent any time at all in Washington, DC, you know this is really a radical concept for the government.(Laughter)I actually asked to visit McGowan in the CMU. And I was approved. That came as quite a shock. First, because as I've discussed on this stage before, I learned that the FBI has been monitoring my work. Second, because it would make me the first and only journalist to visit a CMU. I had even learned through the Bureau of Prisons Counterterrorism Unit, that they had been monitoring my speeches about CMUs, like this one. So how could I possibly be approved to visit? A few days before I went out to the prison, I got an answer.I was allowed to visit McGowan as a friend, not a journalist. Journalists are not allowed here. McGowan was told by CMU officials that if I asked any questions or published any story, that he would be punished for my reporting. When I arrived for our visit, the guards reminded me that they knew who I was and knew about my work. And they said that if I attempted to interview McGowan, the visit would be terminated. The Bureau of Prisons describes CMUs as "self-contained housing units." But I think that's an Orwellian way of describing black holes. When you visit a CMU, you go through all the security checkpoints that you would expect. But then the walk to the visitation room is silent. When a CMU prisoner has a visit, the rest of the prison is on lockdown. I was ushered into a small room, so small my outstretched arms could touch each wall. There was a grapefruit-sized orb in the ceiling for the visit to be live-monitored by the Counterterrorism Unit in West Virginia. The unit insists that all the visits have to be in English for CMU prisoners, which is an additional hardship for many of the Muslim families. There is a thick sheet of foggy, bulletproof glass and on the other side was Daniel McGowan. We spoke through these handsets attached to the wall and talked about books and movies. We did our best to find reasons to laugh. To fight boredom and amuse himself while in the CMU, McGowan had been spreading a rumor that I was secretly the president of a Twilight fan club in Washington, DC(Laughter)For the record, I'm not.(Laughter) But I kind of the hope the FBI now thinks that Bella and Edward are terrorist code names.(Laughter)During our visit, McGowan spoke most and at length about his niece Lily, his wife Jenny and how torturous it feels to never be able to hug them, to never be able to hold their hands. Three months after our visit, McGowan was transferred out of the CMU and then, without warning, he was sent back again. I had published leaked CMU documents on my website and the Counterterrorism Unit said that McGowan had called his wife and asked her to mail them. He wanted to see what the government was saying about him, and for that he was sent back to the CMU. When he was finally released at the end of his sentence, his story got even more Kafkaesque. He wrote an article for the Huffington Post headlined, "Court Documents Prove I was Sent to a CMU for my Political Speech."The next day he was thrown back in jail for his political speech. His attorneys quickly secured his release, but the message was very clear: Don't talk about this place.Today, nine years after they were opened by the Bush administration, the government is codifying how and why CMUs were created. According to the Bureau of Prisons, they are for prisoners with "inspirational significance." I think that is very nice way of saying these are political prisons for political prisoners.Prisoners are sent to a CMU because of their race, their religion or their political beliefs.Now, if you think that characterization is too strong, just look at some of the government's own documents. When some of McGowan's mail was rejected by the CMU, the sender was told it's because the letters were intended "for political prisoners." When another prisoner, animal rights activist Andy Stepanian, was sent to a CMU, it was because of his anti-government and anti-corporate views.Now, I know all of this may be hard to believe, that it's happening right now, and in the United States. But the unknown reality is that the US has a dark history of disproportionately punishing people because of their political beliefs. In the 1960s, before Marion was home to the CMU, it was home to the notorious Control Unit. Prisoners were locked down in solitary for 22 hours a day. The warden said the unit was to "control revolutionary attitudes." In the 1980s, another experiment called the Lexington High Security Unit held women connected to the Weather Underground, Black Liberation and Puerto Rican independent struggles. The prison radically restricted communication and used sleep deprivation, and constant light for so-called "ideological conversion." Those prisons were eventually shut down, but only through the campaigning of religious groups and human rights advocates, like Amnesty International.Today, civil rights lawyers with the Center for Constitutional Rights are challenging CMUs in court for depriving prisoners of their due process rights and for retaliating against them for their protected political and religious speech. Many of these documents would have never come to light without this lawsuit.The message of these groups and my message for you today is that we must bear witness to what is being done to these prisoners. Their treatment is a reflection of the values held beyond prison walls. This story is not just about prisoners. It is about us. It is about our own commitment to human rights. It is about whether we will choose to stop repeating the mistakes of our past. If we don't listen to what Father Berrigan described as the stories of the dead, they will soon become the stories of ourselves.Thank you.(Applause)(Applause ends)Tom Rielly: I have a couple questions. When I was in high school, I learned about the Bill of Rights, the Constitution, freedom of speech, due process and  about 25 other laws and rights that seem to be violated by this. How could this possibly be happening?Will Potter: I think that's the number one question I get throughout all of my work, and the short answer is that people don't know. I think the solution to any of these types of situations, any rights abuses, are really dependent on two things. They're dependent on knowledge that it's actually happening and then a means and efficacy to actually make a change. And unfortunately with these prisoners, one, people don't know what's happening at all and then they're already disenfranchised populations who don't have access to attorneys, not native English speakers. In some of these cases, they have great representation that I mentioned, but there's just not a public awareness of what's happening.TR: Isn't it guaranteed in prison that you have right to council or access to council?WP: There's a tendency in our culture to see when people have been convicted of a crime, no matter if that charge was bogus or legitimate, that whatever happens to them after that is warranted. And I think that's a really damaging and dangerous narrative that we have, that allows these types of things to happen, as the general public just kind of turns a blind eye to it.TR: All those documents on screen were all real documents, word for word, unchanged at all, right?WP: Absolutely. I've actually uploaded all of them to my website. It's willpotter.com/CMU and it's a footnoted version of the talk, so you can see the documents for yourself without the little snippets. You can see the full version. I relied overwhelmingly on primary source documents or on primary interviews with former and current prisoners, with people that are dealing with this situation every day. And like I said, I've been there myself, as well.TR: You're doing courageous work.WP: Thank you very much. Thank you all.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.691 --> 00:00:16.855
Father Daniel Berrigan once said
that "writing about prisoners

00:00:16.879 --> 00:00:18.992
is a little like writing about the dead."

00:00:19.678 --> 00:00:22.868
I think what he meant is that
we treat prisoners as ghosts.

00:00:22.892 --> 00:00:24.959
They're unseen and unheard.

00:00:25.639 --> 00:00:27.275
It's easy to simply ignore them

00:00:27.299 --> 00:00:31.688
and it's even easier when the government
goes to great lengths to keep them hidden.

00:00:31.712 --> 00:00:33.927
As a journalist, I think these stories

00:00:33.951 --> 00:00:36.999
of what people in power do
when no one is watching,

00:00:37.023 --> 00:00:39.450
are precisely the stories
that we need to tell.

00:00:40.016 --> 00:00:41.555
That's why I began investigating

00:00:41.579 --> 00:00:45.366
the most secretive and experimental
prison units in the United States,

00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:48.156
for so-called "second-tier" terrorists.

00:00:49.280 --> 00:00:54.465
The government calls these units
Communications Management Units or CMUs.

00:00:54.816 --> 00:00:57.925
Prisoners and guards call them
"Little Guantanamo."

00:00:58.844 --> 00:01:01.137
They are islands unto themselves.

00:01:01.161 --> 00:01:05.508
But unlike Gitmo they exist
right here, at home,

00:01:05.532 --> 00:01:08.378
floating within larger federal prisons.

00:01:09.263 --> 00:01:10.887
There are 2 CMUs.

00:01:10.911 --> 00:01:14.031
One was opened inside the prison
in Terre Haute, Indiana,

00:01:14.055 --> 00:01:17.739
and the other is inside this prison,
in Marion, Illinois.

00:01:18.627 --> 00:01:21.052
Neither of them underwent
the formal review process

00:01:21.076 --> 00:01:24.252
that is required by law
when they were opened.

00:01:25.190 --> 00:01:27.655
CMU prisoners have all
been convicted of crimes.

00:01:28.011 --> 00:01:32.147
Some of their cases are questionable
and some involve threats and violence.

00:01:33.068 --> 00:01:36.005
I'm not here to argue the guilt
or innocence of any prisoner.

00:01:36.346 --> 00:01:39.881
I'm here because as Supreme Court Justice
Thurgood Marshall said,

00:01:39.905 --> 00:01:42.362
"When the prisons and gates slam shut,

00:01:42.386 --> 00:01:44.988
prisoners do not lose
their human quality."

00:01:46.473 --> 00:01:51.140
Every prisoner I've interviewed
has said there are three flecks of light

00:01:51.164 --> 00:01:53.598
in the darkness of prison:

00:01:53.622 --> 00:01:54.820
phone calls,

00:01:54.844 --> 00:01:55.995
letters

00:01:56.019 --> 00:01:57.459
and visits from family.

00:01:58.124 --> 00:02:02.027
CMUs aren't solitary confinement,
but they radically restrict all of these

00:02:02.051 --> 00:02:05.950
to levels that meet or exceed the most
extreme prisons in the United States.

00:02:06.454 --> 00:02:09.735
Their phone calls can be limited
to 45 minutes a month,

00:02:09.759 --> 00:02:13.427
compared to the 300 minutes
other prisoners receive.

00:02:14.303 --> 00:02:17.041
Their letters can be limited
to six pieces of paper.

00:02:17.474 --> 00:02:19.905
Their visits can be limited
to four hours per month,

00:02:19.929 --> 00:02:25.635
compared to the 35 hours that people
like Olympic Park bomber Eric Rudolph

00:02:25.659 --> 00:02:27.279
receive in the supermax.

00:02:28.173 --> 00:02:33.161
On top of that, CMU visits are non-contact
which means prisoners are not allowed

00:02:33.185 --> 00:02:35.099
to even hug their family.

00:02:36.051 --> 00:02:37.977
As one CMU prisoner said,

00:02:38.001 --> 00:02:41.430
"We're not being tortured here,
except psychologically."

00:02:42.851 --> 00:02:45.293
The government won't say
who is imprisoned here.

00:02:45.708 --> 00:02:49.335
But through court documents,
open records requests

00:02:49.359 --> 00:02:51.917
and interviews with current
and former prisoners,

00:02:51.941 --> 00:02:55.114
some small windows
into the CMUs have opened.

00:02:55.963 --> 00:02:59.045
There's an estimated
60 to 70 prisoners here,

00:02:59.069 --> 00:03:01.342
and they're overwhelmingly Muslim.

00:03:01.783 --> 00:03:04.951
They include people like Dr. Rafil Dhafir,

00:03:04.975 --> 00:03:08.999
who violated the economic sanctions
on Iraq by sending medical supplies

00:03:09.023 --> 00:03:10.557
for the children there.

00:03:11.925 --> 00:03:14.354
They've included people like Yassin Aref.

00:03:14.850 --> 00:03:20.028
Aref and his family fled to New York
from Saddam Hussein's Iraq as refugees.

00:03:20.052 --> 00:03:23.845
He was arrested in 2004
as part of an FBI sting.

00:03:24.742 --> 00:03:28.216
Aref is an imam and he was asked
to bear witness to a loan,

00:03:28.240 --> 00:03:30.637
which is a tradition in Islamic culture.

00:03:30.661 --> 00:03:34.477
It turned out that one of the people
involved in the loan was trying to enlist

00:03:34.501 --> 00:03:36.865
someone else in a fake attack.

00:03:37.410 --> 00:03:38.780
Aref didn't know.

00:03:39.519 --> 00:03:40.789
For that, he was convicted

00:03:40.813 --> 00:03:44.846
of conspiracy to provide material support
to a terrorist group.

00:03:46.267 --> 00:03:49.497
The CMUs also include
some non-Muslim prisoners.

00:03:49.521 --> 00:03:52.324
The guards call them "balancers,"

00:03:52.348 --> 00:03:55.212
meaning they help balance out
the racial numbers,

00:03:55.236 --> 00:03:57.295
in hopes of deflecting law suits.

00:03:58.181 --> 00:04:01.823
These balancers include animal rights
and environmental activists

00:04:01.847 --> 00:04:03.157
like Daniel McGowan.

00:04:03.601 --> 00:04:06.387
McGowan was convicted
of participating in two arsons

00:04:06.411 --> 00:04:08.523
in the name of defending the environment

00:04:08.547 --> 00:04:10.880
as part of the Earth Liberation Front.

00:04:11.648 --> 00:04:14.396
During his sentencing, he was afraid
that he would be sent

00:04:14.420 --> 00:04:16.789
to a rumored secret prison for terrorists.

00:04:17.518 --> 00:04:19.382
The judge dismissed all those fears,

00:04:19.406 --> 00:04:22.007
saying that they
weren't supported by any facts.

00:04:22.564 --> 00:04:25.819
But that might be because the government
hasn't fully explained

00:04:25.843 --> 00:04:28.245
why some prisoners end up in a CMU,

00:04:28.269 --> 00:04:31.290
and who is responsible
for these decisions.

00:04:32.100 --> 00:04:34.135
When McGowan was transferred, he was told

00:04:34.159 --> 00:04:37.561
it's because he is a "domestic terrorist,"

00:04:37.585 --> 00:04:42.156
a term the FBI uses repeatedly when
talking about environmental activists.

00:04:42.936 --> 00:04:46.707
Now, keep in mind there are about 400
prisoners in US prisons

00:04:46.731 --> 00:04:48.494
who are classified as terrorists,

00:04:48.518 --> 00:04:50.612
and only a handful of them
are in the CMUs.

00:04:51.127 --> 00:04:54.750
In McGowan's case, he was previously
at a low-security prison

00:04:54.774 --> 00:04:57.897
and he had no communications violations.

00:04:59.312 --> 00:05:00.948
So, why was he moved?

00:05:02.131 --> 00:05:03.468
Like other CMU prisoners,

00:05:03.492 --> 00:05:07.382
McGowan repeatedly asked
for an answer, a hearing,

00:05:07.406 --> 00:05:09.724
or some opportunity for an appeal.

00:05:10.392 --> 00:05:14.646
This example from another prisoner
shows how those requests are viewed.

00:05:15.199 --> 00:05:18.176
"Wants a transfer." "Told him no."

00:05:19.324 --> 00:05:23.051
At one point, the prison warden himself
recommended McGowan's transfer

00:05:23.075 --> 00:05:26.348
out of the CMU citing his good behavior,

00:05:26.372 --> 00:05:28.413
but the warden was overruled

00:05:28.437 --> 00:05:31.651
by the Bureau of Prison's
Counterterrorism Unit,

00:05:31.675 --> 00:05:34.629
working with the Joint Terrorism
Task Force of the FBI.

00:05:35.529 --> 00:05:38.145
Later I found out that McGowan
was really sent to a CMU

00:05:38.169 --> 00:05:40.088
not because of what he did,

00:05:40.112 --> 00:05:41.649
but what he has said.

00:05:42.107 --> 00:05:47.425
A memo from the Counterterrorism Unit
cited McGowan's "anti-government beliefs."

00:05:48.291 --> 00:05:51.802
While imprisoned, he continued writing
about environmental issues,

00:05:51.826 --> 00:05:54.644
saying that activists must
reflect on their mistakes

00:05:54.668 --> 00:05:56.215
and listen to each other.

00:05:56.718 --> 00:05:59.979
Now, in fairness, if you've spent
any time at all in Washington, DC,

00:06:00.003 --> 00:06:04.342
you know this is really a radical
concept for the government.

00:06:04.366 --> 00:06:05.610
(Laughter)

00:06:06.767 --> 00:06:09.705
I actually asked to visit
McGowan in the CMU.

00:06:10.286 --> 00:06:11.690
And I was approved.

00:06:12.418 --> 00:06:14.512
That came as quite a shock.

00:06:14.536 --> 00:06:19.537
First, because as I've discussed
on this stage before,

00:06:19.561 --> 00:06:22.858
I learned that the FBI has been
monitoring my work.

00:06:23.388 --> 00:06:28.417
Second, because it would make me the first
and only journalist to visit a CMU.

00:06:29.147 --> 00:06:30.305
I had even learned

00:06:30.329 --> 00:06:33.535
through the Bureau of Prisons
Counterterrorism Unit,

00:06:33.559 --> 00:06:38.214
that they had been monitoring my speeches
about CMUs, like this one.

00:06:39.086 --> 00:06:42.548
So how could I possibly
be approved to visit?

00:06:43.180 --> 00:06:47.389
A few days before I went
out to the prison, I got an answer.

00:06:48.429 --> 00:06:52.794
I was allowed to visit McGowan
as a friend, not a journalist.

00:06:52.818 --> 00:06:54.559
Journalists are not allowed here.

00:06:54.930 --> 00:06:58.475
McGowan was told by CMU officials
that if I asked any questions

00:06:58.499 --> 00:07:00.418
or published any story,

00:07:00.442 --> 00:07:03.277
that he would be punished
for my reporting.

00:07:04.266 --> 00:07:06.730
When I arrived for our visit,
the guards reminded me

00:07:06.754 --> 00:07:09.028
that they knew who I was
and knew about my work.

00:07:09.052 --> 00:07:11.632
And they said that if I attempted
to interview McGowan,

00:07:11.656 --> 00:07:13.333
the visit would be terminated.

00:07:14.629 --> 00:07:20.126
The Bureau of Prisons describes CMUs
as "self-contained housing units."

00:07:20.473 --> 00:07:24.234
But I think that's an Orwellian way
of describing black holes.

00:07:24.763 --> 00:07:25.915
When you visit a CMU,

00:07:25.939 --> 00:07:29.065
you go through all the security
checkpoints that you would expect.

00:07:29.089 --> 00:07:32.204
But then the walk
to the visitation room is silent.

00:07:33.714 --> 00:07:38.185
When a CMU prisoner has a visit,
the rest of the prison is on lockdown.

00:07:39.070 --> 00:07:40.896
I was ushered into a small room,

00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:44.408
so small my outstretched arms
could touch each wall.

00:07:44.719 --> 00:07:47.514
There was a grapefruit-sized
orb in the ceiling

00:07:47.538 --> 00:07:50.713
for the visit to be live-monitored
by the Counterterrorism Unit

00:07:50.737 --> 00:07:52.186
in West Virginia.

00:07:52.598 --> 00:07:56.957
The unit insists that all the visits
have to be in English for CMU prisoners,

00:07:56.981 --> 00:08:00.179
which is an additional hardship
for many of the Muslim families.

00:08:00.592 --> 00:08:03.974
There is a thick sheet of foggy,
bulletproof glass

00:08:03.998 --> 00:08:07.256
and on the other side was Daniel McGowan.

00:08:08.062 --> 00:08:10.920
We spoke through these handsets
attached to the wall

00:08:10.944 --> 00:08:13.268
and talked about books and movies.

00:08:13.292 --> 00:08:15.916
We did our best to find reasons to laugh.

00:08:16.512 --> 00:08:19.679
To fight boredom and amuse himself
while in the CMU,

00:08:19.703 --> 00:08:23.783
McGowan had been spreading a rumor
that I was secretly the president

00:08:23.807 --> 00:08:27.778
of a Twilight fan club in Washington, DC

00:08:27.802 --> 00:08:29.357
(Laughter)

00:08:29.794 --> 00:08:32.143
For the record, I'm not.

00:08:32.167 --> 00:08:33.407
(Laughter)

00:08:33.712 --> 00:08:37.310
But I kind of the hope the FBI
now thinks that Bella and Edward

00:08:37.334 --> 00:08:39.480
are terrorist code names.

00:08:39.504 --> 00:08:41.014
(Laughter)

00:08:42.031 --> 00:08:48.473
During our visit, McGowan spoke most
and at length about his niece Lily,

00:08:48.497 --> 00:08:54.621
his wife Jenny and how torturous
it feels to never be able to hug them,

00:08:54.645 --> 00:08:56.875
to never be able to hold their hands.

00:08:58.185 --> 00:09:01.708
Three months after our visit, McGowan
was transferred out of the CMU

00:09:01.732 --> 00:09:04.748
and then, without warning,
he was sent back again.

00:09:05.914 --> 00:09:10.154
I had published leaked
CMU documents on my website

00:09:10.178 --> 00:09:13.399
and the Counterterrorism Unit said
that McGowan had called his wife

00:09:13.423 --> 00:09:15.709
and asked her to mail them.

00:09:16.265 --> 00:09:18.998
He wanted to see what the government
was saying about him,

00:09:19.022 --> 00:09:21.630
and for that he was sent back to the CMU.

00:09:21.940 --> 00:09:24.590
When he was finally released
at the end of his sentence,

00:09:24.614 --> 00:09:26.696
his story got even more Kafkaesque.

00:09:27.392 --> 00:09:29.932
He wrote an article
for the Huffington Post headlined,

00:09:29.956 --> 00:09:33.657
"Court Documents Prove I was Sent to
a CMU for my Political Speech."

00:09:34.080 --> 00:09:39.995
The next day he was thrown
back in jail for his political speech.

00:09:40.881 --> 00:09:42.914
His attorneys quickly secured his release,

00:09:42.938 --> 00:09:45.536
but the message was very clear:

00:09:45.560 --> 00:09:47.259
Don't talk about this place.

00:09:48.430 --> 00:09:53.023
Today, nine years after they were opened
by the Bush administration,

00:09:53.047 --> 00:09:57.640
the government is codifying
how and why CMUs were created.

00:09:57.664 --> 00:09:59.336
According to the Bureau of Prisons,

00:09:59.360 --> 00:10:03.334
they are for prisoners
with "inspirational significance."

00:10:04.283 --> 00:10:08.487
I think that is very nice way of saying
these are political prisons

00:10:08.511 --> 00:10:10.095
for political prisoners.

00:10:10.722 --> 00:10:13.478
Prisoners are sent to a CMU
because of their race,

00:10:13.502 --> 00:10:16.149
their religion or their
political beliefs.

00:10:16.728 --> 00:10:19.549
Now, if you think that
characterization is too strong,

00:10:19.573 --> 00:10:22.390
just look at some
of the government's own documents.

00:10:22.414 --> 00:10:26.930
When some of McGowan's mail was rejected
by the CMU, the sender was told

00:10:26.954 --> 00:10:30.568
it's because the letters were intended
"for political prisoners."

00:10:31.368 --> 00:10:35.186
When another prisoner, animal rights
activist Andy Stepanian,

00:10:35.210 --> 00:10:40.599
was sent to a CMU, it was because of his
anti-government and anti-corporate views.

00:10:41.680 --> 00:10:44.650
Now, I know all of this
may be hard to believe,

00:10:44.674 --> 00:10:48.632
that it's happening right now,
and in the United States.

00:10:49.117 --> 00:10:52.753
But the unknown reality
is that the US has a dark history

00:10:52.777 --> 00:10:57.168
of disproportionately punishing people
because of their political beliefs.

00:10:57.628 --> 00:11:02.074
In the 1960s, before Marion
was home to the CMU,

00:11:02.098 --> 00:11:04.979
it was home to the notorious Control Unit.

00:11:05.532 --> 00:11:09.481
Prisoners were locked down
in solitary for 22 hours a day.

00:11:10.198 --> 00:11:15.904
The warden said the unit
was to "control revolutionary attitudes."

00:11:16.804 --> 00:11:21.751
In the 1980s, another experiment called
the Lexington High Security Unit

00:11:21.775 --> 00:11:24.203
held women connected
to the Weather Underground,

00:11:24.227 --> 00:11:27.493
Black Liberation and Puerto Rican
independent struggles.

00:11:27.945 --> 00:11:32.191
The prison radically restricted
communication and used sleep deprivation,

00:11:32.215 --> 00:11:36.812
and constant light for so-called
"ideological conversion."

00:11:37.934 --> 00:11:43.026
Those prisons were eventually shut down,
but only through the campaigning

00:11:43.050 --> 00:11:47.451
of religious groups and human rights
advocates, like Amnesty International.

00:11:48.356 --> 00:11:52.282
Today, civil rights lawyers
with the Center for Constitutional Rights

00:11:52.306 --> 00:11:54.685
are challenging CMUs in court

00:11:54.709 --> 00:11:57.264
for depriving prisoners
of their due process rights

00:11:57.288 --> 00:11:59.368
and for retaliating against them

00:11:59.392 --> 00:12:02.702
for their protected political
and religious speech.

00:12:03.254 --> 00:12:06.922
Many of these documents would have
never come to light without this lawsuit.

00:12:08.356 --> 00:12:12.987
The message of these groups
and my message for you today

00:12:13.011 --> 00:12:16.767
is that we must bear witness
to what is being done to these prisoners.

00:12:16.791 --> 00:12:21.834
Their treatment is a reflection
of the values held beyond prison walls.

00:12:22.297 --> 00:12:24.913
This story is not just about prisoners.

00:12:24.937 --> 00:12:26.961
It is about us.

00:12:26.985 --> 00:12:29.732
It is about our own commitment
to human rights.

00:12:29.756 --> 00:12:34.481
It is about whether we will choose to stop
repeating the mistakes of our past.

00:12:35.035 --> 00:12:40.067
If we don't listen to what Father Berrigan
described as the stories of the dead,

00:12:40.091 --> 00:12:42.554
they will soon become
the stories of ourselves.

00:12:42.858 --> 00:12:44.008
Thank you.

00:12:44.032 --> 00:12:46.730
(Applause)

00:12:51.395 --> 00:12:53.395
(Applause ends)

00:12:53.807 --> 00:12:55.642
Tom Rielly: I have a couple questions.

00:12:55.666 --> 00:12:59.594
When I was in high school,
I learned about the Bill of Rights,

00:12:59.618 --> 00:13:02.514
the Constitution, freedom of speech,

00:13:02.538 --> 00:13:07.071
due process and 
about 25 other laws and rights

00:13:07.095 --> 00:13:08.879
that seem to be violated by this.

00:13:09.664 --> 00:13:12.368
How could this possibly be happening?

00:13:12.392 --> 00:13:15.083
Will Potter: I think that's
the number one question I get

00:13:15.107 --> 00:13:17.094
throughout all of my work,

00:13:17.118 --> 00:13:20.252
and the short answer is
that people don't know.

00:13:20.767 --> 00:13:24.658
I think the solution to any of these types
of situations, any rights abuses,

00:13:24.682 --> 00:13:26.375
are really dependent on two things.

00:13:26.399 --> 00:13:29.195
They're dependent on knowledge
that it's actually happening

00:13:29.219 --> 00:13:33.501
and then a means and efficacy
to actually make a change.

00:13:33.525 --> 00:13:35.922
And unfortunately with these prisoners,

00:13:35.946 --> 00:13:38.521
one, people don't know
what's happening at all

00:13:38.545 --> 00:13:41.133
and then they're already
disenfranchised populations

00:13:41.157 --> 00:13:45.189
who don't have access to attorneys,
not native English speakers.

00:13:45.213 --> 00:13:48.623
In some of these cases, they have great
representation that I mentioned,

00:13:48.647 --> 00:13:51.709
but there's just not a public awareness
of what's happening.

title: How CRISPR lets us edit our DNA
transcript: A few years ago, with my colleague, Emmanuelle Charpentier, I invented a new technology for editing genomes. It's called CRISPR-Cas9. The CRISPR technology allows scientists to make changes to the DNA in cells that could allow us to cure genetic disease.You might be interested to know that the CRISPR technology came about through a basic research project that was aimed at discovering how bacteria fight viral infections. Bacteria have to deal with viruses in their environment, and we can think about a viral infection like a ticking time bomb — a bacterium has only a few minutes to defuse the bomb before it gets destroyed. So, many bacteria have in their cells an adaptive immune system called CRISPR, that allows them to detect viral DNA and destroy it.Part of the CRISPR system is a protein called Cas9, that's able to seek out, cut and eventually degrade viral DNA in a specific way. And it was through our research to understand the activity of this protein, Cas9, that we realized that we could harness its function as a genetic engineering technology — a way for scientists to delete or insert specific bits of DNA into cells with incredible precision — that would offer opportunities to do things that really haven't been possible in the past.The CRISPR technology has already been used to change the DNA in the cells of mice and monkeys, other organisms as well. Chinese scientists showed recently that they could even use the CRISPR technology to change genes in human embryos. And scientists in Philadelphia showed they could use CRISPR to remove the DNA of an integrated HIV virus from infected human cells.The opportunity to do this kind of genome editing also raises various ethical issues that we have to consider, because this technology can be employed not only in adult cells, but also in the embryos of organisms, including our own species. And so, together with my colleagues, I've called for a global conversation about the technology that I co-invented, so that we can consider all of the ethical and societal implications of a technology like this.What I want to do now is tell you what the CRISPR technology is, what it can do, where we are today and why I think we need to take a prudent path forward in the way that we employ this technology.When viruses infect a cell, they inject their DNA. And in a bacterium, the CRISPR system allows that DNA to be plucked out of the virus, and inserted in little bits into the chromosome — the DNA of the bacterium. And these integrated bits of viral DNA get inserted at a site called CRISPR. CRISPR stands for clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats. (Laughter)A big mouthful — you can see why we use the acronym CRISPR. It's a mechanism that allows cells to record, over time, the viruses they have been exposed to. And importantly, those bits of DNA are passed on to the cells' progeny, so cells are protected from viruses not only in one generation, but over many generations of cells. This allows the cells to keep a record of infection, and as my colleague, Blake Wiedenheft, likes to say, the CRISPR locus is effectively a genetic vaccination card in cells. Once those bits of DNA have been inserted into the bacterial chromosome, the cell then makes a little copy of a molecule called RNA, which is orange in this picture, that is an exact replicate of the viral DNA. RNA is a chemical cousin of DNA, and it allows interaction with DNA molecules that have a matching sequence.So those little bits of RNA from the CRISPR locus associate — they bind — to protein called Cas9, which is white in the picture, and form a complex that functions like a sentinel in the cell. It searches through all of the DNA in the cell, to find sites that match the sequences in the bound RNAs. And when those sites are found — as you can see here, the blue molecule is DNA — this complex associates with that DNA and allows the Cas9 cleaver to cut up the viral DNA. It makes a very precise break. So we can think of the Cas9 RNA sentinel complex like a pair of scissors that can cut DNA — it makes a double-stranded break in the DNA helix. And importantly, this complex is programmable, so it can be programmed to recognize particular DNA sequences, and make a break in the DNA at that site.As I'm going to tell you now, we recognized that that activity could be harnessed for genome engineering, to allow cells to make a very precise change to the DNA at the site where this break was introduced. That's sort of analogous to the way that we use a word-processing program to fix a typo in a document.The reason we envisioned using the CRISPR system for genome engineering is because cells have the ability to detect broken DNA and repair it. So when a plant or an animal cell detects a double-stranded break in its DNA, it can fix that break, either by pasting together the ends of the broken DNA with a little, tiny change in the sequence of that position, or it can repair the break by integrating a new piece of DNA at the site of the cut. So if we have a way to introduce double-stranded breaks into DNA at precise places, we can trigger cells to repair those breaks, by either the disruption or incorporation of new genetic information. So if we were able to program the CRISPR technology to make a break in DNA at the position at or near a mutation causing cystic fibrosis, for example, we could trigger cells to repair that mutation.Genome engineering is actually not new, it's been in development since the 1970s. We've had technologies for sequencing DNA, for copying DNA, and even for manipulating DNA. And these technologies were very promising, but the problem was that they were either inefficient, or they were difficult enough to use that most scientists had not adopted them for use in their own laboratories, or certainly for many clinical applications. So, the opportunity to take a technology like CRISPR and utilize it has appeal, because of its relative simplicity. We can think of older genome engineering technologies as similar to having to rewire your computer each time you want to run a new piece of software, whereas the CRISPR technology is like software for the genome, we can program it easily, using these little bits of RNA.So once a double-stranded break is made in DNA, we can induce repair, and thereby potentially achieve astounding things, like being able to correct mutations that cause sickle cell anemia or cause Huntington's Disease. I actually think that the first applications of the CRISPR technology are going to happen in the blood, where it's relatively easier to deliver this tool into cells, compared to solid tissues.Right now, a lot of the work that's going on applies to animal models of human disease, such as mice. The technology is being used to make very precise changes that allow us to study the way that these changes in the cell's DNA affect either a tissue or, in this case, an entire organism.Now in this example, the CRISPR technology was used to disrupt a gene by making a tiny change in the DNA in a gene that is responsible for the black coat color of these mice. Imagine that these white mice differ from their pigmented litter-mates by just a tiny change at one gene in the entire genome, and they're otherwise completely normal. And when we sequence the DNA from these animals, we find that the change in the DNA has occurred at exactly the place where we induced it, using the CRISPR technology.Additional experiments are going on in other animals that are useful for creating models for human disease, such as monkeys. And here we find that we can use these systems to test the application of this technology in particular tissues, for example, figuring out how to deliver the CRISPR tool into cells. We also want to understand better how to control the way that DNA is repaired after it's cut, and also to figure out how to control and limit any kind of off-target, or unintended effects of using the technology.I think that we will see clinical application of this technology, certainly in adults, within the next 10 years. I think that it's likely that we will see clinical trials and possibly even approved therapies within that time, which is a very exciting thing to think about. And because of the excitement around this technology, there's a lot of interest in start-up companies that have been founded to commercialize the CRISPR technology, and lots of venture capitalists that have been investing in these companies.But we have to also consider that the CRISPR technology can be used for things like enhancement. Imagine that we could try to engineer humans that have enhanced properties, such as stronger bones, or less susceptibility to cardiovascular disease or even to have properties that we would consider maybe to be desirable, like a different eye color or to be taller, things like that. "Designer humans," if you will. Right now, the genetic information to understand what types of genes would give rise to these traits is mostly not known.
