on one of those massifs,

00:06:37.062 --> 00:06:40.913
the Auyán-tepui, which is very famous
because it hosts Angel Falls,

00:06:40.937 --> 00:06:43.526
which is the highest
waterfall in the world --

00:06:43.550 --> 00:06:47.609
about 979 meters of vertical drop.

00:06:47.633 --> 00:06:52.519
And I was searching for hints
of the existence of cave systems

00:06:52.543 --> 00:06:54.411
through satellite images,

00:06:54.435 --> 00:06:59.125
and finally we identified an area
of collapses of the surface --

00:06:59.149 --> 00:07:01.395
so, big boulders, rock piles --

00:07:01.419 --> 00:07:04.730
and that means that there
was a void below.

00:07:04.754 --> 00:07:08.703
It was a clear indication that there
was something inside the mountain.

00:07:08.727 --> 00:07:13.573
So we did several attempts
to reach this area,

00:07:13.597 --> 00:07:15.359
by land and with a helicopter,

00:07:15.383 --> 00:07:18.933
but it was really difficult
because -- you have to imagine

00:07:18.957 --> 00:07:23.336
that these mountains are covered
by clouds most of the year, by fog.

00:07:23.360 --> 00:07:24.733
There are strong winds,

00:07:24.757 --> 00:07:29.339
and there are almost 4,000 millimeters
of rainfall per year,

00:07:29.363 --> 00:07:32.625
so it's really, really difficult
to find good conditions.

00:07:32.649 --> 00:07:37.432
And only in 2013 we finally
landed on the spot

00:07:37.456 --> 00:07:39.950
and we started
the exploration of the cave.

00:07:40.681 --> 00:07:42.598
The cave is huge.

00:07:42.622 --> 00:07:46.449
It's a huge network under the surface
of the tepui plateau,

00:07:46.473 --> 00:07:50.167
and in only ten days of expedition,

00:07:50.191 --> 00:07:54.314
we explored more than 20 kilometers
of cave passages.

00:07:54.338 --> 00:07:59.735
And it's a huge network
of underground rivers,

00:07:59.759 --> 00:08:04.933
channels, big rooms,
extremely deep shafts.

00:08:04.957 --> 00:08:07.981
So it's really an incredible place.

00:08:08.005 --> 00:08:10.546
And we named it Imawarì Yeuta.

00:08:10.570 --> 00:08:16.831
That means, in the Pemón indigenous
language, "The House of the Gods."

00:08:16.855 --> 00:08:20.637
You have to imagine that indigenous people
have never been there.

00:08:20.661 --> 00:08:24.166
It was impossible for them
to reach this area.

00:08:24.190 --> 00:08:26.396
However, there were legends
about the existence

00:08:26.420 --> 00:08:28.447
of a cave in the mountain.

00:08:28.471 --> 00:08:30.241
So when we started the exploration,

00:08:30.265 --> 00:08:32.495
we had to explore with a great respect,

00:08:32.519 --> 00:08:36.080
both because of the religious beliefs
of the indigenous people,

00:08:36.104 --> 00:08:38.469
but also because
it was really a sacred place,

00:08:38.493 --> 00:08:41.828
because no human had entered there before.

00:08:41.852 --> 00:08:43.655
So we had to use special protocols

00:08:43.679 --> 00:08:46.468
to not contaminate the environment
with our presence,

00:08:46.492 --> 00:08:48.667
and we tried also to share
with the community,

00:08:48.691 --> 00:08:51.364
with the indigenous community,
our discoveries.

00:08:51.388 --> 00:08:55.944
And the caves represent, really,
a snapshot of the past.

00:08:56.461 --> 00:08:59.173
The time needed for their formation

00:08:59.197 --> 00:09:04.121
could be as long as 50 or even
100 million years,

00:09:04.145 --> 00:09:09.046
which makes them possibly the oldest caves
that we can explore on earth.

00:09:10.879 --> 00:09:16.606
What you can find there
is really evidence of a lost world.

00:09:17.259 --> 00:09:19.246
When you enter a quartzite cave,

00:09:19.270 --> 00:09:22.718
you have to completely forget
what you know about caves --

00:09:22.742 --> 00:09:25.739
classic limestone caves
or the touristic caves

00:09:25.763 --> 00:09:28.120
that you can visit
in several places in the world.

00:09:28.144 --> 00:09:31.069
Because what seems
a simple stalactite here

00:09:31.093 --> 00:09:36.178
is not made by calcium carbonate,
but is made by opal,

00:09:36.202 --> 00:09:41.786
and one of those stalactites can require
tens of millions of years to be formed.

00:09:42.643 --> 00:09:46.720
But you can find even stranger forms,
like these mushrooms of silica

00:09:46.744 --> 00:09:48.818
growing on a boulder.

00:09:48.842 --> 00:09:52.628
And you can imagine our talks
when we were exploring the cave.

00:09:52.652 --> 00:09:57.645
We were the first entering
and discovering those unknown things,

00:09:57.669 --> 00:10:00.507
things like those monster eggs.

00:10:00.531 --> 00:10:04.927
And we were a bit scared
because it was all a discovery,

00:10:04.951 --> 00:10:07.034
and we didn't want to find a dinosaur.

00:10:07.058 --> 00:10:08.562
We didn't find a dinosaur.

00:10:08.586 --> 00:10:10.183
(Laughter)

00:10:10.207 --> 00:10:13.504
Anyway, actually, we know
that this kind of formation,

00:10:13.528 --> 00:10:16.061
after several studies,

00:10:16.085 --> 00:10:19.310
we know that these kinds of formations
are living organisms.

00:10:19.334 --> 00:10:24.768
They are bacterial colonies using silica
to build mineral structures

00:10:24.792 --> 00:10:26.722
resembling stromatolites.

00:10:26.746 --> 00:10:31.267
Stromatolites are some of the oldest
forms of life that we can find on earth.

00:10:31.291 --> 00:10:33.094
And here in the tepuis,

00:10:33.118 --> 00:10:37.801
the interesting thing is that these
bacteria colonies have evolved

00:10:37.825 --> 00:10:42.054
in complete isolation
from the external surface,

00:10:42.078 --> 00:10:44.702
and without being in contact with humans.

00:10:44.726 --> 00:10:47.323
They have never been
in contact with humans.

00:10:47.347 --> 00:10:50.414
So the implications
for science are enormous,

00:10:50.438 --> 00:10:54.440
because here you could find,
for example, microbes

00:10:54.464 --> 00:10:59.416
that could be useful to resolve
diseases in medicine,

00:10:59.440 --> 00:11:03.376
or you could find even a new kind
of material with unknown properties.

00:11:03.400 --> 00:11:07.459
And, in fact, we discovered in the cave
a new mineral structure for science,

00:11:07.483 --> 00:11:10.490
which is rossiantonite,
a phosphate-sulfate.

00:11:11.564 --> 00:11:16.278
So whatever you find in the cave,
even a small cricket,

00:11:16.302 --> 00:11:20.270
has evolved in the dark
in complete isolation.

00:11:20.294 --> 00:11:24.547
And, really, everything that you can feel
in the cave are real connections

00:11:24.571 --> 00:11:27.611
between the biological
and the mineralogical world.

00:11:28.502 --> 00:11:34.318
So as we explore this dark continent

00:11:34.342 --> 00:11:40.746
and discover its mineralogical
and biological diversity and uniqueness,

00:11:40.770 --> 00:11:45.139
we will find probably clues
about the origin of life on our planet

00:11:45.163 --> 00:11:48.140
and on the relationship
and evolution of life

00:11:48.164 --> 00:11:51.150
in relationship with the mineral world.

00:11:51.174 --> 00:11:55.116
What seems only a dark, empty environment

00:11:55.140 --> 00:11:57.933
could be in reality a chest of wonders

00:11:57.957 --> 00:12:00.437
full of useful information.

00:12:02.060 --> 00:12:05.933
With a team of Italian, Venezuelan
and Brazilian speleologists,

00:12:05.957 --> 00:12:09.148
which is called La Venta Teraphosa,

00:12:09.172 --> 00:12:11.240
we will be back soon to Latin America,

00:12:11.264 --> 00:12:16.712
because we want to explore other tepuis
in the farthest areas of the Amazon.

00:12:16.736 --> 00:12:19.756
There are still very unknown mountains,

00:12:19.780 --> 00:12:24.474
like Marahuaca, which is almost
3,000 meters high above sea level,

00:12:24.498 --> 00:12:28.597
or Aracà, which is in the upper region
of Rio Negro in Brazil.

00:12:28.621 --> 00:12:33.540
And we suppose that we could find there
even bigger cave systems,

00:12:33.564 --> 00:12:38.252
and each one with its own
undiscovered world.

00:12:38.594 --> 00:12:39.768
Thank you.

00:12:39.792 --> 00:12:45.246
(Applause)

00:12:45.270 --> 00:12:49.007
Bruno Giussani: Thank you, Francesco.
Give me that to start so we don't forget.

00:12:49.031 --> 00:12:52.869
Francesco, you said we don't need
to go to Mars to find alien life,

00:12:52.893 --> 00:12:55.818
and indeed, last time we spoke,
you were in Sardinia

00:12:55.842 --> 00:12:58.085
and you were training European astronauts.

00:12:58.109 --> 00:13:01.583
So what do you, a speleologist,
tell and teach to the astronauts?

00:13:01.607 --> 00:13:04.390
Francesco Sauro: Yeah, we are --
it's a program of training

00:13:04.414 --> 00:13:09.315
for not only European, but also NASA,
Roskosmos, JAXA astronauts, in a cave.

00:13:09.339 --> 00:13:12.867
So they stay in a cave
for about one week in isolation.

00:13:12.891 --> 00:13:16.771
They have to work together
in a real, real dangerous environment,

00:13:16.795 --> 00:13:20.605
and it's a real alien environment for them
because it's unusual.

00:13:20.629 --> 00:13:24.933
It's always dark. They have to do science.
They have a lot of tasks.

00:13:24.957 --> 00:13:27.489
And it's very similar to a journey to Mars

00:13:27.513 --> 00:13:29.185
or the International Space Station.

00:13:29.209 --> 00:13:30.468
BG: In principle.
FS: Yes.

00:13:30.492 --> 00:13:32.569
BG: I want to go back
to one of the pictures

00:13:32.593 --> 00:13:34.426
that was in your slide show,

00:13:34.450 --> 00:13:36.839
and it's just representative
of the other photos --

00:13:36.863 --> 00:13:39.161
Weren't those photos amazing? Yeah?

00:13:39.185 --> 00:13:40.343
Audience: Yeah!

00:13:40.367 --> 00:13:44.103
(Applause)

00:13:44.127 --> 00:13:47.253
FS: I have to thank the photographers
from the team La Venta,

00:13:47.277 --> 00:13:51.050
because all of those photos
are from the photographers.

00:13:51.074 --> 00:13:54.776
BG: You bring, actually, photographers
with you in the expedition.

00:13:54.800 --> 00:13:57.767
They're professionals,
they're speleologists and photographers.

00:13:57.791 --> 00:14:02.691
But when I look at these pictures,
I wonder: there is zero light down there,

00:14:02.715 --> 00:14:05.498
and yet they look incredibly well-exposed.

00:14:05.522 --> 00:14:07.010
How do you take these pictures?

00:14:07.034 --> 00:14:10.085
How do your colleagues,
the photographers, take these pictures?

00:14:10.109 --> 00:14:12.600
FS: Yeah. They are working
in a darkroom, basically,

00:14:12.624 --> 00:14:14.743
so you can open the shutter of the camera

00:14:14.767 --> 00:14:17.185
and use the lights
to paint the environment.

00:14:17.209 --> 00:14:18.464
BG: So you're basically --

00:14:18.488 --> 00:14:21.223
FS: Yes. You can even keep
the shutter open for one minute

00:14:21.247 --> 00:14:22.771
and then paint the environment.

00:14:22.795 --> 00:14:25.499
The final result is what
you want to achieve.

00:14:25.523 --> 00:14:28.596
BG: You spray the environment with light
and that's what you get.

00:14:28.620 --> 00:14:31.062
Maybe we can try this at home
someday, I don't know.

00:14:31.086 --> 00:14:32.090
(Laughter)

00:14:32.114 --> 00:14:33.705
BG: Francesco, grazie.
FS: Grazie.

00:14:33.729 --> 00:14:36.957
(Applause)

title: Social services are broken. How we can fix them
transcript: I want to tell you three stories about the power of relationships to solve the deep and complex social problems of this century.You know, sometimes it seems like all these problems of poverty, inequality, ill health, unemployment, violence, addiction — they're right there in one person's life. So I want to tell you about someone like this that I know. I'm going to call her Ella. Ella lives in a British city on a run down estate. The shops are closed, the pub's gone, the playground's pretty desolate and never used, and inside Ella's house, the tension is palpable and the noise levels are deafening. The TV's on at full volume. One of her sons is fighting with one of her daughters. Another son, Ryan, is keeping up this constant stream of abuse from the kitchen, and the dogs are locked behind the bedroom door and straining. Ella is stuck. She has lived with crisis for 40 years. She knows nothing else, and she knows no way out. She's had a whole series of abusive partners, and, tragically, one of her children has been taken into care by social services. The three children that still live with her suffer from a whole range of problems, and none of them are in education. And Ella says to me that she is repeating the cycle of her own mother's life before her.But when I met Ella, there were 73 different services on offer for her and her family in the city where she lives, 73 different services run out of 24 departments in one city, and Ella and her partners and her children were known to most of them. They think nothing of calling social services to try and mediate one of the many arguments that broke out. And the family home was visited on a regular basis by social workers, youth workers, a health officer, a housing officer, a home tutor and the local policemen. And the governments say that there are 100,000 families in Britain today like Ella's, struggling to break the cycle of economic, social and environmental deprivation. And they also say that managing this problem costs a quarter of a million pounds per family per year and yet nothing changes. None of these well-meaning visitors are making a difference.This is a chart we made in the same city with another family like Ella's. This shows 30 years of intervention in that family's life. And just as with Ella, not one of these interventions is part of an overall plan. There's no end goal in sight. None of the interventions are dealing with the underlying issues. These are just containment measures, ways of managing a problem. One of the policemen says to me, "Look, I just deliver the message and then I leave."So, I've spent time living with families like Ella's in different parts of the world, because I want to know: what can we learn from places where our social institutions just aren't working? I want to know what it feels like to live in Ella's family. I want to know what's going on and what we can do differently.Well, the first thing I learned is that cost is a really slippery concept. Because when the government says that a family like Ella's costs a quarter of a million pounds a year to manage, what it really means is that this system costs a quarter of a million pounds a year. Because not one penny of this money actually touches Ella's family in a way that makes a difference. Instead, the system is just like this costly gyroscope that spins around the families, keeping them stuck at its heart, exactly where they are.And I also spent time with the frontline workers, and I learned that it is an impossible situation. So Tom, who is the social worker for Ella's 14-year-old son Ryan, has to spend 86 percent of his time servicing the system: meetings with colleagues, filling out forms, more meetings with colleagues to discuss the forms, and maybe most shockingly, the 14 percent of the time he has to be with Ryan is spent getting data and information for the system. So he says to Ryan, "How often have you been smoking? Have you been drinking? When did you go to school?" And this kind of interaction rules out the possibility of a normal conversation. It rules out the possibility of what's needed to build a relationship between Tom and Ryan.When we made this chart, the frontline workers, the professionals — they stared at it absolutely amazed. It snaked around the walls of their offices. So many hours, so well meant, but ultimately so futile. And there was this moment of absolute breakdown, and then of clarity: we had to work in a different way.So in a really brave step, the leaders of the city where Ella lives agreed that we could start by reversing Ryan's ratio. So everyone who came into contact with Ella or a family like Ella's would spend 80 percent of their time working with the families and only 20 percent servicing the system. And even more radically, the families would lead and they would decide who was in a best position to help them. So Ella and another mother were asked to be part of an interview panel, to choose from amongst the existing professionals who would work with them. And many, many people wanted to join us, because you don't go into this kind of work to manage a system, you go in because you can and you want to make a difference.So Ella and the mother asked everybody who came through the door, "What will you do when my son starts kicking me?" And so the first person who comes in says, "Well, I'll look around for the nearest exit and I will back out very slowly, and if the noise is still going on, I'll call my supervisor." And the mothers go, "You're the system. Get out of here!" And then the next person who comes is a policeman, and he says, "Well, I'll tackle your son to the ground and then I'm not sure what I'll do." And the mothers say, "Thank you." So, they chose professionals who confessed they didn't necessarily have the answers, who said — well, they weren't going to talk in jargon. They showed their human qualities and convinced the mothers that they would stick with them through thick and thin, even though they wouldn't be soft with them.So these new teams and the families were then given a sliver of the former budget, but they could spend the money in any way they chose. And so one of the families went out for supper. They went to McDonald's and they sat down and they talked and they listened for the first time in a long time. Another family asked the team if they would help them do up their home. And one mother took the money and she used it as a float to start a social enterprise.And in a really short space of time, something new started to grow: a relationship between the team and the workers. And then some remarkable changes took place. Maybe it's not surprising that the journey for Ella has had some big steps backwards as well as forwards. But today, she's completed an IT training course, she has her first paid job, her children are back in school, and the neighbors, who previously just hoped this family would be moved anywhere except next door to them, are fine. They've made some new friendships. And all the same people have been involved in this transformation — same families, same workers. But the relationship between them has been supported to change.So I'm telling you about Ella because I think that relationships are the critical resource we have in solving some of these intractable problems. But today, our relationships are all but written off by our politics, our social policies, our welfare institutions. And I've learned that this really has to change.So what do I mean by relationships? I'm talking about the simple human bonds between us, a kind of authentic sense of connection, of belonging, the bonds that make us happy, that support us to change, to be brave like Ella and try something new. And, you know, it's no accident that those who run and work in the institutions that are supposed to support Ella and her family don't talk about relationships, because relationships are expressly designed out of a welfare model that was drawn up in Britain and exported around the world. The contemporaries of William Beveridge, who was the architect of the first welfare state and the author of the Beveridge Report, had little faith in what they called the average sensual or emotional man. Instead, they trusted this idea of the impersonal system and the bureaucrat who would be detached and work in this system. And the impact of Beveridge on the way the modern state sees social issues just can't be underestimated. The Beveridge Report sold over 100,000 copies in the first weeks of publication alone. People queued in the rain on a November night to get hold of a copy, and it was read across the country, across the colonies, across Europe, across the United States of America, and it had this huge impact on the way that welfare states were designed around the globe. The cultures, the bureaucracies, the institutions — they are global, and they've come to seem like common sense. They've become so ingrained in us, that actually we don't even see them anymore. And I think it's really important to say that in the 20th century, they were remarkably successful, these institutions. They led to longer lifespans, the eradication of mass disease, mass housing, almost universal education. But at the same time, Beveridge sowed the seeds of today's challenges.So let me tell you a second story. What do you think today is a bigger killer than a lifetime of smoking? It's loneliness. According to government statistics, one person over 60 — one in three — doesn't speak to or see another person in a week. One person in 10, that's 850,000 people, doesn't speak to anyone else in a month. And we're not the only people with this problem; this problem touches the whole of the Western world. And it's even more acute in countries like China, where a process of rapid urbanization, mass migration, has left older people alone in the villages. And so the services that Beveridge designed and exported — they can't address this kind of problem. Loneliness is like a collective relational challenge, and it can't be addressed by a traditional bureaucratic response.So some years ago, wanting to understand this problem, I started to work with a group of about 60 older people in South London, where I live. I went shopping, I played bingo, but mainly I was just observing and listening. I wanted to know what we could do differently. And if you ask them, people tell you they want two things. They want somebody to go up a ladder and change a light bulb, or to be there when they come out of hospital. They want on-demand, practical support. And they want to have fun. They want to go out, do interesting things with like-minded people, and make friends like we've all made friends at every stage of our lives. So we rented a phone line, hired a couple of handymen, and started a service we called "Circle." And Circle offers its local membership a toll-free 0 800 number that they can call on demand for any support. And people have called us for so many reasons. They've called because their pets are unwell, their DVD is broken, they've forgotten how to use their mobile phone, or maybe they are coming out of hospital and they want someone to be there. And Circle also offers a rich social calendar — knitting, darts, museum tours, hot air ballooning — you name it. But here's the interesting thing, the really deep change: over time, the friendships that have formed have begun to replace the practical offer.So let me tell you about Belinda. Belinda's a Circle member, and she was going into hospital for a hip operation, so she called her local Circle to say they wouldn't see her for a bit. And Damon, who runs the local Circle, calls her back and says, "How can I help?" And Belinda says, "Oh no, I'm fine — Jocelyn is doing the shopping, Tony's doing the gardening, Melissa and Joe are going to come in and cook and chat." So five Circle members had organized themselves to take care of Belinda. And Belinda's 80, although she says that she feels 25 inside, but she also says that she felt stuck and pretty down when she joined Circle. But the simple act of encouraging her to come along to that first event led to a process where natural friendships formed, friendships that today are replacing the need for expensive services. It's relationships that are making the difference.So I think that three factors have converged that enable us to put relationships at the heart and center of how we solve social problems today. Firstly, the nature of the problems — they've changed, and they require different solutions. Secondly, the cost, human as much as financial, of doing business as usual. And thirdly, technology.I've talked about the first two factors. It's technology that enables these approaches to scale and potentially now support thousands of people. So the technology we've used is really simple, it's made up of available things like databases, mobile phones. Circle has got this very simple system that underpins it, enables a small local team to support a membership of up to a thousand. And you can contrast this with a neighborhood organization of the 1970s, when this kind of scale just wasn't possible, neither was the quality or the longevity that the spine of technology can provide.So it's relationships underpinned by technology that can turn the Beveridge models on their heads. The Beveridge models are all about institutions with finite resources, anonymously managing access. In my work at the front line, I've seen again and again how up to 80 percent of resource is spent keeping people out. So professionals have to administer these increasingly complex forms of administration that are basically about stopping people accessing the service or managing the queue. And Circle, like the relational services that we and others have designed, inverts this logic. What it says is, the more people, the more relationships, the stronger the solution. So I want to tell you my third and final story, which is about unemployment. In Britain, as in most places in the world, our welfare states were primarily designed to get people into work, to educate them for this, and to keep them healthy. But here, too, the systems are failing. And so the response has been to try and make these old systems even more efficient and transactional — to speed up processing times, divide people into ever-smaller categories, try and target services at them more efficiently — in other words, the very opposite of relational.But guess how most people find work today? Through word of mouth. It turns out that in Britain today, most new jobs are not advertised. So it's friends that tell you about a job, it's friends that recommend you for a job, and it's a rich and diverse social network that helps you find work. Maybe some of you here this evening are thinking, "But I found my job through an advert," but if you think back, it was probably a friend that showed you the ad and then encouraged you to apply. But not surprisingly, people who perhaps most need this rich and diverse network are those who are most isolated from it.So knowing this, and also knowing about the costs and failure of current systems, we designed something new with relationships at its heart. We designed a service that encourages people to meet up, people in and out of work, to work together in structured ways and try new opportunities. And, well, it's very hard to compare the results of these new systems with the old transactional models, but it looks like, with our first 1,000 members, we outperformed existing services by a factor of three, at a fraction of the cost. And here, too, we've used technology, but not to network people in the way that a social platform would do. We've used it to bring people face to face and connect them with each other, building real relationships and supporting people to find work.At the end of his life, in 1948, Beveridge wrote a third report. And in it he said he had made a dreadful mistake. He had left people and their communities out. And this omission, he said, led to seeing people, and people starting to see themselves, within the categories of the bureaucracies and the institutions. And human relationships were already withering. But unfortunately, this third report was much less read than Beveridge's earlier work.But today, we need to bring people and their communities back into the heart of the way we design new systems and new services, in an approach that I call "Relational Welfare." We need to leave behind these old, transactional, unsuitable, outdated models, and we need to adopt instead the shared collective relational responses that can support a family like Ella's, that can address an issue like loneliness, that can support people into work and up the skills curve in a modern labor market, that can also address challenges of education, of health care systems, and so many more of those problems that are pressing on our societies. It is all about relationships. Relationships are the critical resource we have.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.719 --> 00:00:15.207
I want to tell you three stories

00:00:15.231 --> 00:00:17.683
about the power of relationships

00:00:17.707 --> 00:00:21.996
to solve the deep and complex
social problems of this century.

00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:24.933
You know, sometimes it seems
like all these problems

00:00:24.957 --> 00:00:29.746
of poverty, inequality, ill health,
unemployment, violence, addiction --

00:00:29.770 --> 00:00:32.596
they're right there in one person's life.

00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:36.301
So I want to tell you about someone
like this that I know.

00:00:36.325 --> 00:00:38.394
I'm going to call her Ella.

00:00:38.418 --> 00:00:42.124
Ella lives in a British city
on a run down estate.

00:00:42.148 --> 00:00:44.342
The shops are closed, the pub's gone,

00:00:44.366 --> 00:00:46.665
the playground's pretty desolate
and never used,

00:00:46.689 --> 00:00:49.515
and inside Ella's house,
the tension is palpable

00:00:49.539 --> 00:00:51.539
and the noise levels are deafening.

00:00:51.563 --> 00:00:53.377
The TV's on at full volume.

00:00:53.401 --> 00:00:55.933
One of her sons is fighting
with one of her daughters.

00:00:55.957 --> 00:00:59.728
Another son, Ryan, is keeping up this
constant stream of abuse from the kitchen,

00:00:59.752 --> 00:01:02.933
and the dogs are locked
behind the bedroom door and straining.

00:01:02.957 --> 00:01:04.669
Ella is stuck.

00:01:04.693 --> 00:01:07.253
She has lived with crisis for 40 years.

00:01:07.277 --> 00:01:11.011
She knows nothing else,
and she knows no way out.

00:01:11.035 --> 00:01:13.684
She's had a whole series
of abusive partners,

00:01:13.708 --> 00:01:18.025
and, tragically, one of her children has
been taken into care by social services.

00:01:18.049 --> 00:01:20.321
The three children
that still live with her

00:01:20.345 --> 00:01:23.820
suffer from a whole range of problems,
and none of them are in education.

00:01:23.844 --> 00:01:26.841
And Ella says to me that she
is repeating the cycle

00:01:26.865 --> 00:01:29.629
of her own mother's life before her.

00:01:29.653 --> 00:01:32.933
But when I met Ella,
there were 73 different services

00:01:32.957 --> 00:01:36.095
on offer for her and her family
in the city where she lives,

00:01:36.119 --> 00:01:40.388
73 different services
run out of 24 departments in one city,

00:01:40.412 --> 00:01:43.722
and Ella and her partners and her children
were known to most of them.

00:01:43.746 --> 00:01:45.860
They think nothing of calling
social services

00:01:45.884 --> 00:01:48.736
to try and mediate one of the many
arguments that broke out.

00:01:48.760 --> 00:01:52.209
And the family home was visited
on a regular basis by social workers,

00:01:52.233 --> 00:01:56.933
youth workers, a health officer,
a housing officer, a home tutor

00:01:56.957 --> 00:01:58.933
and the local policemen.

00:01:58.957 --> 00:02:01.695
And the governments say
that there are 100,000 families

00:02:01.719 --> 00:02:03.818
in Britain today like Ella's,

00:02:03.842 --> 00:02:09.203
struggling to break the cycle of economic,
social and environmental deprivation.

00:02:09.227 --> 00:02:11.401
And they also say
that managing this problem

00:02:11.425 --> 00:02:14.427
costs a quarter of a million pounds
per family per year

00:02:14.451 --> 00:02:15.823
and yet nothing changes.

00:02:15.847 --> 00:02:18.933
None of these well-meaning visitors
are making a difference.

00:02:18.957 --> 00:02:23.240
This is a chart we made in the same city
with another family like Ella's.

00:02:23.264 --> 00:02:26.866
This shows 30 years of intervention
in that family's life.

00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:30.721
And just as with Ella, not one of these
interventions is part of an overall plan.

00:02:30.745 --> 00:02:32.192
There's no end goal in sight.

00:02:32.216 --> 00:02:35.267
None of the interventions
are dealing with the underlying issues.

00:02:35.291 --> 00:02:38.301
These are just containment measures,
ways of managing a problem.

00:02:38.325 --> 00:02:40.044
One of the policemen says to me,

00:02:40.068 --> 00:02:42.557
"Look, I just deliver the message
and then I leave."

00:02:42.581 --> 00:02:45.266
So, I've spent time living
with families like Ella's

00:02:45.290 --> 00:02:46.830
in different parts of the world,

00:02:46.854 --> 00:02:49.092
because I want to know: what can we learn

00:02:49.116 --> 00:02:52.609
from places where our social institutions
just aren't working?

00:02:52.633 --> 00:02:55.424
I want to know what it feels like
to live in Ella's family.

00:02:55.448 --> 00:02:59.459
I want to know what's going on
and what we can do differently.

00:02:59.483 --> 00:03:03.572
Well, the first thing I learned
is that cost is a really slippery concept.

00:03:03.596 --> 00:03:06.314
Because when the government says
that a family like Ella's

00:03:06.338 --> 00:03:08.935
costs a quarter of a million pounds
a year to manage,

00:03:08.959 --> 00:03:10.110
what it really means

00:03:10.134 --> 00:03:13.104
is that this system costs
a quarter of a million pounds a year.

00:03:13.128 --> 00:03:16.243
Because not one penny of this money
actually touches Ella's family

00:03:16.267 --> 00:03:17.847
in a way that makes a difference.

00:03:17.871 --> 00:03:20.414
Instead, the system is just
like this costly gyroscope

00:03:20.438 --> 00:03:23.417
that spins around the families,
keeping them stuck at its heart,

00:03:23.441 --> 00:03:25.466
exactly where they are.

00:03:25.490 --> 00:03:27.813
And I also spent time
with the frontline workers,

00:03:27.837 --> 00:03:30.660
and I learned that it
is an impossible situation.

00:03:30.684 --> 00:03:35.399
So Tom, who is the social worker
for Ella's 14-year-old son Ryan,

00:03:35.423 --> 00:03:38.933
has to spend 86 percent of his time
servicing the system:

00:03:38.957 --> 00:03:41.028
meetings with colleagues,
filling out forms,

00:03:41.052 --> 00:03:43.480
more meetings with colleagues
to discuss the forms,

00:03:43.504 --> 00:03:44.750
and maybe most shockingly,

00:03:44.774 --> 00:03:47.343
the 14 percent of the time
he has to be with Ryan

00:03:47.367 --> 00:03:49.863
is spent getting data
and information for the system.

00:03:49.887 --> 00:03:51.038
So he says to Ryan,

00:03:51.062 --> 00:03:53.749
"How often have you been smoking?
Have you been drinking?

00:03:53.773 --> 00:03:55.086
When did you go to school?"

00:03:55.110 --> 00:03:57.660
And this kind of interaction
rules out the possibility

00:03:57.684 --> 00:03:58.896
of a normal conversation.

00:03:58.920 --> 00:04:01.038
It rules out the possibility
of what's needed

00:04:01.062 --> 00:04:04.039
to build a relationship
between Tom and Ryan.

00:04:04.957 --> 00:04:06.346
When we made this chart,

00:04:06.370 --> 00:04:08.385
the frontline workers,
the professionals --

00:04:08.409 --> 00:04:10.180
they stared at it absolutely amazed.

00:04:10.204 --> 00:04:12.933
It snaked around the walls
of their offices.

00:04:12.957 --> 00:04:18.933
So many hours, so well meant,
but ultimately so futile.

00:04:18.957 --> 00:04:22.397
And there was this moment
of absolute breakdown,

00:04:22.421 --> 00:04:24.253
and then of clarity:

00:04:24.277 --> 00:04:26.890
we had to work in a different way.

00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:30.915
So in a really brave step,
the leaders of the city where Ella lives

00:04:30.939 --> 00:04:33.584
agreed that we could start
by reversing Ryan's ratio.

00:04:33.608 --> 00:04:36.768
So everyone who came into contact
with Ella or a family like Ella's

00:04:36.792 --> 00:04:39.704
would spend 80 percent of their time
working with the families

00:04:39.728 --> 00:04:42.293
and only 20 percent servicing the system.

00:04:42.317 --> 00:04:44.168
And even more radically,

00:04:44.192 --> 00:04:45.362
the families would lead

00:04:45.386 --> 00:04:48.713
and they would decide who
was in a best position to help them.

00:04:48.737 --> 00:04:52.096
So Ella and another mother were asked
to be part of an interview panel,

00:04:52.120 --> 00:04:54.443
to choose from amongst
the existing professionals

00:04:54.467 --> 00:04:56.734
who would work with them.

00:04:56.758 --> 00:04:58.724
And many, many people wanted to join us,

00:04:58.748 --> 00:05:01.819
because you don't go into this kind
of work to manage a system,

00:05:01.843 --> 00:05:04.696
you go in because you can
and you want to make a difference.

00:05:04.720 --> 00:05:07.933
So Ella and the mother asked
everybody who came through the door,

00:05:07.957 --> 00:05:10.389
"What will you do when my son
starts kicking me?"

00:05:10.413 --> 00:05:12.933
And so the first person who comes in says,

00:05:12.957 --> 00:05:15.076
"Well, I'll look around
for the nearest exit

00:05:15.100 --> 00:05:17.933
and I will back out very slowly,

00:05:17.957 --> 00:05:20.958
and if the noise is still going on,
I'll call my supervisor."

00:05:20.982 --> 00:05:23.695
And the mothers go,
"You're the system. Get out of here!"

00:05:23.719 --> 00:05:26.933
And then the next person who comes
is a policeman, and he says,

00:05:26.957 --> 00:05:30.933
"Well, I'll tackle your son to the ground
and then I'm not sure what I'll do."

00:05:30.957 --> 00:05:32.635
And the mothers say, "Thank you."

00:05:32.659 --> 00:05:34.881
So, they chose professionals who confessed

00:05:34.905 --> 00:05:36.875
they didn't necessarily have the answers,

00:05:36.899 --> 00:05:40.488
who said -- well, they weren't
going to talk in jargon.

00:05:40.512 --> 00:05:43.401
They showed their human qualities
and convinced the mothers

00:05:43.425 --> 00:05:46.038
that they would stick with them
through thick and thin,

00:05:46.062 --> 00:05:48.121
even though they wouldn't
be soft with them.

00:05:48.145 --> 00:05:49.837
So these new teams and the families

00:05:49.861 --> 00:05:52.020
were then given a sliver
of the former budget,

00:05:52.044 --> 00:05:54.535
but they could spend the money
in any way they chose.

00:05:54.559 --> 00:05:56.794
And so one of the families
went out for supper.

00:05:56.818 --> 00:06:00.423
They went to McDonald's and they sat down
and they talked and they listened

00:06:00.447 --> 00:06:02.507
for the first time in a long time.

00:06:02.531 --> 00:06:04.121
Another family asked the team

00:06:04.145 --> 00:06:07.187
if they would help them do up their home.

00:06:07.211 --> 00:06:08.718
And one mother took the money

00:06:08.742 --> 00:06:12.269
and she used it as a float
to start a social enterprise.

00:06:12.293 --> 00:06:14.742
And in a really short space of time,

00:06:14.766 --> 00:06:17.175
something new started to grow:

00:06:17.199 --> 00:06:20.097
a relationship between the team
and the workers.

00:06:20.121 --> 00:06:23.038
And then some remarkable
changes took place.

00:06:23.062 --> 00:06:24.582
Maybe it's not surprising

00:06:24.606 --> 00:06:27.340
that the journey for Ella has had
some big steps backwards

00:06:27.364 --> 00:06:28.525
as well as forwards.

00:06:28.549 --> 00:06:31.314
But today, she's completed
an IT training course,

00:06:31.338 --> 00:06:34.626
she has her first paid job,
her children are back in school,

00:06:34.650 --> 00:06:35.801
and the neighbors,

00:06:35.825 --> 00:06:38.734
who previously just hoped this family
would be moved anywhere

00:06:38.758 --> 00:06:39.964
except next door to them,

00:06:39.988 --> 00:06:41.139
are fine.

00:06:41.163 --> 00:06:43.263
They've made some new friendships.

00:06:43.287 --> 00:06:47.303
And all the same people have been
involved in this transformation --

00:06:47.327 --> 00:06:49.933
same families, same workers.

00:06:49.957 --> 00:06:53.864
But the relationship between them
has been supported to change.

00:06:54.514 --> 00:06:57.595
So I'm telling you about Ella
because I think that relationships

00:06:57.619 --> 00:06:59.556
are the critical resource we have

00:06:59.580 --> 00:07:01.958
in solving some of these
intractable problems.

00:07:01.982 --> 00:07:04.704
But today, our relationships
are all but written off

00:07:04.728 --> 00:07:08.596
by our politics, our social policies,
our welfare institutions.

00:07:08.620 --> 00:07:11.296
And I've learned that this
really has to change.

00:07:11.960 --> 00:07:13.910
So what do I mean by relationships?

00:07:14.369 --> 00:07:17.373
I'm talking about the simple
human bonds between us,

00:07:17.397 --> 00:07:19.933
a kind of authentic sense
of connection, of belonging,

00:07:19.957 --> 00:07:22.641
the bonds that make us happy,
that support us to change,

00:07:22.665 --> 00:07:25.469
to be brave like Ella
and try something new.

00:07:25.493 --> 00:07:27.413
And, you know, it's no accident

00:07:27.437 --> 00:07:29.976
that those who run and work
in the institutions

00:07:30.000 --> 00:07:32.258
that are supposed to support
Ella and her family

00:07:32.282 --> 00:07:33.796
don't talk about relationships,

00:07:33.820 --> 00:07:37.892
because relationships are expressly
designed out of a welfare model

00:07:37.916 --> 00:07:41.374
that was drawn up in Britain
and exported around the world.

00:07:41.398 --> 00:07:43.331
The contemporaries of William Beveridge,

00:07:43.355 --> 00:07:45.613
who was the architect
of the first welfare state

00:07:45.637 --> 00:07:47.557
and the author of the Beveridge Report,

00:07:47.581 --> 00:07:51.080
had little faith in what they called
the average sensual or emotional man.

00:07:51.104 --> 00:07:54.548
Instead, they trusted this idea
of the impersonal system

00:07:54.572 --> 00:07:58.933
and the bureaucrat who would be detached
and work in this system.

00:07:58.957 --> 00:08:01.072
And the impact of Beveridge

00:08:01.096 --> 00:08:03.339
on the way the modern state
sees social issues

00:08:03.363 --> 00:08:05.422
just can't be underestimated.

00:08:05.446 --> 00:08:08.622
The Beveridge Report
sold over 100,000 copies

00:08:08.646 --> 00:08:10.975
in the first weeks of publication alone.

00:08:10.999 --> 00:08:14.208
People queued in the rain
on a November night to get hold of a copy,

00:08:14.232 --> 00:08:17.598
and it was read across the country,
across the colonies, across Europe,

00:08:17.622 --> 00:08:19.363
across the United States of America,

00:08:19.387 --> 00:08:21.159
and it had this huge impact

00:08:21.183 --> 00:08:24.780
on the way that welfare states
were designed around the globe.

00:08:24.804 --> 00:08:29.865
The cultures, the bureaucracies,
the institutions -- they are global,

00:08:29.889 --> 00:08:31.909
and they've come to seem
like common sense.

00:08:31.933 --> 00:08:34.017
They've become so ingrained in us,

00:08:34.041 --> 00:08:36.288
that actually we don't even
see them anymore.

00:08:36.814 --> 00:08:39.933
And I think it's really important to say
that in the 20th century,

00:08:39.957 --> 00:08:42.594
they were remarkably successful,
these institutions.

00:08:42.618 --> 00:08:46.049
They led to longer lifespans,
the eradication of mass disease,

00:08:46.073 --> 00:08:49.064
mass housing, almost universal education.

00:08:49.957 --> 00:08:51.933
But at the same time,

00:08:51.957 --> 00:08:55.389
Beveridge sowed the seeds
of today's challenges.

00:08:55.957 --> 00:08:57.721
So let me tell you a second story.

00:08:57.745 --> 00:09:02.957
What do you think today is a bigger killer
than a lifetime of smoking?

00:09:05.184 --> 00:09:06.792
It's loneliness.

00:09:07.699 --> 00:09:12.615
According to government statistics,
one person over 60 -- one in three --

00:09:12.639 --> 00:09:15.831
doesn't speak to or see
another person in a week.

00:09:16.624 --> 00:09:19.933
One person in 10, that's 850,000 people,

00:09:19.957 --> 00:09:22.292
doesn't speak to anyone else in a month.

00:09:22.882 --> 00:09:25.156
And we're not the only people
with this problem;

00:09:25.180 --> 00:09:27.611
this problem touches the whole
of the Western world.

00:09:27.635 --> 00:09:29.933
And it's even more acute
in countries like China,

00:09:29.957 --> 00:09:33.640
where a process of rapid urbanization,
mass migration, has left older people

00:09:33.664 --> 00:09:35.208
alone in the villages.

00:09:35.232 --> 00:09:39.053
And so the services that Beveridge
designed and exported --

00:09:39.077 --> 00:09:41.364
they can't address this kind of problem.

00:09:41.388 --> 00:09:43.998
Loneliness is like a collective
relational challenge,

00:09:44.022 --> 00:09:47.869
and it can't be addressed
by a traditional bureaucratic response.

00:09:48.444 --> 00:09:51.395
So some years ago,
wanting to understand this problem,

00:09:51.419 --> 00:09:54.292
I started to work with a group
of about 60 older people

00:09:54.316 --> 00:09:56.137
in South London, where I live.

00:09:56.161 --> 00:09:58.236
I went shopping, I played bingo,

00:09:58.260 --> 00:10:00.423
but mainly I was just
observing and listening.

00:10:00.447 --> 00:10:02.992
I wanted to know
what we could do differently.

00:10:03.795 --> 00:10:06.623
And if you ask them, people tell you
they want two things.

00:10:06.647 --> 00:10:09.556
They want somebody to go up a ladder
and change a light bulb,

00:10:09.580 --> 00:10:11.878
or to be there when they
come out of hospital.

00:10:11.902 --> 00:10:14.256
They want on-demand, practical support.

00:10:14.280 --> 00:10:15.838
And they want to have fun.

00:10:15.862 --> 00:10:19.080
They want to go out, do interesting things
with like-minded people,

00:10:19.104 --> 00:10:22.824
and make friends like we've all
made friends at every stage of our lives.

00:10:23.436 --> 00:10:26.165
So we rented a phone line,
hired a couple of handymen,

00:10:26.189 --> 00:10:28.526
and started a service we called "Circle."

00:10:28.550 --> 00:10:32.371
And Circle offers its local membership
a toll-free 0 800 number

00:10:32.395 --> 00:10:35.124
that they can call on demand
for any support.

00:10:35.148 --> 00:10:37.317
And people have called us
for so many reasons.

00:10:37.341 --> 00:10:39.460
They've called because
their pets are unwell,

00:10:39.484 --> 00:10:42.758
their DVD is broken, they've forgotten
how to use their mobile phone,

00:10:42.782 --> 00:10:44.707
or maybe they are coming out of hospital

00:10:44.731 --> 00:10:46.384
and they want someone to be there.

00:10:46.408 --> 00:10:49.558
And Circle also offers
a rich social calendar --

00:10:49.582 --> 00:10:53.697
knitting, darts, museum tours,
hot air ballooning -- you name it.

00:10:54.213 --> 00:10:58.608
But here's the interesting thing,
the really deep change:

00:10:58.632 --> 00:11:01.843
over time, the friendships
that have formed

00:11:01.867 --> 00:11:04.421
have begun to replace the practical offer.

00:11:04.922 --> 00:11:06.555
So let me tell you about Belinda.

00:11:06.579 --> 00:11:10.815
Belinda's a Circle member, and she was
going into hospital for a hip operation,

00:11:10.839 --> 00:11:14.823
so she called her local Circle to say
they wouldn't see her for a bit.

00:11:14.847 --> 00:11:18.647
And Damon, who runs the local Circle,
calls her back and says, "How can I help?"

00:11:18.671 --> 00:11:20.582
And Belinda says, "Oh no, I'm fine --

00:11:20.606 --> 00:11:23.399
Jocelyn is doing the shopping,
Tony's doing the gardening,

00:11:23.423 --> 00:11:26.120
Melissa and Joe are going
to come in and cook and chat."

00:11:26.144 --> 00:11:29.151
So five Circle members
had organized themselves

00:11:29.175 --> 00:11:31.079
to take care of Belinda.

00:11:32.081 --> 00:11:35.427
And Belinda's 80, although she says
that she feels 25 inside,

00:11:35.451 --> 00:11:37.015
but she also says

00:11:37.039 --> 00:11:40.485
that she felt stuck and pretty down
when she joined Circle.

00:11:41.041 --> 00:11:45.522
But the simple act of encouraging her
to come along to that first event

00:11:45.546 --> 00:11:48.746
led to a process where
natural friendships formed,

00:11:48.770 --> 00:11:53.091
friendships that today are replacing
the need for expensive services.

00:11:53.115 --> 00:11:56.092
It's relationships
that are making the difference.

00:11:57.530 --> 00:12:00.438
So I think that three factors
have converged

00:12:00.462 --> 00:12:03.454
that enable us to put relationships
at the heart and center

00:12:03.478 --> 00:12:06.323
of how we solve social problems today.

00:12:06.347 --> 00:12:08.410
Firstly, the nature of the problems --

00:12:08.434 --> 00:12:11.089
they've changed, and they require
different solutions.

00:12:11.113 --> 00:12:15.603
Secondly, the cost, human as much
as financial, of doing business as usual.

00:12:15.627 --> 00:12:17.362
And thirdly, technology.

00:12:17.967 --> 00:12:20.487
I've talked about the first two factors.

00:12:20.511 --> 00:12:23.459
It's technology that enables
these approaches to scale

00:12:23.483 --> 00:12:26.437
and potentially now support
thousands of people.

00:12:26.869 --> 00:12:29.028
So the technology we've used
is really simple,

00:12:29.052 --> 00:12:32.505
it's made up of available things
like databases, mobile phones.

00:12:32.529 --> 00:12:35.265
Circle has got this very simple
system that underpins it,

00:12:35.289 --> 00:12:39.149
enables a small local team to support
a membership of up to a thousand.

00:12:39.173 --> 00:12:41.946
And you can contrast this
with a neighborhood organization

00:12:41.970 --> 00:12:43.127
of the 1970s,

00:12:43.151 --> 00:12:45.314
when this kind of scale
just wasn't possible,

00:12:45.338 --> 00:12:49.454
neither was the quality or the longevity
that the spine of technology can provide.

00:12:49.478 --> 00:12:52.707
So it's relationships
underpinned by technology

00:12:52.731 --> 00:12:55.644
that can turn the Beveridge
models on their heads.

00:12:55.668 --> 00:12:59.314
The Beveridge models are all
about institutions with finite resources,

00:12:59.338 --> 00:13:01.779
anonymously managing access.

00:13:01.803 --> 00:13:03.423
In my work at the front line,

00:13:03.447 --> 00:13:07.133
I've seen again and again how
up to 80 percent of resource

00:13:07.157 --> 00:13:09.192
is spent keeping people out.

00:13:09.216 --> 00:13:10.906
So professionals have to administer

00:13:10.930 --> 00:13:13.324
these increasingly complex forms
of administration

00:13:13.348 --> 00:13:16.690
that are basically about stopping people
accessing the service

00:13:16.714 --> 00:13:18.441
or managing the queue.

00:13:18.888 --> 00:13:23.224
And Circle, like the relational services
that we and others have designed,

00:13:23.248 --> 00:13:24.613
inverts this logic.

00:13:24.637 --> 00:13:28.630
What it says is, the more people,
the more relationships,

00:13:28.654 --> 00:13:30.710
the stronger the solution.

00:13:31.692 --> 00:13:34.054
So I want to tell you my third
and final story,

00:13:34.078 --> 00:13:36.037
which is about unemployment.

00:13:37.258 --> 00:13:40.024
In Britain, as in most places
in the world,

00:13:40.048 --> 00:13:42.588
our welfare states were primarily designed

00:13:42.612 --> 00:13:45.257
to get people into work,

00:13:45.281 --> 00:13:47.273
to educate them for this,

00:13:47.297 --> 00:13:48.969
and to keep them healthy.

00:13:48.993 --> 00:13:51.526
But here, too, the systems are failing.

00:13:51.550 --> 00:13:52.922
And so the response has been

00:13:52.946 --> 00:13:56.483
to try and make these old systems
even more efficient and transactional --

00:13:56.507 --> 00:14:00.139
to speed up processing times, divide
people into ever-smaller categories,

00:14:00.163 --> 00:14:03.334
try and target services at them
more efficiently -- in other words,

00:14:03.358 --> 00:14:06.004
the very opposite of relational.

00:14:07.383 --> 00:14:10.787
But guess how most people find work today?

00:14:11.541 --> 00:14:13.333
Through word of mouth.

00:14:13.357 --> 00:14:17.958
It turns out that in Britain today,
most new jobs are not advertised.

00:14:17.982 --> 00:14:20.125
So it's friends that tell you about a job,

00:14:20.149 --> 00:14:22.422
it's friends that recommend you for a job,

00:14:22.446 --> 00:14:26.737
and it's a rich and diverse social network
that helps you find work.

00:14:26.761 --> 00:14:29.086
Maybe some of you here
this evening are thinking,

00:14:29.110 --> 00:14:30.971
"But I found my job through an advert,"

00:14:30.995 --> 00:14:34.317
but if you think back, it was probably
a friend that showed you the ad

00:14:34.341 --> 00:14:35.918
and then encouraged you to apply.

00:14:35.942 --> 00:14:37.265
But not surprisingly,

00:14:37.289 --> 00:14:40.568
people who perhaps most need
this rich and diverse network

00:14:40.592 --> 00:14:43.291
are those who are most isolated from it.

00:14:43.315 --> 00:14:44.590
So knowing this,

00:14:44.614 --> 00:14:47.636
and also knowing about the costs
and failure of current systems,

00:14:47.660 --> 00:14:50.609
we designed something new
with relationships at its heart.

00:14:50.633 --> 00:14:55.995
We designed a service
that encourages people to meet up,

00:14:56.019 --> 00:14:57.459
people in and out of work,

00:14:57.483 --> 00:14:59.234
to work together in structured ways

00:14:59.258 --> 00:15:01.175
and try new opportunities.

00:15:02.266 --> 00:15:06.237
And, well, it's very hard to compare
the results of these new systems

00:15:06.261 --> 00:15:07.933
with the old transactional models,

00:15:07.957 --> 00:15:10.258
but it looks like,
with our first 1,000 members,

00:15:10.282 --> 00:15:13.173
we outperformed existing services
by a factor of three,

00:15:13.197 --> 00:15:15.157
at a fraction of the cost.

00:15:15.181 --> 00:15:18.061
And here, too, we've used technology,

00:15:18.085 --> 00:15:21.483
but not to network people in the way
that a social platform would do.

00:15:21.507 --> 00:15:25.109
We've used it to bring people face to face
and connect them with each other,

00:15:25.133 --> 00:15:28.550
building real relationships
and supporting people to find work.

00:15:30.266 --> 00:15:33.213
At the end of his life, in 1948,

00:15:33.237 --> 00:15:35.226
Beveridge wrote a third report.

00:15:35.871 --> 00:15:39.232
And in it he said he had made
a dreadful mistake.

00:15:40.314 --> 00:15:44.137
He had left people
and their communities out.

00:15:45.069 --> 00:15:49.674
And this omission, he said,
led to seeing people,

00:15:49.698 --> 00:15:51.833
and people starting to see themselves,

00:15:51.857 --> 00:15:55.642
within the categories
of the bureaucracies and the institutions.

00:15:55.666 --> 00:15:58.431
And human relationships
were already withering.

00:15:59.254 --> 00:16:02.470
But unfortunately, this third report
was much less read

00:16:02.494 --> 00:16:04.269
than Beveridge's earlier work.

00:16:05.073 --> 00:16:09.284
But today, we need to bring people
and their communities

00:16:09.308 --> 00:16:13.435
back into the heart of the way
we design new systems and new services,

00:16:13.459 --> 00:16:15.966
in an approach that I call
"Relational Welfare."

00:16:15.990 --> 00:16:18.506
We need to leave behind
these old, transactional,

00:16:18.530 --> 00:16:20.788
unsuitable, outdated models,

00:16:20.812 --> 00:16:24.323
and we need to adopt instead
the shared collective relational responses

00:16:24.347 --> 00:16:26.803
that can support a family like Ella's,

00:16:26.827 --> 00:16:29.134
that can address an issue like loneliness,

00:16:29.158 --> 00:16:31.893
that can support people into work
and up the skills curve

00:16:31.917 --> 00:16:33.361
in a modern labor market,

00:16:33.385 --> 00:16:37.523
that can also address challenges
of education, of health care systems,

00:16:37.547 --> 00:16:41.827
and so many more of those problems
that are pressing on our societies.

00:16:42.264 --> 00:16:44.826
It is all about relationships.

00:16:45.282 --> 00:16:48.309
Relationships are the critical
resource we have.

00:16:48.333 --> 00:16:49.484
Thank you.

00:16:49.508 --> 00:16:54.957
(Applause)

title: How I teach kids to love science
transcript: When I was a kid, my parents would tell me, "You can make a mess, but you have to clean up after yourself." So freedom came with responsibility. But my imagination would take me to all these wonderful places, where everything was possible. So I grew up in a bubble of innocence — or a bubble of ignorance, I should say, because adults would lie to us to protect us from the ugly truth. And growing up, I found out that adults make a mess, and they're not very good at cleaning up after themselves.Fast forward, I am an adult now, and I teach citizen science and invention at the Hong Kong Harbour School. And it doesn't take too long before my students walk on a beach and stumble upon piles of trash. So as good citizens, we clean up the beaches — and no, he is not drinking alcohol, and if he is, I did not give it to him.(Laughter)And so it's sad to say, but today more than 80 percent  of the oceans have plastic in them. It's a horrifying fact. And in past decades, we've been taking those big ships out and those big nets, and we collect those plastic bits that we look at under a microscope, and we sort them, and then we put this data onto a map. But that takes forever, it's very expensive, and so it's quite risky to take those big boats out.So with my students, ages six to 15, we've been dreaming of inventing a better way. So we've transformed our tiny Hong Kong classroom into a workshop. And so we started building this small workbench, with different heights, so even really short kids can participate. And let me tell you, kids with power tools are awesome and safe.(Laughter)Not really. And so, back to plastic. We collect this plastic and we grind it to the size we find it in the ocean, which is very small because it breaks down. And so this is how we work. I let the imaginations of my students run wild. And my job is to try to collect the best of each kid's idea and try to combine it into something that hopefully would work. And so we have agreed that instead of collecting plastic bits, we are going to collect only the data. So we're going to get an image of the plastic with a robot — so robots, kids get very excited. And the next thing we do — we do what we call "rapid prototyping." We are so rapid at prototyping that the lunch is still in the lunchbox when we're hacking it.(Laughter)And we hack table lamps and webcams, into plumbing fixtures and we assemble that into a floating robot that will be slowly moving through water and through the plastic that we have there — and this is the image that we get in the robot. So we see the plastic pieces floating slowly through the sensor, and the computer on board will process this image, and measure the size of each particle, so we have a rough estimate of how much plastic there is in the water.So we documented this invention step by step on a website for inventors called Instructables, in the hope that somebody would make it even better.What was really cool about this project was that the students saw a local problem, and boom — they are trying to immediately address it.[I can investigate my local problem]But my students in Hong Kong are hyperconnected kids. And they watch the news, they watch the Internet, and they came across this image. This was a child, probably under 10, cleaning up an oil spill bare-handed, in the Sundarbans, which is the world's largest mangrove forest in Bangladesh. So they were very shocked, because this is the water they drink, this is the water they bathe in, this is the water they fish in — this is the place where they live. And also you can see the water is brown, the mud is brown and oil is brown, so when everything is mixed up, it's really hard to see what's in the water. But, there's a technology that's rather simple, that's called spectrometry, that allows you see what's in the water. So we built a rough prototype of a spectrometer, and you can shine light through different substances that produce different spectrums, so that can help you identify what's in the water. So we packed this prototype of a sensor, and we shipped it to Bangladesh. So what was cool about this project was that beyond addressing a local problem, or looking at a local problem, my students used their empathy and their sense of being creative to help, remotely, other kids.[I can investigate a remote problem]So I was very compelled by doing the second experiments, and I wanted to take it even further — maybe addressing an even harder problem, and it's also closer to my heart.So I'm half Japanese and half French, and maybe you remember in 2011 there was a massive earthquake in Japan. It was so violent that it triggered several giant waves — they are called tsunami — and those tsunami destroyed many cities on the eastern coast of Japan. More than 14,000 people died in an instant. Also, it damaged the nuclear power plant of Fukushima, the nuclear power plant just by the water. And today, I read the reports and an average of 300 tons are leaking from the nuclear power plant into the Pacific Ocean. And today the whole Pacific Ocean has traces of contamination of cesium-137. If you go outside on the West Coast, you can measure Fukushima everywhere. But if you look at the map, it can look like most of the radioactivity has been washed away from the Japanese coast, and most of it is now — it looks like it's safe, it's blue. Well, reality is a bit more complicated than this.So I've been going to Fukushima every year since the accident, and I measure independently and with other scientists, on land, in the river — and this time we wanted to take the kids. So of course we didn't take the kids, the parents wouldn't allow that to happen.(Laughter)But every night we would report to "Mission Control" — different masks they're wearing. It could look like they didn't take the work seriously, but they really did because they're going to have to live with radioactivity their whole life. And so what we did with them is that we'd discuss the data we collected that day, and talk about where we should be going next — strategy, itinerary, etc... And to do this, we built a very rough topographical map of the region around the nuclear power plant. And so we built the elevation map, we sprinkled pigments to represent real-time data for radioactivity, and we sprayed water to simulate the rainfall. And with this we could see that the radioactive dust was washing from the top of the mountain into the river system, and leaking into the ocean. So it was a rough estimate.But with this in mind, we organized this expedition, which was the closest civilians have been to the nuclear power plant. We are sailing 1.5 kilometers away from the nuclear power plant, and with the help of the local fisherman, we are collecting sediment from the seabed with a custom sediment sampler we've invented and built. We pack the sediment into small bags, we then dispatch them to hundreds of small bags that we send to different universities, and we produce the map of the seabed radioactivity, especially in estuaries where the fish will reproduce, and I will hope that we will have improved the safety of the local fishermen and of your favorite sushi.(Laughter)You can see a progression here — we've gone from a local problem to a remote problem to a global problem. And it's been super exciting to work at these different scales, with also very simple, open-source technologies. But at the same time, it's been increasingly frustrating because we have only started to measure the damage that we have done. We haven't even started to try to solve the problems. And so I wonder if we should just take a leap and try to invent better ways to do all these things.And so the classroom started to feel a little bit small, so we found an industrial site in Hong Kong, and we turned it into the largest mega-space focused on social and environmental impact. It's in central Hong Kong, and it's a place we can work with wood, metal, chemistry, a bit of biology, a bit of optics, basically you can build pretty much everything there. And its a place where adults and kids can play together. It's a place where kids' dreams can come true, with the help of adults, and where adults can be kids again.Student: Acceleration! Acceleration!Cesar Harada: We're asking questions such as, can we invent the future of mobility with renewable energy? For example. Or, can we help the mobility of the aging population by transforming very standard wheelchairs into cool, electric vehicles?So plastic, oil and radioactivity are horrible, horrible legacies, but the very worst legacy that we can leave our children is lies. We can no longer afford to shield the kids from the ugly truth because we need their imagination to invent the solutions.So citizen scientists, makers, dreamers — we must prepare the next generation that cares about the environment and people, and that can actually do something about it.Thank you.(Applause)
