00:00:13.198 --> 00:00:15.758
A few years ago,
I broke into my own house.

00:00:16.838 --> 00:00:18.054
I had just driven home,

00:00:18.078 --> 00:00:20.614
it was around midnight
in the dead of Montreal winter,

00:00:20.638 --> 00:00:22.934
I had been visiting my friend,
Jeff, across town,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:27.734
and the thermometer on the front porch
read minus 40 degrees --

00:00:27.758 --> 00:00:30.854
and don't bother asking
if that's Celsius or Fahrenheit,

00:00:30.878 --> 00:00:33.334
minus 40 is where the two scales meet --

00:00:33.358 --> 00:00:34.614
it was very cold.

00:00:34.638 --> 00:00:37.854
And as I stood on the front porch
fumbling in my pockets,

00:00:37.878 --> 00:00:40.134
I found I didn't have my keys.

00:00:40.158 --> 00:00:42.254
In fact, I could see them
through the window,

00:00:42.278 --> 00:00:45.374
lying on the dining room table
where I had left them.

00:00:45.398 --> 00:00:48.534
So I quickly ran around
and tried all the other doors and windows,

00:00:48.558 --> 00:00:50.134
and they were locked tight.

00:00:50.158 --> 00:00:53.301
I thought about calling a locksmith --
at least I had my cellphone,

00:00:53.325 --> 00:00:56.654
but at midnight, it could take a while
for a locksmith to show up,

00:00:56.678 --> 00:00:58.838
and it was cold.

00:01:00.379 --> 00:01:03.094
I couldn't go back to my friend
Jeff's house for the night

00:01:03.118 --> 00:01:05.785
because I had an early flight
to Europe the next morning,

00:01:05.809 --> 00:01:08.048
and I needed to get
my passport and my suitcase.

00:01:08.358 --> 00:01:10.854
So, desperate and freezing cold,

00:01:10.878 --> 00:01:14.494
I found a large rock and I broke
through the basement window,

00:01:14.518 --> 00:01:16.494
cleared out the shards of glass,

00:01:16.518 --> 00:01:17.854
I crawled through,

00:01:17.878 --> 00:01:21.294
I found a piece of cardboard
and taped it up over the opening,

00:01:21.318 --> 00:01:23.938
figuring that in the morning,
on the way to the airport,

00:01:23.962 --> 00:01:26.734
I could call my contractor
and ask him to fix it.

00:01:26.758 --> 00:01:28.235
This was going to be expensive,

00:01:28.259 --> 00:01:31.814
but probably no more expensive
than a middle-of-the-night locksmith,

00:01:31.838 --> 00:01:35.998
so I figured, under the circumstances,
I was coming out even.

00:01:36.878 --> 00:01:39.054
Now, I'm a neuroscientist by training

00:01:39.078 --> 00:01:43.174
and I know a little bit
about how the brain performs under stress.

00:01:43.198 --> 00:01:46.734
It releases cortisol
that raises your heart rate,

00:01:46.758 --> 00:01:49.014
it modulates adrenaline levels

00:01:49.038 --> 00:01:50.518
and it clouds your thinking.

00:01:51.038 --> 00:01:53.014
So the next morning,

00:01:53.038 --> 00:01:55.494
when I woke up on too little sleep,

00:01:55.518 --> 00:01:58.254
worrying about the hole in the window,

00:01:58.278 --> 00:02:01.054
and a mental note
that I had to call my contractor,

00:02:01.078 --> 00:02:02.774
and the freezing temperatures,

00:02:02.798 --> 00:02:05.254
and the meetings I had upcoming in Europe,

00:02:05.278 --> 00:02:08.814
and, you know, with all
the cortisol in my brain,

00:02:08.838 --> 00:02:10.214
my thinking was cloudy,

00:02:10.238 --> 00:02:13.654
but I didn't know it was cloudy
because my thinking was cloudy.

00:02:13.678 --> 00:02:15.174
(Laughter)

00:02:15.198 --> 00:02:18.454
And it wasn't until I got
to the airport check-in counter,

00:02:18.478 --> 00:02:20.734
that I realized I didn't have my passport.

00:02:20.758 --> 00:02:22.774
(Laughter)

00:02:22.798 --> 00:02:26.254
So I raced home in the snow
and ice, 40 minutes,

00:02:26.278 --> 00:02:28.734
got my passport,
raced back to the airport,

00:02:28.758 --> 00:02:30.574
I made it just in time,

00:02:30.598 --> 00:02:32.837
but they had given away
my seat to someone else,

00:02:32.861 --> 00:02:35.837
so I got stuck in the back of the plane,
next to the bathrooms,

00:02:35.861 --> 00:02:39.078
in a seat that wouldn't recline,
on an eight-hour flight.

00:02:39.838 --> 00:02:43.294
Well, I had a lot of time to think
during those eight hours and no sleep.

00:02:43.318 --> 00:02:44.454
(Laughter)

00:02:44.478 --> 00:02:47.134
And I started wondering,
are there things that I can do,

00:02:47.158 --> 00:02:49.094
systems that I can put into place,

00:02:49.118 --> 00:02:51.574
that will prevent bad things
from happening?

00:02:51.598 --> 00:02:53.494
Or at least if bad things happen,

00:02:53.518 --> 00:02:58.518
will minimize the likelihood
of it being a total catastrophe.

00:02:59.318 --> 00:03:00.894
So I started thinking about that,

00:03:00.918 --> 00:03:03.776
but my thoughts didn't crystallize
until about a month later.

00:03:03.800 --> 00:03:07.494
I was having dinner with my colleague,
Danny Kahneman, the Nobel Prize winner,

00:03:07.518 --> 00:03:10.894
and I somewhat embarrassedly told him
about having broken my window,

00:03:10.918 --> 00:03:13.334
and, you know, forgotten my passport,

00:03:13.358 --> 00:03:14.574
and Danny shared with me

00:03:14.598 --> 00:03:19.094
that he'd been practicing
something called prospective hindsight.

00:03:19.118 --> 00:03:20.854
(Laughter)

00:03:20.878 --> 00:03:24.021
It's something that he had gotten
from the psychologist Gary Klein,

00:03:24.045 --> 00:03:26.094
who had written about it
a few years before,

00:03:26.118 --> 00:03:28.214
also called the pre-mortem.

00:03:28.238 --> 00:03:30.191
Now, you all know what the postmortem is.

00:03:30.215 --> 00:03:31.694
Whenever there's a disaster,

00:03:31.718 --> 00:03:36.014
a team of experts come in and they try
to figure out what went wrong, right?

00:03:36.038 --> 00:03:38.454
Well, in the pre-mortem, Danny explained,

00:03:38.478 --> 00:03:42.374
you look ahead and you try to figure out
all the things that could go wrong,

00:03:42.398 --> 00:03:44.974
and then you try to figure out
what you can do

00:03:44.998 --> 00:03:48.494
to prevent those things from happening,
or to minimize the damage.

00:03:48.518 --> 00:03:51.454
So what I want to talk to you about today

00:03:51.478 --> 00:03:55.014
are some of the things we can do
in the form of a pre-mortem.

00:03:55.038 --> 00:03:57.934
Some of them are obvious,
some of them are not so obvious.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.894
I'll start with the obvious ones.

00:03:59.918 --> 00:04:04.998
Around the home, designate a place
for things that are easily lost.

00:04:05.638 --> 00:04:09.494
Now, this sounds
like common sense, and it is,

00:04:09.518 --> 00:04:12.054
but there's a lot of science
to back this up,

00:04:12.078 --> 00:04:15.374
based on the way our spatial memory works.

00:04:15.398 --> 00:04:18.254
There's a structure in the brain
called the hippocampus,

00:04:18.278 --> 00:04:21.214
that evolved over tens
of thousands of years,

00:04:21.238 --> 00:04:25.014
to keep track of the locations
of important things --

00:04:25.038 --> 00:04:27.454
where the well is,
where fish can be found,

00:04:27.478 --> 00:04:29.974
that stand of fruit trees,

00:04:29.998 --> 00:04:32.614
where the friendly and enemy tribes live.

00:04:32.638 --> 00:04:34.543
The hippocampus is the part of the brain

00:04:34.567 --> 00:04:38.054
that in London taxicab drivers
becomes enlarged.

00:04:38.078 --> 00:04:41.774
It's the part of the brain
that allows squirrels to find their nuts.

00:04:41.798 --> 00:04:44.656
And if you're wondering,
somebody actually did the experiment

00:04:44.680 --> 00:04:47.454
where they cut off
the olfactory sense of the squirrels,

00:04:47.478 --> 00:04:49.294
and they could still find their nuts.

00:04:49.318 --> 00:04:52.134
They weren't using smell,
they were using the hippocampus,

00:04:52.158 --> 00:04:57.174
this exquisitely evolved mechanism
in the brain for finding things.

00:04:57.198 --> 00:05:00.934
But it's really good for things
that don't move around much,

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.414
not so good for things that move around.

00:05:03.438 --> 00:05:07.734
So this is why we lose car keys
and reading glasses and passports.

00:05:07.758 --> 00:05:10.254
So in the home,
designate a spot for your keys --

00:05:10.278 --> 00:05:13.134
a hook by the door,
maybe a decorative bowl.

00:05:13.158 --> 00:05:15.254
For your passport, a particular drawer.

00:05:15.278 --> 00:05:18.054
For your reading glasses,
a particular table.

00:05:18.078 --> 00:05:21.534
If you designate a spot
and you're scrupulous about it,

00:05:21.558 --> 00:05:24.374
your things will always be there
when you look for them.

00:05:24.398 --> 00:05:25.614
What about travel?

00:05:25.638 --> 00:05:28.014
Take a cell phone picture
of your credit cards,

00:05:28.038 --> 00:05:30.334
your driver's license, your passport,

00:05:30.358 --> 00:05:32.614
mail it to yourself so it's in the cloud.

00:05:32.638 --> 00:05:37.014
If these things are lost or stolen,
you can facilitate replacement.

00:05:37.038 --> 00:05:39.654
Now these are some rather obvious things.

00:05:39.678 --> 00:05:43.214
Remember, when you're under stress,
the brain releases cortisol.

00:05:43.238 --> 00:05:46.454
Cortisol is toxic,
and it causes cloudy thinking.

00:05:46.478 --> 00:05:49.014
So part of the practice of the pre-mortem

00:05:49.038 --> 00:05:53.294
is to recognize that under stress
you're not going to be at your best,

00:05:53.318 --> 00:05:55.614
and you should put systems in place.

00:05:55.638 --> 00:05:58.574
And there's perhaps
no more stressful a situation

00:05:58.598 --> 00:06:02.014
than when you're confronted
with a medical decision to make.

00:06:02.038 --> 00:06:05.334
And at some point, all of us
are going to be in that position,

00:06:05.358 --> 00:06:07.734
where we have to make
a very important decision

00:06:07.758 --> 00:06:11.054
about the future of our medical care
or that of a loved one,

00:06:11.078 --> 00:06:12.734
to help them with a decision.

00:06:12.758 --> 00:06:14.374
And so I want to talk about that.

00:06:14.398 --> 00:06:17.414
And I'm going to talk about
a very particular medical condition.

00:06:17.438 --> 00:06:20.974
But this stands as a proxy for all kinds
of medical decision-making,

00:06:20.998 --> 00:06:25.014
and indeed for financial decision-making,
and social decision-making --

00:06:25.038 --> 00:06:27.294
any kind of decision you have to make

00:06:27.318 --> 00:06:31.334
that would benefit from a rational
assessment of the facts.

00:06:31.358 --> 00:06:34.494
So suppose you go to your doctor
and the doctor says,

00:06:34.518 --> 00:06:38.638
"I just got your lab work back,
your cholesterol's a little high."

00:06:39.198 --> 00:06:42.214
Now, you all know that high cholesterol

00:06:42.238 --> 00:06:46.374
is associated with an increased risk
of cardiovascular disease,

00:06:46.398 --> 00:06:47.814
heart attack, stroke.

00:06:47.838 --> 00:06:49.054
And so you're thinking

00:06:49.078 --> 00:06:51.174
having high cholesterol
isn't the best thing,

00:06:51.198 --> 00:06:54.214
and so the doctor says,
"You know, I'd like to give you a drug

00:06:54.238 --> 00:06:57.014
that will help you
lower your cholesterol, a statin."

00:06:57.038 --> 00:06:58.934
And you've probably heard of statins,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.768
you know that they're among
the most widely prescribed drugs

00:07:01.792 --> 00:07:02.966
in the world today,

00:07:02.990 --> 00:07:05.069
you probably even know
people who take them.

00:07:05.093 --> 00:07:07.474
And so you're thinking,
"Yeah! Give me the statin."

00:07:07.499 --> 00:07:09.934
But there's a question
you should ask at this point,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.814
a statistic you should ask for

00:07:11.838 --> 00:07:14.294
that most doctors
don't like talking about,

00:07:14.318 --> 00:07:17.478
and pharmaceutical companies
like talking about even less.

00:07:18.758 --> 00:07:21.134
It's for the number needed to treat.

00:07:21.158 --> 00:07:23.134
Now, what is this, the NNT?

00:07:23.158 --> 00:07:26.214
It's the number of people
that need to take a drug

00:07:26.238 --> 00:07:29.094
or undergo a surgery
or any medical procedure

00:07:29.118 --> 00:07:31.494
before one person is helped.

00:07:31.518 --> 00:07:34.374
And you're thinking,
what kind of crazy statistic is that?

00:07:34.398 --> 00:07:35.614
The number should be one.

00:07:35.638 --> 00:07:37.694
My doctor wouldn't prescribe
something to me

00:07:37.718 --> 00:07:39.003
if it's not going to help.

00:07:39.027 --> 00:07:41.511
But actually, medical practice
doesn't work that way.

00:07:41.536 --> 00:07:43.067
And it's not the doctor's fault,

00:07:43.092 --> 00:07:46.011
if it's anybody's fault,
it's the fault of scientists like me.

00:07:46.035 --> 00:07:48.900
We haven't figured out
the underlying mechanisms well enough.

00:07:48.924 --> 00:07:51.334
But GlaxoSmithKline estimates

00:07:51.358 --> 00:07:56.334
that 90 percent of the drugs work
in only 30 to 50 percent of the people.

00:07:56.358 --> 00:08:00.174
So the number needed to treat
for the most widely prescribed statin,

00:08:00.198 --> 00:08:02.334
what do you suppose it is?

00:08:02.358 --> 00:08:05.174
How many people have to take it
before one person is helped?

00:08:05.198 --> 00:08:06.398
300.

00:08:07.033 --> 00:08:08.414
This is according to research

00:08:08.438 --> 00:08:11.934
by research practitioners
Jerome Groopman and Pamela Hartzband,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.734
independently confirmed by Bloomberg.com.

00:08:14.758 --> 00:08:17.158
I ran through the numbers myself.

00:08:17.878 --> 00:08:20.254
300 people have to
take the drug for a year

00:08:20.278 --> 00:08:24.254
before one heart attack, stroke
or other adverse event is prevented.

00:08:24.278 --> 00:08:25.659
Now you're probably thinking,

00:08:25.683 --> 00:08:28.494
"Well, OK, one in 300 chance
of lowering my cholesterol.

00:08:28.518 --> 00:08:30.734
Why not, doc? Give me
the prescription anyway."

00:08:30.758 --> 00:08:33.614
But you should ask at this point
for another statistic,

00:08:33.638 --> 00:08:36.214
and that is, "Tell me
about the side effects." Right?

00:08:36.238 --> 00:08:37.894
So for this particular drug,

00:08:37.918 --> 00:08:41.574
the side effects occur
in five percent of the patients.

00:08:41.598 --> 00:08:43.265
And they include terrible things --

00:08:43.289 --> 00:08:47.733
debilitating muscle and joint pain,
gastrointestinal distress --

00:08:47.757 --> 00:08:49.616
but now you're thinking, "Five percent,

00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.654
not very likely
it's going to happen to me,

00:08:51.678 --> 00:08:52.916
I'll still take the drug."

00:08:52.940 --> 00:08:54.134
But wait a minute.

00:08:54.158 --> 00:08:56.494
Remember under stress
you're not thinking clearly.

00:08:56.518 --> 00:08:59.683
So think about how you're going
to work through this ahead of time,

00:08:59.708 --> 00:09:02.906
so you don't have to manufacture
the chain of reasoning on the spot.

00:09:02.931 --> 00:09:05.423
300 people take the drug, right?
One person's helped,

00:09:05.447 --> 00:09:07.854
five percent of those 300
have side effects,

00:09:07.878 --> 00:09:09.358
that's 15 people.

00:09:09.758 --> 00:09:13.654
You're 15 times more likely
to be harmed by the drug

00:09:13.678 --> 00:09:16.494
than you are to be helped by the drug.

00:09:16.518 --> 00:09:19.423
Now, I'm not saying whether you
should take the statin or not.

00:09:19.447 --> 00:09:22.590
I'm just saying you should have
this conversation with your doctor.

00:09:22.614 --> 00:09:23.934
Medical ethics requires it,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.254
it's part of the principle
of informed consent.

00:09:26.278 --> 00:09:29.494
You have the right to have access
to this kind of information

00:09:29.518 --> 00:09:33.414
to begin the conversation about whether
you want to take the risks or not.

00:09:33.438 --> 00:09:34.654
Now you might be thinking

00:09:34.678 --> 00:09:37.374
I've pulled this number
out of the air for shock value,

00:09:37.398 --> 00:09:40.654
but in fact it's rather typical,
this number needed to treat.

00:09:40.678 --> 00:09:45.294
For the most widely performed surgery
on men over the age of 50,

00:09:45.318 --> 00:09:47.534
removal of the prostate for cancer,

00:09:47.558 --> 00:09:50.134
the number needed to treat is 49.

00:09:50.158 --> 00:09:54.334
That's right, 49 surgeries are done
for every one person who's helped.

00:09:54.358 --> 00:09:59.014
And the side effects in that case
occur in 50 percent of the patients.

00:09:59.038 --> 00:10:01.894
They include impotence,
erectile dysfunction,

00:10:01.918 --> 00:10:04.694
urinary incontinence, rectal tearing,

00:10:04.718 --> 00:10:06.174
fecal incontinence.

00:10:06.198 --> 00:10:09.694
And if you're lucky, and you're one
of the 50 percent who has these,

00:10:09.718 --> 00:10:11.758
they'll only last for a year or two.

00:10:12.838 --> 00:10:16.454
So the idea of the pre-mortem
is to think ahead of time

00:10:16.478 --> 00:10:19.014
to the questions
that you might be able to ask

00:10:19.038 --> 00:10:21.414
that will push the conversation forward.

00:10:21.438 --> 00:10:24.534
You don't want to have to manufacture
all of this on the spot.

00:10:24.558 --> 00:10:27.454
And you also want to think
about things like quality of life.

00:10:27.478 --> 00:10:29.254
Because you have a choice oftentimes,

00:10:29.278 --> 00:10:31.574
do you I want a shorter life
that's pain-free,

00:10:31.598 --> 00:10:35.374
or a longer life that might have
a great deal of pain towards the end?

00:10:35.398 --> 00:10:37.814
These are things to talk about
and think about now,

00:10:37.838 --> 00:10:39.654
with your family and your loved ones.

00:10:39.678 --> 00:10:42.174
You might change your mind
in the heat of the moment,

00:10:42.198 --> 00:10:45.254
but at least you're practiced
with this kind of thinking.

00:10:45.278 --> 00:10:49.894
Remember, our brain under stress
releases cortisol,

00:10:49.918 --> 00:10:52.254
and one of the things
that happens at that moment

00:10:52.278 --> 00:10:54.214
is a whole bunch on systems shut down.

00:10:54.238 --> 00:10:56.143
There's an evolutionary reason for this.

00:10:56.167 --> 00:10:59.574
Face-to-face with a predator,
you don't need your digestive system,

00:10:59.598 --> 00:11:02.054
or your libido, or your immune system,

00:11:02.078 --> 00:11:05.734
because if you're body is expending
metabolism on those things

00:11:05.758 --> 00:11:07.414
and you don't react quickly,

00:11:07.438 --> 00:11:11.414
you might become the lion's lunch,
and then none of those things matter.

00:11:11.438 --> 00:11:12.854
Unfortunately,

00:11:12.878 --> 00:11:16.494
one of the things that goes out the window
during those times of stress

00:11:16.518 --> 00:11:18.494
is rational, logical thinking,

00:11:18.518 --> 00:11:21.934
as Danny Kahneman
and his colleagues have shown.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:25.134
So we need to train ourselves
to think ahead

00:11:25.158 --> 00:11:27.414
to these kinds of situations.

00:11:27.438 --> 00:11:33.614
I think the important point here
is recognizing that all of us are flawed.

00:11:33.638 --> 00:11:36.494
We all are going to fail now and then.

00:11:36.518 --> 00:11:40.134
The idea is to think ahead
to what those failures might be,

00:11:40.158 --> 00:11:44.054
to put systems in place
that will help minimize the damage,

00:11:44.078 --> 00:11:47.598
or to prevent the bad things
from happening in the first place.

00:11:48.238 --> 00:11:50.894
Getting back to that
snowy night in Montreal,

00:11:50.918 --> 00:11:52.654
when I got back from my trip,

00:11:52.678 --> 00:11:56.534
I had my contractor install
a combination lock next to the door,

00:11:56.558 --> 00:12:00.094
with a key to the front door in it,
an easy to remember combination.

00:12:00.118 --> 00:12:01.334
And I have to admit,

00:12:01.358 --> 00:12:04.774
I still have piles of mail
that haven't been sorted,

00:12:04.798 --> 00:12:07.374
and piles of emails
that I haven't gone through.

00:12:07.398 --> 00:12:09.174
So I'm not completely organized,

00:12:09.198 --> 00:12:12.334
but I see organization
as a gradual process,

00:12:12.358 --> 00:12:13.574
and I'm getting there.

00:12:13.598 --> 00:12:14.814
Thank you very much.

00:12:14.838 --> 00:12:19.230
(Applause)

title: How data from a crisis text line is saving lives
transcript: A girl I've never met before changed my life and the life of thousands of other people. I'm the CEO of DoSomething.org. It's one of the largest organizations in the world for young people. In fact it's bigger than the Boy Scouts in the United States. title: A boat carrying 500 refugees sunk at sea. The story of two survivors
transcript: Every day, I listen to harrowing stories of people fleeing for their lives, across dangerous borders and unfriendly seas. But there's one story that keeps me awake at night, and it's about Doaa.A Syrian refugee, 19 years old, she was living a grinding existence in Egypt working day wages. Her dad was constantly thinking of his thriving business back in Syria that had been blown to pieces by a bomb. And the war that drove them there was still raging in its fourth year. And the community that once welcomed them there had become weary of them. And one day, men on motorcycles tried to kidnap her. Once an aspiring student thinking only of her future, now she was scared all the time.But she was also full of hope, because she was in love with a fellow Syrian refugee named Bassem. Bassem was also struggling in Egypt, and he said to Doaa, "Let's go to Europe; seek asylum, safety. I will work, you can study — the promise of a new life." And he asked her father for her hand in marriage.But they knew to get to Europe they had to risk their lives, traveling across the Mediterranean Sea, putting their hands in smugglers', notorious for their cruelty. And Doaa was terrified of the water. She always had been. She never learned to swim.It was August that year, and already 2,000 people had died trying to cross the Mediterranean, but Doaa knew of a friend who had made it all the way to Northern Europe, and she thought, "Maybe we can, too." So she asked her parents if they could go, and after a painful discussion, they consented, and Bassem paid his entire life savings — 2,500 dollars each — to the smugglers.It was a Saturday morning when the call came, and they were taken by bus to a beach, hundreds of people on the beach. They were taken then by small boats onto an old fishing boat, 500 of them crammed onto that boat, 300 below, [200] above. There were Syrians, Palestinians, Africans, Muslims and Christians, 100 children, including Sandra — little Sandra, six years old — and Masa, 18 months. There were families on that boat, crammed together shoulder to shoulder, feet to feet. Doaa was sitting with her legs crammed up to her chest, Bassem holding her hand.Day two on the water, they were sick with worry and sick to their stomachs from the rough sea.Day three, Doaa had a premonition. And she said to Bassem, "I fear we're not going to make it. I fear the boat is going to sink." And Bassem said to her, "Please be patient. We will make it to Sweden, we will get married and we will have a future."Day four, the passengers were getting agitated. They asked the captain, "When will we get there?" He told them to shut up, and he insulted them. He said, "In 16 hours we will reach the shores of Italy." They were weak and weary. Soon they saw a boat approach — a smaller boat, 10 men on board, who started shouting at them, hurling insults, throwing sticks, asking them to all disembark and get on this smaller, more unseaworthy boat. The parents were terrified for their children, and they collectively refused to disembark. So the boat sped away in anger, and a half an hour later, came back and started deliberately ramming a hole in the side of Doaa's boat, just below where she and Bassem were sitting. And she heard how they yelled, "Let the fish eat your flesh!" And they started laughing as the boat capsized and sank.The 300 people below deck were doomed. Doaa was holding on to the side of the boat as it sank, and watched in horror as a small child was cut to pieces by the propeller. Bassem said to her, "Please let go, or you'll be swept in and the propeller will kill you, too." And remember — she can't swim. But she let go and she started moving her arms and her legs, thinking, "This is swimming." And miraculously, Bassem found a life ring. It was one of those child's rings that they use to play in swimming pools and on calm seas. And Doaa climbed onto the ring, her arms and her legs dangling by the side. Bassem was a good swimmer, so he held her hand and tread water. Around them there were corpses. Around 100 people survived initially, and they started coming together in groups, praying for rescue. But when a day went by and no one came, some people gave up hope, and Doaa and Bassem watched as men in the distance took their life vests off and sank into the water.One man approached them with a small baby perched on his shoulder, nine months old — Malek. He was holding onto a gas canister to stay afloat, and he said to them, "I fear I am not going to survive. I'm too weak. I don't have the courage anymore." And he handed little Malek over to Bassem and to Doaa, and they perched her onto the life ring. So now they were three, Doaa, Bassem and little Malek.And let me take a pause in this story right here and ask the question: why do refugees like Doaa take these kinds of risks? Millions of refugees are living in exile, in limbo. They're living in countries [fleeing] from a war that has been raging for four years. Even if they wanted to return, they can't. Their homes, their businesses, their towns and their cities have been completely destroyed. This is a UNESCO World Heritage City, Homs, in Syria. So people continue to flee into neighboring countries, and we build refugee camps for them in the desert. Hundreds of thousands of people live in camps like these, and thousands and thousands more, millions, live in towns and cities. And the communities, the neighboring countries that once welcomed them with open arms and hearts are overwhelmed. There are simply not enough schools, water systems, sanitation. Even rich European countries could never handle such an influx without massive investment. The Syria war has driven almost four million people over the borders, but over seven million people are on the run inside the country. That means that over half the Syrian population has been forced to flee. Back to those neighboring countries hosting so many. They feel that the richer world has done too little to support them. And days have turned into months, months into years. A refugee's stay is supposed to be temporary.Back to Doaa and Bassem in the water. It was their second day, and Bassem was getting very weak. And now it was Doaa's turn to say to Bassem, "My love, please hold on to hope, to our future. We will make it." And he said to her, "I'm sorry, my love, that I put you in this situation. I have never loved anyone as much as I love you." And he released himself into the water, and Doaa watched as the love of her life drowned before her eyes.Later that day, a mother came up to Doaa with her small 18-month-old daughter, Masa. This was the little girl I showed you in the picture earlier, with the life vests. Her older sister Sandra had just drowned, and her mother knew she had to do everything in her power to save her daughter. And she said to Doaa, "Please take this child. Let her be part of you. I will not survive." And then she went away and drowned.So Doaa, the 19-year-old refugee who was terrified of the water, who couldn't swim, found herself in charge of two little baby kids. And they were thirsty and they were hungry and they were agitated, and she tried her best to amuse them, to sing to them, to say words to them from the Quran. Around them, the bodies were bloating and turning black. The sun was blazing during the day. At night, there was a cold moon and fog. It was very frightening. On the fourth day in the water, this is how Doaa probably looked on the ring with her two children.A woman came on the fourth day and approached her and asked her to take another child — a little boy, just four years old. When Doaa took the little boy and the mother drowned, she said to the sobbing child, "She just went away to find you water and food." But his heart soon stopped, and Doaa had to release the little boy into the water.Later that day, she looked up into the sky with hope, because she saw two planes crossing in the sky. And she waved her arms, hoping they would see her, but the planes were soon gone.But that afternoon, as the sun was going down, she saw a boat, a merchant vessel. And she said, "Please, God, let them rescue me." She waved her arms and she felt like she shouted for about two hours. And it had become dark, but finally the searchlights found her and they extended a rope, astonished to see a woman clutching onto two babies.They pulled them onto the boat, they got oxygen and blankets, and a Greek helicopter came to pick them up and take them to the island of Crete.But Doaa looked down and asked, "What of Malek?" And they told her the little baby did not survive — she drew her last breath in the boat's clinic. But Doaa was sure that as they had been pulled up onto the rescue boat, that little baby girl had been smiling.Only 11 people survived that wreck, of the 500. There was never an international investigation into what happened. There were some media reports about mass murder at sea, a terrible tragedy, but that was only for one day. And then the news cycle moved on.Meanwhile, in a pediatric hospital on Crete, little Masa was on the edge of death. She was really dehydrated. Her kidneys were failing. Her glucose levels were dangerously low. The doctors did everything in their medical power to save them, and the Greek nurses never left her side, holding her, hugging her, singing her words. My colleagues also visited and said pretty words to her in Arabic. Amazingly, little Masa survived.And soon the Greek press started reporting about the miracle baby, who had survived four days in the water without food or anything to drink, and offers to adopt her came from all over the country.And meanwhile, Doaa was in another hospital on Crete, thin, dehydrated. An Egyptian family took her into their home as soon as she was released. And soon word went around about Doaa's survival, and a phone number was published on Facebook. Messages started coming in."Doaa, do you know what happened to my brother? My sister? My parents? My friends? Do you know if they survived?"One of those messages said, "I believe you saved my little niece, Masa." And it had this photo. This was from Masa's uncle, a Syrian refugee who had made it to Sweden with his family and also Masa's older sister. Soon, we hope, Masa will be reunited with him in Sweden, and until then, she's being cared for in a beautiful orphanage in Athens.And Doaa? Well, word went around about her survival, too. And the media wrote about this slight woman, and couldn't imagine how she could survive all this time under such conditions in that sea, and still save another life. The Academy of Athens, one of Greece's most prestigious institutions, gave her an award of bravery, and she deserves all that praise, and she deserves a second chance. But she wants to still go to Sweden. She wants to reunite with her family there. She wants to bring her mother and her father and her younger siblings away from Egypt there as well, and I believe she will succeed. She wants to become a lawyer or a politician or something that can help fight injustice. She is an extraordinary survivor.But I have to ask: what if she didn't have to take that risk? Why did she have to go through all that? Why wasn't there a legal way for her to study in Europe? Why couldn't Masa have taken an airplane to Sweden? Why couldn't Bassem have found work? Why is there no massive resettlement program for Syrian refugees, the victims of the worst war of our times? The world did this for the Vietnamese in the 1970s. Why not now? Why is there so little investment in the neighboring countries hosting so many refugees? And why, the root question, is so little being done to stop the wars, the persecution and the poverty that is driving so many people to the shores of Europe? Until these issues are resolved, people will continue to take to the seas and to seek safety and asylum.And what happens next? Well, that is largely Europe's choice. And I understand the public fears. People are worried about their security, their economies, the changes of culture. But is that more important than saving human lives? Because there is something fundamental here that I think overrides the rest, and it is about our common humanity. No person fleeing war or persecution should have to die crossing a sea to reach safety.(Applause)One thing is for sure, that no refugee would be on those dangerous boats if they could thrive where they are. And no migrant would take that dangerous journey if they had enough food for themselves and their children. And no one would put their life savings in the hands of those notorious smugglers if there was a legal way to migrate.So on behalf of little Masa and on behalf of Doaa and of Bassem and of those 500 people who drowned with them, can we make sure that they did not die in vain? Could we be inspired by what happened, and take a stand for a world in which every life matters?Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.330 --> 00:00:19.479
Every day, I listen to harrowing stories
of people fleeing for their lives,

00:00:19.503 --> 00:00:23.416
across dangerous borders
and unfriendly seas.

00:00:24.067 --> 00:00:28.562
But there's one story
that keeps me awake at night,

00:00:28.586 --> 00:00:30.142
and it's about Doaa.

00:00:30.166 --> 00:00:32.989
A Syrian refugee, 19 years old,

00:00:33.013 --> 00:00:38.849
she was living a grinding existence
in Egypt working day wages.

00:00:38.873 --> 00:00:44.260
Her dad was constantly thinking
of his thriving business back in Syria

00:00:44.284 --> 00:00:47.632
that had been blown to pieces by a bomb.

00:00:48.196 --> 00:00:54.252
And the war that drove them there
was still raging in its fourth year.

00:00:54.957 --> 00:00:58.166
And the community
that once welcomed them there

00:00:58.190 --> 00:01:00.555
had become weary of them.

00:01:01.206 --> 00:01:04.264
And one day, men on motorcycles
tried to kidnap her.

00:01:05.042 --> 00:01:09.791
Once an aspiring student
thinking only of her future,

00:01:09.815 --> 00:01:13.393
now she was scared all the time.

00:01:14.227 --> 00:01:16.236
But she was also full of hope,

00:01:16.260 --> 00:01:21.283
because she was in love
with a fellow Syrian refugee named Bassem.

00:01:21.307 --> 00:01:26.317
Bassem was also struggling in Egypt,
and he said to Doaa,

00:01:26.341 --> 00:01:29.707
"Let's go to Europe; seek asylum, safety.

00:01:29.731 --> 00:01:33.874
I will work, you can study --
the promise of a new life."

00:01:34.787 --> 00:01:38.015
And he asked her father
for her hand in marriage.

00:01:38.682 --> 00:01:44.198
But they knew to get to Europe
they had to risk their lives,

00:01:44.222 --> 00:01:46.722
traveling across the Mediterranean Sea,

00:01:46.746 --> 00:01:52.203
putting their hands in smugglers',
notorious for their cruelty.

00:01:53.131 --> 00:01:56.520
And Doaa was terrified of the water.

00:01:57.250 --> 00:02:00.300
She always had been.
She never learned to swim.

00:02:02.180 --> 00:02:06.933
It was August that year,
and already 2,000 people had died

00:02:06.957 --> 00:02:08.911
trying to cross the Mediterranean,

00:02:08.935 --> 00:02:12.905
but Doaa knew of a friend who had made it
all the way to Northern Europe,

00:02:12.929 --> 00:02:15.198
and she thought, "Maybe we can, too."

00:02:15.957 --> 00:02:18.959
So she asked her parents if they could go,

00:02:18.983 --> 00:02:22.325
and after a painful discussion,
they consented,

00:02:22.349 --> 00:02:28.479
and Bassem paid his entire life savings --
2,500 dollars each --

00:02:28.503 --> 00:02:29.899
to the smugglers.

00:02:30.779 --> 00:02:33.994
It was a Saturday morning
when the call came,

00:02:34.018 --> 00:02:38.497
and they were taken by bus to a beach,
hundreds of people on the beach.

00:02:38.831 --> 00:02:42.879
They were taken then by small boats
onto an old fishing boat,

00:02:42.903 --> 00:02:45.461
500 of them crammed onto that boat,

00:02:45.485 --> 00:02:48.361
300 below, [200] above.

00:02:49.424 --> 00:02:53.962
There were Syrians, Palestinians,
Africans, Muslims and Christians,

00:02:53.986 --> 00:02:59.314
100 children, including Sandra --
little Sandra, six years old --

00:02:59.338 --> 00:03:02.154
and Masa, 18 months.

00:03:03.456 --> 00:03:07.354
There were families on that boat,
crammed together shoulder to shoulder,

00:03:07.378 --> 00:03:08.910
feet to feet.

00:03:08.934 --> 00:03:12.742
Doaa was sitting with her legs
crammed up to her chest,

00:03:12.766 --> 00:03:15.281
Bassem holding her hand.

00:03:16.344 --> 00:03:19.051
Day two on the water,
they were sick with worry

00:03:19.075 --> 00:03:22.154
and sick to their stomachs
from the rough sea.

00:03:23.067 --> 00:03:26.042
Day three, Doaa had a premonition.

00:03:27.026 --> 00:03:31.579
And she said to Bassem,
"I fear we're not going to make it.

00:03:31.603 --> 00:03:33.642
I fear the boat is going to sink."

00:03:34.475 --> 00:03:37.624
And Bassem said to her,
"Please be patient.

00:03:37.648 --> 00:03:40.830
We will make it to Sweden,
we will get married

00:03:40.854 --> 00:03:42.408
and we will have a future."

00:03:43.709 --> 00:03:47.562
Day four, the passengers
were getting agitated.

00:03:47.586 --> 00:03:50.722
They asked the captain,
"When will we get there?"

00:03:50.746 --> 00:03:54.134
He told them to shut up,
and he insulted them.

00:03:54.698 --> 00:03:58.440
He said, "In 16 hours we will reach
the shores of Italy."

00:03:58.464 --> 00:04:01.638
They were weak and weary.

00:04:01.662 --> 00:04:05.933
Soon they saw a boat approach --
a smaller boat, 10 men on board,

00:04:05.957 --> 00:04:09.372
who started shouting at them,
hurling insults,

00:04:09.396 --> 00:04:13.746
throwing sticks, asking them
to all disembark

00:04:13.770 --> 00:04:17.485
and get on this smaller,
more unseaworthy boat.

00:04:17.509 --> 00:04:21.027
The parents were terrified
for their children,

00:04:21.051 --> 00:04:25.052
and they collectively
refused to disembark.

00:04:26.115 --> 00:04:29.231
So the boat sped away in anger,

00:04:29.255 --> 00:04:33.485
and a half an hour later, came back

00:04:33.509 --> 00:04:39.561
and started deliberately ramming a hole
in the side of Doaa's boat,

00:04:39.585 --> 00:04:42.198
just below where she
and Bassem were sitting.

00:04:43.722 --> 00:04:47.061
And she heard how they yelled,

00:04:47.085 --> 00:04:50.446
"Let the fish eat your flesh!"

00:04:51.557 --> 00:04:57.395
And they started laughing
as the boat capsized and sank.

00:04:57.957 --> 00:05:01.016
The 300 people below deck were doomed.

00:05:01.715 --> 00:05:06.304
Doaa was holding on to the side
of the boat as it sank,

00:05:06.328 --> 00:05:13.146
and watched in horror as a small child
was cut to pieces by the propeller.

00:05:14.313 --> 00:05:16.512
Bassem said to her, "Please let go,

00:05:16.536 --> 00:05:19.701
or you'll be swept in and the propeller
will kill you, too."

00:05:20.225 --> 00:05:22.273
And remember -- she can't swim.

00:05:22.957 --> 00:05:27.145
But she let go and she started moving
her arms and her legs,

00:05:27.169 --> 00:05:28.605
thinking, "This is swimming."

00:05:28.629 --> 00:05:33.002
And miraculously,
Bassem found a life ring.

00:05:33.764 --> 00:05:35.812
It was one of those child's rings

00:05:35.836 --> 00:05:39.933
that they use to play
in swimming pools and on calm seas.

00:05:39.957 --> 00:05:42.002
And Doaa climbed onto the ring,

00:05:42.026 --> 00:05:45.746
her arms and her legs
dangling by the side.

00:05:46.793 --> 00:05:48.734
Bassem was a good swimmer,

00:05:48.758 --> 00:05:52.552
so he held her hand and tread water.

00:05:54.022 --> 00:05:55.960
Around them there were corpses.

00:05:55.984 --> 00:05:58.452
Around 100 people survived initially,

00:05:58.476 --> 00:06:03.017
and they started coming together
in groups, praying for rescue.

00:06:03.041 --> 00:06:07.358
But when a day went by and no one came,

00:06:07.382 --> 00:06:09.207
some people gave up hope,

00:06:09.231 --> 00:06:11.405
and Doaa and Bassem watched

00:06:11.429 --> 00:06:18.010
as men in the distance took their
life vests off and sank into the water.

00:06:19.010 --> 00:06:24.933
One man approached them
with a small baby perched on his shoulder,

00:06:24.957 --> 00:06:26.607
nine months old -- Malek.

00:06:26.631 --> 00:06:31.710
He was holding onto a gas canister
to stay afloat, and he said to them,

00:06:31.734 --> 00:06:33.684
"I fear I am not going to survive.

00:06:33.708 --> 00:06:36.374
I'm too weak. I don't have
the courage anymore."

00:06:36.787 --> 00:06:41.933
And he handed little Malek
over to Bassem and to Doaa,

00:06:41.957 --> 00:06:44.669
and they perched her onto the life ring.

00:06:45.732 --> 00:06:51.146
So now they were three,
Doaa, Bassem and little Malek.

00:06:51.170 --> 00:06:54.299
And let me take a pause
in this story right here

00:06:54.323 --> 00:06:56.621
and ask the question:

00:06:56.645 --> 00:07:01.438
why do refugees like Doaa
take these kinds of risks?

00:07:03.019 --> 00:07:07.862
Millions of refugees are living
in exile, in limbo.

00:07:09.190 --> 00:07:13.490
They're living in countries [fleeing]
from a war that has been raging

00:07:13.514 --> 00:07:15.798
for four years.

00:07:17.592 --> 00:07:20.753
Even if they wanted to return, they can't.

00:07:20.777 --> 00:07:23.539
Their homes, their businesses,

00:07:23.563 --> 00:07:27.085
their towns and their cities
have been completely destroyed.

00:07:27.109 --> 00:07:29.933
This is a UNESCO World Heritage City,

00:07:29.957 --> 00:07:31.714
Homs, in Syria.

00:07:33.055 --> 00:07:37.620
So people continue to flee
into neighboring countries,

00:07:37.644 --> 00:07:41.243
and we build refugee camps
for them in the desert.

00:07:41.267 --> 00:07:45.277
Hundreds of thousands of people
live in camps like these,

00:07:45.301 --> 00:07:50.274
and thousands and thousands more,
millions, live in towns and cities.

00:07:50.298 --> 00:07:51.516
And the communities,

00:07:51.540 --> 00:07:54.396
the neighboring countries
that once welcomed them

00:07:54.420 --> 00:07:56.182
with open arms and hearts

00:07:56.206 --> 00:07:57.824
are overwhelmed.

00:07:58.689 --> 00:08:03.141
There are simply not enough schools,
water systems, sanitation.

00:08:03.705 --> 00:08:08.328
Even rich European countries
could never handle such an influx

00:08:08.352 --> 00:08:11.595
without massive investment.

00:08:13.365 --> 00:08:18.391
The Syria war has driven almost
four million people over the borders,

00:08:18.415 --> 00:08:23.352
but over seven million people
are on the run inside the country.

00:08:23.376 --> 00:08:27.067
That means that over half
the Syrian population

00:08:27.091 --> 00:08:29.351
has been forced to flee.

00:08:29.724 --> 00:08:34.017
Back to those neighboring
countries hosting so many.

00:08:35.072 --> 00:08:40.105
They feel that the richer world
has done too little to support them.

00:08:41.359 --> 00:08:45.756
And days have turned into months,
months into years.

00:08:46.441 --> 00:08:50.013
A refugee's stay is supposed
to be temporary.

00:08:50.037 --> 00:08:53.358
Back to Doaa and Bassem in the water.

00:08:53.382 --> 00:08:57.731
It was their second day,
and Bassem was getting very weak.

00:08:58.722 --> 00:09:02.723
And now it was Doaa's turn
to say to Bassem,

00:09:02.747 --> 00:09:08.430
"My love, please hold on to hope,
to our future. We will make it."

00:09:09.334 --> 00:09:12.015
And he said to her,

00:09:12.039 --> 00:09:16.476
"I'm sorry, my love,
that I put you in this situation.

00:09:16.500 --> 00:09:21.177
I have never loved anyone
as much as I love you."

00:09:22.829 --> 00:09:26.227
And he released himself into the water,

00:09:26.251 --> 00:09:32.507
and Doaa watched as the love of her life
drowned before her eyes.

00:09:35.846 --> 00:09:38.262
Later that day,

00:09:38.286 --> 00:09:43.937
a mother came up to Doaa with her
small 18-month-old daughter, Masa.

00:09:44.699 --> 00:09:47.624
This was the little girl I showed you
in the picture earlier,

00:09:47.648 --> 00:09:49.496
with the life vests.

00:09:49.520 --> 00:09:51.713
Her older sister Sandra had just drowned,

00:09:51.737 --> 00:09:55.856
and her mother knew she had to do
everything in her power

00:09:55.880 --> 00:09:57.372
to save her daughter.

00:09:57.951 --> 00:10:01.808
And she said to Doaa,
"Please take this child.

00:10:01.832 --> 00:10:05.860
Let her be part of you.
I will not survive."

00:10:07.083 --> 00:10:10.425
And then she went away and drowned.

00:10:11.783 --> 00:10:16.017
So Doaa, the 19-year-old refugee
who was terrified of the water,

00:10:16.041 --> 00:10:17.933
who couldn't swim,

00:10:17.957 --> 00:10:23.549
found herself in charge
of two little baby kids.

00:10:23.573 --> 00:10:27.254
And they were thirsty and they were hungry
and they were agitated,

00:10:27.278 --> 00:10:29.976
and she tried her best to amuse them,

00:10:30.000 --> 00:10:34.033
to sing to them, to say words
to them from the Quran.

00:10:35.192 --> 00:10:39.626
Around them, the bodies were bloating
and turning black.

00:10:39.650 --> 00:10:41.396
The sun was blazing during the day.

00:10:41.420 --> 00:10:44.140
At night, there was a cold moon and fog.

00:10:44.164 --> 00:10:46.140
It was very frightening.

00:10:46.934 --> 00:10:51.673
On the fourth day in the water,
this is how Doaa probably looked

00:10:51.697 --> 00:10:53.818
on the ring with her two children.

00:10:53.842 --> 00:10:57.389
A woman came on the fourth day
and approached her

00:10:57.413 --> 00:11:00.524
and asked her to take another child --

00:11:00.548 --> 00:11:03.563
a little boy, just four years old.

00:11:04.957 --> 00:11:08.974
When Doaa took the little boy
and the mother drowned,

00:11:08.998 --> 00:11:10.958
she said to the sobbing child,

00:11:10.982 --> 00:11:14.418
"She just went away
to find you water and food."

00:11:16.346 --> 00:11:18.339
But his heart soon stopped,

00:11:18.363 --> 00:11:22.036
and Doaa had to release
the little boy into the water.

00:11:22.981 --> 00:11:25.006
Later that day,

00:11:25.030 --> 00:11:28.309
she looked up into the sky with hope,

00:11:28.333 --> 00:11:32.348
because she saw two planes
crossing in the sky.

00:11:32.372 --> 00:11:36.871
And she waved her arms,
hoping they would see her,

00:11:36.895 --> 00:11:38.751
but the planes were soon gone.

00:11:39.275 --> 00:11:42.178
But that afternoon,
as the sun was going down,

00:11:42.202 --> 00:11:45.058
she saw a boat, a merchant vessel.

00:11:46.067 --> 00:11:50.084
And she said, "Please, God,
let them rescue me."

00:11:50.108 --> 00:11:54.068
She waved her arms and she felt
like she shouted for about two hours.

00:11:54.092 --> 00:11:58.702
And it had become dark,
but finally the searchlights found her

00:11:58.726 --> 00:12:00.933
and they extended a rope,

00:12:00.957 --> 00:12:05.926
astonished to see a woman
clutching onto two babies.

00:12:06.728 --> 00:12:10.216
They pulled them onto the boat,
they got oxygen and blankets,

00:12:10.240 --> 00:12:13.247
and a Greek helicopter came
to pick them up

00:12:13.271 --> 00:12:15.383
and take them to the island of Crete.

00:12:16.311 --> 00:12:19.818
But Doaa looked down and asked,
"What of Malek?"

00:12:20.358 --> 00:12:23.933
And they told her the little baby
did not survive --

00:12:23.957 --> 00:12:27.344
she drew her last breath
in the boat's clinic.

00:12:28.161 --> 00:12:33.933
But Doaa was sure that as they had
been pulled up onto the rescue boat,

00:12:33.957 --> 00:12:37.204
that little baby girl had been smiling.

00:12:39.236 --> 00:12:45.238
Only 11 people survived
that wreck, of the 500.

00:12:46.262 --> 00:12:50.933
There was never an international
investigation into what happened.

00:12:50.957 --> 00:12:55.052
There were some media reports
about mass murder at sea,

00:12:55.076 --> 00:12:56.401
a terrible tragedy,

00:12:56.425 --> 00:12:58.892
but that was only for one day.

00:12:59.448 --> 00:13:03.272
And then the news cycle moved on.

00:13:04.494 --> 00:13:09.036
Meanwhile, in a pediatric
hospital on Crete,

00:13:09.060 --> 00:13:12.432
little Masa was on the edge of death.

00:13:13.639 --> 00:13:17.349
She was really dehydrated.
Her kidneys were failing.

00:13:17.373 --> 00:13:19.397
Her glucose levels were dangerously low.

00:13:19.421 --> 00:13:22.987
The doctors did everything
in their medical power to save them,

00:13:23.011 --> 00:13:26.671
and the Greek nurses never left her side,

00:13:26.695 --> 00:13:28.822
holding her, hugging her,
singing her words.

00:13:28.846 --> 00:13:34.415
My colleagues also visited
and said pretty words to her in Arabic.

00:13:34.439 --> 00:13:38.635
Amazingly, little Masa survived.

00:13:40.150 --> 00:13:46.086
And soon the Greek press started reporting
about the miracle baby,

00:13:46.110 --> 00:13:51.777
who had survived four days in the water
without food or anything to drink,

00:13:51.801 --> 00:13:56.535
and offers to adopt her came
from all over the country.

00:13:57.424 --> 00:14:00.814
And meanwhile, Doaa
was in another hospital on Crete,

00:14:00.838 --> 00:14:02.450
thin, dehydrated.

00:14:03.529 --> 00:14:09.074
An Egyptian family took her into their
home as soon as she was released.

00:14:10.206 --> 00:14:14.953
And soon word went around
about Doaa's survival,

00:14:14.977 --> 00:14:18.155
and a phone number
was published on Facebook.

00:14:19.258 --> 00:14:21.823
Messages started coming in.

00:14:22.957 --> 00:14:27.745
"Doaa, do you know
what happened to my brother?

00:14:27.769 --> 00:14:34.310
My sister? My parents? My friends?
Do you know if they survived?"

00:14:35.159 --> 00:14:38.933
One of those messages said,

00:14:38.957 --> 00:14:43.405
"I believe you saved
my little niece, Masa."

00:14:44.207 --> 00:14:46.699
And it had this photo.

00:14:47.699 --> 00:14:49.961
This was from Masa's uncle,

00:14:49.985 --> 00:14:54.707
a Syrian refugee who had made it
to Sweden with his family

00:14:54.731 --> 00:14:56.938
and also Masa's older sister.

00:14:57.605 --> 00:15:03.289
Soon, we hope, Masa will be reunited
with him in Sweden,

00:15:03.313 --> 00:15:08.837
and until then, she's being cared for
in a beautiful orphanage in Athens.

00:15:10.179 --> 00:15:15.961
And Doaa? Well, word went around
about her survival, too.

00:15:16.957 --> 00:15:20.670
And the media wrote
about this slight woman,

00:15:20.694 --> 00:15:24.606
and couldn't imagine how
she could survive all this time

00:15:24.630 --> 00:15:27.624
under such conditions in that sea,

00:15:27.648 --> 00:15:30.679
and still save another life.

00:15:32.417 --> 00:15:37.804
The Academy of Athens, one of Greece's
most prestigious institutions,

00:15:37.828 --> 00:15:41.184
gave her an award of bravery,

00:15:41.208 --> 00:15:44.199
and she deserves all that praise,

00:15:44.223 --> 00:15:46.644
and she deserves a second chance.

00:15:47.957 --> 00:15:51.397
But she wants to still go to Sweden.

00:15:51.421 --> 00:15:53.651
She wants to reunite
with her family there.

00:15:53.675 --> 00:15:57.786
She wants to bring her mother
and her father and her younger siblings

00:15:57.810 --> 00:16:00.128
away from Egypt there as well,

00:16:00.152 --> 00:16:03.333
and I believe she will succeed.

00:16:03.357 --> 00:16:06.079
She wants to become a lawyer
or a politician

00:16:06.103 --> 00:16:10.997
or something that can help
fight injustice.

00:16:11.021 --> 00:16:14.085
She is an extraordinary survivor.

00:16:15.173 --> 00:16:17.737
But I have to ask:

00:16:17.761 --> 00:16:20.033
what if she didn't have to take that risk?

00:16:20.057 --> 00:16:22.533
Why did she have to go through all that?

00:16:23.184 --> 00:16:28.248
Why wasn't there a legal way
for her to study in Europe?

00:16:28.272 --> 00:16:32.568
Why couldn't Masa have taken
an airplane to Sweden?

00:16:32.592 --> 00:16:34.964
Why couldn't Bassem have found work?

00:16:36.083 --> 00:16:41.505
Why is there no massive resettlement
program for Syrian refugees,

00:16:41.529 --> 00:16:45.149
the victims of the worst war of our times?

00:16:45.736 --> 00:16:51.241
The world did this for the Vietnamese
in the 1970s. Why not now?

00:16:52.582 --> 00:16:57.199
Why is there so little investment
in the neighboring countries

00:16:57.223 --> 00:16:59.889
hosting so many refugees?

00:17:01.071 --> 00:17:03.933
And why, the root question,

00:17:03.957 --> 00:17:10.353
is so little being done to stop
the wars, the persecution

00:17:10.377 --> 00:17:14.933
and the poverty that is driving
so many people

00:17:14.957 --> 00:17:16.809
to the shores of Europe?

00:17:17.957 --> 00:17:20.566
Until these issues are resolved,

00:17:20.590 --> 00:17:23.925
people will continue to take to the seas

00:17:23.949 --> 00:17:27.378
and to seek safety and asylum.

00:17:28.061 --> 00:17:29.719
And what happens next?

00:17:30.211 --> 00:17:33.042
Well, that is largely Europe's choice.

00:17:33.066 --> 00:17:36.097
And I understand the public fears.

00:17:36.963 --> 00:17:42.890
People are worried about their security,
their economies, the changes of culture.

00:17:43.851 --> 00:17:47.992
But is that more important
than saving human lives?

00:17:48.817 --> 00:17:51.596
Because there is something
fundamental here

00:17:51.620 --> 00:17:54.424
that I think overrides the rest,

00:17:54.448 --> 00:17:58.010
and it is about our common humanity.

00:17:58.677 --> 00:18:03.146
No person fleeing war or persecution

00:18:03.170 --> 00:18:08.331
should have to die
crossing a sea to reach safety.

00:18:08.355 --> 00:18:14.687
(Applause)

00:18:14.711 --> 00:18:15.878
One thing is for sure,

00:18:15.902 --> 00:18:19.085
that no refugee would be
on those dangerous boats

00:18:19.109 --> 00:18:21.457
if they could thrive where they are.

00:18:21.481 --> 00:18:24.759
And no migrant would take
that dangerous journey

00:18:24.783 --> 00:18:28.669
if they had enough food
for themselves and their children.

00:18:28.693 --> 00:18:31.312
And no one would put their life savings

00:18:31.336 --> 00:18:34.129
in the hands of those notorious smugglers

00:18:34.153 --> 00:18:36.580
if there was a legal way to migrate.

00:18:37.429 --> 00:18:41.024
So on behalf of little Masa

00:18:41.048 --> 00:18:43.317
and on behalf of Doaa

00:18:43.341 --> 00:18:45.065
and of Bassem

00:18:45.089 --> 00:18:50.226
and of those 500 people
who drowned with them,

00:18:50.250 --> 00:18:53.393
can we make sure that they
did not die in vain?

00:18:54.266 --> 00:18:57.933
Could we be inspired by what happened,

00:18:57.957 --> 00:19:03.908
and take a stand for a world
in which every life matters?

00:19:04.957 --> 00:19:06.268
Thank you.

00:19:06.292 --> 00:19:12.886
(Applause)

title: The coolest animal you know nothing about ... and how we can save it
transcript: This is one of the most amazing animals on the face of the Earth. This is a tapir. Now this, this is a baby tapir, the cutest animal offspring in the animal kingdom.(Laughter)By far. There is no competition here.I have dedicated the past 20 years of my life to the research and conservation of tapirs in Brazil, and it has been absolutely amazing. But at the moment, I've been thinking really, really hard about the impact of my work. I've been questioning myself about the real contributions I have made for the conservation of these animals I love so much. Am I being effective in safeguarding their survival? Am I doing enough? I guess the big question here is, am I studying tapirs and contributing to their conservation, or am I just documenting their extinction?The world is facing so many different conservation crises. We all know that. It's all over the news every day. Tropical forests and other ecosystems are being destroyed, climate change, so many species on the brink of extinction: tigers, lions, elephants, rhinos, tapirs.This is the lowland tapir, the tapir species I work with, the largest terrestrial mammal of South America. They're massive. They're powerful. Adults can weigh up to 300 kilos. That's half the size of a horse. They're gorgeous.Tapirs are mostly found in tropical forests such as the Amazon, and they absolutely need large patches of habitat in order to find all the resources they need to reproduce and survive. But their habitat is being destroyed, and they have been hunted out of several parts of their geographic distribution.And you see, this is very, very unfortunate because tapirs are extremely important for the habitats where they are found. They're herbivores. Fifty percent of their diet consists of fruit, and when they eat the fruit, they swallow the seeds, which they disperse throughout the habitat through their feces. They play this major role in shaping and maintaining the structure and diversity of the forest, and for that reason, tapirs are known as gardeners of the forest. Isn't that amazing? If you think about it, the extinction of tapirs would seriously affect biodiversity as a whole.I started my tapir work in 1996, still very young, fresh out of college, and it was a pioneer research and conservation program. At that point, we had nearly zero information about tapirs, mostly because they're so difficult to study. They're nocturnal, solitary, very elusive animals, and we got started getting very basic data about these animals.But what is it that a conservationist does? Well, first, we need data. We need field research. We need those long-term datasets to support conservation action, and I told you tapirs are very hard to study, so we have to rely on indirect methods to study them. We have to capture and anesthetize them so that we can install GPS collars around their necks and follow their movements, which is a technique used by many other conservationists around the world. And then we can gather information about how they use space, how they move through the landscape, what are their priority habitats, and so much more.Next, we must disseminate what we learn. We have to educate people about tapirs and how important these animals are. And it's amazing how many people around the world do not know what a tapir is. In fact, many people think this is a tapir. Let me tell you, this is not a tapir.(Laughter)This is a giant anteater. Tapirs do not eat ants. Never. Ever.And then next we have to provide training, capacity building. It is our responsibility to prepare the conservationists of the future. We are losing several conservation battles, and we need more people doing what we do, and they need the skills, and they need the passion to do that. Ultimately, we conservationists, we must be able to apply our data, to apply our accumulated knowledge to support actual conservation action. Our first tapir program took place in the Atlantic Forest in the eastern part of Brazil, one of the most threatened biomes in the world. The destruction of the Atlantic Forest began in the early 1500s, when the Portuguese first arrived in Brazil, beginning European colonization in the eastern part of South America. This forest was almost completely cleared for timber, agriculture, cattle ranching and the construction of cities, and today only seven percent of the Atlantic forest is still left standing. And tapirs are found in very, very small, isolated, disconnected populations. In the Atlantic Forest, we found out that tapirs move through open areas of pastureland and agriculture going from one patch of forest to patch of forest. So our main approach in this region was to use our tapir data to identify the potential places for the establishment of wildlife corridors in between those patches of forest, reconnecting the habitat so that tapirs and many other animals could cross the landscape safely.After 12 years in the Atlantic Forest, in 2008, we expanded our tapir conservation efforts to the Pantanal in the western part of Brazil near the border with Bolivia and Paraguay. This is the largest continuous freshwater floodplain in the world, an incredible place and one of the most important strongholds for lowland tapirs in South America. And working in the Pantanal has been extremely refreshing because we found large, healthy tapir populations in the area, and we have been able to study tapirs in the most natural conditions we'll ever find, very much free of threats.In the Pantanal, besides the GPS collars, we are using another technique: camera traps. This camera is equipped with a movement sensor and it photographs animals when they walk in front of it. So thanks to these amazing devices, we have been able to gather precious information about tapir reproduction and social organization which are very important pieces of the puzzle when you're trying to develop those conservation strategies.And right now, 2015, we are expanding our work once again to the Brazilian Cerrado, the open grasslands and shrub forests in the central part of Brazil. Today this region is the very epicenter of economic development in my country, where natural habitat and wildlife populations are rapidly being eradicated by several different threats, including once again cattle ranching, large sugarcane and soybean plantations, poaching, roadkill, just to name a few. And somehow, tapirs are still there, which gives me a lot of hope. But I have to say that starting this new program in the Cerrado was a bit of a slap in the face. When you drive around and you find dead tapirs along the highways and signs of tapirs wandering around in the middle of sugarcane plantations where they shouldn't be, and you talk to kids and they tell you that they know how tapir meat tastes because their families poach and eat them, it really breaks your heart.The situation in the Cerrado made me realize — it gave me the sense of urgency. I am swimming against the tide. It made me realize that despite two decades of hard work trying to save these animals, we still have so much work to do if we are to prevent them from disappearing. We have to find ways to solve all these problems. We really do, and you know what? We really came to a point in the conservation world where we have to think out of the box. We'll have to be a lot more creative than we are right now. And I told you, roadkill is a big problem for tapirs in the Cerrado, so we just came up with the idea of putting reflective stickers on the GPS collars we put on the tapirs. These are the same stickers used on big trucks to avoid collision. Tapirs cross the highways after dark, so the stickers will hopefully help drivers see this shining thing crossing the highway, and maybe they will slow down a little bit. For now, this is just a crazy idea. We don't know. We'll see if it will reduce the amount of tapir roadkill. But the point is, maybe this is the kind of stuff that needs to be done.And although I'm struggling with all these questions in my mind right now, I have a pact with tapirs. I know in my heart that tapir conservation is my cause. This is my passion. I am not alone. I have this huge network of supporters behind me, and there is no way I'm ever going to stop. I will continue doing this, most probably for the rest of my life. And I'll keep doing this for Patrícia, my namesake, one of the first tapirs we captured and monitored in the Atlantic Forest many, many years ago; for Rita and her baby Vincent in the Pantanal. And I'll keep doing this for Ted, a baby tapir we captured in December last year also in the Pantanal.And I will keep doing this for the hundreds of tapirs that I've had the pleasure to meet over the years and the many others I know I will encounter in the future. These animals deserve to be cared for. They need me. They need us. And you know? We human beings deserve to live in a world where we can get out there and see and benefit from not only tapirs but all the other beautiful species, now and in the future.Thank you so much.(Applause)

00:06:33.718 --> 00:06:35.694
in the western part of Brazil

00:06:35.718 --> 00:06:39.094
near the border with Bolivia and Paraguay.

00:06:39.118 --> 00:06:44.534
This is the largest continuous
freshwater floodplain in the world,

00:06:44.558 --> 00:06:46.014
an incredible place

00:06:46.038 --> 00:06:50.694
and one of the most important strongholds
for lowland tapirs in South America.

00:06:50.718 --> 00:06:55.214
And working in the Pantanal
has been extremely refreshing

00:06:55.238 --> 00:06:59.214
because we found large,
healthy tapir populations in the area,

00:06:59.238 --> 00:07:01.174
and we have been able to study tapirs

00:07:01.198 --> 00:07:04.934
in the most natural conditions
we'll ever find,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.798
very much free of threats.

00:07:08.238 --> 00:07:12.934
In the Pantanal, besides the GPS collars,
we are using another technique:

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.174
camera traps.

00:07:14.198 --> 00:07:17.094
This camera is equipped
with a movement sensor

00:07:17.118 --> 00:07:20.134
and it photographs animals
when they walk in front of it.

00:07:20.158 --> 00:07:22.614
So thanks to these amazing devices,

00:07:22.638 --> 00:07:25.854
we have been able
to gather precious information

00:07:25.878 --> 00:07:28.814
about tapir reproduction
and social organization

00:07:28.838 --> 00:07:31.374
which are very important
pieces of the puzzle

00:07:31.398 --> 00:07:35.494
when you're trying to develop
those conservation strategies.

00:07:35.518 --> 00:07:40.214
And right now, 2015,
we are expanding our work once again

00:07:40.238 --> 00:07:42.094
to the Brazilian Cerrado,

00:07:42.118 --> 00:07:46.294
the open grasslands and shrub forests
in the central part of Brazil.

00:07:46.318 --> 00:07:53.214
Today this region is the very epicenter
of economic development in my country,

00:07:53.238 --> 00:07:55.934
where natural habitat
and wildlife populations

00:07:55.958 --> 00:08:00.054
are rapidly being eradicated
by several different threats,

00:08:00.078 --> 00:08:02.654
including once again cattle ranching,

00:08:02.678 --> 00:08:05.414
large sugarcane and soybean plantations,

00:08:05.438 --> 00:08:08.934
poaching, roadkill, just to name a few.

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:12.574
And somehow, tapirs are still there,

00:08:12.598 --> 00:08:15.014
which gives me a lot of hope.

00:08:15.038 --> 00:08:19.534
But I have to say that starting
this new program in the Cerrado

00:08:19.558 --> 00:08:22.414
was a bit of a slap in the face.

00:08:22.438 --> 00:08:23.894
When you drive around

00:08:23.918 --> 00:08:27.734
and you find dead tapirs
along the highways

00:08:27.758 --> 00:08:32.774
and signs of tapirs wandering around
in the middle of sugarcane plantations

00:08:32.798 --> 00:08:34.814
where they shouldn't be,

00:08:34.838 --> 00:08:39.054
and you talk to kids and they tell you
that they know how tapir meat tastes

00:08:39.078 --> 00:08:42.454
because their families poach and eat them,

00:08:42.478 --> 00:08:44.718
it really breaks your heart.

00:08:45.997 --> 00:08:49.214
The situation in the Cerrado
made me realize --

00:08:49.238 --> 00:08:52.174
it gave me the sense of urgency.

00:08:52.198 --> 00:08:54.493
I am swimming against the tide.

00:08:54.517 --> 00:08:58.174
It made me realize that despite
two decades of hard work

00:08:58.198 --> 00:09:01.734
trying to save these animals,
we still have so much work to do

00:09:01.758 --> 00:09:04.814
if we are to prevent them
from disappearing.

00:09:04.838 --> 00:09:08.774
We have to find ways
to solve all these problems.

00:09:08.798 --> 00:09:10.654
We really do, and you know what?

00:09:10.678 --> 00:09:14.094
We really came to a point
in the conservation world

00:09:14.118 --> 00:09:16.854
where we have to think out of the box.

00:09:16.878 --> 00:09:20.614
We'll have to be a lot more creative
than we are right now.

00:09:20.638 --> 00:09:24.534
And I told you, roadkill is a big problem
for tapirs in the Cerrado,

00:09:24.558 --> 00:09:27.974
so we just came up with the idea
of putting reflective stickers

00:09:27.998 --> 00:09:30.814
on the GPS collars we put on the tapirs.

00:09:30.838 --> 00:09:33.174
These are the same stickers
used on big trucks

00:09:33.198 --> 00:09:34.814
to avoid collision.

00:09:34.838 --> 00:09:38.054
Tapirs cross the highways after dark,

00:09:38.078 --> 00:09:43.254
so the stickers will hopefully
help drivers see this shining thing

00:09:43.278 --> 00:09:44.694
crossing the highway,

00:09:44.718 --> 00:09:48.254
and maybe they will
slow down a little bit.

00:09:48.278 --> 00:09:50.854
For now, this is just a crazy idea.

00:09:50.878 --> 00:09:55.534
We don't know. We'll see if it will
reduce the amount of tapir roadkill.

00:09:55.558 --> 00:09:59.558
But the point is, maybe this is
the kind of stuff that needs to be done.

00:10:00.878 --> 00:10:04.614
And although I'm struggling
with all these questions

00:10:04.638 --> 00:10:07.414
in my mind right now,

00:10:07.438 --> 00:10:10.334
I have a pact with tapirs.

00:10:10.358 --> 00:10:12.094
I know in my heart

00:10:12.118 --> 00:10:15.054
that tapir conservation is my cause.

00:10:15.078 --> 00:10:16.774
This is my passion.

00:10:16.798 --> 00:10:18.334
I am not alone.

00:10:18.358 --> 00:10:22.094
I have this huge network
of supporters behind me,

00:10:22.118 --> 00:10:25.134
and there is no way
I'm ever going to stop.

00:10:25.158 --> 00:10:29.534
I will continue doing this,
most probably for the rest of my life.

00:10:29.558 --> 00:10:33.854
And I'll keep doing this
for Patrícia, my namesake,

00:10:33.878 --> 00:10:37.654
one of the first tapirs we captured
and monitored in the Atlantic Forest

00:10:37.678 --> 00:10:39.774
many, many years ago;

00:10:39.798 --> 00:10:44.334
for Rita and her baby Vincent
in the Pantanal.

00:10:44.358 --> 00:10:48.454
And I'll keep doing this for Ted,
a baby tapir we captured

00:10:48.478 --> 00:10:51.894
in December last year
also in the Pantanal.

00:10:51.918 --> 00:10:54.014
And I will keep doing this

00:10:54.038 --> 00:10:57.694
for the hundreds of tapirs
that I've had the pleasure to meet

00:10:57.718 --> 00:10:58.934
over the years

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:02.494
and the many others I know
I will encounter in the future.

00:11:02.518 --> 00:11:05.854
These animals deserve to be cared for.

00:11:05.878 --> 00:11:08.854
They need me. They need us.

00:11:08.878 --> 00:11:13.854
And you know? We human beings
deserve to live in a world

00:11:13.878 --> 00:11:17.774
where we can get out there
and see and benefit from

00:11:17.798 --> 00:11:19.454
not only tapirs

00:11:19.478 --> 00:11:22.294
but all the other beautiful species,

00:11:22.318 --> 00:11:25.134
now and in the future.

00:11:25.158 --> 00:11:27.254
Thank you so much.

00:11:27.278 --> 00:11:31.678
(Applause)

title: Forget Wi-Fi. Meet the new Li-Fi Internet
transcript: I would like to demonstrate for the first time in public that it is possible to transmit a video from a standard off-the-shelf LED lamp to a solar cell with a laptop acting as a receiver. There is no Wi-Fi involved, it's just light.And you may wonder, what's the point? And the point is this: There will be a massive extension of the Internet to close the digital divide, and also to allow for what we call "The Internet of Things" — tens of billions of devices connected to the Internet.In my view, such an extension of the Internet can only work if it's almost energy-neutral. This means we need to use existing infrastructure as much as possible. And this is where the solar cell and the LED come in.I demonstrated for the first time, at TED in 2011, Li-Fi, or Light Fidelity. Li-Fi uses off-the-shelf LEDs to transmit data incredibly fast, and also in a safe and secure manner. Data is transported by the light, encoded in subtle changes of the brightness. If we look around, we have many LEDs around us, so there's a rich infrastructure of Li-Fi transmitters around us. But so far, we have been using special devices — small photo detectors, to receive the information encoded in the data. I wanted to find a way to also use existing infrastructure to receive data from our Li-Fi lights. And this is why I have been looking into solar cells and solar panels.A solar cell absorbs light and converts it into electrical energy. This is why we can use a solar cell to charge our mobile phone. But now we need to remember that the data is encoded in subtle changes of the brightness of the LED, so if the incoming light fluctuates, so does the energy harvested from the solar cell. This means we have a principal mechanism in place to receive information from the light and by the solar cell, because the fluctuations of the energy harvested correspond to the data transmitted.Of course the question is: can we receive very fast and subtle changes of the brightness, such as the ones transmitted by our LED lights? And the answer to that is yes, we can. We have shown in the lab that we can receive up to 50 megabytes per second from a standard, off-the-shelf solar cell. And this is faster than most broadband connections these days.Now let me show you in practice. In this box is a standard, off-the-shelf LED lamp. This is a standard, off-the-shelf solar cell; it is connected to the laptop. And also we have an instrument here to visualize the energy we harvest from the solar cell. And this instrument shows something at the moment. This is because the solar cell already harvests light from the ambient light.Now what I would like to do first is switch on the light, and I'll simply, only switch on the light, for a moment, and what you'll notice is that the instrument jumps to the right. So the solar cell, for a moment, is harvesting energy from this artificial light source. If I turn it off, we see it drops. I turn it on ... So we harvest energy with the solar cell.But next I would like to activate the streaming of the video. And I've done this by pressing this button. So now this LED lamp here is streaming a video by changing the brightness of the LED in a very subtle way, and in a way that you can't recognize with your eye, because the changes are too fast to recognize. But in order to prove the point, I can block the light of the solar cell. So first you notice the energy harvesting drops and the video stops as well. If I remove the blockage, the video will restart.(Applause)And I can repeat that. So we stop the transmission of the video and energy harvesting stops as well. So that is to show that the solar cell acts as a receiver.But now imagine that this LED lamp is a street light, and there's fog. And so I want to simulate fog, and that's why I brought a handkerchief with me.(Laughter)And let me put the handkerchief over the solar cell. First you notice the energy harvested drops, as expected, but now the video still continues. This means, despite the blockage, there's sufficient light coming through the handkerchief to the solar cell, so that the solar cell is able to decode and stream that information, in this case, a high-definition video.What's really important here is that a solar cell has become a receiver for high-speed wireless signals encoded in light, while it maintains its primary function as an energy-harvesting device. That's why it is possible to use existing solar cells on the roof of a hut to act as a broadband receiver from a laser station on a close by hill, or indeed, lamp post.And It really doesn't matter where the beam hits the solar cell. And the same is true for translucent solar cells integrated into windows, solar cells integrated into street furniture, or indeed, solar cells integrated into these billions of devices that will form the Internet of Things. Because simply, we don't want to charge these devices regularly, or worse, replace the batteries every few months.As I said to you, this is the first time I've shown this in public. It's very much a lab demonstration, a prototype. But my team and I are confident that we can take this to market within the next two to three years. And we hope we will be able to contribute to closing the digital divide, and also contribute to connecting all these billions of devices to the Internet. And all of this without causing a massive explosion of energy consumption — because of the solar cells, quite the opposite.Thank you.(Applause)

title: This is what LGBT life is like around the world
transcript: Jenni Chang: When I told my parents I was gay, the first thing they said to me was, "We're bringing you back to Taiwan."(Laughter)In their minds, my sexual orientation was America's fault. The West had corrupted me with divergent ideas, and if only my parents had never left Taiwan, this would not have happened to their only daughter. In truth, I wondered if they were right.Of course, there are gay people in Asia, just as there are gay people in every part of the world. But is the idea of living an "out" life, in the "I'm gay, this is my spouse, and we're proud of our lives together" kind of way just a Western idea?If I had grown up in Taiwan, or any place outside of the West, would I have found models of happy, thriving LGBT people?Lisa Dazols: I had similar notions. As an HIV social worker in San Francisco, I had met many gay immigrants. They told me their stories of persecution in their home countries, just for being gay, and the reasons why they escaped to the US. I saw how this had beaten them down. After 10 years of doing this kind of work, I needed better stories for myself. I knew the world was far from perfect, but surely not every gay story was tragic.JC: So as a couple, we both had a need to find stories of hope. So we set off on a mission to travel the world and look for the people we finally termed as the "Supergays."(Laughter)These would be the LGBT individuals who were doing something extraordinary in the world. to change their part of the world,

and momentum as more and more countries

find models of equality in one another.

love will win out.

I now pronounce you spouses for life.

00:11:41.638 --> 00:11:42.854
You may kiss.
