You know, maybe they would want to see the old storytelling of the tapestries. They were confronted by our virtual reality cameras. But a lot of people tried it, and over a five-day run we ended up with 54 pages of guest book comments, and we were told by the curators there that they'd never seen such an outpouring. Things like, "It's so real," "Absolutely believable," or, of course, the one that I was excited about, "A real feeling as if you were in the middle of something that you normally see on the TV news."So, it works, right? This stuff works. And it doesn't really matter where you're from or what age you are — it's really evocative.Now, don't get me wrong — I'm not saying that when you're in a piece you forget that you're here. But it turns out we can feel like we're in two places at once. We can have what I call this duality of presence, and I think that's what allows me to tap into these feelings of empathy. Right?So that means, of course, that I have to be very cautious about creating these pieces. I have to really follow best journalistic practices and make sure that these powerful stories are built with integrity. If we don't capture the material ourselves, we have to be extremely exacting about figuring out the provenance and where did this stuff come from and is it authentic?Let me give you an example. With this Trayvon Martin case, this is a guy, a kid, who was 17 years old and he bought soda and a candy at a store, and on his way home he was tracked by a neighborhood watchman named George Zimmerman who ended up shooting and killing him. To make that piece, we got the architectural drawings of the entire complex, and we rebuilt the entire scene inside and out, based on those drawings. All of the action is informed by the real 911 recorded calls to the police. And interestingly, we broke some news with this story. The forensic house that did the audio reconstruction, Primeau Productions, they say that they would testify that George Zimmerman, when he got out of the car, he cocked his gun before he went to give chase to Martin.So you can see that the basic tenets of journalism, they don't really change here, right? We're still following the same principles that we would always. What is different is the sense of being on scene, whether you're watching a guy collapse from hunger or feeling like you're in the middle of a bomb scene. And this is kind of what has driven me forward with these pieces, and thinking about how to make them. We're trying to make this, obviously, beyond the headset, more available. We're creating mobile pieces like the Trayvon Martin piece. And these things have had impact. I've had Americans tell me that they've donated, direct deductions from their bank account, money to go to Syrian children refugees. And "Hunger in LA," well, it's helped start a new form of doing journalism that I think is going to join all the other normal platforms in the future.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.743 --> 00:00:14.623
What if I could present you a story

00:00:14.647 --> 00:00:17.061
that you would remember
with your entire body

00:00:17.085 --> 00:00:19.242
and not just with your mind?

00:00:19.266 --> 00:00:21.941
My whole life as a journalist,
I've really been compelled

00:00:21.965 --> 00:00:24.276
to try to make stories
that can make a difference

00:00:24.300 --> 00:00:26.870
and maybe inspire people to care.

00:00:26.894 --> 00:00:29.220
I've worked in print.
I've worked in documentary.

00:00:29.244 --> 00:00:30.513
I've worked in broadcast.

00:00:30.537 --> 00:00:33.599
But it really wasn't until
I got involved with virtual reality

00:00:33.623 --> 00:00:36.464
that I started seeing
these really intense,

00:00:36.488 --> 00:00:38.472
authentic reactions from people

00:00:38.496 --> 00:00:40.171
that really blew my mind.

00:00:40.195 --> 00:00:44.868
So the deal is that with VR,
virtual reality,

00:00:44.892 --> 00:00:47.892
I can put you on scene

00:00:47.916 --> 00:00:49.717
in the middle of the story.

00:00:50.106 --> 00:00:53.590
By putting on these goggles
that track wherever you look,

00:00:53.614 --> 00:00:56.542
you get this whole-body sensation,

00:00:56.566 --> 00:00:58.773
like you're actually, like, there.

00:00:59.167 --> 00:01:02.569
So five years ago was about when
I really began to push the envelope

00:01:02.593 --> 00:01:05.843
with using virtual reality
and journalism together.

00:01:05.867 --> 00:01:08.415
And I wanted to do a piece about hunger.

00:01:08.439 --> 00:01:11.598
Families in America are going hungry,
food banks are overwhelmed,

00:01:11.622 --> 00:01:13.677
and they're often running out of food.

00:01:14.288 --> 00:01:17.907
Now, I knew I couldn't
make people feel hungry,

00:01:17.931 --> 00:01:21.748
but maybe I could figure out a way
to get them to feel something physical.

00:01:22.684 --> 00:01:25.748
So -- again, this is five years ago --

00:01:25.772 --> 00:01:28.948
so doing journalism
and virtual reality together

00:01:28.972 --> 00:01:31.955
was considered
a worse-than-half-baked idea,

00:01:31.979 --> 00:01:33.334
and I had no funding.

00:01:33.358 --> 00:01:35.857
Believe me, I had a lot
of colleagues laughing at me.

00:01:35.881 --> 00:01:39.671
And I did, though,
have a really great intern,

00:01:39.695 --> 00:01:41.933
a woman named Michaela Kobsa-Mark.

00:01:41.957 --> 00:01:43.775
And together we went out to food banks

00:01:43.799 --> 00:01:46.871
and started recording
audio and photographs.

00:01:46.895 --> 00:01:48.815
Until one day she came back to my office

00:01:48.839 --> 00:01:51.234
and she was bawling, she was just crying.

00:01:51.258 --> 00:01:53.860
She had been on scene at a long line,

00:01:53.884 --> 00:01:57.829
where the woman running the line
was feeling extremely overwhelmed,

00:01:57.853 --> 00:02:00.821
and she was screaming,
"There's too many people!

00:02:00.845 --> 00:02:02.741
There's too many people!"

00:02:02.765 --> 00:02:06.320
And this man with diabetes
doesn't get food in time,

00:02:06.344 --> 00:02:09.899
his blood sugar drops too low,
and he collapses into a coma.

00:02:10.653 --> 00:02:12.185
As soon as I heard that audio,

00:02:12.209 --> 00:02:15.454
I knew that this would be
the kind of evocative piece

00:02:15.478 --> 00:02:18.582
that could really describe
what was going on at food banks.

00:02:19.248 --> 00:02:22.864
So here's the real line.
You can see how long it was, right?

00:02:22.888 --> 00:02:25.515
And again, as I said, we didn't
have very much funding,

00:02:25.539 --> 00:02:29.289
so I had to reproduce it
with virtual humans that were donated,

00:02:29.313 --> 00:02:33.439
and people begged and borrowed favors
to help me create the models

00:02:33.463 --> 00:02:35.622
and make things as accurate as we could.

00:02:35.646 --> 00:02:38.255
And then we tried to convey
what happened that day

00:02:38.279 --> 00:02:41.073
with as much as accuracy as is possible.

00:02:41.638 --> 00:02:45.836
(Video) Voice: There's too many people!
There's too many people!

00:02:54.298 --> 00:02:57.019
Voice: OK, he's having a seizure.

00:03:10.981 --> 00:03:13.830
Voice: We need an ambulance.

00:03:14.139 --> 00:03:16.156
Nonny de la Peña: So the man on the right,

00:03:16.180 --> 00:03:18.052
for him, he's walking around the body.

00:03:18.076 --> 00:03:20.773
For him, he's in the room with that body.

00:03:21.313 --> 00:03:23.130
Like, that guy is at his feet.

00:03:23.559 --> 00:03:25.766
And even though,
through his peripheral vision,

00:03:25.790 --> 00:03:27.861
he can see that he's in this lab space,

00:03:27.885 --> 00:03:32.098
he should be able to see
that he's not actually on the street,

00:03:32.122 --> 00:03:35.018
but he feels like he's there
with those people.

00:03:35.042 --> 00:03:37.052
He's very cautious not to step on this guy

00:03:37.076 --> 00:03:38.742
who isn't really there, right?

00:03:39.464 --> 00:03:42.567
So that piece ended up
going to Sundance in 2012,

00:03:42.591 --> 00:03:46.512
a kind of amazing thing,
and it was the first virtual reality film

00:03:46.536 --> 00:03:48.496
ever, basically.

00:03:49.020 --> 00:03:50.981
And when we went, I was really terrified.

00:03:51.005 --> 00:03:53.442
I didn't really know
how people were going to react

00:03:53.466 --> 00:03:54.855
and what was going to happen.

00:03:54.879 --> 00:03:57.776
And we showed up
with this duct-taped pair of goggles.

00:03:57.800 --> 00:04:01.785
(Video) Oh, you're crying.
You're crying. Gina, you're crying.

00:04:01.809 --> 00:04:04.529
So you can hear
the surprise in my voice, right?

00:04:04.553 --> 00:04:08.148
And this kind of reaction ended up being
the kind of reaction we saw

00:04:08.172 --> 00:04:10.942
over and over and over:

00:04:10.966 --> 00:04:14.672
people down on the ground
trying to comfort the seizure victim,

00:04:14.696 --> 00:04:16.616
trying to whisper something into his ear

00:04:16.640 --> 00:04:20.598
or in some way help,
even though they couldn't.

00:04:20.622 --> 00:04:23.306
And I had a lot of people
come out of that piece saying,

00:04:23.330 --> 00:04:26.054
"Oh my God, I was so frustrated.
I couldn't help the guy,"

00:04:26.078 --> 00:04:27.799
and take that back into their lives.

00:04:28.957 --> 00:04:30.823
So after this piece was made,

00:04:32.156 --> 00:04:35.965
the dean of the cinema school at USC,
the University of Southern California,

00:04:35.989 --> 00:04:40.196
brought in the head of the World
Economic Forum to try "Hunger,"

00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:41.561
and he took off the goggles,

00:04:41.585 --> 00:04:44.625
and he commissioned
a piece about Syria on the spot.

00:04:44.649 --> 00:04:47.562
And I really wanted to do something
about Syrian refugee kids,

00:04:47.586 --> 00:04:51.878
because children have been the worst
affected by the Syrian civil war.

00:04:52.767 --> 00:04:56.725
I sent a team to the border of Iraq
to record material at refugee camps,

00:04:56.749 --> 00:04:59.900
basically an area I wouldn't
send a team now,

00:04:59.924 --> 00:05:02.392
as that's where ISIS is really operating.

00:05:02.416 --> 00:05:05.122
And then we also recreated a street scene

00:05:05.146 --> 00:05:08.669
in which a young girl is singing
and a bomb goes off.

00:05:09.298 --> 00:05:11.377
Now, when you're
in the middle of that scene

00:05:11.401 --> 00:05:13.955
and you hear those sounds,

00:05:13.979 --> 00:05:16.272
and you see the injured around you,

00:05:16.296 --> 00:05:19.296
it's an incredibly scary and real feeling.

00:05:19.320 --> 00:05:23.860
I've had individuals who have been
involved in real bombings tell me

00:05:23.884 --> 00:05:27.359
that it evokes the same kind of fear.

00:05:28.169 --> 00:05:32.688
[The civil war in Syria may seem far away]

00:05:34.036 --> 00:05:40.302
[until you experience it yourself.]

00:05:41.020 --> 00:05:47.971
(Girl singing)

00:05:47.995 --> 00:05:50.773
(Explosion)

00:05:50.797 --> 00:05:55.034
[Project Syria]

00:05:55.946 --> 00:05:57.943
[A virtual reality experience]

00:05:58.611 --> 00:06:00.679
NP: We were then invited to take the piece

00:06:00.703 --> 00:06:02.757
to the Victoria and Albert
Museum in London.

00:06:02.781 --> 00:06:04.138
And it wasn't advertised.

00:06:04.162 --> 00:06:06.486
And we were put in this tapestry room.

00:06:06.510 --> 00:06:07.852
There was no press about it,

00:06:07.876 --> 00:06:11.613
so anybody who happened to walk
into the museum to visit it that day

00:06:11.637 --> 00:06:13.400
would see us with these crazy lights.

00:06:13.424 --> 00:06:17.099
You know, maybe they would want to see
the old storytelling of the tapestries.

00:06:17.123 --> 00:06:19.590
They were confronted
by our virtual reality cameras.

00:06:20.471 --> 00:06:23.598
But a lot of people tried it,
and over a five-day run

00:06:23.622 --> 00:06:28.162
we ended up with 54 pages
of guest book comments,

00:06:28.186 --> 00:06:30.522
and we were told by the curators there

00:06:30.546 --> 00:06:33.135
that they'd never seen such an outpouring.

00:06:33.159 --> 00:06:37.786
Things like, "It's so real,"
"Absolutely believable,"

00:06:37.810 --> 00:06:40.270
or, of course, the one
that I was excited about,

00:06:40.294 --> 00:06:43.143
"A real feeling as if you were
in the middle of something

00:06:43.167 --> 00:06:45.429
that you normally see on the TV news."

00:06:46.421 --> 00:06:49.897
So, it works, right? This stuff works.

00:06:50.255 --> 00:06:54.050
And it doesn't really matter
where you're from or what age you are --

00:06:54.074 --> 00:06:56.277
it's really evocative.

00:06:56.301 --> 00:07:00.253
Now, don't get me wrong -- I'm not saying
that when you're in a piece

00:07:00.277 --> 00:07:03.157
you forget that you're here.

00:07:03.181 --> 00:07:06.356
But it turns out we can feel
like we're in two places at once.

00:07:06.380 --> 00:07:09.530
We can have what I call
this duality of presence,

00:07:09.554 --> 00:07:14.411
and I think that's what allows me
to tap into these feelings of empathy.

00:07:14.435 --> 00:07:15.586
Right?

00:07:15.999 --> 00:07:19.190
So that means, of course,

00:07:19.214 --> 00:07:24.109
that I have to be very cautious
about creating these pieces.

00:07:24.133 --> 00:07:28.395
I have to really follow
best journalistic practices

00:07:28.419 --> 00:07:30.554
and make sure that these powerful stories

00:07:30.578 --> 00:07:32.164
are built with integrity.

00:07:32.188 --> 00:07:34.561
If we don't capture
the material ourselves,

00:07:34.585 --> 00:07:39.553
we have to be extremely exacting

00:07:39.577 --> 00:07:42.878
about figuring out the provenance
and where did this stuff come from

00:07:42.902 --> 00:07:44.210
and is it authentic?

00:07:44.234 --> 00:07:45.591
Let me give you an example.

00:07:45.615 --> 00:07:48.552
With this Trayvon Martin case,
this is a guy, a kid,

00:07:48.576 --> 00:07:52.679
who was 17 years old and he bought
soda and a candy at a store,

00:07:52.703 --> 00:07:56.179
and on his way home he was tracked
by a neighborhood watchman

00:07:56.203 --> 00:07:59.068
named George Zimmerman
who ended up shooting and killing him.

00:07:59.615 --> 00:08:00.767
To make that piece,

00:08:00.791 --> 00:08:04.393
we got the architectural drawings
of the entire complex,

00:08:04.417 --> 00:08:09.186
and we rebuilt the entire scene
inside and out, based on those drawings.

00:08:09.210 --> 00:08:10.505
All of the action

00:08:10.529 --> 00:08:15.448
is informed by the real 911
recorded calls to the police.

00:08:16.369 --> 00:08:19.146
And interestingly, we broke
some news with this story.

00:08:19.170 --> 00:08:23.145
The forensic house that did the audio
reconstruction, Primeau Productions,

00:08:23.169 --> 00:08:25.115
they say that they would testify

00:08:25.139 --> 00:08:27.814
that George Zimmerman,
when he got out of the car,

00:08:27.838 --> 00:08:30.670
he cocked his gun before he went
to give chase to Martin.

00:08:31.971 --> 00:08:35.376
So you can see that
the basic tenets of journalism,

00:08:35.400 --> 00:08:37.273
they don't really change here, right?

00:08:37.297 --> 00:08:40.701
We're still following the same principles
that we would always.

00:08:40.725 --> 00:08:44.028
What is different is the sense
of being on scene,

00:08:44.052 --> 00:08:46.393
whether you're watching
a guy collapse from hunger

00:08:46.417 --> 00:08:48.902
or feeling like you're
in the middle of a bomb scene.

00:08:48.926 --> 00:08:53.874
And this is kind of what has driven me
forward with these pieces,

00:08:53.898 --> 00:08:55.621
and thinking about how to make them.

00:08:55.645 --> 00:08:59.840
We're trying to make this, obviously,
beyond the headset, more available.

00:08:59.864 --> 00:09:02.791
We're creating mobile pieces
like the Trayvon Martin piece.

00:09:02.815 --> 00:09:06.364
And these things have had impact.

00:09:06.388 --> 00:09:08.960
I've had Americans tell me
that they've donated,

00:09:08.984 --> 00:09:13.378
direct deductions from their bank account,
money to go to Syrian children refugees.

00:09:13.402 --> 00:09:15.735
And "Hunger in LA," well,
it's helped start

00:09:15.759 --> 00:09:18.188
a new form of doing journalism

00:09:18.212 --> 00:09:21.308
that I think is going to join
all the other normal platforms

00:09:21.332 --> 00:09:22.483
in the future.

00:09:22.507 --> 00:09:23.671
Thank you.

00:09:23.695 --> 00:09:26.107
(Applause)

title: My country will be underwater soon -- unless we work together
transcript: Chris Anderson: Perhaps we could start by just telling us about your country. It's three dots there on the globe. Those dots are pretty huge. I think each one is about the size of California. Tell us about Kiribati.Anote Tong: Well, let me first begin by saying how deeply grateful I am for this opportunity to share my story with people who do care. I think I've been sharing my story with a lot of people who don't care too much. But Kiribati is comprised of three groups of islands: the Gilbert Group on the west, we have the Phoenix Islands in the middle, and the Line Islands in the east. And quite frankly, Kiribati is perhaps the only country that is actually in the four corners of the world, because we are in the Northern Hemisphere, in the Southern Hemisphere, and also in the east and the west of the International Date Line. These islands are entirely made up of coral atolls, and on average about two meters above sea level. And so this is what we have. Usually not more than two kilometers in width. And so, on many occasions, I've been asked by people, "You know, you're suffering, why don't you move back?" They don't understand. They have no concept of what it is that's involved. With the rising sea, they say, "Well, you can move back." And so this is what I tell them. If we move back, we will fall off on the other side of the ocean. OK? But these are the kinds of issues that people don't understand.CA: So certainly this is just a picture of fragility there. When was it that you yourself realized that there might be impending peril for your country?AT: Well, the story of climate change has been one that has been going on for quite a number of decades. And when I came into office in 2003, I began talking about climate change at the United Nations General Assembly, but not with so much passion, because then there was still this controversy among the scientists whether it was human-induced, whether it was real or it wasn't. But I think that that debate was fairly much concluded in 2007 with the Fourth Assessment Report of the IPCC, which made a categorical statement that it is real, it's human-induced, and it's predicting some very serious scenarios for countries like mine. And so that's when I got very serious. In the past, I talked about it. We were worried. But when the scenarios, the predictions came in 2007, it became a real issue for us.CA: Now, those predictions are, I think, that by 2100, sea levels are forecast to rise perhaps three feet. There's scenarios where it's higher than that, for sure, but what would you say to a skeptic who said, "What's three feet? You're on average six feet above sea level. What's the problem?"AT: Well, I think it's got to be understood that a marginal rise in sea level would mean a loss of a lot of land, because much of the land is low. And quite apart from that, we are getting the swells at the moment. So it's not about getting two feet. I think what many people do not understand is they think climate change is something that is happening in the future. Well, we're at the very bottom end of the spectrum. It's already with us. We have communities who already have been dislocated. They have had to move, and every parliament session, I'm getting complaints from different communities asking for assistance to build seawalls, to see what we can do about the freshwater lens because it's being destroyed, and so in my trips to the different islands, I'm seeing evidence of communities which are now having to cope with the loss of food crops, the contamination of the water lenses, and I see these communities perhaps leaving, having to relocate, within five to 10 years.CA: And then, I think the country suffered its first cyclone, and this is connected, yes? What happened here?AT: Well, we're on the equator, and I'm sure many of you understand that when you're on the equator, it's supposed to be in the doldrums. We're not supposed to get the cyclones. We create them, and then we send them either north or south.(Laughter)But they aren't supposed to come back. But for the first time, at the beginning of this year, the Cyclone Pam, which destroyed Vanuatu, and in the process, the very edges of it actually touched our two southernmost islands, and all of Tuvalu was underwater when Hurricane Pam struck. But for our two southernmost islands, we had waves come over half the island, and so this has never happened before. It's a new experience. And I've just come back from my own constituency, and I've seen these beautiful trees which had been there for decades, they've been totally destroyed. So this is what's happening, but when we talk about the rising sea level, we think it's something that happens gradually. It comes with the winds, it comes with the swells, and so they can be magnified, but what we are beginning to witness is the change in the weather pattern, which is perhaps the more urgent challenge that we will face sooner than perhaps the rising sea level.CA: So the country is already seeing effects now. As you look forward, what are your options as a country, as a nation?AT: Well, I've been telling this story every year. I think I visit a number of — I've been traveling the world to try and get people to understand. We have a plan, we think we have a plan. And on one occasion, I think I spoke in Geneva and there was a gentleman who was interviewing me on something like this, and I said, "We are looking at floating islands," and he thought it was funny, but somebody said, "No, this is not funny. These people are looking for solutions." And so I have been looking at floating islands. The Japanese are interested in building floating islands.But, as a country, we have made a commitment that no matter what happens, we will try as much as possible to stay and continue to exist as a nation. What that will take, it's going to be something quite significant, very, very substantial. Either we live on floating islands, or we have to build up the islands to continue to stay out of the water as the sea level rises and as the storms get more severe. But even that, it's going to be very, very difficult to get the kind of resourcing that we would need.CA: And then the only recourse is some form of forced migration.AT: Well, we are also looking at that because in the event that nothing comes forward from the international community, we are preparing, we don't want to be caught like what's happening in Europe. OK? We don't want to mass migrate at some point in time. We want to be able to give the people the choice today, those who choose and want to do that, to migrate. We don't want something to happen that they are forced to migrate without having been prepared to do so. Of course, our culture is very different, our society is very different, and once we migrate into a different environment, a different culture, there's a whole lot of adjustments that are required.CA: Well, there's forced migration in your country's past, and I think just this week, just yesterday or the day before yesterday, you visited these people. What happened here? What's the story here?AT: Yes, and I'm sorry, I think somebody was asking why we were sneaking off to visit that place. I had a very good reason, because we have a community of Kiribati people living in that part of the Solomon Islands, but these were people who were relocated from the Phoenix Islands, in fact, in the 1960s. There was serious drought, and the people could not continue to live on the island, and so they were moved to live here in the Solomon Islands. And so yesterday it was very interesting to meet with these people. They didn't know who I was. They hadn't heard of me. Some of them later recognized me, but I think they were very happy. Later they really wanted to have the opportunity to welcome me formally. But I think what I saw yesterday was very interesting because here I see our people. I spoke in our language, and of course they spoke back, they replied, but their accent, they are beginning not to be able to speak Kiribati properly. I saw them, there was this lady with red teeth. She was chewing betel nuts, and it's not something we do in Kiribati. We don't chew betel nuts. I met also a family who have married the local people here, and so this is what is happening. As you go into another community, there are bound to be changes. There is bound to be a certain loss of identity, and this is what we will be looking for in the future if and when we do migrate.CA: It must have been just an extraordinarily emotional day because of these questions about identity, the joy of seeing you and perhaps an emphasized sense of what they had lost. And it's very inspiring to hear you say you're going to fight to the end to try to preserve the nation in a location.AT: This is our wish. Nobody wants ever to leave their home, and so it's been a very difficult decision for me. As a leader, you don't make plans to leave your island, your home, and so I've been asked on a number of occasions, "So how do you feel?" And it doesn't feel good at all. It's an emotional thing, and I've tried to live with it, and I know that on occasions, I'm accused of not trying to solve the problem because I can't solve the problem. It's something that's got to be done collectively.Climate change is a global phenomenon, and as I've often argued, unfortunately, the countries, when we come to the United Nations — I was in a meeting with the Pacific Island Forum countries where Australia and New Zealand are also members, and we had an argument. There was a bit of a story in the news because they were arguing that to cut emissions, it would be something that they're unable to do because it would affect the industries. And so here I was saying, OK, I hear you, I understand what you're saying, but try also to understand what I'm saying because if you do not cut your emissions, then our survival is on the line. And so it's a matter for you to weigh this, these moral issues. It's about industry as opposed to the survival of a people.CA: You know, I ask you yesterday what made you angry, and you said, "I don't get angry." But then you paused. I think this made you angry.AT: I'd refer you to my earlier statement at the United Nations. I was very angry, very frustrated and then depressed. There was a sense of futility that we are fighting a fight that we have no hope of winning. I had to change my approach. I had to become more reasonable because I thought people would listen to somebody who was rational, but I remain radically rational, whatever that is.(Laughter)CA: Now, a core part of your nation's identity is fishing. I think you said pretty much everyone is involved in fishing in some way.AT: Well, we eat fish every day, every day, and I think there is no doubt that our rate of consumption of fish is perhaps the highest in the world. We don't have a lot of livestock, so it's fish that we depend on.CA: So you're dependent on fish, both at the local level and for the revenues that the country receives from the global fishing business for tuna, and yet despite that, a few years ago you took a very radical step. Can you tell us about that? I think something happened right here in the Phoenix Islands.AT: Let me give some of the background of what fish means for us. We have one of the largest tuna fisheries remaining in the world. In the Pacific, I think we own something like 60 percent of the remaining tuna fisheries, and it remains relatively healthy for some species, but not all. And Kiribati is one of the three major resource owners, tuna resource owners. And at the moment, we have been getting something like 80 to 90 percent of our revenue from access fees, license fees.CA: Of your national revenue.AT: National revenue, which drives everything that we do in governments, hospitals, schools and what have you. But we decided to close this, and it was a very difficult decision. I can assure you, politically, locally, it was not easy, but I was convinced that we had to do this in order to ensure that the fishery remains sustainable. There had been some indications that some of the species, in particular the bigeye, was under serious threat. The yellowfin was also heavily fished. Skipjack remains healthy. And so we had to do something like that, and so that was the reason I did that. Another reason why I did that was because I had been asking the international community that in order to deal with climate change, in order to fight climate change, there has got to be sacrifice, there has got to be commitment. So in asking the international community to make a sacrifice, I thought we ourselves need to make that sacrifice. And so we made the sacrifice. And forgoing commercial fishing in the Phoenix Islands protected area would mean a loss of revenue. We are still trying to assess what that loss would be because we actually closed it off at the beginning of this year, and so we will see by the end of this year what it means in terms of the lost revenue.CA: So there's so many things playing into this. On the one hand, it may prompt healthier fisheries. I mean, how much are you able to move the price up that you charge for the remaining areas?AT: The negotiations have been very difficult, but we have managed to raise the cost of a vessel day. For any vessel to come in to fish for a day, we have raised the fee from — it was $6,000 and $8,000, now to $10,000, $12,000 per vessel day. And so there's been that significant increase. But at the same time, what's important to note is, whereas in the past these fishing boats might be fishing in a day and maybe catch 10 tons, now they're catching maybe 100 tons because they've become so efficient. And so we've got to respond likewise. We've got to be very, very careful because the technology has so improved. There was a time when the Brazilian fleet moved from the Atlantic to the Pacific. They couldn't. They started experimenting if they could, per se. But now they've got ways of doing it, and they've become so efficient.CA: Can you give us a sense of what it's like in those negotiations? Because you're up against companies that have hundreds of millions of dollars at stake, essentially. How do you hold the line? Is there any advice you can give to other leaders who are dealing with the same companies about how to get the most for your country, get the most for the fish? What advice would you give?AT: Well, I think we focus too often on licensing in order to get the rate of return, because what we are getting from license fees is about 10 percent of the landed value of the catch on the side of the wharf, not in the retail shops. And we only get about 10 percent. What we have been trying to do over the years is actually to increase our participation in the industry, in the harvesting, in the processing, and eventually, hopefully, the marketing. They're not easy to penetrate, but we are working towards that, and yes, the answer would be to enhance. In order to increase our rate of return, we have to become more involved. And so we've started doing that, and we have to restructure the industry. We've got to tell these people that the world has changed. Now we want to produce the fish ourselves.CA: And meanwhile, for your local fishermen, they are still able to fish, but what is business like for them? Is it getting harder? Are the waters depleted? Or is that being run on a sustainable basis?AT: For the artisanal fishery, we do not participate in the commercial fishing activity except only to supply the domestic market. The tuna fishery is really entirely for the foreign market, mostly here in the US, Europe, Japan. So I am a fisherman, very much, and I used to be able to catch yellowfin. Now it's very, very rare to be able to catch yellowfin because they are being lifted out of the water by the hundreds of tons by these purse seiners.CA: So here's a couple of beautiful girls from your country. I mean, as you think about their future, what message would you have for them and what message would you have for the world?AT: Well, I've been telling the world that we really have to do something about what is happening to the climate because for us, it's about the future of these children. I have 12 grandchildren, at least. I think I have 12, my wife knows.(Laughter)And I think I have eight children. It's about their future. Every day I see my grandchildren, about the same age as these young girls, and I do wonder, and I get angry sometimes, yes I do. I wonder what is to become of them. And so it's about them that we should be telling everybody, that it's not about their own national interest, because climate change, regrettably, unfortunately, is viewed by many countries as a national problem. It's not. And this is the argument we got into recently with our partners, the Australians and New Zealanders, because they said, "We can't cut any more." This is what one of the leaders, the Australian leader, said, that we've done our part, we are cutting back. I said, What about the rest? Why don't you keep it? If you could keep the rest of your emissions within your boundaries, within your borders, we'd have no question. You can go ahead as much as you like. But unfortunately, you're sending it our way, and it's affecting the future of our children. And so surely I think that is the heart of the problem of climate change today.We will be meeting in Paris at the end of this year, but until we can think of this as a global phenomenon, because we create it, individually, as nations, but it affects everybody else, and yet, we refuse to do anything about it, and we deal with it as a national problem, which it is not — it is a global issue, and it's got to be dealt with collectively.CA: People are incredibly bad at responding to graphs and numbers, and we shut our minds to it. Somehow, to people, we're slightly better at responding to that sometimes. And it seems like it's very possible that your nation, despite, actually because of the intense problems you face, you may yet be the warning light to the world that shines most visibly, most powerfully. I just want to thank you,  I'm sure, on behalf of all of us, for your extraordinary leadership and for being here.Mr. President, thank you so much.AT: Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.718 --> 00:00:16.374
Chris Anderson: Perhaps we could start
by just telling us about your country.

00:00:16.398 --> 00:00:20.254
It's three dots there on the globe.
Those dots are pretty huge.

00:00:20.278 --> 00:00:22.934
I think each one
is about the size of California.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.814
Tell us about Kiribati.

00:00:24.838 --> 00:00:29.334
Anote Tong: Well, let me first begin
by saying how deeply grateful I am

00:00:29.358 --> 00:00:33.494
for this opportunity to share my story
with people who do care.

00:00:33.518 --> 00:00:39.094
I think I've been sharing my story with
a lot of people who don't care too much.

00:00:39.118 --> 00:00:42.974
But Kiribati is comprised
of three groups of islands:

00:00:42.998 --> 00:00:45.814
the Gilbert Group on the west,

00:00:45.838 --> 00:00:49.174
we have the Phoenix Islands in the middle,

00:00:49.198 --> 00:00:53.614
and the Line Islands in the east.

00:00:53.638 --> 00:00:56.734
And quite frankly, Kiribati
is perhaps the only country

00:00:56.758 --> 00:00:59.099
that is actually
in the four corners of the world,

00:00:59.124 --> 00:01:02.423
because we are in the Northern Hemisphere,
in the Southern Hemisphere,

00:01:02.448 --> 00:01:05.503
and also in the east and the west
of the International Date Line.

00:01:05.528 --> 00:01:11.854
These islands are entirely
made up of coral atolls,

00:01:11.878 --> 00:01:16.813
and on average about
two meters above sea level.

00:01:16.837 --> 00:01:20.294
And so this is what we have.

00:01:20.318 --> 00:01:25.134
Usually not more
than two kilometers in width.

00:01:25.158 --> 00:01:28.094
And so, on many occasions,
I've been asked by people,

00:01:28.118 --> 00:01:30.654
"You know, you're suffering,
why don't you move back?"

00:01:30.678 --> 00:01:31.894
They don't understand.

00:01:31.918 --> 00:01:35.614
They have no concept
of what it is that's involved.

00:01:35.638 --> 00:01:39.214
With the rising sea, they say,
"Well, you can move back."

00:01:39.238 --> 00:01:40.814
And so this is what I tell them.

00:01:40.838 --> 00:01:45.174
If we move back, we will fall off
on the other side of the ocean. OK?

00:01:45.198 --> 00:01:49.974
But these are the kinds of issues
that people don't understand.

00:01:49.998 --> 00:01:54.214
CA: So certainly this is
just a picture of fragility there.

00:01:54.238 --> 00:01:56.774
When was it that you yourself realized

00:01:56.798 --> 00:02:00.414
that there might be
impending peril for your country?

00:02:00.438 --> 00:02:03.894
AT: Well, the story of climate change
has been one that has been going on

00:02:03.918 --> 00:02:05.374
for quite a number of decades.

00:02:05.398 --> 00:02:10.134
And when I came into office in 2003,

00:02:10.158 --> 00:02:14.414
I began talking about climate change
at the United Nations General Assembly,

00:02:14.438 --> 00:02:17.174
but not with so much passion,

00:02:17.198 --> 00:02:20.814
because then there was still
this controversy among the scientists

00:02:20.838 --> 00:02:26.094
whether it was human-induced,
whether it was real or it wasn't.

00:02:26.118 --> 00:02:32.254
But I think that that debate
was fairly much concluded in 2007

00:02:32.278 --> 00:02:37.854
with the Fourth Assessment
Report of the IPCC,

00:02:37.878 --> 00:02:44.734
which made a categorical statement
that it is real, it's human-induced,

00:02:44.758 --> 00:02:48.694
and it's predicting
some very serious scenarios

00:02:48.718 --> 00:02:51.254
for countries like mine.

00:02:51.278 --> 00:02:54.534
And so that's when I got very serious.

00:02:54.558 --> 00:02:58.534
In the past, I talked about it.

00:02:58.558 --> 00:02:59.774
We were worried.

00:02:59.798 --> 00:03:03.534
But when the scenarios,
the predictions came in 2007,

00:03:03.558 --> 00:03:05.894
it became a real issue for us.

00:03:05.918 --> 00:03:11.534
CA: Now, those predictions are,
I think, that by 2100,

00:03:11.558 --> 00:03:14.334
sea levels are forecast to rise
perhaps three feet.

00:03:14.358 --> 00:03:16.978
There's scenarios where
it's higher than that, for sure,

00:03:17.002 --> 00:03:19.138
but what would you say
to a skeptic who said,

00:03:19.162 --> 00:03:20.334
"What's three feet?

00:03:20.358 --> 00:03:22.534
You're on average
six feet above sea level.

00:03:22.558 --> 00:03:24.134
What's the problem?"

00:03:24.158 --> 00:03:26.214
AT: Well, I think
it's got to be understood

00:03:26.238 --> 00:03:28.294
that a marginal rise in sea level

00:03:28.318 --> 00:03:30.894
would mean a loss of a lot of land,

00:03:30.918 --> 00:03:34.174
because much of the land is low.

00:03:34.198 --> 00:03:39.294
And quite apart from that,
we are getting the swells at the moment.

00:03:39.318 --> 00:03:41.494
So it's not about getting two feet.

00:03:41.518 --> 00:03:44.534
I think what many people do not understand

00:03:44.558 --> 00:03:50.734
is they think climate change is something
that is happening in the future.

00:03:50.758 --> 00:03:53.574
Well, we're at the very
bottom end of the spectrum.

00:03:53.598 --> 00:03:54.854
It's already with us.

00:03:54.878 --> 00:03:58.694
We have communities
who already have been dislocated.

00:03:58.718 --> 00:04:02.654
They have had to move,
and every parliament session,

00:04:02.678 --> 00:04:05.014
I'm getting complaints
from different communities

00:04:05.038 --> 00:04:08.094
asking for assistance to build seawalls,

00:04:08.118 --> 00:04:10.654
to see what we can do
about the freshwater lens

00:04:10.678 --> 00:04:12.494
because it's being destroyed,

00:04:12.518 --> 00:04:15.254
and so in my trips
to the different islands,

00:04:15.278 --> 00:04:17.974
I'm seeing evidence of communities

00:04:17.998 --> 00:04:21.614
which are now having to cope
with the loss of food crops,

00:04:21.638 --> 00:04:25.214
the contamination of the water lenses,

00:04:25.238 --> 00:04:29.574
and I see these communities
perhaps leaving, having to relocate,

00:04:29.598 --> 00:04:31.934
within five to 10 years.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:35.894
CA: And then, I think the country
suffered its first cyclone,

00:04:35.918 --> 00:04:39.454
and this is connected, yes?
What happened here?

00:04:39.478 --> 00:04:42.174
AT: Well, we're on the equator,

00:04:42.198 --> 00:04:46.614
and I'm sure many of you understand
that when you're on the equator,

00:04:46.638 --> 00:04:50.214
it's supposed to be in the doldrums.
We're not supposed to get the cyclones.

00:04:50.238 --> 00:04:53.048
We create them, and then we send them
either north or south.

00:04:53.072 --> 00:04:54.454
(Laughter)

00:04:54.478 --> 00:04:56.334
But they aren't supposed to come back.

00:04:56.358 --> 00:04:58.882
But for the first time,
at the beginning of this year,

00:04:58.906 --> 00:05:02.574
the Cyclone Pam,
which destroyed Vanuatu,

00:05:02.598 --> 00:05:06.054
and in the process,
the very edges of it actually touched

00:05:06.078 --> 00:05:08.454
our two southernmost islands,

00:05:08.478 --> 00:05:13.854
and all of Tuvalu was underwater
when Hurricane Pam struck.

00:05:13.878 --> 00:05:17.574
But for our two southernmost islands,

00:05:17.598 --> 00:05:20.934
we had waves come over half the island,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.414
and so this has never happened before.

00:05:23.438 --> 00:05:25.014
It's a new experience.

00:05:25.038 --> 00:05:30.374
And I've just come back
from my own constituency,

00:05:30.398 --> 00:05:33.734
and I've seen these beautiful trees
which had been there for decades,

00:05:33.758 --> 00:05:35.734
they've been totally destroyed.

00:05:35.758 --> 00:05:37.454
So this is what's happening,

00:05:37.478 --> 00:05:41.334
but when we talk
about the rising sea level,

00:05:41.358 --> 00:05:44.454
we think it's something
that happens gradually.

00:05:44.478 --> 00:05:47.534
It comes with the winds,
it comes with the swells,

00:05:47.558 --> 00:05:49.494
and so they can be magnified,

00:05:49.518 --> 00:05:55.694
but what we are beginning to witness
is the change in the weather pattern,

00:05:55.718 --> 00:05:58.454
which is perhaps the more urgent challenge

00:05:58.478 --> 00:06:03.014
that we will face sooner
than perhaps the rising sea level.

00:06:03.038 --> 00:06:06.294
CA: So the country
is already seeing effects now.

00:06:06.318 --> 00:06:08.494
As you look forward,

00:06:08.518 --> 00:06:12.454
what are your options
as a country, as a nation?

00:06:12.478 --> 00:06:15.134
AT: Well, I've been telling
this story every year.

00:06:15.158 --> 00:06:16.587
I think I visit a number of --

00:06:16.611 --> 00:06:21.574
I've been traveling the world
to try and get people to understand.

00:06:21.598 --> 00:06:24.054
We have a plan, we think we have a plan.

00:06:24.078 --> 00:06:27.494
And on one occasion,
I think I spoke in Geneva

00:06:27.518 --> 00:06:31.694
and there was a gentleman
who was interviewing me

00:06:31.718 --> 00:06:33.454
on something like this,

00:06:33.478 --> 00:06:35.814
and I said, "We are looking
at floating islands,"

00:06:35.838 --> 00:06:38.054
and he thought it was funny,
but somebody said,

00:06:38.078 --> 00:06:42.014
"No, this is not funny.
These people are looking for solutions."

00:06:42.038 --> 00:06:45.574
And so I have been looking
at floating islands.

00:06:45.598 --> 00:06:49.334
The Japanese are interested
in building floating islands.

00:06:49.358 --> 00:06:52.294
But, as a country,
we have made a commitment

00:06:52.318 --> 00:06:56.014
that no matter what happens,
we will try as much as possible

00:06:56.038 --> 00:07:00.214
to stay and continue to exist as a nation.

00:07:00.238 --> 00:07:01.774
What that will take,

00:07:01.798 --> 00:07:05.214
it's going to be
something quite significant,

00:07:05.238 --> 00:07:07.254
very, very substantial.

00:07:07.278 --> 00:07:09.054
Either we live on floating islands,

00:07:09.078 --> 00:07:13.054
or we have to build up the islands
to continue to stay out of the water

00:07:13.078 --> 00:07:17.814
as the sea level rises
and as the storms get more severe.

00:07:17.838 --> 00:07:20.267
But even that, it's going to be
very, very difficult

00:07:20.291 --> 00:07:23.134
to get the kind of resourcing
that we would need.

00:07:23.158 --> 00:07:27.014
CA: And then the only recourse
is some form of forced migration.

00:07:27.038 --> 00:07:29.254
AT: Well, we are also looking at that

00:07:29.278 --> 00:07:32.174
because in the event
that nothing comes forward

00:07:32.198 --> 00:07:34.014
from the international community,

00:07:34.038 --> 00:07:35.294
we are preparing,

00:07:35.318 --> 00:07:38.534
we don't want to be caught
like what's happening in Europe.

00:07:38.558 --> 00:07:41.254
OK? We don't want to mass migrate
at some point in time.

00:07:41.278 --> 00:07:44.694
We want to be able
to give the people the choice today,

00:07:44.718 --> 00:07:48.374
those who choose
and want to do that, to migrate.

00:07:48.398 --> 00:07:53.454
We don't want something to happen
that they are forced to migrate

00:07:53.478 --> 00:07:55.774
without having been prepared to do so.

00:07:55.798 --> 00:07:59.294
Of course, our culture is very different,
our society is very different,

00:07:59.318 --> 00:08:01.654
and once we migrate
into a different environment,

00:08:01.678 --> 00:08:02.894
a different culture,

00:08:02.918 --> 00:08:05.854
there's a whole lot
of adjustments that are required.

00:08:05.878 --> 00:08:09.134
CA: Well, there's forced migration
in your country's past,

00:08:09.158 --> 00:08:10.814
and I think just this week,

00:08:10.838 --> 00:08:14.094
just yesterday
or the day before yesterday,

00:08:14.118 --> 00:08:16.294
you visited these people.

00:08:16.318 --> 00:08:18.494
What happened here? What's the story here?

00:08:18.518 --> 00:08:20.934
AT: Yes, and I'm sorry,
I think somebody was asking

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.934
why we were sneaking off
to visit that place.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.934
I had a very good reason, because we have
a community of Kiribati people

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:32.054
living in that part
of the Solomon Islands,

00:08:32.078 --> 00:08:35.934
but these were people who were relocated
from the Phoenix Islands, in fact,

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.414
in the 1960s.

00:08:37.438 --> 00:08:41.974
There was serious drought, and the people
could not continue to live on the island,

00:08:41.998 --> 00:08:45.374
and so they were moved
to live here in the Solomon Islands.

00:08:45.398 --> 00:08:48.574
And so yesterday it was very interesting
to meet with these people.

00:08:48.598 --> 00:08:51.054
They didn't know who I was.
They hadn't heard of me.

00:08:51.078 --> 00:08:53.654
Some of them later recognized me,

00:08:53.678 --> 00:08:57.254
but I think they were very happy.

00:08:57.278 --> 00:09:01.694
Later they really wanted to have
the opportunity to welcome me formally.

00:09:01.718 --> 00:09:04.974
But I think what I saw yesterday
was very interesting

00:09:04.998 --> 00:09:06.814
because here I see our people.

00:09:06.838 --> 00:09:12.654
I spoke in our language, and of course
they spoke back, they replied,

00:09:12.678 --> 00:09:17.374
but their accent, they are beginning
not to be able to speak Kiribati properly.

00:09:17.398 --> 00:09:19.894
I saw them, there was
this lady with red teeth.

00:09:19.918 --> 00:09:22.134
She was chewing betel nuts,

00:09:22.158 --> 00:09:24.414
and it's not something we do in Kiribati.

00:09:24.438 --> 00:09:27.054
We don't chew betel nuts.

00:09:27.078 --> 00:09:32.934
I met also a family who have married
the local people here,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:37.054
and so this is what is happening.

00:09:37.078 --> 00:09:40.654
As you go into another community,
there are bound to be changes.

00:09:40.678 --> 00:09:45.134
There is bound to be
a certain loss of identity,

00:09:45.158 --> 00:09:48.614
and this is what we will be
looking for in the future

00:09:48.638 --> 00:09:50.894
if and when we do migrate.

00:09:50.918 --> 00:09:54.094
CA: It must have been
just an extraordinarily emotional day

00:09:54.118 --> 00:09:56.934
because of these questions about identity,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:10:02.174
the joy of seeing you and perhaps
an emphasized sense of what they had lost.

00:10:02.198 --> 00:10:05.579
And it's very inspiring to hear you say
you're going to fight to the end

00:10:05.603 --> 00:10:10.014
to try to preserve
the nation in a location.

00:10:10.038 --> 00:10:11.334
AT: This is our wish.

00:10:11.358 --> 00:10:14.414
Nobody wants ever to leave their home,

00:10:14.438 --> 00:10:17.494
and so it's been
a very difficult decision for me.

00:10:17.518 --> 00:10:22.894
As a leader, you don't make plans
to leave your island, your home,

00:10:22.918 --> 00:10:25.174
and so I've been asked
on a number of occasions,

00:10:25.198 --> 00:10:26.414
"So how do you feel?"

00:10:26.438 --> 00:10:29.574
And it doesn't feel good at all.

00:10:29.598 --> 00:10:33.174
It's an emotional thing,
and I've tried to live with it,

00:10:33.198 --> 00:10:38.134
and I know that on occasions, I'm accused
of not trying to solve the problem

00:10:38.158 --> 00:10:40.134
because I can't solve the problem.

00:10:40.158 --> 00:10:42.974
It's something that's got
to be done collectively.

00:10:42.998 --> 00:10:48.774
Climate change is a global phenomenon,
and as I've often argued,

00:10:48.798 --> 00:10:53.294
unfortunately, the countries,
when we come to the United Nations --

00:10:53.318 --> 00:10:58.214
I was in a meeting with
the Pacific Island Forum countries

00:10:58.238 --> 00:11:00.734
where Australia and New Zealand
are also members,

00:11:00.758 --> 00:11:02.494
and we had an argument.

00:11:02.518 --> 00:11:05.214
There was a bit of a story in the news

00:11:05.238 --> 00:11:09.534
because they were arguing
that to cut emissions,

00:11:09.558 --> 00:11:11.814
it would be something
that they're unable to do

00:11:11.838 --> 00:11:15.054
because it would affect the industries.

00:11:15.078 --> 00:11:16.534
And so here I was saying,

00:11:16.558 --> 00:11:18.774
OK, I hear you,

00:11:18.798 --> 00:11:20.454
I understand what you're saying,

00:11:20.478 --> 00:11:22.734
but try also to understand what I'm saying

00:11:22.758 --> 00:11:25.374
because if you do not cut your emissions,

00:11:25.398 --> 00:11:27.774
then our survival is on the line.

00:11:27.798 --> 00:11:32.134
And so it's a matter for you
to weigh this, these moral issues.

00:11:32.158 --> 00:11:36.174
It's about industry as opposed to
the survival of a people.

00:11:36.198 --> 00:11:38.854
CA: You know, I ask you yesterday
what made you angry,

00:11:38.878 --> 00:11:42.374
and you said, "I don't get angry."
But then you paused.

00:11:42.398 --> 00:11:44.014
I think this made you angry.

00:11:44.038 --> 00:11:48.934
AT: I'd refer you to my earlier
statement at the United Nations.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:53.894
I was very angry, very frustrated
and then depressed.

00:11:53.918 --> 00:11:55.894
There was a sense of futility

00:11:55.918 --> 00:12:01.374
that we are fighting a fight
that we have no hope of winning.

00:12:01.398 --> 00:12:03.574
I had to change my approach.

00:12:03.598 --> 00:12:05.694
I had to become more reasonable

00:12:05.718 --> 00:12:08.861
because I thought people would listen
to somebody who was rational,

00:12:08.885 --> 00:12:11.454
but I remain radically rational,
whatever that is.

00:12:11.478 --> 00:12:13.094
(Laughter)

00:12:13.118 --> 00:12:16.854
CA: Now, a core part
of your nation's identity is fishing.

00:12:16.878 --> 00:12:20.374
I think you said pretty much everyone
is involved in fishing in some way.

00:12:20.398 --> 00:12:23.174
AT: Well, we eat fish
every day, every day,

00:12:23.198 --> 00:12:27.734
and I think there is no doubt
that our rate of consumption of fish

00:12:27.758 --> 00:12:29.894
is perhaps the highest in the world.

00:12:29.918 --> 00:12:32.374
We don't have a lot of livestock,

00:12:32.398 --> 00:12:35.174
so it's fish that we depend on.

00:12:35.198 --> 00:12:38.334
CA: So you're dependent on fish,
both at the local level

00:12:38.358 --> 00:12:41.054
and for the revenues
that the country receives

00:12:41.078 --> 00:12:43.654
from the global fishing business for tuna,

00:12:43.678 --> 00:12:48.574
and yet despite that, a few years ago
you took a very radical step.

00:12:48.598 --> 00:12:49.974
Can you tell us about that?

00:12:49.998 --> 00:12:53.334
I think something happened
right here in the Phoenix Islands.

00:12:53.358 --> 00:12:58.654
AT: Let me give some of the background
of what fish means for us.

00:12:58.678 --> 00:13:02.614
We have one of the largest
tuna fisheries remaining in the world.

00:13:02.638 --> 00:13:05.494
In the Pacific, I think we own
something like 60 percent

00:13:05.518 --> 00:13:07.414
of the remaining tuna fisheries,

00:13:07.438 --> 00:13:11.694
and it remains relatively healthy
for some species, but not all.

00:13:11.718 --> 00:13:16.838
And Kiribati is one of the three
major resource owners,

00:13:17.878 --> 00:13:19.574
tuna resource owners.

00:13:19.598 --> 00:13:23.174
And at the moment, we have been getting

00:13:23.198 --> 00:13:26.094
something like 80 to 90
percent of our revenue

00:13:26.118 --> 00:13:28.574
from access fees, license fees.

00:13:28.598 --> 00:13:30.454
CA: Of your national revenue.

00:13:30.478 --> 00:13:32.294
AT: National revenue,

00:13:32.318 --> 00:13:35.134
which drives everything that we do

00:13:35.158 --> 00:13:39.174
in governments, hospitals,
schools and what have you.

00:13:39.198 --> 00:13:44.414
But we decided to close this,
and it was a very difficult decision.

00:13:44.438 --> 00:13:49.974
I can assure you, politically,
locally, it was not easy,

00:13:49.998 --> 00:13:53.934
but I was convinced that we had to do this

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:58.534
in order to ensure
that the fishery remains sustainable.

00:13:58.558 --> 00:14:01.334
There had been some indications
that some of the species,

00:14:01.358 --> 00:14:05.494
in particular the bigeye,
was under serious threat.

00:14:05.518 --> 00:14:08.894
The yellowfin was also heavily fished.

00:14:08.918 --> 00:14:10.654
Skipjack remains healthy.

00:14:10.678 --> 00:14:15.454
And so we had to do something like that,
and so that was the reason I did that.

00:14:15.478 --> 00:14:19.374
Another reason why I did that

00:14:19.398 --> 00:14:24.094
was because I had been asking
the international community

00:14:24.118 --> 00:14:28.654
that in order to deal with climate change,
in order to fight climate change,

00:14:28.678 --> 00:14:32.574
there has got to be sacrifice,
there has got to be commitment.

00:14:32.598 --> 00:14:37.894
So in asking the international community
to make a sacrifice,

00:14:37.918 --> 00:14:40.734
I thought we ourselves
need to make that sacrifice.

00:14:40.758 --> 00:14:42.574
And so we made the sacrifice.

00:14:42.598 --> 00:14:47.541
And forgoing commercial fishing

00:14:47.566 --> 00:14:50.174
in the Phoenix Islands protected area

00:14:50.198 --> 00:14:52.054
would mean a loss of revenue.

00:14:52.078 --> 00:14:54.555
We are still trying to assess
what that loss would be

00:14:54.579 --> 00:14:59.814
because we actually closed it off
at the beginning of this year,

00:14:59.838 --> 00:15:02.174
and so we will see by the end of this year

00:15:02.198 --> 00:15:05.694
what it means in terms
of the lost revenue.

00:15:05.718 --> 00:15:07.974
CA: So there's so many things
playing into this.

00:15:07.998 --> 00:15:14.974
On the one hand,
it may prompt healthier fisheries.

00:15:14.998 --> 00:15:17.374
I mean, how much are you able
to move the price up

00:15:17.398 --> 00:15:19.894
that you charge for the remaining areas?

00:15:19.918 --> 00:15:24.534
AT: The negotiations
have been very difficult,

00:15:24.558 --> 00:15:28.414
but we have managed
to raise the cost of a vessel day.

00:15:28.438 --> 00:15:31.054
For any vessel
to come in to fish for a day,

00:15:31.078 --> 00:15:34.694
we have raised the fee from --
it was $6,000 and $8,000,

00:15:34.718 --> 00:15:39.294
now to $10,000, $12,000 per vessel day.

00:15:39.318 --> 00:15:42.534
And so there's been
that significant increase.

00:15:42.558 --> 00:15:47.134
But at the same time,
what's important to note is,

00:15:47.158 --> 00:15:51.494
whereas in the past these fishing boats

00:15:51.518 --> 00:15:55.454
might be fishing in a day
and maybe catch 10 tons,

00:15:55.478 --> 00:15:59.374
now they're catching maybe 100 tons
because they've become so efficient.

00:15:59.398 --> 00:16:01.734
And so we've got to respond likewise.

00:16:01.758 --> 00:16:05.934
We've got to be very, very careful
because the technology has so improved.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:11.374
There was a time when the Brazilian fleet
moved from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

00:16:11.398 --> 00:16:12.614
They couldn't.

00:16:12.638 --> 00:16:15.854
They started experimenting
if they could, per se.

00:16:15.878 --> 00:16:19.558
But now they've got ways of doing it,
and they've become so efficient.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:24.156
CA: Can you give us a sense
of what it's like in those negotiations?

00:16:24.181 --> 00:16:25.878
Because you're up against companies

00:16:25.902 --> 00:16:29.494
that have hundreds of millions
of dollars at stake, essentially.

00:16:29.518 --> 00:16:32.854
How do you hold the line?

00:16:32.878 --> 00:16:34.934
Is there any advice you can give

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.014
to other leaders who are dealing
with the same companies

00:16:38.038 --> 00:16:42.334
about how to get
the most for your country,

00:16:42.358 --> 00:16:46.374
get the most for the fish?

00:16:46.398 --> 00:16:47.934
What advice would you give?

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:54.214
AT: Well, I think we focus
too often on licensing

00:16:54.238 --> 00:16:55.905
in order to get the rate of return,

00:16:55.929 --> 00:16:58.734
because what we are getting
from license fees

00:16:58.758 --> 00:17:01.374
is about 10 percent
of the landed value of the catch

00:17:01.398 --> 00:17:04.534
on the side of the wharf,
not in the retail shops.

00:17:04.558 --> 00:17:08.534
And we only get about 10 percent.

00:17:08.558 --> 00:17:11.174
What we have been trying
to do over the years

00:17:11.198 --> 00:17:15.054
is actually to increase
our participation in the industry,

00:17:15.078 --> 00:17:17.694
in the harvesting, in the processing,

00:17:17.718 --> 00:17:19.575
and eventually, hopefully, the marketing.

00:17:19.600 --> 00:17:23.294
They're not easy to penetrate,

00:17:23.317 --> 00:17:25.614
but we are working towards that,

00:17:25.638 --> 00:17:28.254
and yes, the answer would be to enhance.

00:17:28.277 --> 00:17:32.494
In order to increase our rate of return,
we have to become more involved.

00:17:32.518 --> 00:17:35.694
And so we've started doing that,

00:17:35.718 --> 00:17:39.974
and we have to restructure the industry.

00:17:39.998 --> 00:17:43.374
We've got to tell these people
that the world has changed.

00:17:43.398 --> 00:17:45.814
Now we want to produce the fish ourselves.

00:17:45.838 --> 00:17:47.934
CA: And meanwhile,
for your local fishermen,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:51.054
they are still able to fish,

00:17:51.078 --> 00:17:53.534
but what is business like for them?

00:17:53.558 --> 00:17:55.894
Is it getting harder?
Are the waters depleted?

00:17:55.918 --> 00:17:59.374
Or is that being run
on a sustainable basis?

00:17:59.398 --> 00:18:00.854
AT: For the artisanal fishery,

00:18:00.878 --> 00:18:04.134
we do not participate
in the commercial fishing activity

00:18:04.158 --> 00:18:07.174
except only to supply the domestic market.

00:18:07.198 --> 00:18:10.494
The tuna fishery is really
entirely for the foreign market,

00:18:10.518 --> 00:18:16.734
mostly here in the US, Europe, Japan.

00:18:16.758 --> 00:18:21.294
So I am a fisherman, very much,

00:18:21.318 --> 00:18:24.494
and I used to be able to catch yellowfin.

00:18:24.518 --> 00:18:27.294
Now it's very, very rare
to be able to catch yellowfin

00:18:27.318 --> 00:18:30.694
because they are being lifted
out of the water by the hundreds of tons

00:18:30.718 --> 00:18:32.598
by these purse seiners.

00:18:34.318 --> 00:18:39.254
CA: So here's a couple
of beautiful girls from your country.

00:18:39.278 --> 00:18:42.494
I mean, as you think about their future,

00:18:42.518 --> 00:18:45.174
what message would you have for them

00:18:45.198 --> 00:18:48.214
and what message
would you have for the world?

00:18:48.238 --> 00:18:51.667
AT: Well, I've been telling the world
that we really have to do something

00:18:51.691 --> 00:18:53.534
about what is happening to the climate

00:18:53.558 --> 00:18:56.334
because for us, it's about
the future of these children.

00:18:56.358 --> 00:18:58.294
I have 12 grandchildren, at least.

00:18:58.318 --> 00:19:00.334
I think I have 12, my wife knows.

00:19:00.358 --> 00:19:02.574
(Laughter)

00:19:02.598 --> 00:19:05.614
And I think I have eight children.

00:19:05.638 --> 00:19:06.894
It's about their future.

00:19:06.918 --> 00:19:10.654
Every day I see my grandchildren,
about the same age as these young girls,

00:19:10.678 --> 00:19:13.094
and I do wonder,

00:19:13.118 --> 00:19:15.334
and I get angry sometimes, yes I do.

00:19:15.358 --> 00:19:17.414
I wonder what is to become of them.

00:19:17.438 --> 00:19:20.574
And so it's about them

00:19:20.598 --> 00:19:22.854
that we should be telling everybody,

00:19:22.878 --> 00:19:25.134
that it's not about
their own national interest,

00:19:25.158 --> 00:19:28.814
because climate change,
regrettably, unfortunately,

00:19:28.838 --> 00:19:32.934
is viewed by many countries
as a national problem. It's not.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:35.958
And this is the argument
we got into recently with our partners,

00:19:35.982 --> 00:19:37.678
the Australians and New Zealanders,

00:19:37.702 --> 00:19:41.014
because they said,
"We can't cut any more."

00:19:41.038 --> 00:19:44.654
This is what one of the leaders,
the Australian leader, said,

00:19:44.678 --> 00:19:48.934
that we've done our part,
we are cutting back.

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:52.614
I said, What about the rest?
Why don't you keep it?

00:19:52.638 --> 00:19:55.334
If you could keep
the rest of your emissions

00:19:55.358 --> 00:19:57.654
within your boundaries,
within your borders,

00:19:57.678 --> 00:19:59.454
we'd have no question.

00:19:59.478 --> 00:20:01.294
You can go ahead as much as you like.

00:20:01.318 --> 00:20:03.454
But unfortunately,
you're sending it our way,

00:20:03.478 --> 00:20:05.669
and it's affecting
the future of our children.

00:20:05.693 --> 00:20:10.734
And so surely I think that is the heart
of the problem of climate change today.

00:20:10.758 --> 00:20:13.814
We will be meeting in Paris
at the end of this year,

00:20:13.838 --> 00:20:17.774
but until we can think of this
as a global phenomenon,

00:20:17.798 --> 00:20:21.054
because we create it,
individually, as nations,

00:20:21.078 --> 00:20:23.014
but it affects everybody else,

00:20:23.038 --> 00:20:26.654
and yet, we refuse
to do anything about it,

00:20:26.678 --> 00:20:29.134
and we deal with it as a national problem,

00:20:29.158 --> 00:20:31.254
which it is not -- it is a global issue,

00:20:31.278 --> 00:20:33.998
and it's got to be
dealt with collectively.

00:20:35.078 --> 00:20:39.414
CA: People are incredibly bad
at responding to graphs and numbers,

00:20:39.438 --> 00:20:43.214
and we shut our minds to it.

00:20:43.238 --> 00:20:49.494
Somehow, to people, we're slightly better
at responding to that sometimes.

00:20:49.518 --> 00:20:52.454
And it seems like it's
very possible that your nation,

00:20:52.478 --> 00:20:56.934
despite, actually because of
the intense problems you face,

00:20:56.958 --> 00:21:01.854
you may yet be the warning light
to the world that shines most visibly,

00:21:01.878 --> 00:21:03.854
most powerfully.

00:21:03.878 --> 00:21:06.695
I just want to thank you, 
I'm sure, on behalf of all of us,

00:21:06.720 --> 00:21:09.214
for your extraordinary leadership
and for being here.

00:21:09.238 --> 00:21:10.811
Mr. President, thank you so much.

00:21:10.831 --> 00:21:11.604
AT: Thank you.

00:21:11.624 --> 00:21:14.078
(Applause)

title: What are animals thinking and feeling?
transcript: Have you ever wondered what animals think and feel? Let's start with a question: Does my dog really love me, or does she just want a treat? Well, it's easy to see that our dog really loves us, easy to see, right, what's going on in that fuzzy little head. What is going on? Something's going on.But why is the question always do they love us? Why is it always about us? Why are we such narcissists? I found a different question to ask animals. Who are you?There are capacities of the human mind that we tend to think are capacities only of the human mind. But is that true? What are other beings doing with those brains? What are they thinking and feeling? Is there a way to know? I think there is a way in. I think there are several ways in. We can look at evolution, we can look at their brains and we can watch what they do.The first thing to remember is: our brain is inherited. The first neurons came from jellyfish. Jellyfish gave rise to the first chordates. The first chordates gave rise to the first vertebrates. The vertebrates came out of the sea, and here we are. But it's still true that a neuron, a nerve cell, looks the same in a crayfish, a bird or you. What does that say about the minds of crayfish? Can we tell anything about that? Well, it turns out that if you give a crayfish a lot of little tiny electric shocks every time it tries to come out of its burrow, it will develop anxiety. If you give the crayfish the same drug used to treat anxiety disorder in humans, it relaxes and comes out and explores. How do we show how much we care about crayfish anxiety? Mostly, we boil them.(Laughter)Octopuses use tools, as well as do most apes and they recognize human faces. How do we celebrate the ape-like intelligence of this invertebrate? Mostly boiled. If a grouper chases a fish into a crevice in the coral, it will sometimes go to where it knows a moray eel is sleeping and it will signal to the moray, "Follow me," and the moray will understand that signal. The moray may go into the crevice and get the fish, but the fish may bolt and the grouper may get it. This is an ancient partnership that we have just recently found out about. How do we celebrate that ancient partnership? Mostly fried. A pattern is emerging and it says a lot more about us than it does about them.Sea otters use tools and they take time away from what they're doing to show their babies what to do, which is called teaching. Chimpanzees don't teach. Killer whales teach and killer whales share food.When evolution makes something new, it uses the parts it has in stock, off the shelf, before it fabricates a new twist. And our brain has come to us through the enormity of the deep sweep of time. If you look at the human brain compared to a chimpanzee brain, what you see is we have basically a very big chimpanzee brain. It's a good thing ours is bigger, because we're also really insecure.(Laughter)But, uh oh, there's a dolphin, a bigger brain with more convolutions. OK, maybe you're saying, all right, well, we see brains, but what does that have to say about minds? Well, we can see the working of the mind in the logic of behaviors. So these elephants, you can see, obviously, they are resting. They have found a patch of shade under the palm trees under which to let their babies sleep, while they doze but remain vigilant. We make perfect sense of that image just as they make perfect sense of what they're doing because under the arc of the same sun on the same plains, listening to the howls of the same dangers, they became who they are and we became who we are.We've been neighbors for a very long time. No one would mistake these elephants as being relaxed. They're obviously very concerned about something. What are they concerned about? It turns out that if you record the voices of tourists and you play that recording from a speaker hidden in bushes, elephants will ignore it, because tourists never bother elephants. But if you record the voices of herders who carry spears and often hurt elephants in confrontations at water holes, the elephants will bunch up and run away from the hidden speaker. Not only do elephants know that there are humans, they know that there are different kinds of humans, and that some are OK and some are dangerous.They have been watching us for much longer than we have been watching them. They know us better than we know them. We have the same imperatives: take care of our babies, find food, try to stay alive. Whether we're outfitted for hiking in the hills of Africa or outfitted for diving under the sea, we are basically the same. We are kin under the skin. The elephant has the same skeleton, the killer whale has the same skeleton, as do we. We see helping where help is needed. We see curiosity in the young. We see the bonds of family connections. We recognize affection. Courtship is courtship. And then we ask, "Are they conscious?"When you get general anesthesia, it makes you unconscious, which means you have no sensation of anything. Consciousness is simply the thing that feels like something. If you see, if you hear, if you feel, if you're aware of anything, you are conscious, and they are conscious.Some people say well, there are certain things that make humans humans, and one of those things is empathy. Empathy is the mind's ability to match moods with your companions. It's a very useful thing. If your companions start to move quickly, you have to feel like you need to hurry up. We're all in a hurry now. The oldest form of empathy is contagious fear. If your companions suddenly startle and fly away, it does not work very well for you to say, "Jeez, I wonder why everybody just left."(Laughter)Empathy is old, but empathy, like everything else in life, comes on a sliding scale and has its elaboration. So there's basic empathy: you feel sad, it makes me sad. I see you happy, it makes me happy.Then there's something that I call sympathy, a little more removed: "I'm sorry to hear that your grandmother has just passed away. I don't feel that same grief, but I get it; I know what you feel and it concerns me."And then if we're motivated to act on sympathy, I call that compassion.Far from being the thing that makes us human, human empathy is far from perfect. We round up empathic creatures, we kill them and we eat them. Now, maybe you say OK, well, those are different species. That's just predation, and humans are predators. But we don't treat our own kind too well either. People who seem to know only one thing about animal behavior know that you must never attribute human thoughts and emotions to other species. Well, I think that's silly, because attributing human thoughts and emotions to other species is the best first guess about what they're doing and how they're feeling, because their brains are basically the same as ours. They have the same structures. The same hormones that create mood and motivation in us are in those brains as well. It is not scientific to say that they are hungry when they're hunting and they're tired when their tongues are hanging out, and then say when they're playing with their children and acting joyful and happy, we have no idea if they can possibly be experiencing anything. That is not scientific.So OK, so a reporter said to me, "Maybe, but how do you really know that other animals can think and feel?" And I started to rifle through all the hundreds of scientific references that I put in my book and I realized that the answer was right in the room with me. When my dog gets off the rug and comes over to me — not to the couch, to me — and she rolls over on her back and exposes her belly, she has had the thought, "I would like my belly rubbed. I know that I can go over to Carl, he will understand what I'm asking. I know I can trust him because we're family. He'll get the job done, and it will feel good."(Laughter)She has thought and she has felt, and it's really not more complicated than that.But we see other animals and we say, "Oh look, killer whales, wolves, elephants: that's not how they see it."That tall-finned male is L41. He's 38 years old. The female right on his left side is L22. She's 44. They've known each other for decades. They know exactly who they are. They know who their friends are. They know who their rivals are. Their life follows the arc of a career. They know where they are all the time.This is an elephant named Philo. He was a young male. This is him four days later. Humans not only can feel grief, we create an awful lot of it. We want to carve their teeth. Why can't we wait for them to die? Elephants once ranged from the shores of the Mediterranean Sea all the way down to the Cape of Good Hope. In 1980, there were vast strongholds of elephant range in Central and Eastern Africa. And now their range is shattered into little shards. This is the geography of an animal that we are driving to extinction, a fellow being, the most magnificent creature on land.Of course, we take much better care of our wildlife in the United States. In Yellowstone National Park, we killed every single wolf. We killed every single wolf south of the Canadian border, actually. But in the park, park rangers did that in the 1920s, and then 60 years later they had to bring them back, because the elk numbers had gotten out of control. And then people came. People came by the thousands to see the wolves, the most accessibly visible wolves in the world.And I went there and I watched this incredible family of wolves. A pack is a family. It has some breeding adults and the young of several generations. And I watched the most famous, most stable pack in Yellowstone National Park. And then, when they wandered just outside the border, two of their adults were killed, including the mother, which we sometimes call the alpha female. The rest of the family immediately descended into sibling rivalry. Sisters kicked out other sisters. That one on the left tried for days to rejoin her family. They wouldn't let her because they were jealous of her. She was getting too much attention from two new males, and she was the precocious one. That was too much for them. She wound up wandering outside the park and getting shot. The alpha male wound up being ejected from his own family. As winter was coming in, he lost his territory, his hunting support, the members of his family and his mate.We cause so much pain to them. The mystery is, why don't they hurt us more than they do? This whale had just finished eating part of a grey whale with his companions who had killed that whale. Those people in the boat had nothing at all to fear. This whale is T20. He had just finished tearing a seal into three pieces with two companions. The seal weighed about as much as the people in the boat. They had nothing to fear. They eat seals. Why don't they eat us? Why can we trust them around our toddlers? Why is it that killer whales have returned to researchers lost in thick fog and led them miles until the fog parted and the researchers' home was right there on the shoreline? And that's happened more than one time.In the Bahamas, there's a woman named Denise Herzing, and she studies spotted dolphins and they know her. She knows them very well. She knows who they all are. They know her. They recognize the research boat. When she shows up, it's a big happy reunion. Except, one time showed up and they didn't want to come near the boat, and that was really strange. And they couldn't figure out what was going on until somebody came out on deck and announced that one of the people onboard had died during a nap in his bunk. How could dolphins know that one of the human hearts had just stopped? Why would they care? And why would it spook them? These mysterious things just hint at all of the things that are going on in the minds that are with us on Earth that we almost never think about at all.At an aquarium in South Africa was a little baby bottle-nosed dolphin named Dolly. She was nursing, and one day a keeper took a cigarette break and he was looking into the window into their pool, smoking. Dolly came over and looked at him, went back to her mother, nursed for a minute or two, came back to the window and released a cloud of milk that enveloped her head like smoke. Somehow, this baby bottle-nosed dolphin got the idea of using milk to represent smoke. When human beings use one thing to represent another, we call that art.(Laughter)The things that make us human are not the things that we think make us human. What makes us human is that, of all these things that our minds and their minds have, we are the most extreme. We are the most compassionate, most violent, most creative and most destructive animal that has ever been on this planet, and we are all of those things all jumbled up together. But love is not the thing that makes us human. It's not special to us. We are not the only ones who care about our mates. We are not the only ones who care about our children.Albatrosses frequently fly six, sometimes ten thousand miles over several weeks to deliver one meal, one big meal, to their chick who is waiting for them. They nest on the most remote islands in the oceans of the world, and this is what it looks like. Passing life from one generation to the next is the chain of being. If that stops, it all goes away. If anything is sacred, that is, and into that sacred relationship comes our plastic trash. All of these birds have plastic in them now. This is an albatross six months old, ready to fledge — died, packed with red cigarette lighters.This is not the relationship we are supposed to have with the rest of the world. But we, who have named ourselves after our brains, never think about the consequences. When we welcome new human life into the world, we welcome our babies into the company of other creatures. We paint animals on the walls. We don't paint cell phones. We don't paint work cubicles. We paint animals to show them that we are not alone. We have company. And every one of those animals in every painting of Noah's ark, deemed worthy of salvation is in mortal danger now, and their flood is us.So we started with a question: Do they love us? We're going to ask another question. Are we capable of using what we have to care enough to simply let them continue?Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.957 --> 00:00:16.473
Have you ever wondered
what animals think and feel?

00:00:16.978 --> 00:00:18.862
Let's start with a question:

00:00:19.612 --> 00:00:23.731
Does my dog really love me,
