or does she just want a treat?

00:00:24.949 --> 00:00:29.916
Well, it's easy to see
that our dog really loves us,

00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:32.021
easy to see, right,

00:00:32.045 --> 00:00:35.695
what's going on in that fuzzy little head.

00:00:36.551 --> 00:00:37.926
What is going on?

00:00:39.113 --> 00:00:40.839
Something's going on.

00:00:41.822 --> 00:00:46.221
But why is the question always
do they love us?

00:00:46.245 --> 00:00:48.356
Why is it always about us?

00:00:48.380 --> 00:00:51.023
Why are we such narcissists?

00:00:52.632 --> 00:00:55.671
I found a different question
to ask animals.

00:00:57.869 --> 00:00:59.286
Who are you?

00:01:01.868 --> 00:01:04.763
There are capacities of the human mind

00:01:04.787 --> 00:01:09.649
that we tend to think are capacities
only of the human mind.

00:01:10.134 --> 00:01:11.492
But is that true?

00:01:12.005 --> 00:01:15.980
What are other beings
doing with those brains?

00:01:16.512 --> 00:01:18.865
What are they thinking and feeling?

00:01:19.528 --> 00:01:21.161
Is there a way to know?

00:01:21.185 --> 00:01:22.859
I think there is a way in.

00:01:22.883 --> 00:01:24.573
I think there are several ways in.

00:01:24.908 --> 00:01:29.030
We can look at evolution,
we can look at their brains

00:01:29.054 --> 00:01:31.534
and we can watch what they do.

00:01:33.274 --> 00:01:37.213
The first thing to remember is:
our brain is inherited.

00:01:38.211 --> 00:01:41.918
The first neurons came from jellyfish.

00:01:42.393 --> 00:01:45.233
Jellyfish gave rise
to the first chordates.

00:01:45.257 --> 00:01:48.925
The first chordates gave rise
to the first vertebrates.

00:01:49.235 --> 00:01:51.653
The vertebrates came out of the sea,

00:01:51.677 --> 00:01:53.013
and here we are.

00:01:54.695 --> 00:02:00.285
But it's still true that a neuron,
a nerve cell, looks the same

00:02:00.309 --> 00:02:03.726
in a crayfish, a bird or you.

00:02:04.385 --> 00:02:07.926
What does that say
about the minds of crayfish?

00:02:08.838 --> 00:02:10.395
Can we tell anything about that?

00:02:10.419 --> 00:02:14.448
Well, it turns out that
if you give a crayfish

00:02:14.472 --> 00:02:17.129
a lot of little tiny electric shocks

00:02:17.153 --> 00:02:19.449
every time it tries
to come out of its burrow,

00:02:19.473 --> 00:02:21.658
it will develop anxiety.

00:02:23.091 --> 00:02:26.509
If you give the crayfish the same drug

00:02:26.533 --> 00:02:29.456
used to treat anxiety disorder in humans,

00:02:29.480 --> 00:02:32.561
it relaxes and comes out and explores.

00:02:34.266 --> 00:02:37.353
How do we show how much
we care about crayfish anxiety?

00:02:37.863 --> 00:02:39.217
Mostly, we boil them.

00:02:39.241 --> 00:02:40.557
(Laughter)

00:02:42.448 --> 00:02:47.806
Octopuses use tools,
as well as do most apes

00:02:47.830 --> 00:02:50.173
and they recognize human faces.

00:02:50.766 --> 00:02:55.550
How do we celebrate the ape-like
intelligence of this invertebrate?

00:02:55.957 --> 00:02:57.404
Mostly boiled.

00:02:58.627 --> 00:03:02.933
If a grouper chases a fish
into a crevice in the coral,

00:03:02.957 --> 00:03:07.933
it will sometimes go to where it knows
a moray eel is sleeping

00:03:07.957 --> 00:03:11.530
and it will signal
to the moray, "Follow me,"

00:03:11.554 --> 00:03:14.095
and the moray will understand that signal.

00:03:14.774 --> 00:03:17.751
The moray may go into the crevice
and get the fish,

00:03:17.775 --> 00:03:20.433
but the fish may bolt
and the grouper may get it.

00:03:20.838 --> 00:03:26.869
This is an ancient partnership that we
have just recently found out about.

00:03:26.893 --> 00:03:29.978
How do we celebrate
that ancient partnership?

00:03:30.002 --> 00:03:31.580
Mostly fried.

00:03:32.876 --> 00:03:36.476
A pattern is emerging and it says
a lot more about us

00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:38.660
than it does about them.

00:03:39.568 --> 00:03:41.973
Sea otters use tools

00:03:41.997 --> 00:03:44.974
and they take time away
from what they're doing

00:03:44.998 --> 00:03:49.139
to show their babies what to do,
which is called teaching.

00:03:49.163 --> 00:03:51.841
Chimpanzees don't teach.

00:03:52.957 --> 00:03:56.767
Killer whales teach
and killer whales share food.

00:03:58.837 --> 00:04:00.871
When evolution makes something new,

00:04:00.895 --> 00:04:05.248
it uses the parts it has
in stock, off the shelf,

00:04:05.272 --> 00:04:07.734
before it fabricates a new twist.

00:04:07.758 --> 00:04:09.934
And our brain has come to us

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:14.359
through the enormity
of the deep sweep of time.

00:04:14.383 --> 00:04:17.972
If you look at the human brain
compared to a chimpanzee brain,

00:04:17.996 --> 00:04:21.660
what you see is we have basically
a very big chimpanzee brain.

00:04:21.684 --> 00:04:25.625
It's a good thing ours is bigger,
because we're also really insecure.

00:04:25.649 --> 00:04:27.711
(Laughter)

00:04:27.735 --> 00:04:30.851
But, uh oh, there's a dolphin,

00:04:30.875 --> 00:04:33.851
a bigger brain with more convolutions.

00:04:34.735 --> 00:04:37.442
OK, maybe you're saying,
all right, well, we see brains,

00:04:37.466 --> 00:04:39.893
but what does that
have to say about minds?

00:04:40.305 --> 00:04:44.176
Well, we can see the working of the mind

00:04:44.200 --> 00:04:45.909
in the logic of behaviors.

00:04:46.488 --> 00:04:50.119
So these elephants, you can see,

00:04:50.143 --> 00:04:52.743
obviously, they are resting.

00:04:53.076 --> 00:04:57.440
They have found a patch of shade
under the palm trees

00:04:57.464 --> 00:05:00.264
under which to let their babies sleep,

00:05:00.288 --> 00:05:02.907
while they doze but remain vigilant.

00:05:03.449 --> 00:05:06.301
We make perfect sense of that image

00:05:06.325 --> 00:05:09.956
just as they make perfect sense
of what they're doing

00:05:09.980 --> 00:05:13.782
because under the arc of the same sun
on the same plains,

00:05:13.806 --> 00:05:17.232
listening to the howls
of the same dangers,

00:05:17.256 --> 00:05:21.667
they became who they are
and we became who we are.

00:05:22.494 --> 00:05:24.670
We've been neighbors for a very long time.

00:05:24.694 --> 00:05:28.138
No one would mistake
these elephants as being relaxed.

00:05:28.162 --> 00:05:31.074
They're obviously very
concerned about something.

00:05:31.098 --> 00:05:33.074
What are they concerned about?

00:05:33.638 --> 00:05:37.278
It turns out that if you record
the voices of tourists

00:05:37.302 --> 00:05:41.996
and you play that recording
from a speaker hidden in bushes,

00:05:42.020 --> 00:05:45.655
elephants will ignore it,
because tourists never bother elephants.

00:05:46.060 --> 00:05:50.802
But if you record the voices of herders

00:05:50.826 --> 00:05:55.915
who carry spears and often hurt elephants
in confrontations at water holes,

00:05:55.939 --> 00:06:00.633
the elephants will bunch up
and run away from the hidden speaker.

00:06:00.657 --> 00:06:04.016
Not only do elephants know
that there are humans,

00:06:04.040 --> 00:06:06.576
they know that there are
different kinds of humans,

00:06:06.600 --> 00:06:10.182
and that some are OK
and some are dangerous.

00:06:10.206 --> 00:06:15.273
They have been watching us for much longer
than we have been watching them.

00:06:15.297 --> 00:06:17.587
They know us better than we know them.

00:06:18.230 --> 00:06:21.078
We have the same imperatives:

00:06:21.102 --> 00:06:25.597
take care of our babies,
find food, try to stay alive.

00:06:26.436 --> 00:06:30.265
Whether we're outfitted for hiking
in the hills of Africa

00:06:30.289 --> 00:06:34.472
or outfitted for diving under the sea,
we are basically the same.

00:06:34.496 --> 00:06:36.474
We are kin under the skin.

00:06:36.957 --> 00:06:39.360
The elephant has the same skeleton,

00:06:39.384 --> 00:06:41.726
the killer whale has the same skeleton,

00:06:41.750 --> 00:06:42.986
as do we.

00:06:45.632 --> 00:06:47.894
We see helping where help is needed.

00:06:48.518 --> 00:06:51.146
We see curiosity in the young.

00:06:52.425 --> 00:06:56.028
We see the bonds of family connections.

00:06:57.734 --> 00:06:59.781
We recognize affection.

00:07:00.480 --> 00:07:02.641
Courtship is courtship.

00:07:03.957 --> 00:07:06.640
And then we ask, "Are they conscious?"

00:07:07.258 --> 00:07:10.158
When you get general anesthesia,
it makes you unconscious,

00:07:10.182 --> 00:07:13.017
which means you have
no sensation of anything.

00:07:13.041 --> 00:07:16.612
Consciousness is simply
the thing that feels like something.

00:07:17.250 --> 00:07:21.399
If you see, if you hear, if you feel,
if you're aware of anything,

00:07:21.423 --> 00:07:24.475
you are conscious, and they are conscious.

00:07:27.123 --> 00:07:28.289
Some people say

00:07:28.313 --> 00:07:30.918
well, there are certain things
that make humans humans,

00:07:30.942 --> 00:07:32.864
and one of those things is empathy.

00:07:32.888 --> 00:07:38.575
Empathy is the mind's ability
to match moods with your companions.

00:07:39.400 --> 00:07:40.983
It's a very useful thing.

00:07:41.007 --> 00:07:43.167
If your companions start to move quickly,

00:07:43.191 --> 00:07:45.426
you have to feel like
you need to hurry up.

00:07:45.450 --> 00:07:47.180
We're all in a hurry now.

00:07:47.204 --> 00:07:50.691
The oldest form of empathy
is contagious fear.

00:07:50.715 --> 00:07:53.561
If your companions suddenly
startle and fly away,

00:07:53.585 --> 00:07:55.749
it does not work very well for you to say,

00:07:55.773 --> 00:07:58.676
"Jeez, I wonder why everybody just left."

00:07:58.700 --> 00:08:00.232
(Laughter)

00:08:03.094 --> 00:08:06.933
Empathy is old, but empathy,
like everything else in life,

00:08:06.957 --> 00:08:10.868
comes on a sliding scale
and has its elaboration.

00:08:10.892 --> 00:08:14.613
So there's basic empathy:
you feel sad, it makes me sad.

00:08:14.637 --> 00:08:16.574
I see you happy, it makes me happy.

00:08:17.150 --> 00:08:19.933
Then there's something
that I call sympathy,

00:08:19.957 --> 00:08:21.817
a little more removed:

00:08:22.323 --> 00:08:25.790
"I'm sorry to hear that your grandmother
has just passed away.

00:08:25.814 --> 00:08:29.441
I don't feel that same grief,
but I get it; I know what you feel

00:08:29.465 --> 00:08:30.878
and it concerns me."

00:08:30.902 --> 00:08:33.519
And then if we're motivated
to act on sympathy,

00:08:33.543 --> 00:08:35.349
I call that compassion.

00:08:36.019 --> 00:08:39.569
Far from being the thing
that makes us human,

00:08:39.593 --> 00:08:42.933
human empathy is far from perfect.

00:08:42.957 --> 00:08:47.968
We round up empathic creatures,
we kill them and we eat them.

00:08:47.992 --> 00:08:50.859
Now, maybe you say OK,
well, those are different species.

00:08:50.883 --> 00:08:54.601
That's just predation,
and humans are predators.

00:08:54.625 --> 00:08:59.961
But we don't treat our own kind
too well either.

00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:04.324
People who seem to know
only one thing about animal behavior

00:09:04.348 --> 00:09:08.321
know that you must never attribute
human thoughts and emotions

00:09:08.345 --> 00:09:10.146
to other species.

00:09:10.681 --> 00:09:12.502
Well, I think that's silly,

00:09:12.526 --> 00:09:16.648
because attributing human thoughts
and emotions to other species

00:09:16.672 --> 00:09:20.923
is the best first guess about what
they're doing and how they're feeling,

00:09:20.947 --> 00:09:24.260
because their brains
are basically the same as ours.

00:09:24.284 --> 00:09:26.015
They have the same structures.

00:09:26.039 --> 00:09:31.089
The same hormones that create
mood and motivation in us

00:09:31.113 --> 00:09:33.371
are in those brains as well.

00:09:35.008 --> 00:09:40.078
It is not scientific to say that they
are hungry when they're hunting

00:09:40.102 --> 00:09:43.049
and they're tired when
their tongues are hanging out,

00:09:43.073 --> 00:09:45.763
and then say when they're playing
with their children

00:09:45.787 --> 00:09:47.698
and acting joyful and happy,

00:09:47.722 --> 00:09:52.511
we have no idea if they can possibly
be experiencing anything.

00:09:52.535 --> 00:09:54.529
That is not scientific.

00:09:55.577 --> 00:09:58.262
So OK, so a reporter said to me,

00:09:58.286 --> 00:10:02.594
"Maybe, but how do you really know
that other animals can think and feel?"

00:10:02.618 --> 00:10:05.673
And I started to rifle
through all the hundreds

00:10:05.697 --> 00:10:08.196
of scientific references
that I put in my book

00:10:08.220 --> 00:10:11.460
and I realized that the answer
was right in the room with me.

00:10:11.484 --> 00:10:15.237
When my dog gets off the rug
and comes over to me --

00:10:15.261 --> 00:10:17.023
not to the couch, to me --

00:10:17.047 --> 00:10:21.224
and she rolls over on her back
and exposes her belly,

00:10:21.248 --> 00:10:24.116
she has had the thought,
"I would like my belly rubbed.

00:10:26.523 --> 00:10:29.059
I know that I can go over to Carl,

00:10:29.083 --> 00:10:31.396
he will understand what I'm asking.

00:10:32.042 --> 00:10:34.538
I know I can trust him
because we're family.

00:10:35.364 --> 00:10:38.079
He'll get the job done,
and it will feel good."

00:10:38.103 --> 00:10:39.989
(Laughter)

00:10:40.013 --> 00:10:43.342
She has thought and she has felt,

00:10:43.366 --> 00:10:46.030
and it's really not
more complicated than that.

00:10:46.054 --> 00:10:50.667
But we see other animals
and we say, "Oh look, killer whales,

00:10:50.691 --> 00:10:53.101
wolves, elephants:

00:10:53.125 --> 00:10:54.736
that's not how they see it."

00:10:55.672 --> 00:10:59.966
That tall-finned male is L41.

00:10:59.990 --> 00:11:02.037
He's 38 years old.

00:11:02.061 --> 00:11:05.533
The female right on his left side is L22.

00:11:05.857 --> 00:11:07.409
She's 44.

00:11:07.433 --> 00:11:10.068
They've known each other for decades.

00:11:10.608 --> 00:11:12.580
They know exactly who they are.

00:11:12.604 --> 00:11:14.155
They know who their friends are.

00:11:14.179 --> 00:11:15.877
They know who their rivals are.

00:11:15.901 --> 00:11:18.014
Their life follows the arc of a career.

00:11:18.760 --> 00:11:20.994
They know where they are all the time.

00:11:22.821 --> 00:11:25.196
This is an elephant named Philo.

00:11:25.625 --> 00:11:27.453
He was a young male.

00:11:27.477 --> 00:11:29.295
This is him four days later.

00:11:30.957 --> 00:11:36.287
Humans not only can feel grief,
we create an awful lot of it.

00:11:38.606 --> 00:11:40.920
We want to carve their teeth.

00:11:42.111 --> 00:11:45.415
Why can't we wait for them to die?

00:11:47.956 --> 00:11:51.424
Elephants once ranged from the shores
of the Mediterranean Sea

00:11:51.448 --> 00:11:53.523
all the way down to the Cape of Good Hope.

00:11:53.547 --> 00:11:56.933
In 1980, there were vast
strongholds of elephant range

00:11:56.957 --> 00:11:59.145
in Central and Eastern Africa.

00:11:59.169 --> 00:12:03.506
And now their range is shattered
into little shards.

00:12:03.530 --> 00:12:08.209
This is the geography of an animal
that we are driving to extinction,

00:12:08.233 --> 00:12:12.082
a fellow being, the most
magnificent creature on land.

00:12:13.246 --> 00:12:17.274
Of course, we take much better care
of our wildlife in the United States.

00:12:17.639 --> 00:12:21.874
In Yellowstone National Park,
we killed every single wolf.

00:12:21.898 --> 00:12:25.347
We killed every single wolf
south of the Canadian border, actually.

00:12:25.371 --> 00:12:29.764
But in the park, park rangers
did that in the 1920s,

00:12:29.788 --> 00:12:32.379
and then 60 years later
they had to bring them back,

00:12:32.403 --> 00:12:35.310
because the elk numbers
had gotten out of control.

00:12:36.469 --> 00:12:37.743
And then people came.

00:12:37.767 --> 00:12:41.491
People came by the thousands
to see the wolves,

00:12:41.515 --> 00:12:45.010
the most accessibly
visible wolves in the world.

00:12:45.470 --> 00:12:48.722
And I went there and I watched
this incredible family of wolves.

00:12:48.746 --> 00:12:50.199
A pack is a family.

00:12:50.223 --> 00:12:53.798
It has some breeding adults
and the young of several generations.

00:12:55.116 --> 00:12:59.732
And I watched the most famous, most stable
pack in Yellowstone National Park.

00:13:00.328 --> 00:13:03.458
And then, when they wandered
just outside the border,

00:13:03.482 --> 00:13:06.163
two of their adults were killed,

00:13:06.187 --> 00:13:08.440
including the mother,

00:13:08.464 --> 00:13:10.642
which we sometimes call the alpha female.

00:13:11.460 --> 00:13:15.703
The rest of the family immediately
descended into sibling rivalry.

00:13:16.829 --> 00:13:19.070
Sisters kicked out other sisters.

00:13:19.523 --> 00:13:23.004
That one on the left tried for days
to rejoin her family.

00:13:23.028 --> 00:13:25.720
They wouldn't let her
because they were jealous of her.

00:13:25.744 --> 00:13:28.557
She was getting too much attention
from two new males,

00:13:28.581 --> 00:13:30.599
and she was the precocious one.

00:13:30.623 --> 00:13:32.276
That was too much for them.

00:13:32.300 --> 00:13:35.025
She wound up wandering
outside the park and getting shot.

00:13:36.421 --> 00:13:39.830
The alpha male wound up
being ejected from his own family.

00:13:40.394 --> 00:13:42.397
As winter was coming in,

00:13:42.421 --> 00:13:46.171
he lost his territory,
his hunting support,

00:13:46.195 --> 00:13:48.666
the members of his family and his mate.

00:13:50.841 --> 00:13:54.465
We cause so much pain to them.

00:13:55.623 --> 00:14:00.583
The mystery is, why don't
they hurt us more than they do?

00:14:01.813 --> 00:14:05.011
This whale had just finished eating
part of a grey whale

00:14:05.035 --> 00:14:07.614
with his companions
who had killed that whale.

00:14:07.638 --> 00:14:10.722
Those people in the boat
had nothing at all to fear.

00:14:11.957 --> 00:14:13.946
This whale is T20.

00:14:14.446 --> 00:14:18.697
He had just finished tearing a seal
into three pieces with two companions.

00:14:19.126 --> 00:14:21.818
The seal weighed about as much
as the people in the boat.

00:14:21.842 --> 00:14:23.345
They had nothing to fear.

00:14:24.147 --> 00:14:25.569
They eat seals.

00:14:26.657 --> 00:14:28.343
Why don't they eat us?

00:14:30.781 --> 00:14:34.541
Why can we trust them around our toddlers?

00:14:36.446 --> 00:14:42.348
Why is it that killer whales have returned
to researchers lost in thick fog

00:14:42.372 --> 00:14:45.702
and led them miles until the fog parted

00:14:45.726 --> 00:14:48.891
and the researchers' home
was right there on the shoreline?

00:14:48.915 --> 00:14:50.931
And that's happened more than one time.

00:14:53.129 --> 00:14:55.704
In the Bahamas, there's a woman
named Denise Herzing,

00:14:55.728 --> 00:14:59.052
and she studies spotted dolphins
and they know her.

00:14:59.076 --> 00:15:01.674
She knows them very well.
She knows who they all are.

00:15:01.698 --> 00:15:03.960
They know her.
They recognize the research boat.

00:15:03.984 --> 00:15:06.214
When she shows up,
it's a big happy reunion.

00:15:06.238 --> 00:15:09.553
Except, one time showed up and they
didn't want to come near the boat,

00:15:09.577 --> 00:15:11.651
and that was really strange.

00:15:11.675 --> 00:15:13.839
And they couldn't figure out
what was going on

00:15:13.863 --> 00:15:15.363
until somebody came out on deck

00:15:15.387 --> 00:15:18.022
and announced that one
of the people onboard had died

00:15:18.046 --> 00:15:19.817
during a nap in his bunk.

00:15:20.698 --> 00:15:24.624
How could dolphins know
that one of the human hearts

00:15:24.648 --> 00:15:26.117
had just stopped?

00:15:26.776 --> 00:15:29.066
Why would they care?

00:15:29.090 --> 00:15:31.283
And why would it spook them?

00:15:33.069 --> 00:15:38.368
These mysterious things just hint at
all of the things that are going on

00:15:38.392 --> 00:15:41.134
in the minds that are with us on Earth

00:15:41.158 --> 00:15:45.389
that we almost never think about at all.

00:15:46.216 --> 00:15:48.388
At an aquarium in South Africa

00:15:48.412 --> 00:15:51.636
was a little baby bottle-nosed
dolphin named Dolly.

00:15:52.136 --> 00:15:58.280
She was nursing, and one day
a keeper took a cigarette break

00:15:58.304 --> 00:16:02.411
and he was looking into the window
into their pool, smoking.

00:16:02.435 --> 00:16:04.809
Dolly came over and looked at him,

00:16:04.833 --> 00:16:08.711
went back to her mother,
nursed for a minute or two,

00:16:08.735 --> 00:16:10.538
came back to the window

00:16:10.562 --> 00:16:16.227
and released a cloud of milk
that enveloped her head like smoke.

00:16:16.251 --> 00:16:19.357
Somehow, this baby bottle-nosed dolphin

00:16:19.381 --> 00:16:23.670
got the idea of using milk
to represent smoke.

00:16:24.169 --> 00:16:27.517
When human beings use one thing
to represent another,

00:16:27.541 --> 00:16:29.566
we call that art.

00:16:29.590 --> 00:16:31.613
(Laughter)

00:16:31.637 --> 00:16:33.168
The things that make us human

00:16:33.192 --> 00:16:36.272
are not the things
that we think make us human.

00:16:36.739 --> 00:16:39.063
What makes us human is that,

00:16:39.087 --> 00:16:42.223
of all these things that our minds
and their minds have,

00:16:42.247 --> 00:16:44.487
we are the most extreme.

00:16:46.305 --> 00:16:48.594
We are the most compassionate,

00:16:48.618 --> 00:16:51.635
most violent, most creative

00:16:51.659 --> 00:16:56.319
and most destructive animal
that has ever been on this planet,

00:16:56.343 --> 00:17:00.067
and we are all of those things
all jumbled up together.

00:17:01.299 --> 00:17:05.537
But love is not the thing
that makes us human.

00:17:06.200 --> 00:17:08.552
It's not special to us.

00:17:09.632 --> 00:17:13.603
We are not the only ones
who care about our mates.

00:17:13.627 --> 00:17:16.965
We are not the only ones
who care about our children.

00:17:18.862 --> 00:17:23.832
Albatrosses frequently fly six,
sometimes ten thousand miles

00:17:23.856 --> 00:17:28.343
over several weeks to deliver
one meal, one big meal,

00:17:28.367 --> 00:17:30.343
to their chick who is waiting for them.

00:17:30.793 --> 00:17:35.191
They nest on the most remote islands
in the oceans of the world,

00:17:35.215 --> 00:17:37.588
and this is what it looks like.

00:17:39.328 --> 00:17:43.508
Passing life from one generation
to the next is the chain of being.

00:17:43.532 --> 00:17:46.508
If that stops, it all goes away.

00:17:46.933 --> 00:17:51.583
If anything is sacred, that is,
and into that sacred relationship

00:17:51.607 --> 00:17:54.438
comes our plastic trash.

00:17:54.462 --> 00:17:57.149
All of these birds
have plastic in them now.

00:17:57.948 --> 00:18:02.599
This is an albatross six months old,
ready to fledge --

00:18:02.623 --> 00:18:06.624
died, packed with red cigarette lighters.

00:18:06.648 --> 00:18:09.933
This is not the relationship
we are supposed to have

00:18:09.957 --> 00:18:11.543
with the rest of the world.

00:18:11.567 --> 00:18:14.891
But we, who have named
ourselves after our brains,

00:18:16.153 --> 00:18:19.539
never think about the consequences.

00:18:20.999 --> 00:18:24.119
When we welcome new
human life into the world,

00:18:24.143 --> 00:18:28.646
we welcome our babies
into the company of other creatures.

00:18:28.670 --> 00:18:30.763
We paint animals on the walls.

00:18:30.787 --> 00:18:32.615
We don't paint cell phones.

00:18:32.639 --> 00:18:34.782
We don't paint work cubicles.

00:18:34.806 --> 00:18:38.707
We paint animals to show them
that we are not alone.

00:18:39.274 --> 00:18:41.017
We have company.

00:18:42.485 --> 00:18:47.225
And every one of those animals
in every painting of Noah's ark,

00:18:47.249 --> 00:18:51.589
deemed worthy of salvation
is in mortal danger now,

00:18:51.613 --> 00:18:53.866
and their flood is us.

00:18:55.662 --> 00:18:57.961
So we started with a question:

00:18:57.985 --> 00:18:59.849
Do they love us?

00:19:01.957 --> 00:19:04.005
We're going to ask another question.

00:19:04.957 --> 00:19:08.567
Are we capable of using what we have

00:19:09.876 --> 00:19:14.049
to care enough to simply
let them continue?

00:19:16.683 --> 00:19:18.024
Thank you very much.

00:19:18.048 --> 00:19:23.688
(Applause)

title: Why are these 32 symbols found in ancient caves all over Europe?
transcript: There's something about caves — a shadowy opening in a limestone cliff that draws you in. As you pass through the portal between light and dark, you enter a subterranean world — a place of perpetual gloom, of earthy smells, of hushed silence.Long ago in Europe, ancient people also entered these underground worlds. As witness to their passage, they left behind mysterious engravings and paintings, like this panel of humans, triangles and zigzags from Ojo Guareña in Spain. You now walk the same path as these early artists. And in this surreal, otherworldly place, it's almost possible to imagine that you hear the muffled footfall of skin boots on soft earth, or that you see the flickering of a torch around the next bend.When I'm in a cave, I often find myself wondering what drove these people to go so deep to brave dangerous and narrow passageways to leave their mark? In this video clip, that was shot half a kilometer, or about a third of a mile, underground, in the cave of Cudon in Spain, we found a series of red paintings on a ceiling in a previously unexplored section of the cave. As we crawled forward, military-style, with the ceiling getting ever lower, we finally got to a point where the ceiling was so low that my husband and project photographer, Dylan, could no longer achieve focus on the ceiling with his DSLR camera. So while he filmed me, I kept following the trail of red paint with a single light and a point-and-shoot camera that we kept for that type of occasion. Half a kilometer underground.Seriously. What was somebody doing down there with a torch or a stone lamp?(Laughter)I mean — me, it makes sense, right?But you know, this is the kind of question that I'm trying to answer with my research. I study some of the oldest art in the world. It was created by these early artists in Europe, between 10,000 and 40,000 years ago. And the thing is that I'm not just studying it because it's beautiful, though some of it certainly is. But what I'm interested in is the development of the modern mind, of the evolution of creativity, of imagination, of abstract thought, about what it means to be human. While all species communicate in one way or another, only we humans have really taken it to another level. Our desire and ability to share and collaborate has been a huge part of our success story. Our modern world is based on a global network of information exchange made possible, in large part, by our ability to communicate — in particular, using graphic or written forms of communication. The thing is, though, that we've been building on the mental achievements of those that came before us for so long that it's easy to forget that certain abilities haven't already existed. It's one of the things I find most fascinating about studying our deep history. Those people didn't have the shoulders of any giants to stand on. They were the original shoulders. And while a surprising number of important inventions come out of that distant time, what I want to talk to you about today is the invention of graphic communication.There are three main types of communication, spoken, gestural — so things like sign language — and graphic communication. Spoken and gestural are by their very nature ephemeral. It requires close contact for a message to be sent and received. And after the moment of transmission, it's gone forever. Graphic communication, on the other hand, decouples that relationship. And with its invention, it became possible for the first time for a message to be transmitted and preserved beyond a single moment in place and time.Europe is one of the first places that we start to see graphic marks regularly appearing in caves, rock shelters and even a few surviving open-air sites. But this is not the Europe we know today. This was a world dominated by towering ice sheets, three to four kilometers high, with sweeping grass plains and frozen tundra. This was the Ice Age.Over the last century, more than 350 Ice Age rock art sites have been found across the continent, decorated with animals, abstract shapes and even the occasional human like these engraved figures from Grotta dell'Addaura in Sicily. They provide us with a rare glimpse into the creative world and imagination of these early artists.Since their discovery, it's been the animals that have received the majority of the study like this black horse from Cullalvera in Spain, or this unusual purple bison from La Pasiega. But for me, it was the abstract shapes, what we call geometric signs, that drew me to study the art. The funny this is that at most sites the geometric signs far outnumber the animal and human images. But when I started on this back in 2007, there wasn't even a definitive list of how many shapes there were, nor was there a strong sense of whether the same ones appeared across space or time. Before I could even get started on my questions, my first step was to compile a database of all known geometric signs from all of the rock art sites. The problem was that while they were well documented at some sites, usually the ones with the very nice animals, there was also a large number of them where it was very vague — there wasn't a lot of description or detail. Some of them hadn't been visited in half a century or more. These were the ones that I targeted for my field work.Over the course of two years, my faithful husband Dylan and I each spent over 300 hours underground, hiking, crawling and wriggling around 52 sites in France, Spain, Portugal and Sicily. And it was totally worth it. We found new, undocumented geometric signs at 75 percent of the sites we visited. This is the level of accuracy I knew I was going to need if I wanted to start answering those larger questions.So let's get to those answers. Barring a handful of outliers, there are only 32 geometric signs. Only 32 signs across a 30,000-year time span and the entire continent of Europe. That is a very small number. Now, if these were random doodles or decorations, we would expect to see a lot more variation, but instead what we find are the same signs repeating across both space and time. Some signs start out strong, before losing popularity and vanishing, while other signs are later inventions. But 65 percent of those signs stayed in use during that entire time period — things like lines, rectangles triangles, ovals and circles like we see here from the end of the Ice Age, at a 10,000-year-old site high in the Pyrenees Mountains. And while certain signs span thousands of kilometers, other signs had much more restricted distribution patterns, with some being limited to a single territory, like we see here with these divided rectangles that are only found in northern Spain, and which some researchers have speculated could be some sort of family or clan signs.On a side note, there is surprising degree of similarity in the earliest rock art found all the way from France and Spain to Indonesia and Australia. With many of the same signs appearing in such far-flung places, especially in that 30,000 to 40,000-year range, it's starting to seem increasingly likely that this invention actually traces back to a common point of origin in Africa. But that I'm afraid, is a subject for a future talk.So back to the matter at hand. There could be no doubt that these signs were meaningful to their creators, like these 25,000-year-old bas-relief sculptures from La Roque de Venasque in France. We might not know what they meant, but the people of the time certainly did. The repetition of the same signs, for so long, and at so many sites tells us that the artists were making intentional choices. If we're talking about geometric shapes, with specific, culturally recognized, agreed-upon meanings, than we could very well be looking at one of the oldest systems of graphic communication in the world.I'm not talking about writing yet. There's just not enough characters at this point to have represented all of the words in the spoken language, something which is a requirement for a full writing system. Nor do we see the signs repeating regularly enough to suggest that they were some sort of alphabet. But what we do have are some intriguing one-offs, like this panel from La Pasiega in Spain, known as "The Inscription," with its symmetrical markings on the left, possible stylized representations of hands in the middle, and what looks a bit like a bracket on the right.The oldest systems of graphic communication in the world — Sumerian cuneiform, Egyptian hieroglyphs, the earliest Chinese script, all emerged between 4,000 and 5,000 years ago, with each coming into existence from an earlier protosystem made up of counting marks and pictographic representations, where the meaning and the image were the same. So a picture of a bird would really have represented that animal. It's only later that we start to see these pictographs become more stylized, until they almost become unrecognizable and that we also start to see more symbols being invented to represent all those other missing words in language — things like pronouns, adverbs, adjectives.So knowing all this, it seems highly unlikely that the geometric signs from Ice Age Europe were truly abstract written characters. Instead, what's much more likely is that these early artists were also making counting marks, maybe like this row of lines from Riparo di Za Minic in Sicily, as well as creating stylized representations of things from the world around them. Could some of the signs be weaponry or housing? Or what about celestial objects like star constellations? Or maybe even rivers, mountains, trees — landscape features, possibly like this black penniform surrounded by strange bell-shaped signs from the site of El Castillo in Spain. The term penniform means "feather-shaped" in Latin, but could this actually be a depiction of a plant or a tree? Some researchers have begun to ask these questions about certain signs at specific sites, but I believe the time has come to revisit this category as a whole. The irony in all of this, of course, is that having just carefully classified all of the signs into a single category, I have a feeling that my next step will involve breaking it back apart as different types of imagery are identified and separated off.Now don't get me wrong, the later creation of fully developed writing was an impressive feat in its own right. But it's important to remember that those early writing systems didn't come out of a vacuum. And that even 5,000 years ago, people were already building on something much older, with its origins stretching back tens of thousands of years — to the geometric signs of Ice Age Europe and far beyond, to that point, deep in our collective history, when someone first came up with the idea of making a graphic mark, and forever changed the nature of how we communicate.Thank you.(Applause)

00:04:33.758 --> 00:04:37.014
with sweeping grass plains
and frozen tundra.

00:04:37.038 --> 00:04:39.078
This was the Ice Age.

00:04:40.038 --> 00:04:41.334
Over the last century,

00:04:41.358 --> 00:04:46.654
more than 350 Ice Age rock art sites
have been found across the continent,

00:04:46.678 --> 00:04:51.054
decorated with animals, abstract shapes
and even the occasional human

00:04:51.078 --> 00:04:54.694
like these engraved figures
from Grotta dell'Addaura in Sicily.

00:04:54.718 --> 00:04:56.774
They provide us with a rare glimpse

00:04:56.798 --> 00:05:00.878
into the creative world and imagination
of these early artists.

00:05:01.798 --> 00:05:03.174
Since their discovery,

00:05:03.198 --> 00:05:06.598
it's been the animals that have received
the majority of the study

00:05:07.158 --> 00:05:09.718
like this black horse
from Cullalvera in Spain,

00:05:10.358 --> 00:05:13.638
or this unusual purple bison
from La Pasiega.

00:05:14.838 --> 00:05:20.214
But for me, it was the abstract shapes,
what we call geometric signs,

00:05:20.238 --> 00:05:21.838
that drew me to study the art.

00:05:23.198 --> 00:05:25.494
The funny this is that at most sites

00:05:25.518 --> 00:05:30.014
the geometric signs far outnumber
the animal and human images.

00:05:30.038 --> 00:05:33.214
But when I started on this back in 2007,

00:05:33.238 --> 00:05:37.214
there wasn't even a definitive list
of how many shapes there were,

00:05:37.238 --> 00:05:38.574
nor was there a strong sense

00:05:38.598 --> 00:05:41.478
of whether the same ones
appeared across space or time.

00:05:44.078 --> 00:05:47.174
Before I could even
get started on my questions,

00:05:47.198 --> 00:05:49.294
my first step was to compile a database

00:05:49.318 --> 00:05:53.214
of all known geometric signs
from all of the rock art sites.

00:05:53.238 --> 00:05:56.814
The problem was that while they were
well documented at some sites,

00:05:56.838 --> 00:05:59.134
usually the ones
with the very nice animals,

00:05:59.158 --> 00:06:02.814
there was also a large number of them
where it was very vague --

00:06:02.838 --> 00:06:05.094
there wasn't a lot
of description or detail.

00:06:05.118 --> 00:06:08.454
Some of them hadn't been visited
in half a century or more.

00:06:08.478 --> 00:06:11.894
These were the ones
that I targeted for my field work.

00:06:11.918 --> 00:06:13.774
Over the course of two years,

00:06:13.798 --> 00:06:19.014
my faithful husband Dylan and I
each spent over 300 hours underground,

00:06:19.038 --> 00:06:23.014
hiking, crawling and wriggling
around 52 sites

00:06:23.038 --> 00:06:25.974
in France, Spain, Portugal and Sicily.

00:06:25.998 --> 00:06:27.854
And it was totally worth it.

00:06:27.878 --> 00:06:34.614
We found new, undocumented geometric signs
at 75 percent of the sites we visited.

00:06:34.638 --> 00:06:37.454
This is the level of accuracy
I knew I was going to need

00:06:37.478 --> 00:06:40.654
if I wanted to start answering
those larger questions.

00:06:40.678 --> 00:06:43.254
So let's get to those answers.

00:06:43.278 --> 00:06:47.894
Barring a handful of outliers,
there are only 32 geometric signs.

00:06:47.918 --> 00:06:49.734
Only 32 signs

00:06:49.758 --> 00:06:55.238
across a 30,000-year time span
and the entire continent of Europe.

00:06:55.678 --> 00:06:58.254
That is a very small number.

00:06:58.278 --> 00:07:00.734
Now, if these were random
doodles or decorations,

00:07:00.758 --> 00:07:03.174
we would expect to see
a lot more variation,

00:07:03.198 --> 00:07:05.614
but instead what we find
are the same signs

00:07:05.638 --> 00:07:08.078
repeating across both space and time.

00:07:08.878 --> 00:07:12.774
Some signs start out strong,
before losing popularity and vanishing,

00:07:12.798 --> 00:07:15.134
while other signs are later inventions.

00:07:15.158 --> 00:07:20.774
But 65 percent of those signs stayed
in use during that entire time period --

00:07:20.798 --> 00:07:25.094
things like lines, rectangles
triangles, ovals and circles

00:07:25.118 --> 00:07:27.261
like we see here
from the end of the Ice Age,

00:07:27.285 --> 00:07:31.214
at a 10,000-year-old site
high in the Pyrenees Mountains.

00:07:31.238 --> 00:07:34.454
And while certain signs
span thousands of kilometers,

00:07:34.478 --> 00:07:37.454
other signs had much more
restricted distribution patterns,

00:07:37.478 --> 00:07:39.894
with some being limited
to a single territory,

00:07:39.918 --> 00:07:42.094
like we see here
with these divided rectangles

00:07:42.118 --> 00:07:44.334
that are only found in northern Spain,

00:07:44.358 --> 00:07:46.414
and which some researchers have speculated

00:07:46.438 --> 00:07:48.758
could be some sort
of family or clan signs.

00:07:49.838 --> 00:07:51.214
On a side note,

00:07:51.238 --> 00:07:54.654
there is surprising degree
of similarity in the earliest rock art

00:07:54.678 --> 00:07:59.254
found all the way from France and Spain
to Indonesia and Australia.

00:07:59.278 --> 00:08:03.574
With many of the same signs
appearing in such far-flung places,

00:08:03.598 --> 00:08:06.574
especially in that 30,000
to 40,000-year range,

00:08:06.598 --> 00:08:09.454
it's starting to seem increasingly likely

00:08:09.478 --> 00:08:14.334
that this invention actually traces back
to a common point of origin in Africa.

00:08:14.358 --> 00:08:16.974
But that I'm afraid,
is a subject for a future talk.

00:08:16.998 --> 00:08:18.814
So back to the matter at hand.

00:08:18.838 --> 00:08:22.814
There could be no doubt that these signs
were meaningful to their creators,

00:08:22.838 --> 00:08:25.654
like these 25,000-year-old
bas-relief sculptures

00:08:25.678 --> 00:08:28.294
from La Roque de Venasque in France.

00:08:28.318 --> 00:08:32.718
We might not know what they meant,
but the people of the time certainly did.

00:08:33.718 --> 00:08:39.774
The repetition of the same signs,
for so long, and at so many sites

00:08:39.798 --> 00:08:43.278
tells us that the artists
were making intentional choices.

00:08:43.758 --> 00:08:46.134
If we're talking about geometric shapes,

00:08:46.158 --> 00:08:50.894
with specific, culturally recognized,
agreed-upon meanings,

00:08:50.918 --> 00:08:52.574
than we could very well be looking

00:08:52.598 --> 00:08:57.134
at one of the oldest systems
of graphic communication in the world.

00:08:57.158 --> 00:08:59.054
I'm not talking about writing yet.

00:08:59.078 --> 00:09:01.414
There's just not enough
characters at this point

00:09:01.438 --> 00:09:04.294
to have represented all of the words
in the spoken language,

00:09:04.318 --> 00:09:07.134
something which is a requirement
for a full writing system.

00:09:07.158 --> 00:09:09.534
Nor do we see the signs
repeating regularly enough

00:09:09.558 --> 00:09:12.214
to suggest that they were
some sort of alphabet.

00:09:12.238 --> 00:09:15.054
But what we do have
are some intriguing one-offs,

00:09:15.078 --> 00:09:19.654
like this panel from La Pasiega in Spain,
known as "The Inscription,"

00:09:19.678 --> 00:09:22.214
with its symmetrical markings on the left,

00:09:22.238 --> 00:09:25.454
possible stylized representations
of hands in the middle,

00:09:25.478 --> 00:09:27.798
and what looks a bit
like a bracket on the right.

00:09:29.038 --> 00:09:31.894
The oldest systems of graphic
communication in the world --

00:09:31.918 --> 00:09:36.854
Sumerian cuneiform, Egyptian hieroglyphs,
the earliest Chinese script,

00:09:36.878 --> 00:09:40.454
all emerged between 4,000
and 5,000 years ago,

00:09:40.478 --> 00:09:43.614
with each coming into existence
from an earlier protosystem

00:09:43.638 --> 00:09:47.174
made up of counting marks
and pictographic representations,

00:09:47.198 --> 00:09:49.574
where the meaning
and the image were the same.

00:09:49.598 --> 00:09:53.814
So a picture of a bird would really
have represented that animal.

00:09:53.838 --> 00:09:58.574
It's only later that we start to see
these pictographs become more stylized,

00:09:58.598 --> 00:10:00.934
until they almost become unrecognizable

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.974
and that we also start to see
more symbols being invented

00:10:03.998 --> 00:10:06.894
to represent all those other
missing words in language --

00:10:06.918 --> 00:10:09.038
things like pronouns, adverbs, adjectives.

00:10:10.118 --> 00:10:11.654
So knowing all this,

00:10:11.678 --> 00:10:15.534
it seems highly unlikely that
the geometric signs from Ice Age Europe

00:10:15.558 --> 00:10:18.254
were truly abstract written characters.

00:10:18.278 --> 00:10:20.494
Instead, what's much more likely

00:10:20.518 --> 00:10:24.494
is that these early artists
were also making counting marks,

00:10:24.518 --> 00:10:28.534
maybe like this row of lines
from Riparo di Za Minic in Sicily,

00:10:28.558 --> 00:10:31.174
as well as creating
stylized representations

00:10:31.198 --> 00:10:33.694
of things from the world around them.

00:10:33.718 --> 00:10:36.334
Could some of the signs
be weaponry or housing?

00:10:36.358 --> 00:10:40.494
Or what about celestial objects
like star constellations?

00:10:40.518 --> 00:10:45.134
Or maybe even rivers, mountains,
trees -- landscape features,

00:10:45.158 --> 00:10:49.534
possibly like this black penniform
surrounded by strange bell-shaped signs

00:10:49.558 --> 00:10:52.134
from the site of El Castillo in Spain.

00:10:52.158 --> 00:10:55.454
The term penniform
means "feather-shaped" in Latin,

00:10:55.478 --> 00:10:59.318
but could this actually be
a depiction of a plant or a tree?

00:10:59.678 --> 00:11:02.654
Some researchers have begun
to ask these questions

00:11:02.678 --> 00:11:05.574
about certain signs at specific sites,

00:11:05.598 --> 00:11:10.494
but I believe the time has come
to revisit this category as a whole.

00:11:10.518 --> 00:11:12.254
The irony in all of this, of course,

00:11:12.278 --> 00:11:16.574
is that having just carefully classified
all of the signs into a single category,

00:11:16.598 --> 00:11:20.094
I have a feeling that my next step
will involve breaking it back apart

00:11:20.118 --> 00:11:24.374
as different types of imagery
are identified and separated off.

00:11:24.398 --> 00:11:25.614
Now don't get me wrong,

00:11:25.638 --> 00:11:28.254
the later creation
of fully developed writing

00:11:28.278 --> 00:11:30.894
was an impressive feat in its own right.

00:11:30.918 --> 00:11:32.374
But it's important to remember

00:11:32.398 --> 00:11:35.694
that those early writing systems
didn't come out of a vacuum.

00:11:35.718 --> 00:11:37.694
And that even 5,000 years ago,

00:11:37.718 --> 00:11:41.054
people were already building
on something much older,

00:11:41.078 --> 00:11:44.814
with its origins stretching back
tens of thousands of years --

00:11:44.838 --> 00:11:48.934
to the geometric signs
of Ice Age Europe and far beyond,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.254
to that point, deep
in our collective history,

00:11:52.278 --> 00:11:56.334
when someone first came up with the idea
of making a graphic mark,

00:11:56.358 --> 00:11:59.294
and forever changed the nature
of how we communicate.

00:11:59.318 --> 00:12:00.534
Thank you.

00:12:00.558 --> 00:12:03.998
(Applause)

title: My year reading a book from every country in the world
transcript: It's often said that you can tell a lot about a person by looking at what's on their bookshelves. What do my bookshelves say about me? Well, when I asked myself this question a few years ago, I made an alarming discovery. I'd always thought of myself as a fairly cultured, cosmopolitan sort of person. But my bookshelves told a rather different story. Pretty much all the titles on them were by British or North American authors, and there was almost nothing in translation. Discovering this massive, cultural blind spot in my reading came as quite a shock.And when I thought about it, it seemed like a real shame. I knew there had to be lots of amazing stories out there by writers working in languages other than English. And it seemed really sad to think that my reading habits meant I would probably never encounter them. So, I decided to prescribe myself an intensive course of global reading. 2012 was set to be a very international year for the UK; it was the year of the London Olympics. And so I decided to use it as my time frame to try to read a novel, short story collection or memoir from every country in the world. And so I did. And it was very exciting and I learned some remarkable things and made some wonderful connections that I want to share with you today.But it started with some practical problems. After I'd worked out which of the many different lists of countries in the world to use for my project, I ended up going with the list of UN-recognized nations, to which I added Taiwan, which gave me a total of 196 countries. And after I'd worked out how to fit reading and blogging about, roughly, four books a week around working five days a week,I then had to face up to the fact that I might even not be able to get books in English from every country. Only around 4.5 percent of the literary works published each year in the UK are translations, and the figures are similar for much of the English-speaking world. Although, the proportion of translated books published in many other countries is a lot higher. 4.5 percent is tiny enough to start with, but what that figure doesn't tell you is that many of those books will come from countries with strong publishing networks and lots of industry professionals primed to go out and sell those titles to English-language publishers. So, for example, although well over 100 books are translated from French and published in the UK each year, most of them will come from countries like France or Switzerland. French-speaking Africa, on the other hand, will rarely ever get a look-in.The upshot is that there are actually quite a lot of nations that may have little or even no commercially available literature in English. Their books remain invisible to readers of the world's most published language. But when it came to reading the world, the biggest challenge of all for me was that fact that I didn't know where to start. Having spent my life reading almost exclusively British and North American books, I had no idea how to go about sourcing and finding stories and choosing them from much of the rest of the world. I couldn't tell you how to source a story from Swaziland. I wouldn't know a good novel from Namibia. There was no hiding it — I was a clueless literary xenophobe. So how on earth was I going to read the world?I was going to have to ask for help. So in October 2011, I registered my blog, ayearofreadingtheworld.com, and I posted a short appeal online. I explained who I was, how narrow my reading had been, and I asked anyone who cared to to leave a message suggesting what I might read from other parts of the planet. Now, I had no idea whether anyone would be interested, but within a few hours of me posting that appeal online, people started to get in touch. At first, it was friends and colleagues. Then it was friends of friends. And pretty soon, it was strangers.Four days after I put that appeal online, I got a message from a woman called Rafidah in Kuala Lumpur. She said she loved the sound of my project, could she go to her local English-language bookshop and choose my Malaysian book and post it to me? I accepted enthusiastically, and a few weeks later, a package arrived containing not one, but two books — Rafidah's choice from Malaysia, and a book from Singapore that she had also picked out for me. Now, at the time, I was amazed that a stranger more than 6,000 miles away would go to such lengths to help someone she would probably never meet.But Rafidah's kindness proved to be the pattern for that year. Time and again, people went out of their way to help me. Some took on research on my behalf, and others made detours on holidays and business trips to go to bookshops for me. It turns out, if you want to read the world, if you want to encounter it with an open mind, the world will help you. When it came to countries with little or no commercially available literature in English, people went further still.Books often came from surprising sources. My Panamanian read, for example, came through a conversation I had with the Panama Canal on Twitter. Yes, the Panama Canal has a Twitter account. And when I tweeted at it about my project, it suggested that I might like to try and get hold of the work of the Panamanian author Juan David Morgan. I found Morgan's website and I sent him a message, asking if any of his Spanish-language novels had been translated into English. And he said that nothing had been published, but he did have an unpublished translation of his novel "The Golden Horse." He emailed this to me, allowing me to become one of the first people ever to read that book in English.Morgan was by no means the only wordsmith to share his work with me in this way. From Sweden to Palau, writers and translators sent me self-published books and unpublished manuscripts of books that hadn't been picked up by Anglophone publishers or that were no longer available, giving me privileged glimpses of some remarkable imaginary worlds. I read, for example, about the Southern African king Ngungunhane, who led the resistance against the Portuguese in the 19th century; and about marriage rituals in a remote village on the shores of the Caspian sea in Turkmenistan. I met Kuwait's answer to Bridget Jones.(Laughter)And I read about an orgy in a tree in Angola.But perhaps the most amazing example of the lengths that people were prepared to go to to help me read the world, came towards the end of my quest, when I tried to get hold of a book from the tiny, Portuguese-speaking African island nation of São Tomé and Príncipe. Now, having spent several months trying everything I could think of to find a book that had been translated into English from the nation, it seemed as though the only option left to me was to see if I could get something translated for me from scratch. Now, I was really dubious whether anyone was going to want to help with this, and give up their time for something like that. But, within a week of me putting a call out on Twitter and Facebook for Portuguese speakers, I had more people than I could involve in the project, including Margaret Jull Costa, a leader in her field, who has translated the work of Nobel Prize winner José Saramago. With my nine volunteers in place, I managed to find a book by a São Toméan author that I could buy enough copies of online. Here's one of them. And I sent a copy out to each of my volunteers. They all took on a couple of short stories from this collection, stuck to their word, sent their translations back to me, and within six weeks, I had the entire book to read.In that case, as I found so often during my year of reading the world, my not knowing and being open about my limitations had become a big opportunity. When it came to São Tomé and Príncipe, it was a chance not only to learn something new and discover a new collection of stories, but also to bring together a group of people and facilitate a joint creative endeavor. My weakness had become the project's strength.The books I read that year opened my eyes to many things. As those who enjoy reading will know, books have an extraordinary power to take you out of yourself and into someone else's mindset, so that, for a while at least, you look at the world through different eyes. That can be an uncomfortable experience, particularly if you're reading a book from a culture that may have quite different values to your own. But it can also be really enlightening. Wrestling with unfamiliar ideas can help clarify your own thinking. And it can also show up blind spots in the way you might have been looking at the world.When I looked back at much of the English-language literature I'd grown up with, for example, I began to see how narrow a lot of it was, compared to the richness that the world has to offer. And as the pages turned, something else started to happen, too. Little by little, that long list of countries that I'd started the year with, changed from a rather dry, academic register of place names into living, breathing entities.Now, I don't want to suggest that it's at all possible to get a rounded picture of a country simply by reading one book. But cumulatively, the stories I read that year made me more alive than ever before to the richness, diversity and complexity of our remarkable planet. It was as though the world's stories and the people who'd gone to such lengths to help me read them had made it real to me. These days, when I look at my bookshelves or consider the works on my e-reader, they tell a rather different story. It's the story of the power books have to connect us across political, geographical, cultural, social, religious divides. It's the tale of the potential human beings have to work together.And, it's testament to the extraordinary times we live in, where, thanks to the Internet, it's easier than ever before for a stranger to share a story, a worldview, a book with someone she may never meet, on the other side of the planet. I hope it's a story I'm reading for many years to come. And I hope many more people will join me. If we all read more widely, there'd be more incentive for publishers to translate more books, and we would all be richer for that.Thank you.(Applause)

00:02:43.145 --> 00:02:47.312
and lots of industry professionals
primed to go out and sell those titles

00:02:47.336 --> 00:02:49.296
to English-language publishers.

00:02:49.669 --> 00:02:54.241
So, for example, although well over 100
books are translated from French

00:02:54.265 --> 00:02:56.168
and published in the UK each year,

00:02:56.192 --> 00:03:00.605
most of them will come from countries
like France or Switzerland.

00:03:01.065 --> 00:03:03.803
French-speaking Africa, on the other hand,

00:03:03.827 --> 00:03:05.469
will rarely ever get a look-in.

00:03:06.242 --> 00:03:09.565
The upshot is that there are
actually quite a lot of nations

00:03:09.589 --> 00:03:13.220
that may have little or even no
commercially available literature

00:03:13.244 --> 00:03:14.397
in English.

00:03:15.032 --> 00:03:18.098
Their books remain invisible to readers

00:03:18.122 --> 00:03:20.960
of the world's most published language.

00:03:21.960 --> 00:03:23.778
But when it came to reading the world,

00:03:23.802 --> 00:03:25.572
the biggest challenge of all for me

00:03:25.596 --> 00:03:28.730
was that fact that I didn't
know where to start.

00:03:29.159 --> 00:03:32.517
Having spent my life reading
almost exclusively British

00:03:32.541 --> 00:03:34.190
and North American books,

00:03:34.214 --> 00:03:37.803
I had no idea how to go about
sourcing and finding stories

00:03:37.827 --> 00:03:40.538
and choosing them from much
of the rest of the world.

00:03:40.562 --> 00:03:43.947
I couldn't tell you how to source
a story from Swaziland.

00:03:43.971 --> 00:03:46.606
I wouldn't know a good novel from Namibia.

00:03:47.083 --> 00:03:48.676
There was no hiding it --

00:03:48.700 --> 00:03:52.023
I was a clueless literary xenophobe.

00:03:52.499 --> 00:03:54.953
So how on earth was I
going to read the world?

00:03:55.735 --> 00:03:57.592
I was going to have to ask for help.

00:03:57.616 --> 00:04:01.115
So in October 2011, I registered my blog,

00:04:01.139 --> 00:04:02.910
ayearofreadingtheworld.com,

00:04:02.934 --> 00:04:05.419
and I posted a short appeal online.

00:04:05.821 --> 00:04:07.050
I explained who I was,

00:04:07.074 --> 00:04:09.082
how narrow my reading had been,

00:04:09.106 --> 00:04:10.963
and I asked anyone who cared to

00:04:10.987 --> 00:04:13.552
to leave a message suggesting
what I might read

00:04:13.576 --> 00:04:15.260
from other parts of the planet.

00:04:15.871 --> 00:04:19.944
Now, I had no idea whether
anyone would be interested,

00:04:19.968 --> 00:04:23.082
but within a few hours
of me posting that appeal online,

00:04:23.106 --> 00:04:25.542
people started to get in touch.

00:04:25.566 --> 00:04:28.064
At first, it was friends and colleagues.

00:04:28.424 --> 00:04:29.975
Then it was friends of friends.

00:04:30.341 --> 00:04:32.618
And pretty soon, it was strangers.

00:04:33.357 --> 00:04:36.159
Four days after I put that appeal online,

00:04:36.183 --> 00:04:39.914
I got a message from a woman
called Rafidah in Kuala Lumpur.

00:04:40.250 --> 00:04:42.925
She said she loved
the sound of my project,

00:04:42.949 --> 00:04:45.848
could she go to her local
English-language bookshop

00:04:45.872 --> 00:04:49.162
and choose my Malaysian book
and post it to me?

00:04:49.870 --> 00:04:51.623
I accepted enthusiastically,

00:04:51.647 --> 00:04:53.149
and a few weeks later,

00:04:53.173 --> 00:04:57.721
a package arrived containing
not one, but two books --

00:04:59.221 --> 00:05:01.639
Rafidah's choice from Malaysia,

00:05:02.866 --> 00:05:06.749
and a book from Singapore
that she had also picked out for me.

00:05:08.386 --> 00:05:10.823
Now, at the time, I was amazed

00:05:10.847 --> 00:05:14.423
that a stranger more than 6,000 miles away

00:05:14.447 --> 00:05:16.372
would go to such lengths to help someone

00:05:16.396 --> 00:05:18.455
she would probably never meet.

00:05:19.058 --> 00:05:22.709
But Rafidah's kindness proved
to be the pattern for that year.

00:05:23.198 --> 00:05:26.488
Time and again, people went
out of their way to help me.

00:05:27.184 --> 00:05:29.793
Some took on research on my behalf,

00:05:29.817 --> 00:05:32.840
and others made detours
on holidays and business trips

00:05:32.864 --> 00:05:34.800
to go to bookshops for me.

00:05:35.484 --> 00:05:38.720
It turns out, if you want
to read the world,

00:05:38.744 --> 00:05:42.145
if you want to encounter it
with an open mind,

00:05:42.169 --> 00:05:44.099
the world will help you.

00:05:45.076 --> 00:05:46.291
When it came to countries

00:05:46.315 --> 00:05:49.821
with little or no commercially
available literature in English,

00:05:49.845 --> 00:05:51.658
people went further still.

00:05:52.647 --> 00:05:55.859
Books often came from surprising sources.

00:05:56.494 --> 00:05:59.533
My Panamanian read, for example,
came through a conversation

00:05:59.557 --> 00:06:02.576
I had with the Panama Canal on Twitter.

00:06:03.455 --> 00:06:06.965
Yes, the Panama Canal
has a Twitter account.

00:06:07.689 --> 00:06:10.063
And when I tweeted at it about my project,

00:06:10.087 --> 00:06:13.466
it suggested that I might like to try
and get hold of the work

00:06:13.490 --> 00:06:16.069
of the Panamanian author
Juan David Morgan.

00:06:16.856 --> 00:06:19.426
I found Morgan's website
and I sent him a message,

00:06:19.450 --> 00:06:21.882
asking if any of his
Spanish-language novels

00:06:21.906 --> 00:06:23.896
had been translated into English.

00:06:24.390 --> 00:06:26.821
And he said that nothing
had been published,

00:06:26.845 --> 00:06:29.275
but he did have an unpublished translation

00:06:29.299 --> 00:06:31.283
of his novel "The Golden Horse."

00:06:31.845 --> 00:06:33.183
He emailed this to me,

00:06:33.207 --> 00:06:36.341
allowing me to become
one of the first people ever

00:06:36.365 --> 00:06:38.209
to read that book in English.

00:06:38.887 --> 00:06:41.537
Morgan was by no means the only wordsmith

00:06:41.561 --> 00:06:43.551
to share his work with me in this way.

00:06:43.973 --> 00:06:45.735
From Sweden to Palau,

00:06:45.759 --> 00:06:49.750
writers and translators
sent me self-published books

00:06:49.774 --> 00:06:51.504
and unpublished manuscripts of books

00:06:51.528 --> 00:06:54.408
that hadn't been picked
up by Anglophone publishers

00:06:54.432 --> 00:06:56.454
or that were no longer available,

00:06:56.478 --> 00:07:01.186
giving me privileged glimpses
of some remarkable imaginary worlds.

00:07:01.966 --> 00:07:03.117
I read, for example,

00:07:03.141 --> 00:07:07.731
about the Southern African king
Ngungunhane, who led the resistance

00:07:07.755 --> 00:07:10.417
against the Portuguese
in the 19th century;

00:07:11.071 --> 00:07:13.842
and about marriage rituals
in a remote village

00:07:13.866 --> 00:07:16.864
on the shores of the Caspian sea
in Turkmenistan.

00:07:18.482 --> 00:07:22.091
I met Kuwait's answer to Bridget Jones.

00:07:22.408 --> 00:07:24.408
(Laughter)

00:07:25.259 --> 00:07:28.825
And I read about an orgy
in a tree in Angola.

00:07:32.828 --> 00:07:34.980
But perhaps the most amazing example

00:07:35.004 --> 00:07:37.408
of the lengths that people
were prepared to go to

00:07:37.432 --> 00:07:39.059
to help me read the world,

00:07:39.083 --> 00:07:41.532
came towards the end of my quest,

00:07:41.556 --> 00:07:45.390
when I tried to get hold of a book
from the tiny, Portuguese-speaking

00:07:45.414 --> 00:07:48.681
African island nation
of São Tomé and Príncipe.

00:07:49.322 --> 00:07:52.971
Now, having spent several months
trying everything I could think of to find

00:07:52.995 --> 00:07:56.334
a book that had been translated
into English from the nation,

00:07:56.358 --> 00:07:58.600
it seemed as though
the only option left to me

00:07:58.624 --> 00:08:01.831
was to see if I could get something
translated for me from scratch.

00:08:02.362 --> 00:08:03.863
Now, I was really dubious

00:08:03.887 --> 00:08:06.283
whether anyone was going
to want to help with this,

00:08:06.307 --> 00:08:08.806
and give up their time
for something like that.

00:08:09.483 --> 00:08:13.746
But, within a week of me putting
a call out on Twitter and Facebook

00:08:13.770 --> 00:08:15.724
for Portuguese speakers,

00:08:15.748 --> 00:08:19.319
I had more people than I could
involve in the project,

00:08:19.343 --> 00:08:23.701
including Margaret Jull Costa,
a leader in her field,

00:08:23.725 --> 00:08:29.026
who has translated the work
of Nobel Prize winner José Saramago.

00:08:30.401 --> 00:08:32.336
With my nine volunteers in place,

00:08:32.360 --> 00:08:34.948
I managed to find a book
by a São Toméan author

00:08:34.972 --> 00:08:37.482
that I could buy enough copies of online.

00:08:37.506 --> 00:08:38.660
Here's one of them.

00:08:39.226 --> 00:08:42.790
And I sent a copy out
to each of my volunteers.

00:08:42.814 --> 00:08:45.988
They all took on a couple
of short stories from this collection,

00:08:46.012 --> 00:08:49.639
stuck to their word, sent
their translations back to me,

00:08:49.663 --> 00:08:53.452
and within six weeks,
I had the entire book to read.

00:08:54.380 --> 00:08:58.842
In that case, as I found so often
during my year of reading the world,

00:08:58.866 --> 00:09:02.951
my not knowing and being open
about my limitations

00:09:02.975 --> 00:09:05.116
had become a big opportunity.

00:09:05.893 --> 00:09:08.080
When it came to São Tomé and Príncipe,

00:09:08.104 --> 00:09:11.450
it was a chance not only
to learn something new

00:09:11.474 --> 00:09:14.149
and discover a new collection of stories,

00:09:14.173 --> 00:09:17.119
but also to bring together
a group of people

00:09:17.143 --> 00:09:20.372
and facilitate a joint creative endeavor.

00:09:20.859 --> 00:09:24.759
My weakness had become
the project's strength.

00:09:25.887 --> 00:09:29.443
The books I read that year
opened my eyes to many things.

00:09:29.467 --> 00:09:31.654
As those who enjoy reading will know,

00:09:31.678 --> 00:09:35.458
books have an extraordinary power
to take you out of yourself

00:09:35.482 --> 00:09:37.626
and into someone else's mindset,

00:09:37.650 --> 00:09:39.492
so that, for a while at least,

00:09:39.516 --> 00:09:41.741
you look at the world
through different eyes.

00:09:42.348 --> 00:09:44.811
That can be an uncomfortable experience,

00:09:44.835 --> 00:09:46.607
particularly if you're reading a book

00:09:46.631 --> 00:09:50.055
from a culture that may have quite
different values to your own.

00:09:50.559 --> 00:09:52.708
But it can also be really enlightening.

00:09:53.360 --> 00:09:57.274
Wrestling with unfamiliar ideas
can help clarify your own thinking.

00:09:57.700 --> 00:09:59.867
And it can also show up blind spots

00:09:59.891 --> 00:10:02.533
in the way you might have
been looking at the world.

00:10:03.030 --> 00:10:05.912
When I looked back at much
of the English-language literature

00:10:05.936 --> 00:10:07.622
I'd grown up with, for example,

00:10:07.646 --> 00:10:10.683
I began to see how narrow a lot of it was,

00:10:10.707 --> 00:10:13.519
compared to the richness
that the world has to offer.

00:10:14.844 --> 00:10:17.006
And as the pages turned,

00:10:17.030 --> 00:10:19.496
something else started to happen, too.

00:10:20.108 --> 00:10:21.259
Little by little,

00:10:21.283 --> 00:10:25.568
that long list of countries that
I'd started the year with, changed

00:10:25.592 --> 00:10:29.951
from a rather dry, academic
register of place names

00:10:29.975 --> 00:10:32.656
into living, breathing entities.

00:10:33.433 --> 00:10:36.156
Now, I don't want to suggest
that it's at all possible

00:10:36.180 --> 00:10:40.386
to get a rounded picture of a country
simply by reading one book.

00:10:40.968 --> 00:10:44.557
But cumulatively, the stories
I read that year

00:10:44.581 --> 00:10:47.641
made me more alive than ever before

00:10:47.665 --> 00:10:53.739
to the richness, diversity and complexity
of our remarkable planet.

00:10:54.612 --> 00:10:56.605
It was as though the world's stories

00:10:56.629 --> 00:11:00.529
and the people who'd gone
to such lengths to help me read them

00:11:00.553 --> 00:11:02.458
had made it real to me.

00:11:04.044 --> 00:11:06.579
These days, when I look at my bookshelves

00:11:06.603 --> 00:11:09.728
or consider the works on my e-reader,

00:11:09.752 --> 00:11:11.867
they tell a rather different story.

00:11:12.607 --> 00:11:15.953
It's the story of the power
books have to connect us

00:11:15.977 --> 00:11:20.722
across political, geographical,
cultural, social, religious divides.

00:11:21.380 --> 00:11:25.522
It's the tale of the potential
human beings have to work together.

00:11:26.278 --> 00:11:27.620
And, it's testament

00:11:27.644 --> 00:11:32.267
to the extraordinary times we live
in, where, thanks to the Internet,

00:11:32.291 --> 00:11:34.208
it's easier than ever before

00:11:34.232 --> 00:11:38.661
for a stranger to share a story,
a worldview, a book

00:11:38.685 --> 00:11:42.478
with someone she may never meet,
on the other side of the planet.

00:11:43.553 --> 00:11:46.651
I hope it's a story I'm reading
for many years to come.

00:11:47.032 --> 00:11:49.881
And I hope many more people will join me.

00:11:49.905 --> 00:11:52.519
If we all read more widely,
there'd be more incentive

00:11:52.543 --> 00:11:55.090
for publishers to translate more books,

00:11:55.114 --> 00:11:57.053
and we would all be richer for that.

00:11:57.671 --> 00:11:58.828
Thank you.

00:11:58.852 --> 00:12:02.586
(Applause)

title: Why the best hire might not have the perfect resume
transcript: Your company launches a search for an open position. The applications start rolling in, and the qualified candidates are identified. Now the choosing begins. Person A: Ivy League, 4.0, flawless resume, great recommendations. All the right stuff. Person B: state school, fair amount of job hopping, and odd jobs like cashier and singing waitress. But remember — both are qualified. So I ask you: who are you going to pick?My colleagues and I created very official terms to describe two distinct categories of candidates. We call A "the Silver Spoon," the one who clearly had advantages and was destined for success. And we call B "the Scrapper," the one who had to fight against tremendous odds to get to the same point. You just heard a human resources director refer to people as Silver Spoons and Scrappers —(Laughter)which is not exactly politically correct and sounds a bit judgmental. But before my human resources certification gets revoked —(Laughter)let me explain.A resume tells a story. And over the years, I've learned something about people whose experiences read like a patchwork quilt, that makes me stop and fully consider them before tossing their resumes away. A series of odd jobs may indicate inconsistency, lack of focus, unpredictability. Or it may signal a committed struggle against obstacles. At the very least, the Scrapper deserves an interview.To be clear, I don't hold anything against the Silver Spoon; getting into and graduating from an elite university takes a lot of hard work and sacrifice. But if your whole life has been engineered toward success, how will you handle the tough times? One person I hired felt that because he attended an elite university, there were certain assignments that were beneath him, like temporarily doing manual labor to better understand an operation. Eventually, he quit. But on the flip side, what happens when your whole life is destined for failure and you actually succeed?I want to urge you to interview the Scrapper. I know a lot about this because I am a Scrapper. Before I was born, my father was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia, and he couldn't hold a job in spite of his brilliance. Our lives were one part "Cuckoo's Nest," one part "Awakenings" and one part "A Beautiful Mind."(Laughter)I'm the fourth of five children raised by a single mother in a rough neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York. We never owned a home, a car, a washing machine, and for most of my childhood, we didn't even have a telephone. So I was highly motivated to understand the relationship between business success and Scrappers, because my life could easily have turned out very differently. As I met successful business people and read profiles of high-powered leaders, I noticed some commonality.Many of them had experienced early hardships, anywhere from poverty, abandonment, death of a parent while young, to learning disabilities, alcoholism and violence. The conventional thinking has been that trauma leads to distress, and there's been a lot of focus on the resulting dysfunction. But during studies of dysfunction, data revealed an unexpected insight: that even the worst circumstances can result in growth and transformation. A remarkable and counterintuitive phenomenon has been discovered, which scientists call Post Traumatic Growth.In one study designed to measure the effects of adversity on children at risk, among a subset of 698 children who experienced the most severe and extreme conditions, fully one-third grew up to lead healthy, successful and productive lives. In spite of everything and against tremendous odds, they succeeded. One-third.Take this resume. This guy's parents give him up for adoption. He never finishes college. He job-hops quite a bit, goes on a sojourn to India for a year, and to top it off, he has dyslexia. Would you hire this guy? His name is Steve Jobs.In a study of the world's most highly successful entrepreneurs, it turns out a disproportionate number have dyslexia. In the US, 35 percent of the entrepreneurs studied had dyslexia. What's remarkable — among those entrepreneurs who experience post traumatic growth, they now view their learning disability as a desirable difficulty which provided them an advantage because they became better listeners and paid greater attention to detail. They don't think they are who they are in spite of adversity, they know they are who they are because of adversity. They embrace their trauma and hardships as key elements of who they've become, and know that without those experiences, they might not have developed the muscle and grit required to become successful.One of my colleagues had his life completely upended as a result of the Chinese Cultural Revolution in 1966. At age 13, his parents were relocated to the countryside, the schools were closed and he was left alone in Beijing to fend for himself until 16, when he got a job in a clothing factory. But instead of accepting his fate, he made a resolution that he would continue his formal education. Eleven years later, when the political landscape changed, he heard about a highly selective university admissions test. He had three months to learn the entire curriculum of middle and high school. So, every day he came home from the factory, took a nap, studied until 4am, went back to work and repeated this cycle every day for three months. He did it, he succeeded. His commitment to his education was unwavering, and he never lost hope. Today, he holds a master's degree, and his daughters each have degrees from Cornell and Harvard.Scrappers are propelled by the belief that the only person you have full control over is yourself. When things don't turn out well, Scrappers ask, "What can I do differently to create a better result?" Scrappers have a sense of purpose that prevents them from giving up on themselves, kind of like if you've survived poverty, a crazy father and several muggings, you figure, "Business challenges? —(Laughter)Really? Piece of cake. I got this."(Laughter)And that reminds me — humor. Scrappers know that humor gets you through the tough times, and laughter helps you change your perspective.And finally, there are relationships. People who overcome adversity don't do it alone. Somewhere along the way, they find people who bring out the best in them and who are invested in their success. Having someone you can count on no matter what is essential to overcoming adversity. I was lucky. In my first job after college, I didn't have a car, so I carpooled across two bridges with a woman who was the president's assistant. She watched me work and encouraged me to focus on my future and not dwell on my past. Along the way I've met many people who've provided me brutally honest feedback, advice and mentorship. These people don't mind that I once worked as a singing waitress to help pay for college.(Laughter)I'll leave you with one final, valuable insight. Companies that are committed to diversity and inclusive practices tend to support Scrappers and outperform their peers. According to DiversityInc, a study of their top 50 companies for diversity outperformed the S&P 500 by 25 percent.So back to my original question. Who are you going to bet on: Silver Spoon or Scrapper? I say choose the underestimated contender, whose secret weapons are passion and purpose.Hire the Scrapper.(Applause)
