00:02:17.421 --> 00:02:20.887
getting into and graduating
from an elite university

00:02:20.911 --> 00:02:23.681
takes a lot of hard work and sacrifice.

00:02:24.355 --> 00:02:28.322
But if your whole life has been
engineered toward success,

00:02:28.346 --> 00:02:30.475
how will you handle the tough times?

00:02:31.158 --> 00:02:35.582
One person I hired felt that
because he attended an elite university,

00:02:35.606 --> 00:02:38.469
there were certain assignments
that were beneath him,

00:02:38.493 --> 00:02:43.598
like temporarily doing manual labor
to better understand an operation.

00:02:44.463 --> 00:02:46.431
Eventually, he quit.

00:02:47.511 --> 00:02:49.956
But on the flip side,

00:02:49.980 --> 00:02:54.664
what happens when your whole life
is destined for failure

00:02:54.688 --> 00:02:57.186
and you actually succeed?

00:02:57.790 --> 00:03:01.343
I want to urge you
to interview the Scrapper.

00:03:02.584 --> 00:03:06.903
I know a lot about this
because I am a Scrapper.

00:03:07.576 --> 00:03:09.102
Before I was born,

00:03:09.126 --> 00:03:13.089
my father was diagnosed
with paranoid schizophrenia,

00:03:13.113 --> 00:03:16.828
and he couldn't hold a job
in spite of his brilliance.

00:03:17.557 --> 00:03:20.905
Our lives were one part "Cuckoo's Nest,"

00:03:20.929 --> 00:03:22.995
one part "Awakenings"

00:03:23.019 --> 00:03:25.443
and one part "A Beautiful Mind."

00:03:25.467 --> 00:03:27.557
(Laughter)

00:03:28.879 --> 00:03:32.392
I'm the fourth of five children
raised by a single mother

00:03:32.416 --> 00:03:35.240
in a rough neighborhood
in Brooklyn, New York.

00:03:35.264 --> 00:03:40.020
We never owned a home,
a car, a washing machine,

00:03:40.044 --> 00:03:44.366
and for most of my childhood,
we didn't even have a telephone.

00:03:44.993 --> 00:03:46.419
So I was highly motivated

00:03:46.443 --> 00:03:50.822
to understand the relationship
between business success and Scrappers,

00:03:50.846 --> 00:03:55.627
because my life could easily
have turned out very differently.

00:03:56.556 --> 00:03:58.812
As I met successful business people

00:03:58.836 --> 00:04:02.158
and read profiles of high-powered leaders,

00:04:02.182 --> 00:04:04.033
I noticed some commonality.

00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:08.576
Many of them had experienced
early hardships,

00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:12.169
anywhere from poverty, abandonment,

00:04:12.193 --> 00:04:14.399
death of a parent while young,

00:04:14.423 --> 00:04:18.312
to learning disabilities,
alcoholism and violence.

00:04:18.893 --> 00:04:23.129
The conventional thinking has been
that trauma leads to distress,

00:04:23.153 --> 00:04:26.592
and there's been a lot of focus
on the resulting dysfunction.

00:04:26.616 --> 00:04:32.093
But during studies of dysfunction,
data revealed an unexpected insight:

00:04:32.117 --> 00:04:37.992
that even the worst circumstances
can result in growth and transformation.

00:04:38.373 --> 00:04:42.205
A remarkable and counterintuitive
phenomenon has been discovered,

00:04:42.229 --> 00:04:46.609
which scientists call
Post Traumatic Growth.

00:04:47.452 --> 00:04:50.628
In one study designed to measure
the effects of adversity

00:04:50.652 --> 00:04:52.610
on children at risk,

00:04:52.634 --> 00:04:57.207
among a subset of 698 children

00:04:57.231 --> 00:05:01.516
who experienced the most severe
and extreme conditions,

00:05:01.540 --> 00:05:08.410
fully one-third grew up to lead healthy,
successful and productive lives.

00:05:08.434 --> 00:05:13.599
In spite of everything and against
tremendous odds, they succeeded.

00:05:13.623 --> 00:05:15.117
One-third.

00:05:15.906 --> 00:05:17.583
Take this resume.

00:05:17.607 --> 00:05:20.717
This guy's parents
give him up for adoption.

00:05:20.741 --> 00:05:22.813
He never finishes college.

00:05:23.472 --> 00:05:25.606
He job-hops quite a bit,

00:05:25.630 --> 00:05:28.735
goes on a sojourn to India for a year,

00:05:28.759 --> 00:05:31.870
and to top it off, he has dyslexia.

00:05:32.388 --> 00:05:34.199
Would you hire this guy?

00:05:34.876 --> 00:05:36.941
His name is Steve Jobs.

00:05:38.382 --> 00:05:42.360
In a study of the world's
most highly successful entrepreneurs,

00:05:42.384 --> 00:05:46.253
it turns out a disproportionate
number have dyslexia.

00:05:46.753 --> 00:05:48.147
In the US,

00:05:48.171 --> 00:05:52.142
35 percent of the entrepreneurs
studied had dyslexia.

00:05:52.639 --> 00:05:56.663
What's remarkable --
among those entrepreneurs

00:05:56.687 --> 00:05:59.694
who experience post traumatic growth,

00:05:59.718 --> 00:06:02.997
they now view their learning disability

00:06:03.021 --> 00:06:07.465
as a desirable difficulty
which provided them an advantage

00:06:07.489 --> 00:06:12.491
because they became better listeners
and paid greater attention to detail.

00:06:13.141 --> 00:06:18.228
They don't think they are who they are
in spite of adversity,

00:06:18.252 --> 00:06:22.591
they know they are who they are
because of adversity.

00:06:22.986 --> 00:06:25.340
They embrace their trauma and hardships

00:06:25.364 --> 00:06:28.000
as key elements of who they've become,

00:06:28.024 --> 00:06:31.301
and know that without those experiences,

00:06:31.325 --> 00:06:34.731
they might not have developed
the muscle and grit required

00:06:34.755 --> 00:06:36.303
to become successful.

00:06:37.992 --> 00:06:41.275
One of my colleagues
had his life completely upended

00:06:41.299 --> 00:06:45.701
as a result of the Chinese
Cultural Revolution in 1966.

00:06:46.526 --> 00:06:51.687
At age 13, his parents were relocated
to the countryside,

00:06:51.711 --> 00:06:54.012
the schools were closed

00:06:54.036 --> 00:06:59.262
and he was left alone in Beijing
to fend for himself until 16,

00:06:59.286 --> 00:07:01.616
when he got a job in a clothing factory.

00:07:01.941 --> 00:07:04.223
But instead of accepting his fate,

00:07:04.247 --> 00:07:08.426
he made a resolution that he would
continue his formal education.

00:07:09.610 --> 00:07:13.301
Eleven years later, when
the political landscape changed,

00:07:13.325 --> 00:07:17.591
he heard about a highly selective
university admissions test.

00:07:18.341 --> 00:07:22.221
He had three months to learn
the entire curriculum

00:07:22.245 --> 00:07:23.856
of middle and high school.

00:07:24.563 --> 00:07:28.720
So, every day he came home
from the factory,

00:07:28.744 --> 00:07:33.433
took a nap, studied until 4am,
went back to work

00:07:33.457 --> 00:07:37.320
and repeated this cycle
every day for three months.

00:07:38.352 --> 00:07:40.974
He did it, he succeeded.

00:07:41.577 --> 00:07:46.657
His commitment to his education
was unwavering, and he never lost hope.

00:07:47.239 --> 00:07:50.175
Today, he holds a master's degree,

00:07:50.199 --> 00:07:54.693
and his daughters each have degrees
from Cornell and Harvard.

00:07:55.436 --> 00:07:58.113
Scrappers are propelled by the belief

00:07:58.137 --> 00:08:02.618
that the only person you have
full control over is yourself.

00:08:03.605 --> 00:08:05.601
When things don't turn out well,

00:08:05.625 --> 00:08:10.641
Scrappers ask, "What can I do differently
to create a better result?"

00:08:11.057 --> 00:08:12.992
Scrappers have a sense of purpose

00:08:13.016 --> 00:08:16.122
that prevents them
from giving up on themselves,

00:08:16.146 --> 00:08:22.178
kind of like if you've survived poverty,
a crazy father and several muggings,

00:08:22.202 --> 00:08:24.947
you figure, "Business challenges? --

00:08:24.971 --> 00:08:26.003
(Laughter)

00:08:26.027 --> 00:08:27.415
Really?

00:08:27.439 --> 00:08:29.615
Piece of cake. I got this."

00:08:29.639 --> 00:08:30.800
(Laughter)

00:08:30.824 --> 00:08:32.619
And that reminds me -- humor.

00:08:33.376 --> 00:08:36.798
Scrappers know that humor
gets you through the tough times,

00:08:36.822 --> 00:08:39.376
and laughter helps you
change your perspective.

00:08:40.109 --> 00:08:42.952
And finally, there are relationships.

00:08:43.370 --> 00:08:46.784
People who overcome adversity
don't do it alone.

00:08:47.307 --> 00:08:49.124
Somewhere along the way,

00:08:49.148 --> 00:08:52.584
they find people who
bring out the best in them

00:08:52.608 --> 00:08:55.511
and who are invested in their success.

00:08:56.270 --> 00:08:59.534
Having someone you can
count on no matter what

00:08:59.558 --> 00:09:02.327
is essential to overcoming adversity.

00:09:02.820 --> 00:09:04.306
I was lucky.

00:09:04.661 --> 00:09:06.641
In my first job after college,

00:09:06.665 --> 00:09:09.795
I didn't have a car, so I carpooled
across two bridges

00:09:09.819 --> 00:09:12.489
with a woman who was
the president's assistant.

00:09:13.103 --> 00:09:14.755
She watched me work

00:09:14.779 --> 00:09:17.756
and encouraged me to focus on my future

00:09:17.780 --> 00:09:19.982
and not dwell on my past.

00:09:20.626 --> 00:09:23.595
Along the way I've met many people

00:09:23.619 --> 00:09:27.270
who've provided me
brutally honest feedback,

00:09:27.294 --> 00:09:29.290
advice and mentorship.

00:09:29.891 --> 00:09:31.728
These people don't mind

00:09:31.752 --> 00:09:35.995
that I once worked as a singing waitress
to help pay for college.

00:09:36.019 --> 00:09:37.265
(Laughter)

00:09:37.289 --> 00:09:40.478
I'll leave you with one final,
valuable insight.

00:09:40.873 --> 00:09:45.846
Companies that are committed
to diversity and inclusive practices

00:09:45.870 --> 00:09:47.974
tend to support Scrappers

00:09:47.998 --> 00:09:50.807
and outperform their peers.

00:09:51.437 --> 00:09:54.061
According to DiversityInc,

00:09:54.085 --> 00:09:57.903
a study of their top 50
companies for diversity

00:09:57.927 --> 00:10:02.584
outperformed the S&P 500 by 25 percent.

00:10:04.161 --> 00:10:07.306
So back to my original question.

00:10:08.298 --> 00:10:10.383
Who are you going to bet on:

00:10:10.407 --> 00:10:12.831
Silver Spoon or Scrapper?

00:10:13.688 --> 00:10:17.473
I say choose the underestimated contender,

00:10:17.497 --> 00:10:21.356
whose secret weapons
are passion and purpose.

00:10:22.279 --> 00:10:24.347
Hire the Scrapper.

00:10:24.371 --> 00:10:27.523
(Applause)

title: An art made of trust, vulnerability and connection
transcript: Now... let's go back in time. It's 1974. There is the gallery somewhere in the world, and there is a young girl, age 23, standing in the middle of the space. In the front of her is a table. On the table there are 76 objects for pleasure and for pain. Some of the objects are a glass of water, a coat, a shoe, a rose. But also the knife, the razor blade, the hammer and the pistol with one bullet. There are instructions which say, "I'm an object. You can use everything on the table on me. I'm taking all responsibility — even killing me. And the time is six hours."The beginning of this performance was easy. People would give me the glass of water to drink, they'd give me the rose. But very soon after, there was a man who took the scissors and cut my clothes, and then they took the thorns of the rose and stuck them in my stomach. Somebody took the razor blade and cut my neck and drank the blood, and I still have the scar. The women would tell the men what to do. And the men didn't rape me because it was just a normal opening, and it was all public, and they were with their wives. They carried me around and put me on the table, and put the knife between my legs. And somebody took the pistol and bullet and put it against my temple. And another person took the pistol and they started a fight.And after six hours were finished, I... started walking towards the public. I was a mess. I was half-naked, I was full of blood and tears were running down my face. And everybody escaped, they just ran away. They could not confront myself, with myself as a normal human being. And then — what happened is I went to the hotel, it was at two in the morning. And I looked at myself in the mirror, and I had a piece of gray hair. Alright — please take off your blindfolds.Welcome to the performance world. First of all, let's explain what the performance is. So many artists, so many different explanations, but my explanation for performance is very simple. Performance is a mental and physical construction that the performer makes in a specific time in a space in front of an audience and then energy dialogue happens. The audience and the performer make the piece together. And the difference between performance and theater is huge. In the theater, the knife is not a knife and the blood is just ketchup. In the performance, the blood is the material, and the razor blade or knife is the tool. It's all about being there in the real time, and you can't rehearse performance, because you can't do many of these types of things twice — ever. Which is very important, the performance is — you know, all human beings are always afraid of very simple things. We're afraid of suffering, we're afraid of pain, we're afraid of mortality. So what I'm doing — I'm staging these kinds of fears in front of the audience. I'm using your energy, and with this energy I can go and push my body as far as I can. And then I liberate myself from these fears. And I'm your mirror. If I can do this for myself, you can do it for you.After Belgrade, where I was born, I went to Amsterdam. And you know, I've been doing performances since the last 40 years. And here I met Ulay, and he was the person I actually fell in love with. And we made, for 12 years, performances together. You know the knife and the pistols and the bullets, I exchange into love and trust. So to do this kind work you have to trust the person completely because this arrow is pointing to my heart. So, heart beating and adrenaline is rushing and so on, is about trust, is about total trust to another human being.Our relationship was 12 years, and we worked on so many subjects, both male and female energy. And as every relationship comes to an end, ours went too. We didn't make phone calls like normal human beings do and say, you know, "This is over." We walked the Great Wall of China to say goodbye. I started at the Yellow Sea, and he started from the Gobi Desert. We walked, each of us, three months, two and a half thousand kilometers. It was the mountains, it was difficult. It was climbing, it was ruins. It was, you know, going through the 12 Chinese provinces, this was before China was open in '87. And we succeeded to meet in the middle to say goodbye. And then our relationship stopped.And now, it completely changed how I see the public. And one very important piece I made in those days was "Balkan Baroque." And this was the time of the Balkan Wars, and I wanted to create some very strong, charismatic image, something that could serve for any war at any time, because the Balkan Wars are now finished, but there's always some war, somewhere. So here I am washing two and a half thousand dead, big, bloody cow bones. You can't wash the blood, you never can wash shame off the wars. So I'm washing this six hours, six days, and wars are coming off these bones, and becoming possible — an unbearable smell. But then something stays in the memory.I want to show you the one who really changed my life, and this was the performance in MoMa, which I just recently made. This performance — when I said to the curator, "I'm just going to sit at the chair, and there will be an empty chair at the front, and anybody from the public can come and sit as long as they want." The curator said to me, "That's ridiculous, you know, this is New York, this chair will be empty, nobody has time to sit in front of you."(Laughter)But I sit for three months. And I sit everyday, eight hours — the opening of the museum — and 10 hours on Friday when the museum is open 10 hours, and I never move. And I removed the table and I'm still sitting, and this changed everything. This performance, maybe 10 or 15 years ago — nothing would have happened. But the need of people to actually experience something different, the public was not anymore the group — relation was one to one. I was watching these people, they would come and sit in front of me, but they would have to wait for hours and hours and hours to get to this position, and finally, they sit.And what happened? They are observed by the other people, they're photographed, they're filmed by the camera, they're observed by me and they have nowhere to escape except in themselves. And that makes a difference. There was so much pain and loneliness, there's so much incredible things when you look in somebody else's eyes, because in the gaze with that total stranger, that you never even say one word — everything happened. And I understood when I stood up from that chair after three months, I am not the same anymore. And I understood that I have a very strong mission, that I have to communicate this experience to everybody.And this is how, for me, was born the idea to have an institute of immaterial performing arts. Because thinking about immateriality, performance is time-based art. It's not like a painting. You have the painting on the wall, the next day it's there. Performance, if you are missing it, you only have the memory, or the story of somebody else telling you, but you actually missed the whole thing. So you have to be there. And in my point, if you talk about immaterial art, music is the highest — absolutely highest art of all, because it's the most immaterial. And then after this is performance, and then everything else. That's my subjective way.This institute is going to happen in Hudson, upstate New York, and we are trying to build with Rem Koolhaas, an idea. And it's very simple. If you want to get experience, you have to give me your time. You have to sign the contract before you enter the building, that you will spend there a full six hours, you have to give me your word of honor. It's something so old-fashioned, but if you don't respect your own word of honor and you leave before — that's not my problem. But it's six hours, the experience. And then after you finish, you get a certificate of accomplishment, so get home and frame it if you want.(Laughter)This is orientation hall. The public comes in, and the first thing you have to do is dress in lab coats. It's this importance of stepping from being just a viewer into experimenter. And then you go to the lockers and you put your watch, your iPhone, your iPod, your computer and everything digital, electronic. And you are getting free time for yourself for the first time. Because there is nothing wrong with technology, our approach to technology is wrong. We are losing the time we have for ourselves. This is an institute to actually give you back this time.So what you do here, first you start slow walking, you start slowing down. You're going back to simplicity. After slow walking, you're going to learn how to drink water — very simple, drinking water for maybe half an hour. After this, you're going to the magnet chamber, where you're going to create some magnet streams on your body. Then after this, you go to crystal chamber. After crystal chamber, you go to eye-gazing chamber, after eye-gazing chamber, you go to a chamber where you are lying down. So it's the three basic positions of the human body, sitting, standing and lying. And slow walking. And there is a sound chamber. And then after you've seen all of this, and prepared yourself mentally and physically, then you are ready to see something with a long duration, like in immaterial art. It can be music, it can be opera, it can be a theater piece, it can be film, it can be video dance. You go to the long duration chairs because now you are comfortable. In the long duration chairs, you're transported to the big place where you're going to see the work. And if you fall asleep, which is very possible because it's been a long day, you're going to be transported to the parking lot.(Laughter)And you know, sleeping is very important. In sleeping, you're still receiving art. So in the parking lot you stay for a certain amount of time, and then after this you just, you know, go back, you see more of the things you like to see or go home with your certificate.So this institute right now is virtual. Right now, I am just making my institute in Brazil, then it's going to be in Australia, then it's coming here, to Canada and everywhere. And this is to experience a kind of simple method, how you go back to simplicity in your own life. Counting rice will be another thing.(Laughter)You know, if you count rice you can make life, too. How to count rice for six hours? It's incredibly important. You know, you go through this whole range of being bored, being angry, being completely frustrated, not finishing the amount of rice you're counting. And then this unbelievable amount of peace you get when satisfying work is finished — or counting sand in the desert. Or having the sound-isolated situation — that you have headphones, that you don't hear anything, and you're just there together without sound, with the people experiencing silence, just the simple silence.We are always doing things we like in our life. And this is why you're not changing. You do things in life — it's just nothing happens if you always do things the same way. But my method is to do things I'm afraid of, the things I fear, the things I don't know, to go to territory that nobody's ever been.And then also to include the failure. I think failure is important because if you go, if you experiment, you can fail. If you don't go into that area and you don't fail, you are actually repeating yourself over and over again. And I think that human beings right now need a change, and the only change to be made is a personal level change. You have to make the change on yourself. Because the only way to change consciousness and to change the world around us, is to start with yourself. It's so easy to criticize how it's different, the things in the world and they're not right, and the governments are corrupted and there's hunger in the world and there's wars — the killing. But what we do on the personal level — what is our contribution to this whole thing?Can you turn to your neighbor, the one you don't know, and look at them for two full minutes in their eyes, right now?(Chatter)I'm asking two minutes of your time, that's so little. Breathe slowly, don't try to blink, don't be self-conscious. Be relaxed. And just look a complete stranger in your eyes, in his eyes.(Silence) Thank you for trusting me.(Applause)Chris Anderson: Thank you. Thank you so much.

I was a mess.

00:02:40.558 --> 00:02:44.878
I was half-naked, I was full of blood
and tears were running down my face.

00:02:45.998 --> 00:02:48.838
And everybody escaped, they just ran away.

00:02:49.238 --> 00:02:54.238
They could not confront myself,
with myself as a normal human being.

00:02:54.718 --> 00:02:56.038
And then --

00:02:57.038 --> 00:02:58.518
what happened

00:02:59.198 --> 00:03:03.678
is I went to the hotel,
it was at two in the morning.

00:03:05.038 --> 00:03:06.718
And

00:03:07.638 --> 00:03:09.838
I looked at myself in the mirror,

00:03:10.478 --> 00:03:14.278
and I had a piece of gray hair.

00:03:16.038 --> 00:03:17.398
Alright --

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:19.998
please take off your blindfolds.

00:03:22.718 --> 00:03:24.998
Welcome to the performance world.

00:03:25.478 --> 00:03:28.838
First of all, let's explain
what the performance is.

00:03:29.798 --> 00:03:32.334
So many artists,
so many different explanations,

00:03:32.358 --> 00:03:35.118
but my explanation
for performance is very simple.

00:03:35.598 --> 00:03:40.174
Performance is a mental
and physical construction

00:03:40.198 --> 00:03:43.014
that the performer makes
in a specific time

00:03:43.038 --> 00:03:46.334
in a space in front of an audience

00:03:46.358 --> 00:03:48.678
and then energy dialogue happens.

00:03:49.238 --> 00:03:52.758
The audience and the performer
make the piece together.

00:03:53.558 --> 00:03:57.318
And the difference between
performance and theater is huge.

00:03:58.198 --> 00:04:01.654
In the theater, the knife is not a knife

00:04:01.678 --> 00:04:03.598
and the blood is just ketchup.

00:04:03.998 --> 00:04:08.534
In the performance,
the blood is the material,

00:04:08.558 --> 00:04:11.854
and the razor blade or knife is the tool.

00:04:11.878 --> 00:04:15.774
It's all about being there
in the real time,

00:04:15.798 --> 00:04:17.654
and you can't rehearse performance,

00:04:17.678 --> 00:04:21.998
because you can't do many
of these types of things twice -- ever.

00:04:23.318 --> 00:04:25.814
Which is very important,
the performance is --

00:04:25.838 --> 00:04:30.134
you know, all human beings
are always afraid of very simple things.

00:04:30.158 --> 00:04:33.534
We're afraid of suffering,
we're afraid of pain,

00:04:33.558 --> 00:04:35.638
we're afraid of mortality.

00:04:36.198 --> 00:04:37.454
So what I'm doing --

00:04:37.478 --> 00:04:41.694
I'm staging these kinds of fears
in front of the audience.

00:04:41.718 --> 00:04:43.894
I'm using your energy,

00:04:43.918 --> 00:04:49.694
and with this energy I can go
and push my body as far as I can.

00:04:49.718 --> 00:04:53.294
And then I liberate myself
from these fears.

00:04:53.318 --> 00:04:54.614
And I'm your mirror.

00:04:54.638 --> 00:04:57.918
If I can do this for myself,
you can do it for you.

00:04:58.678 --> 00:05:00.734
After Belgrade, where I was born,

00:05:00.758 --> 00:05:03.038
I went to Amsterdam.

00:05:03.398 --> 00:05:06.014
And you know, I've been doing performances

00:05:06.038 --> 00:05:08.294
since the last 40 years.

00:05:08.318 --> 00:05:09.894
And here I met Ulay,

00:05:09.918 --> 00:05:13.294
and he was the person
I actually fell in love with.

00:05:13.318 --> 00:05:16.454
And we made, for 12 years,
performances together.

00:05:16.478 --> 00:05:19.734
You know the knife
and the pistols and the bullets,

00:05:19.758 --> 00:05:22.694
I exchange into love and trust.

00:05:22.718 --> 00:05:26.334
So to do this kind work
you have to trust the person completely

00:05:26.358 --> 00:05:29.374
because this arrow
is pointing to my heart.

00:05:29.398 --> 00:05:33.734
So, heart beating and adrenaline
is rushing and so on,

00:05:33.758 --> 00:05:38.278
is about trust, is about total trust
to another human being.

00:05:39.278 --> 00:05:41.494
Our relationship was 12 years,

00:05:41.518 --> 00:05:45.374
and we worked on so many subjects,
both male and female energy.

00:05:45.398 --> 00:05:49.534
And as every relationship
comes to an end, ours went too.

00:05:49.558 --> 00:05:53.214
We didn't make phone calls
like normal human beings do

00:05:53.238 --> 00:05:55.214
and say, you know, "This is over."

00:05:55.238 --> 00:05:58.238
We walked the Great Wall
of China to say goodbye.

00:05:58.598 --> 00:06:02.678
I started at the Yellow Sea,
and he started from the Gobi Desert.

00:06:03.158 --> 00:06:06.534
We walked, each of us, three months,

00:06:06.558 --> 00:06:08.398
two and a half thousand kilometers.

00:06:08.758 --> 00:06:10.734
It was the mountains, it was difficult.

00:06:10.758 --> 00:06:13.094
It was climbing, it was ruins.

00:06:13.118 --> 00:06:16.214
It was, you know, going through
the 12 Chinese provinces,

00:06:16.238 --> 00:06:20.054
this was before China was open in '87.

00:06:20.078 --> 00:06:23.614
And we succeeded to meet in the middle

00:06:23.638 --> 00:06:25.118
to say goodbye.

00:06:26.278 --> 00:06:28.118
And then our relationship stopped.

00:06:28.518 --> 00:06:32.918
And now, it completely changed
how I see the public.

00:06:33.238 --> 00:06:36.374
And one very important piece
I made in those days

00:06:36.398 --> 00:06:38.374
was "Balkan Baroque."

00:06:38.398 --> 00:06:41.094
And this was the time of the Balkan Wars,

00:06:41.118 --> 00:06:44.654
and I wanted to create
some very strong, charismatic image,

00:06:44.678 --> 00:06:47.974
something that could serve
for any war at any time,

00:06:47.998 --> 00:06:52.014
because the Balkan Wars are now finished,
but there's always some war, somewhere.

00:06:52.038 --> 00:06:54.014
So here I am washing

00:06:54.038 --> 00:06:57.814
two and a half thousand
dead, big, bloody cow bones.

00:06:57.838 --> 00:07:01.374
You can't wash the blood,
you never can wash shame off the wars.

00:07:01.398 --> 00:07:05.974
So I'm washing this six hours, six days,
and wars are coming off these bones,

00:07:05.998 --> 00:07:09.238
and becoming possible --
an unbearable smell.

00:07:09.598 --> 00:07:12.454
But then something stays in the memory.

00:07:12.478 --> 00:07:15.214
I want to show you the one
who really changed my life,

00:07:15.238 --> 00:07:19.374
and this was the performance in MoMa,
which I just recently made.

00:07:19.398 --> 00:07:22.734
This performance --
when I said to the curator,

00:07:22.758 --> 00:07:24.734
"I'm just going to sit at the chair,

00:07:24.758 --> 00:07:27.294
and there will be
an empty chair at the front,

00:07:27.318 --> 00:07:30.814
and anybody from the public
can come and sit as long as they want."

00:07:30.838 --> 00:07:32.054
The curator said to me,

00:07:32.078 --> 00:07:34.734
"That's ridiculous, you know,
this is New York,

00:07:34.758 --> 00:07:35.974
this chair will be empty,

00:07:35.998 --> 00:07:37.903
nobody has time to sit in front of you."

00:07:37.927 --> 00:07:39.094
(Laughter)

00:07:39.118 --> 00:07:41.014
But I sit for three months.

00:07:41.038 --> 00:07:42.974
And I sit everyday, eight hours --

00:07:42.998 --> 00:07:44.374
the opening of the museum --

00:07:44.398 --> 00:07:47.294
and 10 hours on Friday
when the museum is open 10 hours,

00:07:47.318 --> 00:07:48.492
and I never move.

00:07:48.516 --> 00:07:51.374
And I removed the table
and I'm still sitting,

00:07:51.398 --> 00:07:53.518
and this changed everything.

00:07:53.918 --> 00:07:56.254
This performance,
maybe 10 or 15 years ago --

00:07:56.278 --> 00:07:57.694
nothing would have happened.

00:07:57.718 --> 00:08:02.614
But the need of people to actually
experience something different,

00:08:02.638 --> 00:08:04.734
the public was not anymore the group --

00:08:04.758 --> 00:08:06.758
relation was one to one.

00:08:07.118 --> 00:08:10.854
I was watching these people,
they would come and sit in front of me,

00:08:10.878 --> 00:08:13.574
but they would have to wait
for hours and hours and hours

00:08:13.598 --> 00:08:14.756
to get to this position,

00:08:14.781 --> 00:08:16.334
and finally, they sit.

00:08:16.358 --> 00:08:17.918
And what happened?

00:08:18.398 --> 00:08:20.534
They are observed by the other people,

00:08:20.558 --> 00:08:23.134
they're photographed,
they're filmed by the camera,

00:08:23.158 --> 00:08:24.534
they're observed by me

00:08:24.558 --> 00:08:27.718
and they have nowhere to escape
except in themselves.

00:08:28.198 --> 00:08:29.774
And that makes a difference.

00:08:29.798 --> 00:08:31.614
There was so much pain and loneliness,

00:08:31.638 --> 00:08:35.734
there's so much incredible things
when you look in somebody else's eyes,

00:08:35.758 --> 00:08:38.734
because in the gaze
with that total stranger,

00:08:38.758 --> 00:08:41.758
that you never even say one word --
everything happened.

00:08:42.158 --> 00:08:47.134
And I understood when I stood up
from that chair after three months,

00:08:47.158 --> 00:08:48.733
I am not the same anymore.

00:08:48.757 --> 00:08:51.534
And I understood
that I have a very strong mission,

00:08:51.558 --> 00:08:54.814
that I have to communicate this experience

00:08:54.838 --> 00:08:56.093
to everybody.

00:08:56.117 --> 00:08:58.934
And this is how, for me, was born the idea

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:02.958
to have an institute
of immaterial performing arts.

00:09:03.278 --> 00:09:06.174
Because thinking about immateriality,

00:09:06.198 --> 00:09:07.654
performance is time-based art.

00:09:07.678 --> 00:09:09.014
It's not like a painting.

00:09:09.038 --> 00:09:11.814
You have the painting on the wall,
the next day it's there.

00:09:11.838 --> 00:09:16.534
Performance, if you are missing it,
you only have the memory,

00:09:16.558 --> 00:09:18.894
or the story of somebody else telling you,

00:09:18.918 --> 00:09:20.854
but you actually missed the whole thing.

00:09:20.878 --> 00:09:22.094
So you have to be there.

00:09:22.118 --> 00:09:25.014
And in my point,
if you talk about immaterial art,

00:09:25.038 --> 00:09:28.414
music is the highest --
absolutely highest art of all,

00:09:28.438 --> 00:09:30.214
because it's the most immaterial.

00:09:30.238 --> 00:09:33.096
And then after this is performance,
and then everything else.

00:09:33.120 --> 00:09:34.654
That's my subjective way.

00:09:34.678 --> 00:09:38.574
This institute is going to happen
in Hudson, upstate New York,

00:09:38.598 --> 00:09:41.598
and we are trying to build
with Rem Koolhaas, an idea.

00:09:41.918 --> 00:09:43.174
And it's very simple.

00:09:43.198 --> 00:09:47.854
If you want to get experience,
you have to give me your time.

00:09:47.878 --> 00:09:50.974
You have to sign the contract
before you enter the building,

00:09:50.998 --> 00:09:53.854
that you will spend there
a full six hours,

00:09:53.878 --> 00:09:56.534
you have to give me your word of honor.

00:09:56.558 --> 00:09:58.454
It's something so old-fashioned,

00:09:58.478 --> 00:10:01.814
but if you don't respect your own
word of honor and you leave before --

00:10:01.838 --> 00:10:03.054
that's not my problem.

00:10:03.078 --> 00:10:05.574
But it's six hours, the experience.

00:10:05.598 --> 00:10:08.741
And then after you finish,
you get a certificate of accomplishment,

00:10:08.765 --> 00:10:10.814
so get home and frame it if you want.

00:10:10.838 --> 00:10:11.854
(Laughter)

00:10:11.878 --> 00:10:13.214
This is orientation hall.

00:10:13.238 --> 00:10:17.734
The public comes in, and the first thing
you have to do is dress in lab coats.

00:10:17.758 --> 00:10:18.974
It's this importance

00:10:18.998 --> 00:10:23.214
of stepping from being
just a viewer into experimenter.

00:10:23.238 --> 00:10:25.654
And then you go to the lockers

00:10:25.678 --> 00:10:28.974
and you put your watch,
your iPhone, your iPod, your computer

00:10:28.998 --> 00:10:31.294
and everything digital, electronic.

00:10:31.318 --> 00:10:35.654
And you are getting free time
for yourself for the first time.

00:10:35.678 --> 00:10:39.054
Because there is nothing
wrong with technology,

00:10:39.078 --> 00:10:41.414
our approach to technology is wrong.

00:10:41.438 --> 00:10:44.134
We are losing the time
we have for ourselves.

00:10:44.158 --> 00:10:47.454
This is an institute
to actually give you back this time.

00:10:47.478 --> 00:10:48.734
So what you do here,

00:10:48.758 --> 00:10:51.854
first you start slow walking,
you start slowing down.

00:10:51.878 --> 00:10:53.814
You're going back to simplicity.

00:10:53.838 --> 00:10:57.454
After slow walking, you're going
to learn how to drink water --

00:10:57.478 --> 00:11:01.118
very simple, drinking water
for maybe half an hour.

00:11:01.598 --> 00:11:03.894
After this, you're going to
the magnet chamber,

00:11:03.918 --> 00:11:07.814
where you're going to create
some magnet streams on your body.

00:11:07.838 --> 00:11:10.294
Then after this,
you go to crystal chamber.

00:11:10.318 --> 00:11:13.094
After crystal chamber,
you go to eye-gazing chamber,

00:11:13.118 --> 00:11:17.214
after eye-gazing chamber, you go to
a chamber where you are lying down.

00:11:17.238 --> 00:11:19.694
So it's the three basic positions
of the human body,

00:11:19.718 --> 00:11:21.054
sitting, standing and lying.

00:11:21.078 --> 00:11:22.614
And slow walking.

00:11:22.638 --> 00:11:24.454
And there is a sound chamber.

00:11:24.478 --> 00:11:26.814
And then after you've seen all of this,

00:11:26.838 --> 00:11:28.981
and prepared yourself
mentally and physically,

00:11:29.005 --> 00:11:31.672
then you are ready to see
something with a long duration,

00:11:31.696 --> 00:11:34.054
like in immaterial art.

00:11:34.078 --> 00:11:37.934
It can be music, it can be opera,
it can be a theater piece,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.854
it can be film, it can be video dance.

00:11:40.878 --> 00:11:44.694
You go to the long duration chairs
because now you are comfortable.

00:11:44.718 --> 00:11:46.094
In the long duration chairs,

00:11:46.118 --> 00:11:49.814
you're transported to the big place
where you're going to see the work.

00:11:49.838 --> 00:11:51.054
And if you fall asleep,

00:11:51.078 --> 00:11:53.614
which is very possible
because it's been a long day,

00:11:53.638 --> 00:11:56.094
you're going to be
transported to the parking lot.

00:11:56.118 --> 00:11:57.734
(Laughter)

00:11:57.758 --> 00:12:00.574
And you know, sleeping is very important.

00:12:00.598 --> 00:12:03.374
In sleeping, you're still receiving art.

00:12:03.398 --> 00:12:07.094
So in the parking lot you stay
for a certain amount of time,

00:12:07.118 --> 00:12:10.374
and then after this
you just, you know, go back,

00:12:10.398 --> 00:12:12.734
you see more of the things you like to see

00:12:12.758 --> 00:12:14.798
or go home with your certificate.

00:12:15.238 --> 00:12:18.654
So this institute right now is virtual.

00:12:18.678 --> 00:12:21.534
Right now, I am just
making my institute in Brazil,

00:12:21.558 --> 00:12:23.225
then it's going to be in Australia,

00:12:23.249 --> 00:12:26.374
then it's coming here,
to Canada and everywhere.

00:12:26.398 --> 00:12:29.894
And this is to experience
a kind of simple method,

00:12:29.918 --> 00:12:32.814
how you go back to simplicity
in your own life.

00:12:32.838 --> 00:12:34.798
Counting rice will be another thing.

00:12:35.718 --> 00:12:37.614
(Laughter)

00:12:37.638 --> 00:12:40.134
You know, if you count rice
you can make life, too.

00:12:40.158 --> 00:12:42.334
How to count rice for six hours?

00:12:42.358 --> 00:12:44.054
It's incredibly important.

00:12:44.078 --> 00:12:48.214
You know, you go through this whole range
of being bored, being angry,

00:12:48.238 --> 00:12:52.694
being completely frustrated, not finishing
the amount of rice you're counting.

00:12:52.718 --> 00:12:55.494
And then this unbelievable
amount of peace you get

00:12:55.518 --> 00:12:57.974
when satisfying work is finished --

00:12:57.998 --> 00:12:59.798
or counting sand in the desert.

00:13:00.558 --> 00:13:04.054
Or having the sound-isolated situation --

00:13:04.078 --> 00:13:06.654
that you have headphones,
that you don't hear anything,

00:13:06.678 --> 00:13:09.374
and you're just there
together without sound,

00:13:09.398 --> 00:13:14.254
with the people experiencing silence,
just the simple silence.

00:13:14.278 --> 00:13:18.494
We are always doing things
we like in our life.

00:13:18.518 --> 00:13:20.774
And this is why you're not changing.

00:13:20.798 --> 00:13:22.254
You do things in life --

00:13:22.278 --> 00:13:25.678
it's just nothing happens
if you always do things the same way.

00:13:26.158 --> 00:13:31.254
But my method is to do things
I'm afraid of, the things I fear,

00:13:31.278 --> 00:13:32.774
the things I don't know,

00:13:32.798 --> 00:13:35.654
to go to territory
that nobody's ever been.

00:13:35.678 --> 00:13:38.534
And then also to include the failure.

00:13:38.558 --> 00:13:40.294
I think failure is important

00:13:40.318 --> 00:13:44.054
because if you go,
if you experiment, you can fail.

00:13:44.078 --> 00:13:46.734
If you don't go into that area
and you don't fail,

00:13:46.758 --> 00:13:49.758
you are actually repeating yourself
over and over again.

00:13:50.278 --> 00:13:54.094
And I think that human beings
right now need a change,

00:13:54.118 --> 00:13:58.214
and the only change to be made
is a personal level change.

00:13:58.238 --> 00:14:00.814
You have to make the change on yourself.

00:14:00.838 --> 00:14:03.334
Because the only way
to change consciousness

00:14:03.358 --> 00:14:05.374
and to change the world around us,

00:14:05.398 --> 00:14:07.094
is to start with yourself.

00:14:07.118 --> 00:14:09.614
It's so easy to criticize
how it's different,

00:14:09.638 --> 00:14:11.781
the things in the world
and they're not right,

00:14:11.805 --> 00:14:15.054
and the governments are corrupted
and there's hunger in the world

00:14:15.078 --> 00:14:18.534
and there's wars -- the killing.

00:14:18.558 --> 00:14:21.134
But what we do on the personal level --

00:14:21.158 --> 00:14:24.118
what is our contribution
to this whole thing?

00:14:24.918 --> 00:14:28.014
Can you turn to your neighbor,
the one you don't know,

00:14:28.038 --> 00:14:32.158
and look at them for two full minutes
in their eyes, right now?

00:14:33.798 --> 00:14:38.294
(Chatter)

00:14:38.318 --> 00:14:42.214
I'm asking two minutes
of your time, that's so little.

00:14:42.238 --> 00:14:47.574
Breathe slowly, don't try to blink,
don't be self-conscious.

00:14:47.598 --> 00:14:49.214
Be relaxed.

00:14:49.238 --> 00:14:54.638
And just look a complete
stranger in your eyes, in his eyes.

00:14:55.478 --> 00:14:57.238
(Silence)

00:15:34.998 --> 00:15:36.638
Thank you for trusting me.

00:15:37.678 --> 00:15:44.518
(Applause)

00:15:45.318 --> 00:15:46.918
Chris Anderson: Thank you.

00:15:48.318 --> 00:15:49.998
Thank you so much.

title: How we're growing baby corals to rebuild reefs
transcript: What was the most difficult job you ever did? Was it working in the sun? Was it working to provide food for a family or a community? Was it working days and nights trying to protect lives and property? Was it working alone or working on a project that wasn't guaranteed to succeed, but that might improve human health or save a life? Was it working to build something, create something, make a work of art? Was it work for which you were never sure you were fully understood or appreciated? The people in our communities who do these jobs deserve our attention, our love and our deepest support.But people aren't the only ones in our communities who do these difficult jobs. These jobs are also done by the plants, the animals and the ecosystems on our planet, including the ecosystems I study: the tropical coral reefs. Coral reefs are farmers. They provide food, income and food security for hundreds of millions of people around the world. Coral reefs are security guards. The structures that they build protect our shorelines from storm surge and waves, and the biological systems that they house filter the water and make it safer for us to work and play. Coral reefs are chemists. The molecules that we're discovering on coral reefs are increasingly important in the search for new antibiotics and new cancer drugs. And coral reefs are artists. The structures that they build are some of the most beautiful things on planet Earth. And this beauty is the foundation of the tourism industry in many countries with few or little other natural resources.So for all of these reasons, all of these ecosystem services, economists estimate the value of the world's coral reefs in the hundreds of billions of dollars per year. And yet despite all that hard work being done for us and all that wealth that we gain, we have done almost everything we possibly could to destroy that. We have taken the fish out of the oceans and we have added in fertilizer, sewage, diseases, oil, pollution, sediments. We have trampled the reefs physically with our boats, our fins, our bulldozers, and we have changed the chemistry of the entire sea, warmed the waters and made storms worse. And these would all be bad on their own, but these threats magnify each other and compound one another and make each other worse.I'll give you an example. Where I live and work, in Curaçao, a tropical storm went by a few years ago. And on the eastern end of the island, where the reefs are intact and thriving, you could barely tell a tropical storm had passed. But in town, where corals had died from overfishing, from pollution, the tropical storm picked up the dead corals and used them as bludgeons to kill the corals that were left. This is a coral that I studied during my PhD — I got to know it quite well. And after this storm took off half of its tissue, it became infested with algae, the algae overgrew the tissue and that coral died. This magnification of threats, this compounding of factors is what Jeremy Jackson describes as the "slippery slope to slime." It's hardly even a metaphor because many of our reefs now are literally bacteria and algae and slime.Now, this is the part of the talk where you may expect me to launch into my plea for us to all save the coral reefs. But I have a confession to make: that phrase drives me nuts. Whether I see it in a tweet, in a news headline or the glossy pages of a conservation brochure, that phrase bothers me, because we as conservationists have been sounding the alarms about the death of coral reefs for decades. And yet, almost everyone I meet, no matter how educated, is not sure what a coral is or where they come from. How would we get someone to care about the world's coral reefs when it's an abstract thing they can barely understand? If they don't understand what a coral is or where it comes from, or how funny or interesting or beautiful it is, why would we expect them to care about saving them?So let's change that. Corals are born in a number of different ways, but most often by mass spawning: all of the individuals of a single species on one night a year, releasing all the eggs they've made that year into the water column, packaged into bundles with sperm cells. And those bundles go to the surface of the ocean and break apart. And hopefully — hopefully — at the surface of the ocean, they meet the eggs and sperm from other corals. And that is why you need lots of corals on a coral reef — so that all of their eggs can meet their match at the surface. When they're fertilized, they do what any other animal egg does: divides in half again and again and again. Taking these photos under the microscope every year is one of my favorite and most magical moments of the year. At the end of all this cell division, they turn into a swimming larva — a little tiny blob of fat the size of a poppy seed, but with all of the sensory systems that we have. They can sense color and light, textures, chemicals, pH. They can even feel pressure waves; they can hear sound. And they use those talents to search the bottom of the reef for a place to attach and live the rest of their lives.So imagine finding a place where you would live the rest of your life when you were just two days old. They attach in the place they find most suitable, they build a skeleton underneath themselves, they build a mouth and tentacles, and then they begin the difficult work of building the world's coral reefs. One coral polyp will divide itself again and again and again, leaving a limestone skeleton underneath itself and growing up toward the sun. Given hundreds of years and many species, what you get is a massive limestone structure that can be seen from space in many cases, covered by a thin skin of these hardworking animals. Now, there are only a few hundred species of corals on the planet, maybe 1,000. But these systems house millions and millions of other species, and that diversity is what stabilizes the systems, and it's where we're finding our new medicines. It's how we find new sources of food. I'm lucky enough to work on the island of Curaçao, where we still have reefs that look like this. But, indeed, much of the Caribbean and much of our world is much more like this.Scientists have studied in increasing detail the loss of the world's coral reefs, and they have documented with increasing certainty the causes. Because even in some of these reefs that we probably could have written off long ago, we sometimes see baby corals arrive and survive anyway. And we're starting to think that baby corals may have the ability to adjust to some of the conditions that the adults couldn't. They may be able to adjust ever so slightly more readily to this human planet. We are limited by the space on our bench, the number of hands in the lab and the number of coffees we can drink in any given hour.Now, compare that to our other crises and our other areas of concern as a society. We have advanced medical technology, we have defense technology, we have scientific technology, we even have advanced technology for art. But our technology for conservation is behind. protect our shorelines

that they house filter the water

00:01:24.491 --> 00:01:26.890
and make it safer for us to work and play.

00:01:33.889 --> 00:01:37.462

00:09:12.797 --> 00:09:16.086
This is one of my favorite corals,
and always has been:

00:09:16.110 --> 00:09:18.599
dendrogyra cylindrus, the pillar coral.

00:09:19.031 --> 00:09:21.938
I love it because it makes
this ridiculous shape,

00:09:21.962 --> 00:09:25.105
because its tentacles
are fat and look fuzzy

00:09:25.129 --> 00:09:26.569
and because it's rare.

00:09:26.593 --> 00:09:29.067
Finding one of these on a reef is a treat.

00:09:29.653 --> 00:09:30.805
In fact, it's so rare,

00:09:30.829 --> 00:09:33.345
that last year it was listed
as a threatened species

00:09:33.369 --> 00:09:35.224
on the endangered species list.

00:09:35.248 --> 00:09:38.555
And this was in part because
in over 30 years of research surveys,

00:09:38.579 --> 00:09:42.435
scientists had never found
a baby pillar coral.

00:09:42.761 --> 00:09:45.175
We weren't even sure
if they could still reproduce,

00:09:45.199 --> 00:09:47.198
or if they were still reproducing.

00:09:47.718 --> 00:09:50.387
So four years ago, we started
following these at night

00:09:50.411 --> 00:09:54.700
and watching to see if we could
figure out when they spawn in Curaçao.

00:09:55.950 --> 00:09:58.638
We got some good tips
from our colleagues in Florida,

00:09:58.662 --> 00:10:02.720
who had seen one in 2007, one in 2008,

00:10:02.744 --> 00:10:05.417
and eventually we figured out
when they spawn in Curaçao

00:10:05.441 --> 00:10:06.800
and we caught it.

00:10:06.824 --> 00:10:09.522
Here's a female on the left
with some eggs in her tissue,

00:10:09.546 --> 00:10:11.466
about to release them into the seawater.

00:10:11.490 --> 00:10:14.127
And here's a male
on the right, releasing sperm.

00:10:14.741 --> 00:10:18.425
We collected this, we got it
back to the lab, we got it to fertilize

00:10:18.449 --> 00:10:21.733
and we got baby pillar corals
swimming in our lab.

00:10:22.478 --> 00:10:25.018
Thanks to the work
of our scientific aunts and uncles,

00:10:25.042 --> 00:10:27.899
and thanks to the 10 years of practice
we've had in Curaçao

00:10:27.923 --> 00:10:30.116
at raising other coral species,

00:10:30.140 --> 00:10:34.015
we got some of those larvae
to go through the rest of the process

00:10:34.039 --> 00:10:35.691
and settle and attach,

00:10:35.715 --> 00:10:38.426
and turn into metamorphosed corals.

00:10:38.450 --> 00:10:43.194
So this is the first pillar coral baby
that anyone ever saw.

00:10:43.744 --> 00:10:49.164
(Applause)

00:10:49.188 --> 00:10:52.362
And I have to say --
if you think baby pandas are cute,

00:10:52.386 --> 00:10:53.624
this is cuter.

00:10:53.648 --> 00:10:55.631
(Laughter)

00:10:56.194 --> 00:10:59.318
So we're starting to figure out
the secrets to this process,

00:10:59.342 --> 00:11:02.690
the secrets of coral reproduction
and how we might help them.

00:11:03.047 --> 00:11:04.895
And this is true all around the world;

00:11:04.919 --> 00:11:07.811
scientists are figuring out new ways
to handle their embryos,

00:11:07.835 --> 00:11:08.993
to get them to settle,

00:11:09.017 --> 00:11:13.551
maybe even figuring out the methods
to preserve them at low temperatures,

00:11:13.575 --> 00:11:16.691
so that we can preserve
their genetic diversity

00:11:16.715 --> 00:11:18.597
and work with them more often.

00:11:18.942 --> 00:11:21.815
But this is still so low-tech.

00:11:22.218 --> 00:11:27.233
We are limited by the space on our bench,
the number of hands in the lab

00:11:27.257 --> 00:11:31.427
and the number of coffees
we can drink in any given hour.

00:11:32.063 --> 00:11:34.556
Now, compare that to our other crises

00:11:34.580 --> 00:11:37.793
and our other areas
of concern as a society.

00:11:38.223 --> 00:11:41.875
We have advanced medical technology,
we have defense technology,

00:11:41.899 --> 00:11:43.496
we have scientific technology,

00:11:43.520 --> 00:11:45.946
we even have advanced technology for art.

00:11:45.970 --> 00:11:51.367
But our technology
for conservation is behind.

00:11:52.980 --> 00:11:56.125
Think back to the most
difficult job you ever did.

00:11:56.620 --> 00:11:59.855
Many of you would say
it was being a parent.

00:12:00.272 --> 00:12:01.929
My mother described being a parent

00:12:01.953 --> 00:12:06.164
as something that makes your life
far more amazing and far more difficult

00:12:06.188 --> 00:12:08.718
than you could've ever possibly imagined.

00:12:08.742 --> 00:12:12.767
I've been trying to help corals
become parents for over 10 years now.

00:12:13.521 --> 00:12:15.691
And watching the wonder of life

00:12:15.715 --> 00:12:19.742
has certainly filled me with amazement
to the core of my soul.

00:12:19.766 --> 00:12:23.248
But I've also seen how difficult
it is for them to become parents.

00:12:24.408 --> 00:12:26.588
The pillar corals spawned
again two weeks ago,

00:12:26.612 --> 00:12:29.501
and we collected their eggs
and brought them back to the lab.

00:12:29.525 --> 00:12:31.583
And here you see one embryo dividing,

00:12:31.607 --> 00:12:34.481
alongside 14 eggs that didn't fertilize

00:12:34.505 --> 00:12:36.165
and will blow up.

00:12:36.490 --> 00:12:39.225
They'll be infected with bacteria,
they will explode

00:12:39.249 --> 00:12:42.991
and those bacteria will threaten
the life of this one embryo

00:12:43.015 --> 00:12:45.145
that has a chance.

00:12:45.534 --> 00:12:48.497
We don't know if it was our handling
methods that went wrong

00:12:48.521 --> 00:12:50.148
and we don't know

00:12:50.172 --> 00:12:55.090
if it was just this coral on this reef,
always suffering from low fertility.

00:12:55.540 --> 00:12:56.845
Whatever the cause,

00:12:56.869 --> 00:13:01.386
we have much more work to do
before we can use baby corals

00:13:01.410 --> 00:13:06.352
to grow or fix or, yes,
maybe save coral reefs.

00:13:07.408 --> 00:13:10.479
So never mind that they're worth
hundreds of billions of dollars.

00:13:10.503 --> 00:13:15.930
Coral reefs are hardworking animals
and plants and microbes and fungi.

00:13:15.954 --> 00:13:19.574
They're providing us with art
and food and medicine.

00:13:19.970 --> 00:13:23.546
And we almost took out
an entire generation of corals.

00:13:23.933 --> 00:13:27.974
But a few made it anyway,
despite our best efforts,

00:13:27.998 --> 00:13:31.130
and now it's time for us to thank them
for the work they did

00:13:31.154 --> 00:13:35.979
and give them every chance they have
to raise the coral reefs of the future,

00:13:36.003 --> 00:13:37.491
their coral babies.

00:13:37.515 --> 00:13:38.710
Thank you so much.

00:13:38.734 --> 00:13:44.929
(Applause)

title: The US needs paid family leave -- for the sake of its future
transcript: What does a working mother look like? If you ask the Internet, this is what you'll be told. Never mind that this is what you'll actually produce if you attempt to work at a computer with a baby on your lap.(Laughter)But no, this isn't a working mother. You'll notice a theme in these photos. We'll look at a lot of them. That theme is amazing natural lighting, which, as we all know, is the hallmark of every American workplace.There are thousands of images like these. Just put the term "working mother" into any Google image search engine, stock photo site. They're all over the Internet, they're topping blog posts and news pieces, and I've become kind of obsessed with them and the lie that they tell us and the comfort that they give us, that when it comes to new working motherhood in America, everything's fine.But it's not fine. As a country, we are sending millions of women back to work every year, incredibly and kind of horrifically soon after they give birth. That's a moral problem but today I'm also going to tell you why it's an economic problem.I got so annoyed and obsessed with the unreality of these images, which look nothing like my life, that I recently decided to shoot and star in a parody series of stock photos that I hoped the world would start to use just showing the really awkward reality of going back to work when your baby's food source is attached to your body. I'm just going to show you two of them.(Laughter)Nothing says "Give that girl a promotion" like leaking breast milk through your dress during a presentation. You'll notice that there's no baby in this photo, because that's not how this works, not for most working mothers.Did you know, and this will ruin your day, that every time a toilet is flushed, its contents are aerosolized and they'll stay airborne for hours? And yet, for many new working mothers, this is the only place during the day that they can find to make food for their newborn babies.I put these things, a whole dozen of them, into the world. I wanted to make a point. I didn't know what I was also doing was opening a door, because now, total strangers from all walks of life write to me all the time just to tell me what it's like for them to go back to work within days or weeks of having a baby. I'm going to share 10 of their stories with you today. They are totally real, some of them are very raw, and not one of them looks anything like this.Here's the first. "I was an active duty service member at a federal prison. I returned to work after the maximum allowed eight weeks for my C-section. A male coworker was annoyed that I had been out on 'vacation,' so he intentionally opened the door on me while I was pumping breast milk and stood in the doorway with inmates in the hallway."Most of the stories that these women, total strangers, send to me now, are not actually even about breastfeeding.A woman wrote to me to say, "I gave birth to twins and went back to work after seven unpaid weeks. Emotionally, I was a wreck. Physically, I had a severe hemorrhage during labor, and major tearing, so I could barely get up, sit or walk. My employer told me I wasn't allowed to use my available vacation days because it was budget season."I've come to believe that we can't look situations like these in the eye because then we'd be horrified, and if we get horrified then we have to do something about it. So we choose to look at, and believe, this image. I don't really know what's going on in this picture, because I find it weird and slightly creepy.(Laughter)Like, what is she doing? But I know what it tells us. It tells us that everything's fine. This working mother, all working mothers and all of their babies, are fine. There's nothing to see here. And anyway, women have made a choice, so none of it's even our problem.I want to break this choice thing down into two parts. The first choice says that women have chosen to work. So, that's not true. Today in America, women make up 47 percent of the workforce, and in 40 percent of American households a woman is the sole or primary breadwinner. Our paid work is a part, a huge part, of the engine of this economy, and it is essential for the engines of our families. On a national level, our paid work is not optional.Choice number two says that women are choosing to have babies, so women alone should bear the consequences of those choices. You know, that's one of those things that when you hear it in passing, can sound correct. I didn't make you have a baby. I certainly wasn't there when that happened. But that stance ignores a fundamental truth, which is that our procreation on a national scale is not optional. The babies that women, many of them working women, are having today, will one day fill our workforce, protect our shores, make up our tax base. Our procreation on a national scale is not optional. These aren't choices. We need women to work. We need working women to have babies. So we should make doing those things at the same time at least palatable, right?OK, this is pop quiz time: what percentage of working women in America do you think have no access to paid maternity leave? 88 percent. 88 percent of working mothers will not get one minute of paid leave after they have a baby.So now you're thinking about unpaid leave. It exists in America. It's called FMLA. It does not work. Because of the way it's structured, all kinds of exceptions, half of new mothers are ineligible for it.Here's what that looks like. "We adopted our son. When I got the call, the day he was born, I had to take off work. I had not been there long enough to qualify for FMLA, so I wasn't eligible for unpaid leave. When I took time off to meet my newborn son, I lost my job."These corporate stock photos hide another reality, another layer. Of those who do have access to just that unpaid leave, most women can't afford to take much of it at all. A nurse told me, "I didn't qualify for short-term disability because my pregnancy was considered a preexisting condition. We used up all of our tax returns and half of our savings during my six unpaid weeks. We just couldn't manage any longer. Physically it was hard, but emotionally it was worse. I struggled for months being away from my son."So this decision to go back to work so early, it's a rational economic decision driven by family finances, but it's often physically horrific because putting a human into the world is messy.A waitress told me, "With my first baby, I was back at work five weeks postpartum. With my second, I had to have major surgery after giving birth, so I waited until six weeks to go back. I had third degree tears."23 percent of new working mothers in America will be back on the job within two weeks of giving birth."I worked as a bartender and cook, average of 75 hours a week while pregnant. I had to return to work before my baby was a month old, working 60 hours a week. One of my coworkers was only able to afford 10 days off with her baby."Of course, this isn't just a scenario with economic and physical implications. Childbirth is, and always will be, an enormous psychological event.A teacher told me, "I returned to work eight weeks after my son was born. I already suffer from anxiety, but the panic attacks I had prior to returning to work were unbearable."Statistically speaking, the shorter a woman's leave after having a baby, the more likely she will be to suffer from postpartum mood disorders like depression and anxiety, and among many potential consequences of those disorders, suicide is the second most common cause of death in a woman's first year postpartum.Heads up that this next story — I've never met this woman, but I find it hard to get through."I feel tremendous grief and rage that I lost an essential, irreplaceable and formative time with my son. Labor and delivery left me feeling absolutely broken. For months, all I remember is the screaming: colic, they said. On the inside, I was drowning. Every morning, I asked myself how much longer I could do it. I was allowed to bring my baby to work. I closed my office door while I rocked and shushed and begged him to stop screaming so I wouldn't get in trouble. I hid behind that office door every damn day and cried while he screamed. I cried in the bathroom while I washed out the pump equipment. Every day, I cried all the way to work and all the way home again. I promised my boss that the work I didn't get done during the day, I'd make up at night from home. I thought, there's just something wrong with me that I can't swing this."So those are the mothers. What of the babies? As a country, do we care about the millions of babies born every year to working mothers? I say we don't, not until they're of working and tax-paying and military-serving age. We tell them we'll see them in 18 years, and getting there is kind of on them. One of the reasons I know this is that babies whose mothers have 12 or more weeks at home with them are more likely to get their vaccinations and their well checks in their first year, so those babies are more protected from deadly and disabling diseases. But those things are hidden behind images like this.America has a message for new mothers who work and for their babies. Whatever time you get together, you should be grateful for it, and you're an inconvenience to the economy and to your employers. That narrative of gratitude runs through a lot of the stories I hear.A woman told me, "I went back at eight weeks after my C-section because my husband was out of work. Without me, my daughter had failure to thrive. She wouldn't take a bottle. She started losing weight. Thankfully, my manager was very understanding. He let my mom bring my baby, who was on oxygen and a monitor, four times a shift so I could nurse her."There's a little club of countries in the world that offer no national paid leave to new mothers. Care to guess who they are? The first eight make up eight million in total population. They are Papua New Guinea, Suriname and the tiny island nations of Micronesia, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Niue, Palau and Tonga. Number nine is the United States of America, with 320 million people. Oh, that's it. That's the end of the list. Every other economy on the planet has found a way to make some level of national paid leave work for the people doing the work of the future of those countries, but we say, "We couldn't possibly do that." We say that the market will solve this problem, and then we cheer when corporations offer even more paid leave to the women who are already the highest-educated and highest-paid among us. Remember that 88 percent? Those middle- and low-income women are not going to participate in that. We know that there are staggering economic, financial, physical and emotional costs to this approach. We have decided — decided, not an accident, to pass these costs directly on to working mothers and their babies. We know the price tag is higher for low-income women, therefore disproportionately for women of color. We pass them on anyway.All of this is to America's shame. But it's also to America's risk. Because what would happen if all of these individual so-called choices to have babies started to turn into individual choices not to have babies.One woman told me, "New motherhood is hard. It shouldn't be traumatic. When we talk about expanding our family now, we focus on how much time I would have to care for myself and a new baby. If we were to have to do it again the same way as with our first, we might stick with one kid."The birthrate needed in America to keep the population stable is 2.1 live births per woman. In America today, we are at 1.86. We need women to have babies, and we are actively disincentivizing working women from doing that. What would happen to work force, to innovation, to GDP, if one by one, the working mothers of this country were to decide that they can't bear to do this thing more than once?I'm here today with only one idea worth spreading, and you've guessed what it is. It is long since time for the most powerful country on Earth to offer national paid leave to the people doing the work of the future of this country and to the babies who represent that future. Childbirth is a public good. This leave should be state-subsidized. It should have no exceptions for small businesses, length of employment or entrepreneurs. It should be able to be shared between partners. I've talked today a lot about mothers, but co-parents matter on so many levels.Not one more woman should have to go back to work while she is hobbling and bleeding. Not one more family should have to drain their savings account to buy a few days of rest and recovery and bonding. Not one more fragile infant should have to go directly from the incubator to day care because his parents have used up all of their meager time sitting in the NICU. Not one more working family should be told that the collision of their work, their needed work and their needed parenthood, is their problem alone.The catch is that when this is happening to a new family, it is consuming, and a family with a new baby is more financially vulnerable than they've ever been before, so that new mother cannot afford to speak up on her own behalf. But all of us have voices. I am done, done having babies, and you might be pre-baby, you might be post-baby, you might be no baby. It should not matter. We have to stop framing this as a mother's issue, or even a women's issue. This is an American issue.We need to stop buying the lie that these images tell us. We need to stop being comforted by them. We need to question why we're told that this can't work when we see it work everywhere all over the world. We need to recognize that this American reality is to our dishonor and to our peril. Because this is not, this is not, and this is not what a working mother looks like.(Applause)

So we choose to look at,
and believe, this image.

00:03:53.198 --> 00:03:55.654
I don't really know
what's going on in this picture,

00:03:55.678 --> 00:03:58.334
because I find it weird
and slightly creepy.

00:03:58.358 --> 00:03:59.774
(Laughter)

00:03:59.798 --> 00:04:01.014
Like, what is she doing?

00:04:01.038 --> 00:04:05.054
But I know what it tells us.

00:04:05.078 --> 00:04:07.614
It tells us that everything's fine.

00:04:07.638 --> 00:04:11.374
This working mother, all working mothers
and all of their babies, are fine.

00:04:11.398 --> 00:04:13.374
There's nothing to see here.

00:04:13.398 --> 00:04:16.814
And anyway, women have made a choice,

00:04:16.838 --> 00:04:19.134
so none of it's even our problem.

00:04:19.158 --> 00:04:22.094
I want to break this choice thing
down into two parts.

00:04:22.118 --> 00:04:25.734
The first choice says
that women have chosen to work.

00:04:25.758 --> 00:04:27.974
So, that's not true.

00:04:27.998 --> 00:04:33.213
Today in America, women make up
47 percent of the workforce,

00:04:33.237 --> 00:04:35.214
and in 40 percent of American households

00:04:35.238 --> 00:04:38.774
a woman is the sole
or primary breadwinner.

00:04:38.798 --> 00:04:43.334
Our paid work is a part, a huge part,
of the engine of this economy,

00:04:43.358 --> 00:04:46.134
and it is essential
for the engines of our families.

00:04:46.158 --> 00:04:50.334
On a national level,
our paid work is not optional.

00:04:50.358 --> 00:04:53.294
Choice number two says that women
are choosing to have babies,

00:04:53.318 --> 00:04:56.438
so women alone should bear
the consequences of those choices.

00:04:58.158 --> 00:04:59.934
You know, that's one of those things

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.414
that when you hear it in passing,
can sound correct.

00:05:02.438 --> 00:05:03.867
I didn't make you have a baby.

00:05:03.891 --> 00:05:05.974
I certainly wasn't there
when that happened.

00:05:05.998 --> 00:05:12.014
But that stance
ignores a fundamental truth,

00:05:12.038 --> 00:05:16.934
which is that our procreation
on a national scale is not optional.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:21.454
The babies that women, many of them
working women, are having today,

00:05:21.478 --> 00:05:24.694
will one day fill our workforce,
protect our shores,

00:05:24.718 --> 00:05:26.534
make up our tax base.

00:05:26.558 --> 00:05:30.734
Our procreation
on a national scale is not optional.

00:05:30.758 --> 00:05:32.134
These aren't choices.

00:05:32.158 --> 00:05:35.974
We need women to work.
We need working women to have babies.

00:05:35.998 --> 00:05:38.475
So we should make
doing those things at the same time

00:05:38.499 --> 00:05:39.899
at least palatable, right?

00:05:40.918 --> 00:05:43.614
OK, this is pop quiz time:

00:05:43.638 --> 00:05:46.574
what percentage of working
women in America do you think

00:05:46.598 --> 00:05:50.118
have no access to paid maternity leave?

00:05:51.398 --> 00:05:52.598
88 percent.

00:05:53.831 --> 00:05:56.974
88 percent of working mothers
will not get one minute of paid leave

00:05:56.998 --> 00:05:58.614
after they have a baby.

00:05:58.638 --> 00:06:02.254
So now you're thinking about unpaid leave.

00:06:02.278 --> 00:06:05.854
It exists in America.
It's called FMLA. It does not work.

00:06:05.878 --> 00:06:08.854
Because of the way it's structured,
all kinds of exceptions,

00:06:08.878 --> 00:06:12.894
half of new mothers are ineligible for it.

00:06:12.918 --> 00:06:14.252
Here's what that looks like.

00:06:16.278 --> 00:06:18.094
"We adopted our son.

00:06:18.118 --> 00:06:22.334
When I got the call, the day he was born,
I had to take off work.

00:06:22.358 --> 00:06:25.494
I had not been there long enough
to qualify for FMLA,

00:06:25.518 --> 00:06:28.254
so I wasn't eligible for unpaid leave.

00:06:28.278 --> 00:06:30.694
When I took time off
to meet my newborn son,

00:06:30.718 --> 00:06:31.918
I lost my job."

00:06:33.798 --> 00:06:38.694
These corporate stock photos
hide another reality, another layer.

00:06:38.718 --> 00:06:42.334
Of those who do have access
to just that unpaid leave,

00:06:42.358 --> 00:06:45.534
most women can't afford
to take much of it at all.

00:06:45.558 --> 00:06:49.054
A nurse told me, "I didn't qualify
for short-term disability

00:06:49.078 --> 00:06:53.134
because my pregnancy
was considered a preexisting condition.

00:06:53.158 --> 00:06:55.825
We used up all of our tax returns
and half of our savings

00:06:55.849 --> 00:06:57.694
during my six unpaid weeks.

00:06:57.718 --> 00:06:59.454
We just couldn't manage any longer.

00:06:59.478 --> 00:07:02.014
Physically it was hard,
but emotionally it was worse.

00:07:02.038 --> 00:07:05.014
I struggled for months
being away from my son."

00:07:05.038 --> 00:07:07.934
So this decision
to go back to work so early,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:12.134
it's a rational economic decision
driven by family finances,

00:07:12.158 --> 00:07:14.414
but it's often physically horrific

00:07:14.438 --> 00:07:17.974
because putting a human
into the world is messy.

00:07:17.998 --> 00:07:19.414
A waitress told me,

00:07:19.438 --> 00:07:22.974
"With my first baby, I was back
at work five weeks postpartum.

00:07:22.998 --> 00:07:26.054
With my second, I had to have
major surgery after giving birth,

00:07:26.078 --> 00:07:29.094
so I waited until six weeks to go back.

00:07:29.118 --> 00:07:31.198
I had third degree tears."

00:07:32.838 --> 00:07:35.894
23 percent of new
working mothers in America

00:07:35.918 --> 00:07:40.518
will be back on the job
within two weeks of giving birth.

00:07:42.278 --> 00:07:46.934
"I worked as a bartender and cook,
average of 75 hours a week while pregnant.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.574
I had to return to work
before my baby was a month old,

00:07:49.598 --> 00:07:51.614
working 60 hours a week.

00:07:51.638 --> 00:07:56.694
One of my coworkers was only able
to afford 10 days off with her baby."

00:07:56.718 --> 00:08:00.894
Of course, this isn't just a scenario
with economic and physical implications.

00:08:00.918 --> 00:08:06.094
Childbirth is, and always will be,
an enormous psychological event.

00:08:06.118 --> 00:08:08.214
A teacher told me,

00:08:08.238 --> 00:08:11.214
"I returned to work
eight weeks after my son was born.

00:08:11.238 --> 00:08:13.134
I already suffer from anxiety,

00:08:13.158 --> 00:08:18.254
but the panic attacks I had prior
to returning to work were unbearable."

00:08:18.278 --> 00:08:20.374
Statistically speaking,

00:08:20.398 --> 00:08:23.094
the shorter a woman's leave
after having a baby,

00:08:23.118 --> 00:08:26.334
the more likely she will be to suffer
from postpartum mood disorders

00:08:26.358 --> 00:08:28.454
like depression and anxiety,

00:08:28.478 --> 00:08:32.494
and among many potential
consequences of those disorders,

00:08:32.518 --> 00:08:35.654
suicide is the second
most common cause of death

00:08:35.678 --> 00:08:37.558
in a woman's first year postpartum.

00:08:39.198 --> 00:08:40.774
Heads up that this next story --

00:08:40.798 --> 00:08:45.374
I've never met this woman,
but I find it hard to get through.

00:08:45.398 --> 00:08:49.574
"I feel tremendous grief and rage
that I lost an essential,

00:08:49.598 --> 00:08:53.454
irreplaceable and formative
time with my son.

00:08:53.478 --> 00:08:56.894
Labor and delivery
left me feeling absolutely broken.

00:08:56.918 --> 00:09:01.574
For months, all I remember
is the screaming: colic, they said.

00:09:01.598 --> 00:09:03.734
On the inside, I was drowning.

00:09:03.758 --> 00:09:07.454
Every morning, I asked myself
how much longer I could do it.

00:09:07.478 --> 00:09:10.654
I was allowed to bring my baby to work.

00:09:10.678 --> 00:09:13.814
I closed my office door
while I rocked and shushed

00:09:13.838 --> 00:09:17.334
and begged him to stop screaming
so I wouldn't get in trouble.

00:09:17.358 --> 00:09:19.414
I hid behind that office door
every damn day

00:09:19.438 --> 00:09:21.374
and cried while he screamed.

00:09:21.398 --> 00:09:25.054
I cried in the bathroom
while I washed out the pump equipment.

00:09:25.078 --> 00:09:28.214
Every day, I cried all the way to work
and all the way home again.

00:09:28.238 --> 00:09:31.374
I promised my boss that the work
I didn't get done during the day,

00:09:31.398 --> 00:09:33.054
I'd make up at night from home.

00:09:33.078 --> 00:09:36.878
I thought, there's just something
wrong with me that I can't swing this."

00:09:38.478 --> 00:09:41.094
So those are the mothers.

00:09:41.118 --> 00:09:42.894
What of the babies?

00:09:42.918 --> 00:09:45.414
As a country, do we care
about the millions of babies

00:09:45.438 --> 00:09:47.294
born every year to working mothers?

00:09:47.318 --> 00:09:48.654
I say we don't,

00:09:48.678 --> 00:09:52.134
not until they're of working
and tax-paying and military-serving age.

00:09:52.158 --> 00:09:54.063
We tell them we'll see them in 18 years,

00:09:54.087 --> 00:09:55.849
and getting there is kind of on them.

00:09:57.812 --> 00:10:00.574
One of the reasons I know this
is that babies whose mothers

00:10:00.598 --> 00:10:02.894
have 12 or more weeks at home with them

00:10:02.918 --> 00:10:06.894
are more likely to get their vaccinations
and their well checks in their first year,

00:10:06.918 --> 00:10:11.614
so those babies are more protected
from deadly and disabling diseases.

00:10:11.638 --> 00:10:14.878
But those things are hidden
behind images like this.

00:10:18.238 --> 00:10:23.734
America has a message for new mothers
who work and for their babies.

00:10:23.758 --> 00:10:27.534
Whatever time you get together,
you should be grateful for it,

00:10:27.558 --> 00:10:30.294
and you're an inconvenience

00:10:30.318 --> 00:10:33.334
to the economy and to your employers.

00:10:33.358 --> 00:10:37.894
That narrative of gratitude
runs through a lot of the stories I hear.

00:10:37.918 --> 00:10:39.574
A woman told me,

00:10:39.598 --> 00:10:41.774
"I went back at eight weeks
after my C-section

00:10:41.798 --> 00:10:43.614
because my husband was out of work.

00:10:43.638 --> 00:10:46.374
Without me, my daughter
had failure to thrive.

00:10:46.398 --> 00:10:47.694
She wouldn't take a bottle.

00:10:47.718 --> 00:10:49.334
She started losing weight.

00:10:49.358 --> 00:10:52.174
Thankfully, my manager
was very understanding.

00:10:52.198 --> 00:10:53.734
He let my mom bring my baby,

00:10:53.758 --> 00:10:56.054
who was on oxygen and a monitor,

00:10:56.078 --> 00:10:58.198
