four times a shift so I could nurse her."

00:10:59.918 --> 00:11:03.294
There's a little club
of countries in the world

00:11:03.318 --> 00:11:07.174
that offer no national
paid leave to new mothers.

00:11:07.198 --> 00:11:09.654
Care to guess who they are?

00:11:09.678 --> 00:11:13.614
The first eight make up eight million
in total population.

00:11:13.638 --> 00:11:17.134
They are Papua New Guinea,
Suriname and the tiny island nations

00:11:17.158 --> 00:11:23.374
of Micronesia, Marshall Islands,
Nauru, Niue, Palau and Tonga.

00:11:23.398 --> 00:11:25.774
Number nine is
the United States of America,

00:11:25.798 --> 00:11:27.878
with 320 million people.

00:11:29.278 --> 00:11:31.614
Oh, that's it.

00:11:31.638 --> 00:11:34.214
That's the end of the list.

00:11:34.238 --> 00:11:35.854
Every other economy on the planet

00:11:35.878 --> 00:11:39.774
has found a way to make some level
of national paid leave work

00:11:39.798 --> 00:11:42.774
for the people doing the work
of the future of those countries,

00:11:42.798 --> 00:11:46.854
but we say,
"We couldn't possibly do that."

00:11:46.878 --> 00:11:49.374
We say that the market
will solve this problem,

00:11:49.398 --> 00:11:53.734
and then we cheer when corporations
offer even more paid leave to the women

00:11:53.758 --> 00:11:57.014
who are already the highest-educated
and highest-paid among us.

00:11:57.038 --> 00:11:58.854
Remember that 88 percent?

00:11:58.878 --> 00:12:02.718
Those middle- and low-income women
are not going to participate in that.

00:12:03.838 --> 00:12:09.294
We know that there are staggering
economic, financial, physical

00:12:09.318 --> 00:12:11.854
and emotional costs to this approach.

00:12:11.878 --> 00:12:15.894
We have decided --
decided, not an accident,

00:12:15.918 --> 00:12:19.854
to pass these costs directly
on to working mothers and their babies.

00:12:19.878 --> 00:12:22.534
We know the price tag is higher
for low-income women,

00:12:22.558 --> 00:12:25.334
therefore disproportionately
for women of color.

00:12:25.358 --> 00:12:27.814
We pass them on anyway.

00:12:27.838 --> 00:12:30.454
All of this is to America's shame.

00:12:30.478 --> 00:12:34.374
But it's also to America's risk.

00:12:34.398 --> 00:12:36.294
Because what would happen

00:12:36.318 --> 00:12:40.374
if all of these individual
so-called choices to have babies

00:12:40.398 --> 00:12:44.398
started to turn into individual choices
not to have babies.

00:12:45.278 --> 00:12:46.974
One woman told me,

00:12:46.998 --> 00:12:50.254
"New motherhood is hard.
It shouldn't be traumatic.

00:12:50.278 --> 00:12:52.534
When we talk about expanding
our family now,

00:12:52.558 --> 00:12:56.854
we focus on how much time I would have
to care for myself and a new baby.

00:12:56.878 --> 00:13:00.174
If we were to have to do it again
the same way as with our first,

00:13:00.198 --> 00:13:01.838
we might stick with one kid."

00:13:03.758 --> 00:13:06.654
The birthrate needed in America
to keep the population stable

00:13:06.678 --> 00:13:08.814
is 2.1 live births per woman.

00:13:08.838 --> 00:13:12.814
In America today, we are at 1.86.

00:13:12.838 --> 00:13:15.134
We need women to have babies,

00:13:15.158 --> 00:13:19.694
and we are actively disincentivizing
working women from doing that.

00:13:19.718 --> 00:13:22.934
What would happen to work force,
to innovation, to GDP,

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:27.094
if one by one, the working mothers
of this country were to decide

00:13:27.118 --> 00:13:30.478
that they can't bear
to do this thing more than once?

00:13:31.638 --> 00:13:35.134
I'm here today with only
one idea worth spreading,

00:13:35.158 --> 00:13:37.294
and you've guessed what it is.

00:13:37.318 --> 00:13:41.014
It is long since time
for the most powerful country on Earth

00:13:41.038 --> 00:13:43.094
to offer national paid leave

00:13:43.118 --> 00:13:45.833
to the people doing the work
of the future of this country

00:13:45.857 --> 00:13:48.734
and to the babies
who represent that future.

00:13:48.758 --> 00:13:50.894
Childbirth is a public good.

00:13:50.918 --> 00:13:53.454
This leave should be state-subsidized.

00:13:53.478 --> 00:13:55.974
It should have no exceptions
for small businesses,

00:13:55.998 --> 00:13:58.454
length of employment or entrepreneurs.

00:13:58.478 --> 00:14:00.854
It should be able
to be shared between partners.

00:14:00.878 --> 00:14:02.854
I've talked today a lot about mothers,

00:14:02.878 --> 00:14:05.558
but co-parents matter on so many levels.

00:14:07.478 --> 00:14:10.574
Not one more woman
should have to go back to work

00:14:10.598 --> 00:14:13.774
while she is hobbling and bleeding.

00:14:13.798 --> 00:14:17.454
Not one more family should have
to drain their savings account

00:14:17.478 --> 00:14:21.134
to buy a few days
of rest and recovery and bonding.

00:14:21.158 --> 00:14:23.454
Not one more fragile infant

00:14:23.478 --> 00:14:26.414
should have to go directly
from the incubator to day care

00:14:26.438 --> 00:14:29.134
because his parents have used up
all of their meager time

00:14:29.158 --> 00:14:30.774
sitting in the NICU.

00:14:30.798 --> 00:14:33.656
Not one more working family
should be told that the collision

00:14:33.680 --> 00:14:38.014
of their work, their needed work
and their needed parenthood,

00:14:38.038 --> 00:14:39.518
is their problem alone.

00:14:40.718 --> 00:14:45.374
The catch is that when this is happening
to a new family, it is consuming,

00:14:45.398 --> 00:14:48.174
and a family with a new baby
is more financially vulnerable

00:14:48.198 --> 00:14:49.654
than they've ever been before,

00:14:49.678 --> 00:14:53.614
so that new mother cannot afford
to speak up on her own behalf.

00:14:53.638 --> 00:14:55.854
But all of us have voices.

00:14:55.878 --> 00:14:59.454
I am done, done having babies,

00:14:59.478 --> 00:15:01.334
and you might be pre-baby,

00:15:01.358 --> 00:15:02.734
you might be post-baby,

00:15:02.758 --> 00:15:04.374
you might be no baby.

00:15:04.398 --> 00:15:06.254
It should not matter.

00:15:06.278 --> 00:15:08.694
We have to stop framing this
as a mother's issue,

00:15:08.718 --> 00:15:10.414
or even a women's issue.

00:15:10.438 --> 00:15:11.998
This is an American issue.

00:15:14.158 --> 00:15:17.654
We need to stop buying the lie
that these images tell us.

00:15:17.678 --> 00:15:19.934
We need to stop being comforted by them.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.614
We need to question
why we're told that this can't work

00:15:22.638 --> 00:15:25.934
when we see it work
everywhere all over the world.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:29.734
We need to recognize
that this American reality

00:15:29.758 --> 00:15:33.374
is to our dishonor and to our peril.

00:15:33.398 --> 00:15:35.574
Because this is not,

00:15:35.598 --> 00:15:37.214
this is not,

00:15:37.238 --> 00:15:40.718
and this is not
what a working mother looks like.

00:15:42.158 --> 00:15:43.878
(Applause)

title: How new technology helps blind people explore the world
transcript: You might think there are many things that I can't do because I cannot see. That's largely true. Actually, I just needed to have a bit of help to come up to the stage.But there is also a lot that I can do. This is me rock climbing for the first time. Actually, I love sports and I can play many sports, like swimming, skiing, skating, scuba diving, running and so on. But there is one limitation: somebody needs to help me. I want to be independent.I lost my sight at the age of 14 in a swimming pool accident. I was an active, independent teenager, and suddenly I became blind. The hardest thing for me was losing my independence. Things that until then seemed simple became almost impossible to do alone. For example, one of my challenges was textbooks. Back then, there were no personal computers, no Internet, no smartphones. So I had to ask one of my two brothers to read me textbooks, and I had to create my own books in Braille. Can you imagine? Of course, my brothers were not happy about it, and later, I noticed they were not there whenever I needed them. (Laughter) I think they tried to stay away from me. I don't blame them. I really wanted to be freed from relying on someone. That became my strong desire to ignite innovation.Jump ahead to the mid-1980s. I got to know cutting-edge technologies and I thought to myself, how come there is no computer technology to create books in Braille? These amazing technologies must be able to also help people with limitations like myself. That's the moment my innovation journey began.I started developing digital book technologies, such as a digital Braille editor, digital Braille dictionary and a digital Braille library network. Today, every student who is visually impaired can read textbooks, by using personal computers and mobile devices, in Braille or in voice. This may not surprise you, since everyone now has digital books in their tablets in 2015. But Braille went digital many years before digital books, already in the late 1980s, almost 30 years ago. Strong and specific needs of the blind people made this opportunity to create digital books way back then. And this is actually not the first time this happened, because history shows us accessibility ignites innovation. The telephone was invented while developing a communication tool for hearing impaired people. Some keyboards were also invented to help people with disabilities.Now I'm going to give you another example from my own life. In the '90s, people around me started talking about the Internet and web browsing. I remember the first time I went on the web. I was astonished. I could access newspapers at any time and every day. I could even search for any information by myself. I desperately wanted to help the blind people have access to the Internet, and I found ways to render the web into synthesized voice, which dramatically simplified the user interface.This led me to develop the Home Page Reader in 1997, first in Japanese and later, translated into 11 languages. When I developed the Home Page Reader, I got many comments from users. One that I strongly remember said, "For me, the Internet is a small window to the world."It was a revolutionary moment for the blind. The cyber world became accessible, and this technology that we created for the blind has many uses, way beyond what I imagined. It can help drivers listen to their emails or it can help you listen to a recipe while cooking.Today, I am more independent, but it is still not enough. For example, when I approached the stage just now, I needed assistance. My goal is to come up here independently. And not just here. My goal is to be able to travel and do things that are simple to you.OK, now let me show you the latest technologies. This is a smartphone app that we are working on.(Video) Electronic voice: 51 feet to the door, and keep straight.EV: Take the two doors to go out. The door is on your right.EV: Nick is approaching. Looks so happy. Chieko Asakawa: Hi, Nick!(Laughter) CA: Where are you going? You look so happy.Nick: Oh — well, my paper just got accepted. CA: That's great! Congratulations.Nick: Thanks. Wait — how'd you know it was me, and that I look happy? (Chieko and Nick laugh)Man: Hi. (Laughter) CA: Oh ... hi.EV: He is not talking to you, but on his phone.EV: Potato chips.EV: Dark chocolate with almonds.EV: You gained 5 pounds since yesterday; take apple instead of chocolate.(Laughter)EV: Approaching.EV: You arrived.CA: Now ...(Applause)Thank you.So now the app navigates me by analyzing beacon signals and smartphone sensors and permits me to move around indoor and outdoor environments all by myself. But the computer vision part that showed who is approaching, in which mood — we are still working on that part. And recognizing facial expressions is very important for me to be social.So now the fusions of technologies are ready to help me see the real world. We call this cognitive assistance. It understands our surrounding world and whispers to me in voice or sends a vibration to my fingers. Cognitive assistance will augment missing or weakened abilities — in other words, our five senses. This technology is only in an early stage, but eventually, I'll be able to find a classroom on campus, enjoy window shopping or find a nice restaurant while walking along a street. It will be amazing if I can find you on the street before you notice me. It will become my best buddy, and yours.So, this really is a great challenge. It is a challenge that needs collaboration, which is why we are creating an open community to accelerate research activities. Just this morning, we announced the open-source fundamental technologies you just saw in the video.The frontier is the real world. The blind community is exploring this technical frontier and the pathfinder. I hope to work with you to explore the new era, and the next time that I'm on this stage, through technology and innovation, I will be able to walk up here all by myself.Thank you so much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:20.014 --> 00:00:23.627
You might think there are
many things that I can't do

00:00:23.651 --> 00:00:25.562
because I cannot see.

00:00:26.284 --> 00:00:27.932
That's largely true.

00:00:27.956 --> 00:00:30.439
Actually, I just needed
to have a bit of help

00:00:30.463 --> 00:00:32.297
to come up to the stage.

00:00:32.321 --> 00:00:35.249
But there is also a lot that I can do.

00:00:35.688 --> 00:00:39.100
This is me rock climbing
for the first time.

00:00:39.124 --> 00:00:43.201
Actually, I love sports
and I can play many sports,

00:00:43.225 --> 00:00:48.607
like swimming, skiing, skating,
scuba diving, running and so on.

00:00:49.340 --> 00:00:51.251
But there is one limitation:

00:00:52.103 --> 00:00:53.862
somebody needs to help me.

00:00:54.472 --> 00:00:56.584
I want to be independent.

00:00:57.699 --> 00:01:02.402
I lost my sight at the age of 14
in a swimming pool accident.

00:01:02.947 --> 00:01:05.571
I was an active, independent teenager,

00:01:05.595 --> 00:01:08.011
and suddenly I became blind.

00:01:08.798 --> 00:01:12.862
The hardest thing for me
was losing my independence.

00:01:13.558 --> 00:01:18.965
Things that until then seemed simple
became almost impossible to do alone.

00:01:19.920 --> 00:01:23.661
For example, one of my
challenges was textbooks.

00:01:24.042 --> 00:01:26.792
Back then, there were no
personal computers,

00:01:26.816 --> 00:01:29.253
no Internet, no smartphones.

00:01:29.277 --> 00:01:34.710
So I had to ask one of my two brothers
to read me textbooks,

00:01:34.734 --> 00:01:38.210
and I had to create
my own books in Braille.

00:01:38.611 --> 00:01:39.964
Can you imagine?

00:01:40.561 --> 00:01:43.680
Of course, my brothers
were not happy about it,

00:01:43.704 --> 00:01:47.527
and later, I noticed they were not there
whenever I needed them.

00:01:47.551 --> 00:01:48.552
(Laughter)

00:01:48.576 --> 00:01:52.368
I think they tried to stay away from me.

00:01:52.392 --> 00:01:53.746
I don't blame them.

00:01:54.539 --> 00:01:58.310
I really wanted to be freed
from relying on someone.

00:01:59.118 --> 00:02:03.027
That became my strong desire
to ignite innovation.

00:02:04.058 --> 00:02:06.744
Jump ahead to the mid-1980s.

00:02:06.768 --> 00:02:09.514
I got to know cutting-edge technologies

00:02:09.538 --> 00:02:11.635
and I thought to myself,

00:02:11.659 --> 00:02:15.278
how come there is no computer technology

00:02:15.302 --> 00:02:17.428
to create books in Braille?

00:02:18.246 --> 00:02:22.610
These amazing technologies
must be able to also help people

00:02:22.634 --> 00:02:25.033
with limitations like myself.

00:02:25.763 --> 00:02:29.575
That's the moment
my innovation journey began.

00:02:30.644 --> 00:02:34.498
I started developing
digital book technologies,

00:02:34.522 --> 00:02:39.815
such as a digital Braille editor,
digital Braille dictionary

00:02:39.839 --> 00:02:42.585
and a digital Braille library network.

00:02:43.136 --> 00:02:47.504
Today, every student who is visually
impaired can read textbooks,

00:02:47.528 --> 00:02:51.355
by using personal computers
and mobile devices,

00:02:51.379 --> 00:02:53.464
in Braille or in voice.

00:02:53.956 --> 00:02:56.092
This may not surprise you,

00:02:56.116 --> 00:03:01.176
since everyone now has digital books
in their tablets in 2015.

00:03:01.200 --> 00:03:07.047
But Braille went digital
many years before digital books,

00:03:07.071 --> 00:03:12.303
already in the late 1980s,
almost 30 years ago.

00:03:13.200 --> 00:03:16.999
Strong and specific needs
of the blind people

00:03:17.023 --> 00:03:22.666
made this opportunity to create
digital books way back then.

00:03:23.301 --> 00:03:28.307
And this is actually not
the first time this happened,

00:03:28.331 --> 00:03:34.421
because history shows us
accessibility ignites innovation.

00:03:35.425 --> 00:03:39.442
The telephone was invented
while developing a communication tool

00:03:39.466 --> 00:03:41.333
for hearing impaired people.

00:03:41.695 --> 00:03:47.115
Some keyboards were also invented
to help people with disabilities.

00:03:48.765 --> 00:03:52.242
Now I'm going to give you
another example from my own life.

00:03:52.646 --> 00:03:56.909
In the '90s, people around me
started talking about the Internet

00:03:56.933 --> 00:03:58.376
and web browsing.

00:03:58.853 --> 00:04:01.725
I remember the first time
I went on the web.

00:04:02.106 --> 00:04:03.694
I was astonished.

00:04:04.310 --> 00:04:08.417
I could access newspapers
at any time and every day.

00:04:08.768 --> 00:04:12.624
I could even search
for any information by myself.

00:04:13.133 --> 00:04:18.947
I desperately wanted to help the blind
people have access to the Internet,

00:04:18.971 --> 00:04:24.277
and I found ways to render the web
into synthesized voice,

00:04:24.301 --> 00:04:28.071
which dramatically simplified
the user interface.

00:04:28.643 --> 00:04:34.053
This led me to develop
the Home Page Reader in 1997,

00:04:34.077 --> 00:04:38.970
first in Japanese and later,
translated into 11 languages.

00:04:39.742 --> 00:04:42.319
When I developed the Home Page Reader,

00:04:42.343 --> 00:04:45.272
I got many comments from users.

00:04:45.867 --> 00:04:48.393
One that I strongly remember said,

00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:54.238
"For me, the Internet
is a small window to the world."

00:04:55.143 --> 00:04:58.084
It was a revolutionary moment
for the blind.

00:04:59.088 --> 00:05:01.265
The cyber world became accessible,

00:05:01.289 --> 00:05:05.959
and this technology that we created
for the blind has many uses,

00:05:05.983 --> 00:05:07.958
way beyond what I imagined.

00:05:08.497 --> 00:05:12.643
It can help drivers listen to their emails

00:05:12.667 --> 00:05:16.940
or it can help you listen
to a recipe while cooking.

00:05:18.074 --> 00:05:20.584
Today, I am more independent,

00:05:20.608 --> 00:05:22.924
but it is still not enough.

00:05:23.626 --> 00:05:29.481
For example, when I approached
the stage just now, I needed assistance.

00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:33.791
My goal is to come up here independently.

00:05:34.105 --> 00:05:35.632
And not just here.

00:05:35.949 --> 00:05:41.768
My goal is to be able to travel
and do things that are simple to you.

00:05:42.596 --> 00:05:45.405
OK, now let me show you
the latest technologies.

00:05:45.429 --> 00:05:48.953
This is a smartphone app
that we are working on.

00:05:50.583 --> 00:05:54.217
(Video) Electronic voice: 51 feet
to the door, and keep straight.

00:05:57.660 --> 00:06:00.783
EV: Take the two doors to go out.
The door is on your right.

00:06:07.689 --> 00:06:09.627
EV: Nick is approaching. Looks so happy.

00:06:09.651 --> 00:06:10.856
Chieko Asakawa: Hi, Nick!

00:06:10.880 --> 00:06:11.881
(Laughter)

00:06:11.905 --> 00:06:14.048
CA: Where are you going?
You look so happy.

00:06:14.072 --> 00:06:16.185
Nick: Oh -- well, my paper
just got accepted.

00:06:16.209 --> 00:06:17.856
CA: That's great! Congratulations.

00:06:17.880 --> 00:06:21.531
Nick: Thanks. Wait -- how'd you know
it was me, and that I look happy?

00:06:21.555 --> 00:06:22.905
(Chieko and Nick laugh)

00:06:22.929 --> 00:06:24.088
Man: Hi.

00:06:24.112 --> 00:06:25.829
(Laughter)

00:06:25.853 --> 00:06:27.004
CA: Oh ... hi.

00:06:27.028 --> 00:06:29.345
EV: He is not talking to you,
but on his phone.

00:06:36.392 --> 00:06:37.574
EV: Potato chips.

00:06:45.117 --> 00:06:46.720
EV: Dark chocolate with almonds.

00:06:48.113 --> 00:06:51.634
EV: You gained 5 pounds since yesterday;
take apple instead of chocolate.

00:06:51.658 --> 00:06:53.824
(Laughter)

00:06:54.414 --> 00:06:55.726
EV: Approaching.

00:06:59.996 --> 00:07:01.172
EV: You arrived.

00:07:02.897 --> 00:07:04.136
CA: Now ...

00:07:04.160 --> 00:07:08.088
(Applause)

00:07:08.112 --> 00:07:09.303
Thank you.

00:07:09.327 --> 00:07:12.225
So now the app navigates me

00:07:12.249 --> 00:07:16.265
by analyzing beacon signals
and smartphone sensors

00:07:16.289 --> 00:07:21.425
and permits me to move around
indoor and outdoor environments

00:07:21.449 --> 00:07:23.037
all by myself.

00:07:23.061 --> 00:07:27.909
But the computer vision part
that showed who is approaching,

00:07:27.933 --> 00:07:31.439
in which mood -- we are still
working on that part.

00:07:32.209 --> 00:07:38.615
And recognizing facial expressions
is very important for me to be social.

00:07:39.356 --> 00:07:45.522
So now the fusions of technologies
are ready to help me

00:07:45.546 --> 00:07:47.226
see the real world.

00:07:47.878 --> 00:07:51.107
We call this cognitive assistance.

00:07:51.779 --> 00:07:55.098
It understands our surrounding world

00:07:55.122 --> 00:08:01.339
and whispers to me in voice
or sends a vibration to my fingers.

00:08:02.046 --> 00:08:08.110
Cognitive assistance will augment
missing or weakened abilities --

00:08:08.134 --> 00:08:10.765
in other words, our five senses.

00:08:11.422 --> 00:08:14.733
This technology is only in an early stage,

00:08:14.757 --> 00:08:19.534
but eventually, I'll be able to find
a classroom on campus,

00:08:19.558 --> 00:08:21.312
enjoy window shopping

00:08:21.336 --> 00:08:25.197
or find a nice restaurant
while walking along a street.

00:08:26.046 --> 00:08:30.673
It will be amazing if I can find you
on the street before you notice me.

00:08:31.553 --> 00:08:35.340
It will become my best buddy, and yours.

00:08:36.266 --> 00:08:39.856
So, this really is a great challenge.

00:08:40.353 --> 00:08:44.322
It is a challenge
that needs collaboration,

00:08:44.346 --> 00:08:47.248
which is why we are creating
an open community

00:08:47.272 --> 00:08:50.131
to accelerate research activities.

00:08:51.150 --> 00:08:56.048
Just this morning, we announced
the open-source fundamental technologies

00:08:56.072 --> 00:08:57.699
you just saw in the video.

00:08:58.445 --> 00:09:01.209
The frontier is the real world.

00:09:01.836 --> 00:09:06.249
The blind community is exploring
this technical frontier

00:09:06.273 --> 00:09:07.979
and the pathfinder.

00:09:08.517 --> 00:09:12.255
I hope to work with you
to explore the new era,

00:09:12.279 --> 00:09:15.366
and the next time that I'm on this stage,

00:09:15.390 --> 00:09:17.804
through technology and innovation,

00:09:17.828 --> 00:09:19.853
I will be able to walk up here

00:09:19.877 --> 00:09:21.473
all by myself.

00:09:21.497 --> 00:09:22.736
Thank you so much.

00:09:22.760 --> 00:09:28.378
(Applause)

title: The exhilarating peace of freediving
transcript: (Video) Announcer: 10 seconds. Five, four, three, two, one. Official top. Plus one, two, three, four, five six, seven, eight, nine, ten. Guillaume Néry, France. Constant weight, 123 meters, three minutes and 25 seconds. National record attempt. 70 meters. [123 meters](Applause)(Video) Judge: White card. Guillaume Néry! National record!Guillaume Néry: Thank you.(Applause)Thank you very much, thanks for the warm welcome. That dive you just watched is a journey — a journey between two breaths. A journey that takes place between two breaths — the last one before diving into the water, and the first one, coming back to the surface. That dive is a journey to the very limits of human possibility, a journey into the unknown. But it's also, and above all, an inner journey, where a number of things happen, physiologically as well as mentally. And that's why I'm here today, to share my journey with you and to take you along with me.So, we start with the last breath. (Breathing in) (Breathing out) As you noticed, that last breath in is slow, deep and intense. It ends with a special technique called the carp, which allows me to store one to two extra liters of air in my lungs by compressing it. When I leave the surface, I have about 10 liters of air in my lungs. As soon as I leave the surface the first mechanism kicks in: the diving reflex. The first thing the diving reflex does is make your heart rate drop. My heart beat will drop from about 60-70 per minute to about 30-40 beats per minute in a matter of seconds; almost immediately.Next, the diving reflex causes peripheral vasoconstriction, which means that the blood flow will leave the body's extremities to feed the most important organs: the lungs, the heart and the brain. This mechanism is innate. I cannot control it. If you go underwater, even if you've never done it before, you'll experience the exact same effects. All human beings share this characteristic. And what's extraordinary is that we share this instinct with marine mammals — all marine mammals: dolphins, whales, sea lions, etc. When they dive deep into the ocean, these mechanisms become activated, but to a greater extent. And, of course, it works much better for them. It's absolutely fascinating.Right as I leave the surface, nature gives me a push in the right direction, allowing me to descend with confidence.So as I dive deeper into the blue, the pressure slowly starts to squeeze my lungs. And since it's the amount of air in my lungs that makes me float, the farther down I go, the more pressure there is on my lungs, the less air they contain and the easier it is for my body to fall. And at one point, around 35 or 40 meters down, I don't even need to swim. My body is dense and heavy enough to fall into the depths by itself, and I enter what's called the free fall phase. The free fall phase is the best part of the dive. It's the reason I still dive. Because it feels like you're being pulled down and you don't need to do anything. I can go from 35 meters to 123 meters without making a single movement. I let myself be pulled by the depths, and it feels like I'm flying underwater. It's truly an amazing feeling — an extraordinary feeling of freedom.And so I slowly continue sliding to the bottom. 40 meters down, 50 meters down, and between 50 and 60 meters, a second physiological response kicks in. My lungs reach residual volume, below which they're not supposed to be compressed, in theory. And this second response is called blood shift, or "pulmonary erection" in French. I prefer "blood shift."(Laughter)So blood shift — how does it work? The capillaries in the lungs become engorged with blood — which is caused by the suction — so the lungs can harden and protect the whole chest cavity from being crushed. It prevents the two walls of the lungs from collapsing, from sticking together and caving in. Thanks to this phenomenon, which we also share with marine mammals, I'm able to continue with my dive.60, 70 meters down, I keep falling, faster and faster, because the pressure is crushing my body more and more. Below 80 meters, the pressure becomes a lot stronger, and I start to feel it physically. I really start to feel the suffocation. You can see what it looks like — not pretty at all. The diaphragm is completely collapsed, the rib cage is squeezed in, and mentally, there is something going on as well.You may be thinking, "This doesn't look enjoyable. How do you do it?" If I relied on my earthly reflexes — what do we do above water when there's a problem? We resist, we go against it. We fight. Underwater, that doesn't work. If you try that underwater, you might tear your lungs, spit up blood, develop an edema and you'll have to stop diving for a good amount of time. So what you need to do, mentally, is to tell yourself that nature and the elements are stronger than you.And so I let the water crush me. I accept the pressure and go with it. At this point, my body receives this information, and my lungs start relaxing. I relinquish all control, and relax completely. The pressure starts crushing me, and it doesn't feel bad at all. I even feel like I'm in a cocoon, protected.And the dive continues. 80, 85 meters down, 90, 100. 100 meters — the magic number. In every sport, it's a magic number. For swimmers and athletes and also for us, free divers, it's a number everyone dreams of. Everyone wishes one day to be able to get to 100 meters. And it's a symbolic number for us, because in the 1970s, doctors and physiologists did their math, and predicted that the human body would not be able to go below 100 meters. Below that, they said, the human body would implode. And then the Frenchman, Jacques Mayol — you all know him as the hero in "The Big Blue" — came along and dived down to 100 meters. He even reached 105 meters. At that time, he was doing "no limits." He'd use weights to descend faster and come back up with a balloon, just like in the movie. Today, we go down 200 meters in no limit free diving. I can do 123 meters by simply using muscle strength. And in a way, it's all thanks to him, because he challenged known facts, and with a sweep of his hand, got rid of the theoretical beliefs and all the mental limits that we like to impose on ourselves. He showed us that the human body has an infinite ability to adapt.So I carry on with my dive. 105, 110, 115. The bottom is getting closer. 120, 123 meters. I'm at the bottom.And now, I'd like to ask you to join me and put yourself in my place. Close your eyes. Imagine you get to 123 meters. The surface is far, far away. You're alone. There's hardly any light. It's cold — freezing cold. The pressure is crushing you completely — 13 times stronger than on the surface. And I know what you're thinking: "This is horrible. What the hell am I doing here? He's insane." But no. That's not what I think when I'm down there. When I'm at the bottom, I feel good. I get this extraordinary feeling of well-being. Maybe it's because I've completely released all tensions and let myself go. I feel great, without the need to breathe.Although, you'd agree, I should be worried. I feel like a tiny dot, a little drop of water, floating in the middle of the ocean. And each time, I picture the same image. [The Pale Blue Dot] It's that small dot the arrow is pointing to. Do you know what it is? It's planet Earth. Planet Earth, photographed by the Voyager probe, from 4 billion kilometers away. And it shows that our home is that small dot over there, floating in the middle of nothing.That's how I feel when I'm at the bottom, at 123 meters. I feel like a small dot, a speck of dust, stardust, floating in the middle of the cosmos, in the middle of nothing, in the immensity of space. It's a fascinating sensation, because when I look up, down, left, right, in front, behind, I see the same thing: the infinite deep blue. Nowhere else on Earth you can experience this — looking all around you, and seeing the same thing. It's extraordinary. And at that moment, I still get that feeling each time, building up inside of me — the feeling of humility.Looking at this picture, I feel very humble — just like when I'm all the way down at the bottom — because I'm nothing, I'm a little speck of nothingness lost in all of time and space. And it still is absolutely fascinating. I decide to go back to the surface, because this is not where I belong. I belong up there, on the surface.So I start heading back up. I get something of a shock at the very moment when I decide to go up. First, because it takes a huge effort to tear yourself away from the bottom. It pulled you down on the way in, and will do the same on the way up. You have to swim twice as hard. Then, I'm hit with another phenomenon known as narcosis. I don't know if you've heard of that. It's called nitrogen narcosis. It's something that happens to scuba divers, but it can happen to free divers. It's caused by nitrogen dissolving in the blood, which causes confusion between the conscious and unconscious mind. A flurry of thoughts goes spinning through your head. You can't control them, and you shouldn't try to — you have to let it happen. The more you try to control it, the harder it is to manage. Then, a third thing happens: the desire to breathe. I'm not a fish, I'm a human being, and the desire to breathe reminds me of that fact. Around 60, 70 meters, you start to feel the need to breathe. And with everything else that's going on, you can very easily lose your ground and start to panic. When that happens, you think, "Where's the surface? I want to go up. I want to breathe now." You should not do that. Never look up to the surface — not with your eyes, or your mind. You should never picture yourself up there. You have to stay in the present. I look at the rope right in front of me, leading me back to the surface. And I focus on that, on the present moment. Because if I think about the surface, I panic. And if I panic, it's over. Time goes faster this way.And at 30 meters: deliverance. I'm not alone any more. The safety divers, my guardian angels, join me. They leave the surface, we meet at 30 meters, and they escort me for the final few meters, where potential problems could arise. Every time I see them, I think to myself, "It's thanks to you." It's thanks to them, my team, that I'm here. It brings back the sense of humility. Without my team, without all the people around me, the adventure into the deep would be impossible. A journey into the deep is above all a group effort.So I'm happy to finish my journey with them, because I wouldn't be here if it weren't for them. 20 meters, 10 meters, my lungs slowly return to their normal volume. Buoyancy pushes me up to the surface. Five meters below the surface, I start to breathe out, so that as soon as I get to the surface all I do is breathe in. And so I arrive at the surface. (Breathing in) Air floods into my lungs. It's like being born again, a relief. It feels good. Though the journey was extraordinary, I do need to feel those small oxygen molecules fueling my body. It's an extraordinary sensation, but at the same time it's traumatizing. It's a shock to the system, as you can you imagine. I go from complete darkness to the light of day, from the near-silence of the depths to the commotion up top. In terms of touch, I go from the soft, velvety feeling of the water, to air rubbing across my face. In terms of smell, there is air rushing into my lungs.And in return, my lungs open up. They were completely squashed just 90 seconds ago, and now, they've opened up again. So all of this affects quite a lot of things. I need a few seconds to come back, and to feel "all there" again. But that needs to happen quickly, because the judges are there to verify my performance; I need to show them I'm in perfect physical condition. You saw in the video, I was doing a so-called exit protocol. Once at the surface, I have 15 seconds to take off my nose clip, give this signal and say (English) "I am OK." Plus, you need to be bilingual.(Laughter)On top of everything — that's not very nice. Once the protocol is completed, the judges show me a white card, and that's when the joy starts. I can finally celebrate what has just happened.So, the journey I've just described to you is a more extreme version of free diving. Luckily, it's far from just that. For the past few years, I've been trying to show another side of free diving, because the media mainly talks about competitions and records. But free diving is more than just that. It's about being at ease in the water. It's extremely beautiful, very poetic and artistic.So my wife and I decided to film it and try to show another side of it, mostly to make people want to go into the water. Let me show you some images to finish my story. It's a mix of beautiful underwater photos.(Music)I'd like you to know that if one day you try to stop breathing, you'll realize that when you stop breathing, you stop thinking, too. It calms your mind.Today, in the 21st century, we're under so much pressure. Our minds are overworked, we think at a million miles an hour, we're always stressed. Being able to free dive lets you, just for a moment, relax your mind. Holding your breath underwater means giving yourself the chance to experience weightlessness. It means being underwater, floating, with your body completely relaxed, letting go of all your tensions. This is our plight in the 21st century: our backs hurt, our necks hurt, everything hurts, because we're stressed and tense all the time. But when you're in the water, you let yourself float, as if you were in space. You let yourself go completely. It's an extraordinary feeling. You can finally get in touch with your body, mind and spirit. Everything feels better, all at once.Learning how to free dive is also about learning to breathe correctly. We breathe with our first breath at birth, up until our last one. Breathing gives rhythm to our lives. Learning how to breathe better is learning how to live better. Holding your breath in the sea, not necessarily at 100 meters, but maybe at two or three, putting on your goggles, a pair of flippers, means you can go see another world, another universe, completely magical. You can see little fish, seaweed, the flora and fauna, you can watch it all discreetly, sliding underwater, looking around, and coming back to the surface, leaving no trace. It's an amazing feeling to become one with nature like that.And if I may say one more thing, holding your breath, being in the water, finding this underwater world — it's all about connecting with yourself. You heard me talk a lot about the body's memory that dates back millions of years, to our marine origins. The day you get back into the water, when you hold your breath for a few seconds, you will reconnect with those origins. And I guarantee it's absolute magic. I encourage you to try it out.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.866 --> 00:00:15.751
(Video) Announcer: 10 seconds.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:23.838
Five, four, three, two, one.

00:00:23.862 --> 00:00:25.179
Official top.

00:00:25.203 --> 00:00:30.012
Plus one, two, three, four, five

00:00:30.036 --> 00:00:34.159
six, seven, eight, nine, ten.

00:00:38.111 --> 00:00:40.135
Guillaume Néry, France.

00:00:40.159 --> 00:00:43.799
Constant weight, 123 meters,

00:00:43.823 --> 00:00:46.081
three minutes and 25 seconds.

00:00:46.105 --> 00:00:48.299
National record attempt.

00:01:19.792 --> 00:01:21.133
70 meters.

00:01:32.014 --> 00:01:34.077
[123 meters]

00:02:21.124 --> 00:02:24.082
(Applause)

00:02:24.106 --> 00:02:28.181
(Video) Judge: White card.
Guillaume Néry! National record!

00:02:29.703 --> 00:02:30.949
Guillaume Néry: Thank you.

00:02:30.973 --> 00:02:34.006
(Applause)

00:02:34.798 --> 00:02:37.352
Thank you very much,
thanks for the warm welcome.

00:02:37.376 --> 00:02:40.580
That dive you just watched is a journey --

00:02:40.604 --> 00:02:42.818
a journey between two breaths.

00:02:43.325 --> 00:02:45.620
A journey that takes place
between two breaths --

00:02:45.644 --> 00:02:47.898
the last one before diving into the water,

00:02:47.922 --> 00:02:50.752
and the first one,
coming back to the surface.

00:02:51.352 --> 00:02:55.726
That dive is a journey
to the very limits of human possibility,

00:02:55.750 --> 00:02:57.686
a journey into the unknown.

00:02:58.273 --> 00:03:01.804
But it's also, and above all,
an inner journey,

00:03:01.828 --> 00:03:04.222
where a number of things happen,

00:03:04.246 --> 00:03:06.575
physiologically as well as mentally.

00:03:06.599 --> 00:03:08.615
And that's why I'm here today,

00:03:08.639 --> 00:03:11.972
to share my journey with you
and to take you along with me.

00:03:11.996 --> 00:03:14.461
So, we start with the last breath.

00:03:15.945 --> 00:03:19.020
(Breathing in)

00:03:29.237 --> 00:03:31.077
(Breathing out)

00:03:31.101 --> 00:03:35.544
As you noticed, that last breath
in is slow, deep and intense.

00:03:35.568 --> 00:03:38.124
It ends with a special technique
called the carp,

00:03:38.148 --> 00:03:41.789
which allows me to store one to two
extra liters of air in my lungs

00:03:41.813 --> 00:03:43.926
by compressing it.

00:03:43.950 --> 00:03:48.545
When I leave the surface,
I have about 10 liters of air in my lungs.

00:03:49.497 --> 00:03:53.018
As soon as I leave the surface
the first mechanism kicks in:

00:03:53.042 --> 00:03:54.478
the diving reflex.

00:03:54.502 --> 00:03:59.386
The first thing the diving reflex does
is make your heart rate drop.

00:03:59.410 --> 00:04:02.243
My heart beat will drop
from about 60-70 per minute

00:04:02.267 --> 00:04:04.047
to about 30-40 beats per minute

00:04:04.071 --> 00:04:06.992
in a matter of seconds;
almost immediately.

00:04:07.016 --> 00:04:10.105
Next, the diving reflex causes
peripheral vasoconstriction,

00:04:10.129 --> 00:04:14.299
which means that the blood flow
will leave the body's extremities

00:04:14.323 --> 00:04:17.667
to feed the most important organs:

00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:21.761
the lungs, the heart and the brain.

00:04:22.560 --> 00:04:26.044
This mechanism is innate.

00:04:26.068 --> 00:04:27.484
I cannot control it.

00:04:27.508 --> 00:04:30.300
If you go underwater,
even if you've never done it before,

00:04:30.324 --> 00:04:32.669
you'll experience the exact same effects.

00:04:32.693 --> 00:04:36.316
All human beings
share this characteristic.

00:04:36.340 --> 00:04:38.266
And what's extraordinary

00:04:38.290 --> 00:04:41.807
is that we share this instinct
with marine mammals --

00:04:41.831 --> 00:04:45.489
all marine mammals:
dolphins, whales, sea lions, etc.

00:04:45.513 --> 00:04:50.109
When they dive deep into the ocean,
these mechanisms become activated,

00:04:50.133 --> 00:04:51.466
but to a greater extent.

00:04:51.490 --> 00:04:54.013
And, of course, it works
much better for them.

00:04:55.928 --> 00:04:57.322
It's absolutely fascinating.

00:04:57.346 --> 00:04:58.772
Right as I leave the surface,

00:04:58.796 --> 00:05:01.105
nature gives me a push
in the right direction,

00:05:01.129 --> 00:05:03.521
allowing me to descend with confidence.

00:05:03.545 --> 00:05:05.561
So as I dive deeper into the blue,

00:05:05.585 --> 00:05:09.577
the pressure slowly starts
to squeeze my lungs.

00:05:10.296 --> 00:05:13.547
And since it's the amount of air
in my lungs that makes me float,

00:05:13.571 --> 00:05:16.499
the farther down I go,
the more pressure there is on my lungs,

00:05:16.523 --> 00:05:20.126
the less air they contain
and the easier it is for my body to fall.

00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:22.953
And at one point,
around 35 or 40 meters down,

00:05:22.977 --> 00:05:25.666
I don't even need to swim.

00:05:26.426 --> 00:05:31.197
My body is dense and heavy enough
to fall into the depths by itself,

00:05:31.221 --> 00:05:33.816
and I enter what's called
the free fall phase.

00:05:33.840 --> 00:05:36.562
The free fall phase
is the best part of the dive.

00:05:36.586 --> 00:05:38.464
It's the reason I still dive.

00:05:38.488 --> 00:05:42.448
Because it feels like
you're being pulled down

00:05:43.359 --> 00:05:45.056
and you don't need to do anything.

00:05:45.080 --> 00:05:48.974
I can go from 35 meters to 123 meters
without making a single movement.

00:05:48.998 --> 00:05:50.940
I let myself be pulled by the depths,

00:05:50.964 --> 00:05:52.902
and it feels like I'm flying underwater.

00:05:52.926 --> 00:05:56.909
It's truly an amazing feeling --
an extraordinary feeling of freedom.

00:05:56.933 --> 00:05:59.916
And so I slowly continue
sliding to the bottom.

00:05:59.940 --> 00:06:01.220
40 meters down,

00:06:01.244 --> 00:06:02.541
50 meters down,

00:06:02.565 --> 00:06:06.792
and between 50 and 60 meters,
a second physiological response kicks in.

00:06:07.660 --> 00:06:10.176
My lungs reach residual volume,

00:06:10.200 --> 00:06:15.139
below which they're not supposed
to be compressed, in theory.

00:06:15.163 --> 00:06:18.689
And this second response
is called blood shift,

00:06:18.713 --> 00:06:21.316
or "pulmonary erection" in French.

00:06:22.194 --> 00:06:23.503
I prefer "blood shift."

00:06:23.527 --> 00:06:24.684
(Laughter)

00:06:24.708 --> 00:06:27.453
So blood shift -- how does it work?

00:06:27.477 --> 00:06:32.051
The capillaries in the lungs
become engorged with blood --

00:06:32.075 --> 00:06:33.668
which is caused by the suction --

00:06:33.692 --> 00:06:35.403
so the lungs can harden

00:06:35.427 --> 00:06:38.099
and protect the whole chest cavity
from being crushed.

00:06:38.123 --> 00:06:42.026
It prevents the two walls
of the lungs from collapsing,

00:06:42.050 --> 00:06:44.012
from sticking together and caving in.

00:06:44.036 --> 00:06:47.925
Thanks to this phenomenon,
which we also share with marine mammals,

00:06:47.949 --> 00:06:49.652
I'm able to continue with my dive.

00:06:49.676 --> 00:06:53.252
60, 70 meters down,
I keep falling, faster and faster,

00:06:53.276 --> 00:06:56.188
because the pressure is crushing
my body more and more.

00:06:56.212 --> 00:06:57.735
Below 80 meters,

00:06:58.313 --> 00:07:00.328
the pressure becomes a lot stronger,

00:07:00.352 --> 00:07:02.423
and I start to feel it physically.

00:07:02.447 --> 00:07:04.452
I really start to feel the suffocation.

00:07:04.476 --> 00:07:06.936
You can see what it looks like --
not pretty at all.

00:07:06.960 --> 00:07:11.198
The diaphragm is completely collapsed,
the rib cage is squeezed in,

00:07:11.782 --> 00:07:14.265
and mentally, there is something
going on as well.

00:07:14.289 --> 00:07:17.056
You may be thinking,
"This doesn't look enjoyable.

00:07:17.080 --> 00:07:18.379
How do you do it?"

00:07:18.403 --> 00:07:20.204
If I relied on my earthly reflexes --

00:07:20.228 --> 00:07:23.691
what do we do above water
when there's a problem?

00:07:23.715 --> 00:07:25.924
We resist, we go against it.

00:07:25.948 --> 00:07:27.291
We fight.

00:07:27.315 --> 00:07:28.847
Underwater, that doesn't work.

00:07:28.871 --> 00:07:31.463
If you try that underwater,
you might tear your lungs,

00:07:31.487 --> 00:07:33.053
spit up blood, develop an edema

00:07:33.077 --> 00:07:36.212
and you'll have to stop diving
for a good amount of time.

00:07:36.236 --> 00:07:39.410
So what you need to do, mentally,
is to tell yourself

00:07:39.434 --> 00:07:42.204
that nature and the elements
are stronger than you.

00:07:42.228 --> 00:07:44.854
And so I let the water crush me.

00:07:44.878 --> 00:07:47.726
I accept the pressure and go with it.

00:07:48.439 --> 00:07:50.783
At this point, my body
receives this information,

00:07:50.807 --> 00:07:52.665
and my lungs start relaxing.

00:07:52.689 --> 00:07:55.832
I relinquish all control,
and relax completely.

00:07:55.856 --> 00:07:59.706
The pressure starts crushing me,
and it doesn't feel bad at all.

00:07:59.730 --> 00:08:03.040
I even feel like
I'm in a cocoon, protected.

00:08:03.064 --> 00:08:05.636
And the dive continues.

00:08:05.660 --> 00:08:07.358
80, 85 meters down,

00:08:07.382 --> 00:08:08.601
90,

00:08:08.625 --> 00:08:09.808
100.

00:08:09.832 --> 00:08:12.418
100 meters -- the magic number.

00:08:12.982 --> 00:08:14.844
In every sport, it's a magic number.

00:08:14.868 --> 00:08:17.698
For swimmers and athletes
and also for us, free divers,

00:08:17.722 --> 00:08:19.368
it's a number everyone dreams of.

00:08:19.392 --> 00:08:22.790
Everyone wishes one day
to be able to get to 100 meters.

00:08:22.814 --> 00:08:24.599
And it's a symbolic number for us,

00:08:24.623 --> 00:08:28.490
because in the 1970s,
doctors and physiologists did their math,

00:08:28.514 --> 00:08:33.823
and predicted that the human body
would not be able to go below 100 meters.

00:08:33.847 --> 00:08:36.703
Below that, they said,
the human body would implode.

00:08:36.727 --> 00:08:38.839
And then the Frenchman, Jacques Mayol --

00:08:38.863 --> 00:08:41.156
you all know him as the hero
in "The Big Blue" --

00:08:41.180 --> 00:08:44.433
came along and dived down to 100 meters.

00:08:44.457 --> 00:08:46.022
He even reached 105 meters.

00:08:46.046 --> 00:08:47.942
At that time, he was doing "no limits."

00:08:47.966 --> 00:08:51.315
He'd use weights to descend faster
and come back up with a balloon,

00:08:51.339 --> 00:08:52.511
just like in the movie.

00:08:52.535 --> 00:08:55.113
Today, we go down 200 meters
in no limit free diving.

00:08:55.137 --> 00:08:57.993
I can do 123 meters
by simply using muscle strength.

00:08:58.017 --> 00:09:01.748
And in a way, it's all thanks to him,
because he challenged known facts,

00:09:01.772 --> 00:09:06.139
and with a sweep of his hand,
got rid of the theoretical beliefs

00:09:06.163 --> 00:09:09.564
and all the mental limits
that we like to impose on ourselves.

00:09:09.588 --> 00:09:13.204
He showed us that the human body
has an infinite ability to adapt.

00:09:13.228 --> 00:09:14.947
So I carry on with my dive.

00:09:14.971 --> 00:09:17.105
105, 110, 115.

00:09:17.129 --> 00:09:18.899
The bottom is getting closer.

00:09:18.923 --> 00:09:20.399
120,

00:09:20.423 --> 00:09:21.613
123 meters.

00:09:21.637 --> 00:09:22.916
I'm at the bottom.

00:09:22.940 --> 00:09:26.550
And now, I'd like to ask you to join me
and put yourself in my place.

00:09:26.574 --> 00:09:28.209
Close your eyes.

00:09:28.710 --> 00:09:31.479
Imagine you get to 123 meters.

00:09:33.499 --> 00:09:36.083
The surface is far, far away.

00:09:36.678 --> 00:09:38.134
You're alone.

00:09:39.822 --> 00:09:41.579
There's hardly any light.

00:09:42.282 --> 00:09:43.537
It's cold --

00:09:43.561 --> 00:09:44.918
freezing cold.

00:09:44.942 --> 00:09:46.995
The pressure is crushing you completely --

00:09:47.019 --> 00:09:49.105
13 times stronger than on the surface.

00:09:50.172 --> 00:09:52.081
And I know what you're thinking:

00:09:52.105 --> 00:09:54.054
"This is horrible.

00:09:54.078 --> 00:09:55.934
What the hell am I doing here?

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.648
He's insane."

00:09:58.442 --> 00:09:59.608
But no.

00:09:59.989 --> 00:10:02.249
That's not what I think
when I'm down there.

00:10:02.273 --> 00:10:03.998
When I'm at the bottom, I feel good.

00:10:04.022 --> 00:10:06.279
I get this extraordinary
feeling of well-being.

00:10:06.303 --> 00:10:09.192
Maybe it's because I've completely
released all tensions

00:10:09.216 --> 00:10:10.937
and let myself go.

00:10:10.961 --> 00:10:14.422
I feel great, without the need to breathe.

00:10:17.196 --> 00:10:21.156
Although, you'd agree,
I should be worried.

00:10:21.957 --> 00:10:24.280
I feel like a tiny dot,
a little drop of water,

00:10:24.304 --> 00:10:26.154
floating in the middle of the ocean.

00:10:26.178 --> 00:10:28.813
And each time, I picture the same image.

00:10:29.694 --> 00:10:32.003
[The Pale Blue Dot]

00:10:32.431 --> 00:10:34.885
It's that small dot
the arrow is pointing to.

00:10:34.909 --> 00:10:36.431
Do you know what it is?

00:10:37.438 --> 00:10:38.828
It's planet Earth.

00:10:39.436 --> 00:10:42.097
Planet Earth, photographed
by the Voyager probe,

00:10:42.121 --> 00:10:44.273
from 4 billion kilometers away.

00:10:44.297 --> 00:10:48.393
And it shows that our home
is that small dot over there,

00:10:48.417 --> 00:10:50.060
floating in the middle of nothing.

00:10:50.084 --> 00:10:52.005
That's how I feel

00:10:52.029 --> 00:10:54.180
when I'm at the bottom, at 123 meters.

00:10:54.204 --> 00:10:55.919
I feel like a small dot,

00:10:55.943 --> 00:10:58.498
a speck of dust, stardust,

00:10:58.522 --> 00:11:00.737
floating in the middle of the cosmos,

00:11:00.761 --> 00:11:03.205
in the middle of nothing,
in the immensity of space.

00:11:03.229 --> 00:11:04.670
It's a fascinating sensation,

00:11:04.694 --> 00:11:08.749
because when I look up, down,
left, right, in front, behind,

00:11:08.773 --> 00:11:11.964
I see the same thing:
the infinite deep blue.

00:11:11.988 --> 00:11:15.004
Nowhere else on Earth
you can experience this --

00:11:15.028 --> 00:11:18.591
looking all around you,
and seeing the same thing.

00:11:18.615 --> 00:11:19.865
It's extraordinary.

00:11:20.520 --> 00:11:21.960
And at that moment,

00:11:21.984 --> 00:11:24.985
I still get that feeling each time,
building up inside of me --

00:11:25.009 --> 00:11:27.531
the feeling of humility.

00:11:28.833 --> 00:11:31.739
Looking at this picture,
I feel very humble --

00:11:31.763 --> 00:11:34.294
just like when I'm all the way
down at the bottom --

00:11:34.318 --> 00:11:35.595
because I'm nothing,

00:11:35.619 --> 00:11:38.944
I'm a little speck of nothingness
lost in all of time and space.

00:11:39.610 --> 00:11:41.927
And it still is absolutely fascinating.

00:11:42.618 --> 00:11:46.421
I decide to go back to the surface,
because this is not where I belong.

00:11:46.445 --> 00:11:48.674
I belong up there, on the surface.

00:11:48.698 --> 00:11:50.875
So I start heading back up.

00:11:51.976 --> 00:11:56.227
I get something of a shock

00:11:56.251 --> 00:11:58.714
at the very moment when I decide to go up.

00:11:58.738 --> 00:12:02.645
First, because it takes a huge effort
to tear yourself away from the bottom.

00:12:02.669 --> 00:12:05.149
It pulled you down on the way in,

00:12:05.173 --> 00:12:07.056
and will do the same on the way up.

00:12:07.080 --> 00:12:08.895
You have to swim twice as hard.

00:12:10.438 --> 00:12:13.466
Then, I'm hit with another
phenomenon known as narcosis.

00:12:13.480 --> 00:12:15.252
I don't know if you've heard of that.

00:12:15.276 --> 00:12:17.403
It's called nitrogen narcosis.

00:12:17.427 --> 00:12:19.564
It's something that happens
to scuba divers,

00:12:19.588 --> 00:12:21.207
but it can happen to free divers.

00:12:21.231 --> 00:12:24.760
It's caused by nitrogen
dissolving in the blood,

00:12:24.784 --> 00:12:26.678
which causes confusion

00:12:26.702 --> 00:12:29.305
between the conscious
and unconscious mind.

00:12:30.170 --> 00:12:34.377
A flurry of thoughts goes spinning
through your head.

00:12:34.401 --> 00:12:37.397
You can't control them,
and you shouldn't try to --

00:12:37.421 --> 00:12:39.005
you have to let it happen.

00:12:39.029 --> 00:12:42.736
The more you try to control it,
the harder it is to manage.

00:12:43.181 --> 00:12:44.649
Then, a third thing happens:

00:12:44.673 --> 00:12:45.942
the desire to breathe.

00:12:45.966 --> 00:12:48.276
I'm not a fish, I'm a human being,

00:12:48.300 --> 00:12:51.821
and the desire to breathe
reminds me of that fact.

00:12:51.845 --> 00:12:53.709
Around 60, 70 meters,

00:12:55.509 --> 00:12:57.762
you start to feel the need to breathe.

00:12:59.608 --> 00:13:02.044
And with everything else that's going on,

00:13:02.068 --> 00:13:05.005
you can very easily lose your ground

00:13:05.029 --> 00:13:06.568
and start to panic.

00:13:07.829 --> 00:13:10.250
When that happens, you think,
"Where's the surface?

00:13:10.274 --> 00:13:12.209
I want to go up. I want to breathe now."

00:13:12.233 --> 00:13:13.865
You should not do that.

00:13:13.889 --> 00:13:15.723
Never look up to the surface --

00:13:15.747 --> 00:13:18.376
not with your eyes, or your mind.

00:13:19.119 --> 00:13:21.848
You should never
picture yourself up there.

00:13:21.872 --> 00:13:23.510
You have to stay in the present.

00:13:23.534 --> 00:13:28.356
I look at the rope right in front of me,
leading me back to the surface.

00:13:28.792 --> 00:13:31.302
And I focus on that,
on the present moment.

00:13:31.787 --> 00:13:33.963
Because if I think
about the surface, I panic.

00:13:33.987 --> 00:13:35.676
And if I panic, it's over.

00:13:36.883 --> 00:13:39.094
Time goes faster this way.

00:13:39.118 --> 00:13:41.213
And at 30 meters: deliverance.

00:13:41.237 --> 00:13:42.641
I'm not alone any more.

00:13:42.665 --> 00:13:46.064
The safety divers,
my guardian angels, join me.

00:13:46.088 --> 00:13:48.411
They leave the surface,
we meet at 30 meters,

00:13:48.435 --> 00:13:50.589
and they escort me
for the final few meters,

00:13:50.613 --> 00:13:53.289
where potential problems could arise.

00:13:53.839 --> 00:13:56.184
Every time I see them, I think to myself,

00:13:57.211 --> 00:13:58.799
"It's thanks to you."

00:13:58.823 --> 00:14:00.919
It's thanks to them,
my team, that I'm here.

00:14:00.943 --> 00:14:03.124
It brings back the sense of humility.

00:14:03.569 --> 00:14:07.014
Without my team, without all
the people around me,

00:14:07.038 --> 00:14:09.393
the adventure into the deep
would be impossible.

00:14:09.417 --> 00:14:12.645
A journey into the deep
is above all a group effort.

00:14:13.317 --> 00:14:15.575
So I'm happy to finish
my journey with them,

00:14:15.599 --> 00:14:18.093
because I wouldn't be here
if it weren't for them.

00:14:18.117 --> 00:14:19.708
20 meters, 10 meters,

00:14:19.732 --> 00:14:21.979
my lungs slowly return
to their normal volume.

00:14:22.003 --> 00:14:24.350
Buoyancy pushes me up to the surface.

00:14:24.374 --> 00:14:27.922
Five meters below the surface,
I start to breathe out,

00:14:27.946 --> 00:14:31.211
so that as soon as I get
to the surface all I do is breathe in.

00:14:31.235 --> 00:14:33.200
And so I arrive at the surface.

00:14:33.502 --> 00:14:36.427
(Breathing in)

00:14:39.625 --> 00:14:41.619
Air floods into my lungs.

00:14:41.643 --> 00:14:44.031
It's like being born again, a relief.

00:14:44.854 --> 00:14:46.009
It feels good.

00:14:46.033 --> 00:14:47.899
Though the journey was extraordinary,

00:14:47.923 --> 00:14:51.875
I do need to feel those small
oxygen molecules fueling my body.

00:14:52.343 --> 00:14:55.928
It's an extraordinary sensation,
but at the same time it's traumatizing.

00:14:55.952 --> 00:14:58.349
It's a shock to the system,
as you can you imagine.

00:14:58.373 --> 00:15:01.146
I go from complete darkness
to the light of day,

00:15:01.170 --> 00:15:05.392
from the near-silence of the depths
to the commotion up top.

00:15:06.346 --> 00:15:10.879
In terms of touch, I go from the soft,
velvety feeling of the water,

00:15:10.903 --> 00:15:13.205
to air rubbing across my face.

00:15:13.229 --> 00:15:16.206
In terms of smell,

00:15:16.230 --> 00:15:18.866
there is air rushing into my lungs.

00:15:18.890 --> 00:15:21.302
And in return, my lungs open up.

00:15:21.326 --> 00:15:23.869
They were completely squashed
just 90 seconds ago,

00:15:23.893 --> 00:15:25.581
and now, they've opened up again.

00:15:25.605 --> 00:15:29.441
So all of this affects
quite a lot of things.

00:15:29.465 --> 00:15:31.785
I need a few seconds to come back,

00:15:31.809 --> 00:15:33.388
and to feel "all there" again.

00:15:33.412 --> 00:15:34.994
But that needs to happen quickly,

00:15:35.018 --> 00:15:38.130
because the judges are there
to verify my performance;

00:15:38.154 --> 00:15:40.739
I need to show them
I'm in perfect physical condition.

00:15:40.763 --> 00:15:43.615
You saw in the video,
I was doing a so-called exit protocol.

00:15:43.639 --> 00:15:47.802
Once at the surface, I have 15 seconds
to take off my nose clip,

00:15:48.642 --> 00:15:51.523
give this signal and say
(English) "I am OK."

00:15:51.947 --> 00:15:53.445
Plus, you need to be bilingual.

00:15:53.469 --> 00:15:54.911
(Laughter)

00:15:54.935 --> 00:15:56.101
On top of everything --

00:15:56.125 --> 00:15:57.394
that's not very nice.

00:15:58.855 --> 00:16:02.506
Once the protocol is completed,
the judges show me a white card,

00:16:02.530 --> 00:16:04.127
and that's when the joy starts.

00:16:04.459 --> 00:16:07.159
I can finally celebrate
what has just happened.

00:16:07.934 --> 00:16:10.212
So, the journey I've just described to you

00:16:10.236 --> 00:16:13.409
is a more extreme version of free diving.

00:16:13.879 --> 00:16:16.070
Luckily, it's far from just that.

00:16:16.094 --> 00:16:17.301
For the past few years,

00:16:17.325 --> 00:16:20.012
I've been trying to show
another side of free diving,

00:16:20.036 --> 00:16:23.143
because the media mainly talks
about competitions and records.

00:16:23.167 --> 00:16:25.048
But free diving is more than just that.

00:16:25.072 --> 00:16:27.000
It's about being at ease in the water.

00:16:27.024 --> 00:16:30.008
It's extremely beautiful,
very poetic and artistic.

00:16:30.032 --> 00:16:32.096
So my wife and I decided to film it

00:16:32.120 --> 00:16:34.646
and try to show another side of it,

00:16:35.242 --> 00:16:37.686
mostly to make people want
to go into the water.

00:16:38.047 --> 00:16:42.542
Let me show you some images
to finish my story.

00:16:43.812 --> 00:16:45.994
It's a mix of beautiful underwater photos.

00:16:46.018 --> 00:16:47.170
(Music)

00:16:47.194 --> 00:16:52.253
I'd like you to know that if one day
you try to stop breathing,

00:16:52.277 --> 00:16:54.573
you'll realize that
when you stop breathing,

00:16:54.597 --> 00:16:56.684
you stop thinking, too.

00:16:57.313 --> 00:16:59.105
It calms your mind.

00:16:59.892 --> 00:17:03.178
Today, in the 21st century,
we're under so much pressure.

00:17:03.202 --> 00:17:06.229
Our minds are overworked,
we think at a million miles an hour,

00:17:06.253 --> 00:17:08.133
we're always stressed.

00:17:08.157 --> 00:17:11.161
Being able to free dive
lets you, just for a moment,

00:17:11.185 --> 00:17:12.660
relax your mind.

00:17:13.320 --> 00:17:15.312
Holding your breath underwater

00:17:15.336 --> 00:17:19.332
means giving yourself the chance
to experience weightlessness.

00:17:19.356 --> 00:17:22.310
It means being underwater, floating,

00:17:22.334 --> 00:17:26.157
with your body completely relaxed,
letting go of all your tensions.

00:17:26.181 --> 00:17:28.060
This is our plight in the 21st century:

00:17:28.084 --> 00:17:30.401
our backs hurt, our necks hurt,
everything hurts,

00:17:30.425 --> 00:17:32.634
because we're stressed
and tense all the time.

00:17:32.658 --> 00:17:34.087
But when you're in the water,

00:17:34.111 --> 00:17:36.701
you let yourself float,
as if you were in space.

00:17:37.109 --> 00:17:38.793
You let yourself go completely.

00:17:38.817 --> 00:17:40.310
It's an extraordinary feeling.

00:17:40.334 --> 00:17:45.991
You can finally get in touch
with your body, mind and spirit.

00:17:46.434 --> 00:17:48.472
Everything feels better, all at once.

00:17:49.910 --> 00:17:54.105
Learning how to free dive is also
about learning to breathe correctly.

00:17:54.676 --> 00:17:59.134
We breathe with our first breath
at birth, up until our last one.

00:17:59.158 --> 00:18:02.712
Breathing gives rhythm to our lives.

00:18:02.736 --> 00:18:06.085
Learning how to breathe better
is learning how to live better.

00:18:06.704 --> 00:18:09.839
Holding your breath in the sea,
not necessarily at 100 meters,

00:18:09.863 --> 00:18:11.138
but maybe at two or three,

00:18:11.162 --> 00:18:13.228
putting on your goggles,
a pair of flippers,

00:18:13.252 --> 00:18:14.948
means you can go see another world,

00:18:14.972 --> 00:18:17.030
another universe, completely magical.

00:18:17.054 --> 00:18:20.459
You can see little fish, seaweed,
the flora and fauna,

00:18:20.483 --> 00:18:22.801
you can watch it all discreetly,

00:18:22.825 --> 00:18:26.111
sliding underwater, looking around,
and coming back to the surface,

00:18:26.135 --> 00:18:27.642
leaving no trace.

00:18:28.054 --> 00:18:32.110
It's an amazing feeling
to become one with nature like that.

00:18:33.177 --> 00:18:35.649
And if I may say one more thing,

00:18:36.467 --> 00:18:41.634
holding your breath, being in the water,
finding this underwater world --

00:18:41.658 --> 00:18:43.627
it's all about connecting with yourself.

00:18:43.651 --> 00:18:47.944
You heard me talk a lot
about the body's memory

00:18:48.579 --> 00:18:51.480
that dates back millions of years,
to our marine origins.

00:18:51.504 --> 00:18:54.170
The day you get back into the water,

00:18:54.194 --> 00:18:56.685
when you hold your breath
for a few seconds,

00:18:56.709 --> 00:18:59.629
you will reconnect with those origins.

00:19:00.201 --> 00:19:01.720
And I guarantee

00:19:01.744 --> 00:19:03.085
it's absolute magic.

00:19:03.109 --> 00:19:04.562
I encourage you to try it out.

00:19:04.586 --> 00:19:05.752
Thank you.

00:19:05.776 --> 00:19:09.497
(Applause)

title: The untapped genius that could change science for the better
transcript: Great things happen at intersections. In fact, I would argue that some of the most interesting things of the human experience occur at the intersections, in the liminal space, where by liminal I mean the space in-between. There's freedom in that in-between, freedom to create from the indefiniteness of not-quite-here, not-quite-there, a new self-definition. Some of the great intersections of the world come to mind, like the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, or Times Square in New York City, both bustling with the excitement of a seemingly endless stream of people. Other intersections, like the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama, or Canfield Drive and Copper Creek Court in Ferguson, Missouri, also come to mind because of the tremendous energy at the intersection of human beings, ideologies and the ongoing struggle for justice.Beyond the physical landscape of our planet, some of the most famous celestial images are of intersections. Stars are born at the messy intersection of gas and dust, instigated by gravity's irrevocable pull. Stars die by this same intersection, this time flung outward in a violent collision of smaller atoms, intersecting and efficiently fusing into altogether new and heavier things. We can all think of intersections that have special meaning to us. To be intersectional, then, is to occupy a position at an intersection.I've lived the entirety of my life in the in-between, in the liminal space between dreams and reality, race and gender, poverty and plenty, science and society. I am both black and a woman. Like the birth of stars in the heavenlies, this robust combination of knowing results in a shining example of the explosive fusion of identities.I am also an astrophysicist. I study blazars, supermassive, hyperactive black holes that sit at the centers of massive galaxies and shoot out jets nearby those black holes at speeds approaching the speed of light in a process we are still trying to completely understand.I have dreamed of becoming an astrophysicist since I was 12 years old. I had no idea that at that time, according to Dr. Jamie Alexander's archive of African-American women in physics, only 18 black women in the United States had ever earned a PhD in a physics-related discipline, and that the first black woman to graduate with a PhD in an astronomy-related field did so just one year before my birth.As I journeyed along my path, I encountered the best and worst of life at an intersection: the tremendous opportunity to self-define, the collision of expectation and experience, the exhilaration of victorious breakthroughs and, sometimes, the explosive pain of regeneration.I began my college experience just after my family had fallen apart. Our financial situation disintegrated just after my father's departure from our lives. This thrust my mother, my sister and I out of the relative comfort of middle-class life and into the almost constant struggle to make ends meet. Thus, I was one of roughly 60 percent of women of color who find finances to be a major barrier to their educational goals. Thankfully, Norfolk State University provided me with full funding, and I was able to achieve my bachelor's in physics.After graduation, and despite knowing that I wanted a PhD in astrophysics, I fell through the cracks. It was a poster that saved my dream, and some really incredible people and programs. The American Physical Society had this beautiful poster encouraging students of color to become physicists. It was striking to me because it featured a young black girl, probably around 12 years old, looking studiously at some physics equations. I remember thinking I was looking directly back at the little girl who first dared to dream this dream. I immediately wrote to the Society and requested my personal copy of the poster, which to this day still hangs in my office. I described to them in the email my educational path, and my desire to find myself again in pursuit of the PhD. They directed me to the Fisk-Vanderbilt University Bridge Program, itself an intersection of the master's and PhD degrees at two institutions. After two years out of school, they accepted me into the program, and I found myself again on the path to the PhD.After receiving my master's at Fisk, I went on to Yale to complete my PhD. Once I was physically occupying the space that would ultimately give way to my childhood aspirations, I anticipated a smooth glide to the PhD.(Laughter)It became immediately apparent that not everyone was thrilled to have that degree of liminality in their space. I was ostracized by many of my classmates, one of whom went so far as to invite me to "do what I really came here to do" as he pushed all the dirty dishes from our meal in front of me to clean up. I wish that were an isolated occurrence, but for many women of color in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, or STEM, this is something they have long endured. One hundred percent of the 60 women of color interviewed in a recent study by Joan C. Williams at UC Hastings reported facing racialized gender bias, including being mistaken for the janitorial staff. This mistaken identity was not reported by any of the white women interviewed for this study, which comprised 557 women in total. While there is nothing inherently wrong with a janitorial position, and in fact my forefathers and foremothers were able to attend college because many of their parents worked these jobs, it was a clear attempt to put me in my place.While there was certainly the acute pain of the encounter, the real issue is that my appearance can tell anyone anything about my ability. Beyond that, though, it underscores that the women of color in STEM do not experience the same set of barriers that just women or just people of color face. That's why today I want to highlight women of color in STEM, who are inexorably, unapologetically living as the inseparable sum of identities.STEM itself is an intersectional term, such that its true richness cannot be appreciated without considering the liminal space between disciplines. Science, the pursuit of understanding the physical world by way of chemistry, physics, biology, cannot be accomplished in the absence of mathematics. Engineering requires the application of basic science and math to the lived experience. Technology sits firmly on the foundation of math, engineering and science. Math itself serves the critical role of Rosetta Stone, decoding and encoding the physical principles of the world. STEM is utterly incomplete without each individual piece. This is to say nothing of the enrichment that is realized when STEM is combined with other disciplines.The purpose for this talk is twofold: first, to say directly to every black, Latina, indigenous, First Nation or any other woman or girl who finds herself resting at the blessed intersection of race and gender, that you can be anything you want to be. My personal hope is that you'll become an astrophysicist, but beyond that, anything you want. Do not think for one minute that because you are who you are, you cannot be who you imagine yourself to be. Hold fast to those dreams and let them carry you into a world you can't even imagine.Secondly, among the most pressing issues of our time, most now find their intersection with STEM. We have as a global society solved most of the single-faceted issues of our time. Those that remain require a thorough investigation of the liminal space between disciplines to create the multifaceted solutions of tomorrow. Who better to solve these liminal problems than those who have faced their whole lives at the intersections. We as thought leaders and decision makers must push past the first steps of diversity and into the richer and more robust territory of full inclusion and equal opportunity.One of my favorite examples of liminal excellence comes from the late Dr. Claudia Alexander, a black woman plasma physicist, who passed away this past July after a 10-year bout with breast cancer. She was a NASA project scientist who spearheaded the NASA side of the Rosetta mission, which became famous this year for landing a rover on a comet, and the 1.5 billion dollar Galileo mission to Jupiter, two high-profile scientific victories for NASA, the United States and the world. Dr. Alexander said it this way: "I'm used to walking between two cultures. For me, it's among the purposes of my life to take us from states of ignorance to states of understanding with bold exploration that you can't do every day."This shows exactly the power of a liminal person. She had the technical ability to spearhead some of the most ambitious space missions of our time, and she perfectly understood her place of being exactly who she was in any place she was.Jessica Matthews, inventor of the SOCCKET line of sports products, like soccer balls, that generate renewable energy as you play with them, said it this way: "A major part of invention isn't just creating things, it's understanding people and understanding the systems that make this world." The reason I tell my story and the story of Dr. Alexander and Jessica Matthews is because they are fundamentally intersectional stories, the stories of lives lived at the nexus of race, gender and innovation.Despite implicit and explicit questions of my right to be in an elite space, I'm proud to report that when I graduated, I was the first black woman to earn a PhD in astrophysics in Yale's then 312-year history.(Applause)I am now part of a small but growing cadre of women of color in STEM who are poised to bring new perspectives and new ideas to life on the most pressing issues of our time: things like educational inequities, police brutality, HIV/AIDS, climate change, genetic editing, artificial intelligence and Mars exploration. This is to say nothing of the things we haven't even thought of yet.Women of color in STEM occupy some of the toughest and most exciting sociotechnological issues of our time. Thus, we are uniquely positioned to contribute to and drive these conversations in ways that are more inclusive of a wider variety of lived experience. This outlook can be expanded to the many intersectional people whose experiences, positive and negative, enrich the conversations in ways that outmatch even the best-resourced homogenous groups.This is not a request born out of a desire to fit in. It's a reminder that we cannot get to the best possible outcomes for the totality of humanity without precisely this collaboration, this bringing together of the liminal, the differently lived, distinctly experienced and disparately impacted. Simply put, we cannot be the most excellent expression of our collective genius without the full measure of humanity brought to bear.Thank you.(Applause)
