00:05:46.678 --> 00:05:48.734
It became immediately apparent

00:05:48.758 --> 00:05:52.774
that not everyone was thrilled
to have that degree of liminality

00:05:52.798 --> 00:05:54.414
in their space.

00:05:54.438 --> 00:05:57.494
I was ostracized by many of my classmates,

00:05:57.518 --> 00:06:02.854
one of whom went so far as to invite me
to "do what I really came here to do"

00:06:02.878 --> 00:06:07.318
as he pushed all the dirty dishes
from our meal in front of me to clean up.

00:06:08.518 --> 00:06:11.414
I wish that were an isolated occurrence,

00:06:11.438 --> 00:06:13.174
but for many women of color

00:06:13.198 --> 00:06:19.014
in science, technology, engineering,
and mathematics, or STEM,

00:06:19.038 --> 00:06:21.614
this is something they have long endured.

00:06:21.638 --> 00:06:24.774
One hundred percent
of the 60 women of color

00:06:24.798 --> 00:06:29.134
interviewed in a recent study
by Joan C. Williams at UC Hastings

00:06:29.158 --> 00:06:32.534
reported facing racialized gender bias,

00:06:32.558 --> 00:06:36.278
including being mistaken
for the janitorial staff.

00:06:37.238 --> 00:06:40.134
This mistaken identity was not reported

00:06:40.158 --> 00:06:42.694
by any of the white women
interviewed for this study,

00:06:42.718 --> 00:06:46.318
which comprised 557 women in total.

00:06:47.518 --> 00:06:51.574
While there is nothing inherently wrong
with a janitorial position,

00:06:51.598 --> 00:06:55.014
and in fact my forefathers and foremothers
were able to attend college

00:06:55.038 --> 00:06:57.894
because many of their parents
worked these jobs,

00:06:57.918 --> 00:07:01.718
it was a clear attempt
to put me in my place.

00:07:02.798 --> 00:07:06.014
While there was certainly
the acute pain of the encounter,

00:07:06.038 --> 00:07:08.614
the real issue is that my appearance

00:07:08.638 --> 00:07:13.174
can tell anyone anything about my ability.

00:07:13.198 --> 00:07:15.534
Beyond that, though, it underscores

00:07:15.558 --> 00:07:21.534
that the women of color in STEM
do not experience the same set of barriers

00:07:21.558 --> 00:07:25.654
that just women
or just people of color face.

00:07:25.678 --> 00:07:29.534
That's why today I want to highlight
women of color in STEM,

00:07:29.558 --> 00:07:32.454
who are inexorably, unapologetically

00:07:32.478 --> 00:07:36.278
living as the inseparable
sum of identities.

00:07:37.558 --> 00:07:40.534
STEM itself is an intersectional term,

00:07:40.558 --> 00:07:43.814
such that its true richness
cannot be appreciated

00:07:43.838 --> 00:07:47.694
without considering
the liminal space between disciplines.

00:07:47.718 --> 00:07:50.494
Science, the pursuit
of understanding the physical world

00:07:50.518 --> 00:07:53.614
by way of chemistry, physics, biology,

00:07:53.638 --> 00:07:57.414
cannot be accomplished
in the absence of mathematics.

00:07:57.438 --> 00:08:01.494
Engineering requires the application
of basic science and math

00:08:01.518 --> 00:08:03.534
to the lived experience.

00:08:03.558 --> 00:08:07.254
Technology sits firmly
on the foundation of math,

00:08:07.278 --> 00:08:09.614
engineering and science.

00:08:09.638 --> 00:08:13.654
Math itself serves
the critical role of Rosetta Stone,

00:08:13.678 --> 00:08:18.414
decoding and encoding
the physical principles of the world.

00:08:18.438 --> 00:08:23.374
STEM is utterly incomplete
without each individual piece.

00:08:23.398 --> 00:08:26.774
This is to say nothing
of the enrichment that is realized

00:08:26.798 --> 00:08:30.414
when STEM is combined
with other disciplines.

00:08:30.438 --> 00:08:33.014
The purpose for this talk is twofold:

00:08:33.038 --> 00:08:38.774
first, to say directly to every black,
Latina, indigenous, First Nation

00:08:38.798 --> 00:08:40.814
or any other woman or girl

00:08:40.838 --> 00:08:44.054
who finds herself resting
at the blessed intersection

00:08:44.078 --> 00:08:46.093
of race and gender,

00:08:46.117 --> 00:08:49.078
that you can be anything you want to be.

00:08:50.117 --> 00:08:53.613
My personal hope is
that you'll become an astrophysicist,

00:08:53.637 --> 00:08:56.694
but beyond that, anything you want.

00:08:56.718 --> 00:08:59.774
Do not think for one minute

00:08:59.798 --> 00:09:02.054
that because you are who you are,

00:09:02.078 --> 00:09:05.614
you cannot be
who you imagine yourself to be.

00:09:05.638 --> 00:09:08.094
Hold fast to those dreams

00:09:08.118 --> 00:09:11.798
and let them carry you
into a world you can't even imagine.

00:09:12.598 --> 00:09:16.334
Secondly, among the most
pressing issues of our time,

00:09:16.358 --> 00:09:19.974
most now find
their intersection with STEM.

00:09:19.998 --> 00:09:22.014
We have as a global society solved

00:09:22.038 --> 00:09:25.734
most of the single-faceted
issues of our time.

00:09:25.758 --> 00:09:29.214
Those that remain
require a thorough investigation

00:09:29.238 --> 00:09:32.014
of the liminal space between disciplines

00:09:32.038 --> 00:09:36.454
to create the multifaceted
solutions of tomorrow.

00:09:36.478 --> 00:09:39.574
Who better to solve these liminal problems

00:09:39.598 --> 00:09:43.934
than those who have faced
their whole lives at the intersections.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.894
We as thought leaders and decision makers

00:09:46.918 --> 00:09:50.334
must push past
the first steps of diversity

00:09:50.358 --> 00:09:53.654
and into the richer
and more robust territory

00:09:53.678 --> 00:09:57.694
of full inclusion and equal opportunity.

00:09:57.718 --> 00:10:00.774
One of my favorite examples
of liminal excellence

00:10:00.798 --> 00:10:03.654
comes from the late Dr. Claudia Alexander,

00:10:03.678 --> 00:10:05.414
a black woman plasma physicist,

00:10:05.438 --> 00:10:10.494
who passed away this past July
after a 10-year bout with breast cancer.

00:10:10.518 --> 00:10:14.614
She was a NASA project scientist
who spearheaded the NASA side

00:10:14.638 --> 00:10:16.094
of the Rosetta mission,

00:10:16.118 --> 00:10:20.574
which became famous this year
for landing a rover on a comet,

00:10:20.598 --> 00:10:25.094
and the 1.5 billion dollar
Galileo mission to Jupiter,

00:10:25.118 --> 00:10:28.094
two high-profile scientific victories

00:10:28.118 --> 00:10:32.214
for NASA, the United States
and the world.

00:10:32.238 --> 00:10:34.934
Dr. Alexander said it this way:

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.654
"I'm used to walking between two cultures.

00:10:37.678 --> 00:10:40.814
For me, it's among the purposes of my life

00:10:40.838 --> 00:10:44.454
to take us from states of ignorance
to states of understanding

00:10:44.478 --> 00:10:48.854
with bold exploration
that you can't do every day."

00:10:48.878 --> 00:10:52.654
This shows exactly
the power of a liminal person.

00:10:52.678 --> 00:10:55.054
She had the technical ability to spearhead

00:10:55.078 --> 00:10:58.174
some of the most ambitious
space missions of our time,

00:10:58.198 --> 00:11:01.534
and she perfectly understood her place

00:11:01.558 --> 00:11:05.198
of being exactly who she was
in any place she was.

00:11:06.198 --> 00:11:09.814
Jessica Matthews, inventor
of the SOCCKET line of sports products,

00:11:09.838 --> 00:11:13.814
like soccer balls, that generate
renewable energy as you play with them,

00:11:13.838 --> 00:11:15.694
said it this way:

00:11:15.718 --> 00:11:19.174
"A major part of invention
isn't just creating things,

00:11:19.198 --> 00:11:21.014
it's understanding people

00:11:21.038 --> 00:11:24.278
and understanding the systems
that make this world."

00:11:25.278 --> 00:11:27.094
The reason I tell my story

00:11:27.118 --> 00:11:30.174
and the story of Dr. Alexander
and Jessica Matthews

00:11:30.198 --> 00:11:34.054
is because they are fundamentally
intersectional stories,

00:11:34.078 --> 00:11:40.078
the stories of lives lived at the nexus
of race, gender and innovation.

00:11:40.718 --> 00:11:46.334
Despite implicit and explicit questions
of my right to be in an elite space,

00:11:46.358 --> 00:11:48.934
I'm proud to report that when I graduated,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:52.414
I was the first black woman
to earn a PhD in astrophysics

00:11:52.438 --> 00:11:55.534
in Yale's then 312-year history.

00:11:55.558 --> 00:12:01.454
(Applause)

00:12:01.478 --> 00:12:06.894
I am now part of a small but growing cadre
of women of color in STEM

00:12:06.918 --> 00:12:10.934
who are poised to bring new perspectives
and new ideas to life

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.734
on the most pressing issues of our time:

00:12:13.758 --> 00:12:15.934
things like educational inequities,

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:21.934
police brutality, HIV/AIDS,
climate change, genetic editing,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:25.334
artificial intelligence
and Mars exploration.

00:12:25.358 --> 00:12:29.654
This is to say nothing of the things
we haven't even thought of yet.

00:12:29.678 --> 00:12:33.174
Women of color in STEM
occupy some of the toughest

00:12:33.198 --> 00:12:37.974
and most exciting sociotechnological
issues of our time.

00:12:37.998 --> 00:12:40.334
Thus, we are uniquely positioned

00:12:40.358 --> 00:12:43.774
to contribute to
and drive these conversations

00:12:43.798 --> 00:12:48.934
in ways that are more inclusive
of a wider variety of lived experience.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:52.534
This outlook can be expanded
to the many intersectional people

00:12:52.558 --> 00:12:55.614
whose experiences, positive and negative,

00:12:55.638 --> 00:12:58.694
enrich the conversations
in ways that outmatch

00:12:58.718 --> 00:13:01.798
even the best-resourced homogenous groups.

00:13:02.838 --> 00:13:06.734
This is not a request
born out of a desire to fit in.

00:13:06.758 --> 00:13:11.254
It's a reminder that we cannot get
to the best possible outcomes

00:13:11.278 --> 00:13:13.454
for the totality of humanity

00:13:13.478 --> 00:13:15.934
without precisely this collaboration,

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.494
this bringing together of the liminal,

00:13:18.518 --> 00:13:22.014
the differently lived,
distinctly experienced

00:13:22.038 --> 00:13:24.574
and disparately impacted.

00:13:24.598 --> 00:13:28.614
Simply put, we cannot be
the most excellent expression

00:13:28.638 --> 00:13:30.414
of our collective genius

00:13:30.438 --> 00:13:33.934
without the full measure
of humanity brought to bear.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.174
Thank you.

00:13:35.198 --> 00:13:41.078
(Applause)

title: Forget shopping. Soon you'll download your new clothes
transcript: In the past few months, I've been traveling for weeks at a time with only one suitcase of clothes. One day, I was invited to an important event, and I wanted to wear something special and new for it. So I looked through my suitcase and I couldn't find anything to wear. I was lucky to be at the technology conference on that day, and I had access to 3D printers. So I quickly designed a skirt on my computer, and I loaded the file on the printer. It just printed the pieces overnight. The next morning, I just took all the pieces, assembled them together in my hotel room, and this is actually the skirt that I'm wearing right now.(Applause)So it wasn't the first time that I printed clothes. For my senior collection at fashion design school, I decided to try and 3D print an entire fashion collection from my home. The problem was that I barely knew anything about 3D printing, and I had only nine months to figure out how to print five fashionable looks.I always felt most creative when I worked from home. I loved experimenting with new materials, and I always tried to develop new techniques to make the most unique textiles for my fashion projects. I loved going to old factories and weird stores in search of leftovers of strange powders and weird materials, and then bring them home to experiment on. As you can probably imagine, my roommates didn't like that at all.(Laughter)So I decided to move on to working with big machines, ones that didn't fit in my living room. I love the exact and the custom work I can do with all kinds of fashion technologies, like knitting machines and laser cutting and silk printing.One summer break, I came here to New York for an internship at a fashion house in Chinatown. We worked on two incredible dresses that were 3D printed. They were amazing — like you can see here. But I had a few issues with them. They were made from hard plastics and that's why they were very breakable. The models couldn't sit in them, and they even got scratched from the plastics under their arms.With 3D printing, the designers had so much freedom to make the dresses look exactly like they wanted, but still, they were very dependent on big and expensive industrial printers that were located in a lab far from their studio.Later that year, a friend gave me a 3D printed necklace, printed using a home printer. I knew that these printers were much cheaper and much more accessible than the ones we used at my internship. So I looked at the necklace, and then I thought, "If I can print a necklace from home, why not print my clothes from home, too?" I really liked the idea that I wouldn't have to go to the market and pick fabrics that someone else chose to sell — I could just design them and print them directly from home.I found a small makerspace, where I learned everything I know about 3D printing. Right away, they literally gave me the key to the lab, so I could experiment into the night, every night.The main challenge was to find the right filament for printing clothes with. So what is a filament? Filament is the material you feed the printer with. And I spent a month or so experimenting with PLA, which is a hard and scratchy, breakable material.The breakthrough came when I was introduced to Filaflex, which is a new kind of filament. It's strong, yet very flexible. And with it, I was able to print the first garment, the red jacket that had the word "Liberté" — "freedom" in French — embedded into it. I chose this word because I felt so empowered and free when I could just design a garment from my home and then print it by myself. And actually, you can easily download this jacket, and easily change the word to something else. For example, your name or your sweetheart's name.(Laughter)So the printer plates are small, so I had to piece the garment together, just like a puzzle.And I wanted to solve another challenge. I wanted to print textiles that I would use just like regular fabrics. That's when I found an open-source file from an architect who designed a pattern that I love. And with it, I was able to print a beautiful textile that I would use just like a regular fabric. And it actually even looks a little bit like lace.So I took his file and I modified it, and changed it, played with it — many kinds of versions out of it. And I needed to print another 1,500 more hours to complete printing my collection. So I brought six printers to my home and just printed 24-7. And this is actually a really slow process, but let's remember the Internet was significantly slower 20 years ago, so 3D printing will also accelerate and in no time you'll be able to print a T-Shirt in your home in just a couple of hours, or even minutes.So you guys, you want to see what it looks like?Audience: Yeah!(Applause)Danit Peleg: Rebecca is wearing one of my five outfits. Almost everything here she's wearing, I printed from my home. Even her shoes are printed.Audience: Wow!Audience: Cool!(Applause)Danit Peleg: Thank you, Rebecca. (To audience) Thank you, guys.So I think in the future, materials will evolve, and they will look and feel like fabrics we know today, like cotton or silk. Imagine personalized clothes that fit exactly to your measurements.Music was once a very physical thing. You would have to go to the record shop and buy CDs, but now you can just download the music — digital music — directly to your phone. Fashion is also a very physical thing. And I wonder what our world will look like when our clothes will be digital, just like this skirt is.Thank you so much.(Applause)[Thank You](Applause)

00:04:36.619 --> 00:04:39.213
many kinds of versions out of it.

00:04:39.612 --> 00:04:43.796
And I needed to print
another 1,500 more hours

00:04:43.820 --> 00:04:46.747
to complete printing my collection.

00:04:46.771 --> 00:04:50.579
So I brought six printers to my home
and just printed 24-7.

00:04:51.134 --> 00:04:53.654
And this is actually
a really slow process,

00:04:53.678 --> 00:04:58.021
but let's remember the Internet
was significantly slower 20 years ago,

00:04:58.045 --> 00:05:00.370
so 3D printing will also accelerate

00:05:00.394 --> 00:05:03.377
and in no time you'll be able to print
a T-Shirt in your home

00:05:03.401 --> 00:05:06.366
in just a couple of hours,
or even minutes.

00:05:06.784 --> 00:05:09.104
So you guys, you want to see
what it looks like?

00:05:09.128 --> 00:05:10.429
Audience: Yeah!

00:05:10.453 --> 00:05:12.304
(Applause)

00:05:14.251 --> 00:05:17.767
Danit Peleg: Rebecca is wearing
one of my five outfits.

00:05:17.791 --> 00:05:22.608
Almost everything here she's wearing,
I printed from my home.

00:05:23.037 --> 00:05:25.288
Even her shoes are printed.

00:05:25.312 --> 00:05:26.464
Audience: Wow!

00:05:26.488 --> 00:05:27.653
Audience: Cool!

00:05:29.724 --> 00:05:31.479
(Applause)

00:05:31.503 --> 00:05:33.046
Danit Peleg: Thank you, Rebecca.

00:05:33.664 --> 00:05:35.784
(To audience) Thank you, guys.

00:05:36.806 --> 00:05:39.323
So I think in the future,
materials will evolve,

00:05:39.347 --> 00:05:42.528
and they will look and feel
like fabrics we know today,

00:05:42.552 --> 00:05:44.488
like cotton or silk.

00:05:45.307 --> 00:05:49.274
Imagine personalized clothes
that fit exactly to your measurements.

00:05:51.495 --> 00:05:53.472
Music was once a very physical thing.

00:05:53.496 --> 00:05:56.520
You would have to go
to the record shop and buy CDs,

00:05:56.544 --> 00:05:59.194
but now you can just download the music --

00:05:59.218 --> 00:06:00.377
digital music --

00:06:00.401 --> 00:06:01.734
directly to your phone.

00:06:02.463 --> 00:06:04.924
Fashion is also a very physical thing.

00:06:05.258 --> 00:06:08.140
And I wonder what our world will look like

00:06:08.164 --> 00:06:11.508
when our clothes will be digital,
just like this skirt is.

00:06:12.014 --> 00:06:13.387
Thank you so much.

00:06:13.411 --> 00:06:14.611
(Applause)

00:06:14.635 --> 00:06:15.785
[Thank You]

00:06:15.809 --> 00:06:18.608
(Applause)
